PHILADELPHIA, July 16.--The fact can no longer be concealed that the organization of the Knights of Labor is going down with appalling rapidity. A score of assemblies are lapsing every week, whole crafts are threatening to withdraw altogether, and no corresponding additions to the membership are gained to make up the losses.

The funeral of James M. Conner, the typefounder, was held last evening at the family residence, 12 Mitchell-street. Among those present were a number of employes of his foundry. The services were conducted by the Rev. John Johns. A number of handsome floral designs the gifts of friends of the family, were placed near the casket. The interment will take place at West Chester this morning.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 16.--A "man eater" shark, 15 feet long, jumped up near the steamer River Belle seven or eight times in the Hudson River, opposite West Point, this morning. Gray sharks are occasionally seen in the river, but this is the first known appearance of the "man-eater" variety so far north as West Point.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 16.--Several oarsmen have already arrived and entered for the national amateur regatta on Chautauqua Lake on July 26 and 27. The hotels in Jamestown and along the lake have had applications from many persons coming for the event. Everything indicates that this regatta will be the largest attended for years. PHILADELPHIA, July 16.--Less than $100,000 of the Reading Receivers' certificates are now outstanding, and, as interest upon them has stopped, they will all undoubtedly be soon redeemed. They detective had just laid hands on him last night as the ex-convict drew a revolver and fired the fatal shot.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 17.--The great event of the regatta to-day was the senior four oar, one and one-half miles, for the championship of the association and Manitoba Railroad Cup and $1,000 offered by Sir Donald A. Smith, of London. It was won by the Winnipeg crew in 8:25, three lengths ahead of St. Paul, Turlines, of Minneapolis, third.

Dr. William F. Poole, who is about to assume the direction of the Newberry Library in Chicago, is said to be one of the absolute veterans in the profession and a man who has no superior in qualifications for the place. BUFFALO, N.Y., July 18.--The rumors that the Lackawanna Railroad is to have a line of steamers is confirmed. It is learned to-night that it is settled the road is to build or buy a line for use next season.

PITTSBURG, July 18.--A "strictly confidential" circular marked "Not for publication" was this evening mailed by Secretary Joseph D. Weeks to members of the association of manufacturers of iron, steel, and nails, embracing nearly the entire industry throughout America, with regard to a misunderstanding touching the...
TWIN MOUNTAIN HOUSE, New-Hampshire July 18.--While Moses W. Hill, a student waiter at the Twin Mountain House, was attempting to climb to the top of a huge boulder a quarter...

READING, Penn., July 18.--Two freight trains came into collision on the West Reading Railroad curve, this city, at 9 o'clock this morning. The engineers, realizing that a collision was inevitable, jumped for their lives and escaped with a few bruises. Charles Upp, a brakeman, was not so fortunate. He made a leap for life, but was caught in the wreck and fatally injured. The engines and boilers were badly damaged.

The arguments upon the application of "citizen and taxpayer" Peter McGinness for an injunction restraining the Board of Electrical Control from carrying out its intentions in regard to the building of electrical conduits were begun yesterday before Judge O'Gorman...

It is naturally to be inferred that the number of "shavy heads" to be seen on our streets is due to a desire to keep as cool as possible during the reigning days of Shadrach and company; but the conclusion is not always sound.

P.J. Webber, an employe of Michael Seitz, the brewer, engaged a room Sunday night at the Van Dyke House, 28 Bowery. He was seen about the house at 4 o'clock yesterday morning and an hour later was found lying dead on his bed.
LONDON, July 18.--The replies of the powers to Bulgaria's note asking their approval of the election of Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha as Prince of Bulgaria are evasive.

Just at noon yesterday a dropsical party, with a red nose and a parboiled expression, stopped in front of that depraved and menda cious instrument, erroneously called a thermometer, which hangs in front of a lower Broadway drug store.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 18.--Some comfort for the friends of Union College who think it is time that venerable institution had a President is found in a card issued by Acting President Landon, in response to numerous criticisms which have been made upon the present management of the college.

Thomas W. Barker, aged 70, for many years station agent at Irvington, was killed there at 4:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He was picking up some wheat which had dropped from some cars on a side track, and stepped from behind the cars in front of north-bound Croton special, receiving injuries from which he died in half an hour.

TRENTON, N.J., July 18.--Counsel expected a decision this morning on the motion to dissolve the injunction restraining the erection of the Arthur Kill bridge by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.
The measures which were taken some time ago to have Gov. Tilden's will probated in England and its Executors recognized there have been completed.

BALTIMORE, July 18.--At Emory Grove, a camp meeting ground about 20 miles west of the city, where about 50 families spend the Summer in tents, Miss Ida Andrews, of Baltimore, was killed instantly today by the falling of a large tree, which struck her square on the head. Her sister Jennie was also badly injured.
The police have been asked to look for Agnes Panner, 15 years old, who on the Fourth said she was going to take a walk and who has not since been...

CHICAGO, July 18.--A local paper says: Robert G. Ferguson, 13 years old, of La Grange, Ill., who has been confined in a "Christian home' at Humboldt Park for some time, was found on the street yesterday with iron shackles on his feet.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 18.--The Hon. Mr. Thompson, Minister of Justice, has issued his warrant for the extradition of Buzon, who is wanted at Brussels, Belgium, on a charge of fraudulent bankruptcy and embezzlement. He is now in jail at Montreal.
A demented Chinaman was discovered yesterday afternoon roosting on a stringpiece under the wharf at Pier 41 North River. How long he had been there no one could tell.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18.--The rain yesterday and the unexpected rainstorm this afternoon was anything but pleasing to the cottagers, and it materially decreased the receipts of boatmen, hackmen, and livery stable keepers. Fortunately, the storm cleared in season for the hop at the Casino.

The Earle Guild is now issuing tickets for ice and free excursions to sick children. Mothers of sick children can procure them at the office of the guild, 173 Centre-street, by bringing a voucher from a physician or dispensary.

James G. Blaine has sailed for Europe in poor health, and the steamer on which he went was crowded with prominent invalids. Every vessel that leaves our shores is loaded with people more or less sick, and Government statistics show that America, while a land of liberty, is not one of health.
CINCINNATI, July 18.--Gen. Phil Sheridan was here to-day looking after a new site for the United States Army barracks at Newport, Ky. He said:
The 11 tribes of the Improved Order of Red Men of Kings County held their second annual athletic games at Broadway Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. There was a large crowd present.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 18.--A brutal assault was made at noon to-day by Vancene Palermo and his wife upon Embly Stewart, aged 67 years, and his wife, who is a few years younger.
Judge Gordon, in Common Pleas No. 3 on Saturday granted permission to Gen. Louis Wagner to pay over $2,194 83 to the Home for Disabled and Indigent Soldiers, Sailors, or Mariners, at Erie.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 18.--Mrs. Bloomer, who was held for contempt of court by Judge Brown, of the Superme Court, was released to-day, she having produced the children whom she had taken away. The children were given into their father's custody.

Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT made his start in life in the town of Owego, Tioga County, and he has chosen that spot for the beginning of a campaign in which he proposes to control the action of the Republican Party of this State.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 18.--Tracy Brothers, of Waterbury, recently submitted a bid for doing the carpenter and mason work on New-Haven's new almshouse, which was $2,700 lower than their competitors.

The daily bulletins in regard to the Emperor's health since our last issue have stopped recording improvements and have taken to the less definite phraseology of announcing his condition as "without change."
WASHINGTON, July 18.--The resignation of Schuyler Duryee, chief clerk of the Patent Office, which was offered this morning and accepted this afternoon, was not entirely unexpected.
During the most violent portion of the storm of Sunday, about 1 o'clock P.M., something resembling a meteorite struck the sidewalk in Brooklyn, at Troy and Fulton avenues.

If Mr. Francis Galton is right, temper is even a larger factor in the household unhappiness of English people than is commonly imagined. He declares that rather more than every second adult person in England is in some way or other bad-tempered.

The examination in the case of M.J. Victor Mery, the French scientist and newspaper man, of 226 Fifth-avenue, who is charged with having on July 13 assaulted Miss Blanche Meda, otherwise Amanda Pratt, otherwise Mme.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 18.--John Hammond took refuge under a willow tree near here during Sunday's storm. Lightning struck the tree and felled him to the ground. One of this shoes was torn completely off and hurled some distance away. The other shoe was ripped and burned. Both of Hammond's legs were swollen and portions of his body were burned and discolored. He will probably recover.

BOSTON, July 18.--James E. Row, varnish manufacturer, of Malden, Mass., has made an assignment, with total liabilities of about $21,500 and assets estimated at $8,000. The failure is due to Mr. Row's indorsement of notes of McDougall, Logie Co., oil and paint manufacturers, of Montreal, which firm has failed.
CHICAGO, July 18.--The City Council this evening adopted resolutions cordially inviting President Cleveland to visit Chicago at such time as may suit his convenience,

The inquest in the Arlington explosion case was concluded last night. The jury brought in a verdict to the effect that Miss Muchmore and the Swede, Hulmgren, came to their death by the explosion. They also censured the company for employing unskilled labor, and not taking care in the handling of the material.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 18.--Judge Shipman, of the United States Circuit Court, this afternoon dismissed both the bill and cross bill in the case of the Morse Arms Manufacturing Company, of NewYork, against the Winchester Repeating Arms Company, of New-Haven, involving a patent for the extraction of cartridges from breech-loading guns. The case has been in litigation over 13 years, and the lawyers who first conducted it are all dead.
Mlle. Nordica, widow of Mr. Gower, of Bell Telephone fame, is coming to America at the close of the Drury-Lane season to administer on her late husband's estate.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 18.--Moritz Bullowa, a flour merchant at 217 West-street, NewYork, who resided in Fifty-fifth-street, has been boarding with his family in a farmhouse near Salisbury Mills, this county.

DUBLIN, July 18.--The evictions at Coolgraney were resumed to-day. Many spectators were present, including Mr. Dillon, John and William Redmond, Mr. Crilly, Michael Davitt, Alderman Brennan, of Providence, R.I., and...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 18.--On Friday evening a young man and a young woman, well dressed and of stylish appearance, accompanied by a little boy, registered at the principal hotel of Bainbridge as Henry Dunmore, wife, and child.
The Rockaway Steeplechase Association announce five stake races for their Autumn meeting, entries to which will close on Monday, Aug. 1.

Lottie Lorenz, aged 15, and Eldora Hopkins, aged 14, the young girls who escaped from the New-York Juvenile Asylum, at One Hundred and Seventy-sixth-street and Tenth-avenue, Sunday afternoon, had not been found up to a late...
BOSTON, July 18.--Charles McCabe, a young man from Canton, came to this city yesterday to visit a sick uncle. While taking in the town he cruised through Eliot-street early this...

The body of a son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonough, of 469 Palisade-avenue, was about to be placed in the grave in St. Peter's Cemetery, Jersey City, Sunday, when Catherine Costello created a sensation by wavinig her parasol in the air and shouting loudly.

MYRTLE, Ontario, July 18.--Owing to an open switch a side-tracked Canadian Pacific train here was run into to-day by a rapidly moving east-bound train. Brakeman McIntyre was instantly killed and Engineer Andrews was seriously injured.
There was a number of disappointed veterans at 192 Broadway yesterday who had gone there to get tickets for their transportation to the National Soldiers' Home at Hampton, Va.

On account of the charges of Commissioner of Emigration Stephenson in regard to the American Emigrant Company its officers state that the company invited the Hon. S.V. White to examine its books and papers.

Friends of Charles H. Bradley, a young hatter, of Orange, N.J., are puzzled over his mysterious disappearance. Bradley surprised his parents by walking into the house two weeks ago after a long absence.

I have been shown two letters written on June 2 and June 9 of the present year by the Hon. Frederick Wynn as the amanuensis of his father, Lord Newborough, now in his eightyfourth year, and too infirm to write.
Barney Dowling, the young umbrella manufacturer arrested Sunday evening in company with Elmira Vanderhagen at 239 Wooster-street, was...

The headless body of a woman was found yesterday in the East River at the foot of South Fifthstreet, Williamsburg. The right arm was also missing. The body had been in the water a long time, and Coroner Lindsay says the head and arm became detached by the action of the water. The body was attired in a black dress, black stockings, and laced shoes.

John Powers, an Irish lad, 18 years old, and Bridget Corbitt, a servant girl several years his senior, went rowing on the Passaic Sunday evening. The lad returned alone to his home in Newark after two or three hours. Instead of going at once to the rooms occupied by his mother, he went into a neighbor's house and lay down until after his mother had retired. Then he stole into his own room.
HAMILTON, Ohio, July 18.--Saturday night at Mason, Warren County, Ohio, Whitmore McClung was shot through the head and killed in Bill Tibes's...
The men who were discharged from Higgins's carpet factory because they left the Knights of Labor, although they afterward...
Ex-Mayor Henry Bedlow, of Newport, is at the Everett House.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18.--Information was received to-day from Ounalaska that Bishop Seghers, a Catholic missionary, was murdered by his companion one night in November last. The scene of the tragedy was on the banks of...
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 18.--Happy Bob Van Brunt, the Salvation Army murderer, shot and killed the half brother of Eva Roy in Wyoming County because he was jealous of Roy.
NYACK, N.Y., July 18.--The thunderstorm last night did considerable damage in Rockland County. The large barn of Cornelius Clark, at Sparhill, was struck by lightning and burned down.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 18.--It is comparatively cool here to-night and has been so all day. The thermometer stands at 73 , and a cool northeast breeze is blowing.

It does not appear that any New-York houses have been affected by the failure of the cotton firm of Kauffman Runge, at Galveston.

Daniel Leonard Wright, a brother of the late Gov. Silas Wright, of Canton, died at his home in Weybridge, Vt., on Friday, June 24, 1887, in the eighty-ninth year of his age. He was born at "Lemon Fair," in the town of Weybridge,

Judge Van Hoesen, of the Court of Common Pleas, has denied the application of Thomas W. Rowan for a mandamus compelling the Board of Excise to issue him a license to sell liquors at Sixtyfirst-street and Third-avenue.
AKRON, Ohio, July 18.--A distressing affair is reported from West Richfield, near here. Charles Reed, depressed by financial losses, and, as is stated, greatly excited from the excessive heat,

LONDON, July 18.--In the House of Lords to-day the Crimes bill was read a third time. Mr. Walter Hume Long, Conservative member of Parliament for the Devizes Division of Wiltshire, called the attention of the House of Commons this afternoon to the breach of privilege...

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 18.--An excursion party consisting of about 200 members of the Beethoven Maennerchor, a German singing society of NewYork, arrived here this morning. They are quartered at Congress Hall.
"Roddie" Duggan, the young burglar who committed suicide in his cell in the Gates-avenue (Brooklyn) station house on Sunday, was buried in the Potter's Field yesterday.

Dr. Charcot, the famous hypnotizer, has recently had a chance of examining immediately after decapitation one of the 4 per cent, of French murderers who get executed. Thanks to the assistance of the police, his examination...

Jacob Sharp will hardly become an inmate of Sing Sing Prison this week, though if Judge Potter should render his decision on the motion for a stay without delay Sheriff Grant may be relieved of his prisoner Saturday. Judge Potter granted a stay until yesterday morning, but as Assistant District Attorney Nicoll was not ready to argue the motion it was mutually agreed to postpone the argument until Friday morning at 10 o'clock.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 17, via Galveston. --Great preparations are being made to commemorate the anniversary of the death of President Juarez at San Fernando Cemetery tomorrow, and the approaches to the cemetery are being superbly decorated.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 18.--Five hundred employes of the Pottsville Iron and Steel Company's Fishback Rolling Mills refused to go to work to-day. After a strike in April they were promised an all-around raise of wages of from 8 to 10 per cent.
WINCHESTER, Va., July 18.--The Grand Jury to-day indicted a prominent Israelite merchant, N. Kohn, and his niece, Emma Frankel.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 18.--C.R. Hoe, a nephew of Richard Hoe, the millionaire pressmaker, was arrested to-day on a charge of obtaining money under false pretenses.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., July 18.--Back to civilization once more, and a hotel for white men to inhabit. In innumerable particulars there is a difference between this village and Forest Port. He who enters here does not leave all hope behind.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 18.--The Atlantic Yacht Club brought up here to-day, instead of at New-London, according to the programme. Last evening Commodore Swan issued orders that the preparatory gun would be fired at 6 o'clock this morning, the gun for the second division of the fleet at 6:10, and that for the first division at 6:25. All hands turned out early this morning to get ready for the start.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 18.--Robert Owens, of this city, age 60 years, was killed to-day. He was employed as engineer in charge of the iron ore hoisting machine on the Indianapolis, Bloomington and Western Railroad dock, and in some manner,
The Imperial Russian Geographical Society had decided to erect a monument in memory of the well known Central Asian traveler and explorer, Adolph Schlengenweit,
Recently a turkevhen, the property of Mrs. Joseph L. Garrett, near Cochranville, West Fallowfield, brought out a brood of 19 little turkeys.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 18.--Mrs. A. Hanchett, of Ansonia, who attempted suicide by shooting a few weeks ago, made sure work of it this morning by jumping into the Housatonic River, opposite her home. Her body was found in the river this noon. Since her former attempt she had not lived at home much, and last Saturday her husband "posted" her. It is supposed she thus became discouraged.

OYSTER BAY, Long Island, July 18.--The little town of Oyster Bay, upon Long Island Sound, has for a long time been afflicted with some scores of people whose observance of the moral law has been most lax.
Examination of M. Spiegel, Receiver of the Maison Tortoni, went on yesterday before Referee Clark, in the Potter Building. If answering exasperating questions, which insinuated...
WASHINGTON, July 18.--Acting Secretary Muldrow, of the Interior Department, to-day rendered a decision according to married women the right to enter and purchase timber and stone lands under...
Col. John A. McCaull had a narrow escape from a serious lose by the burning of the Metropolitan Van and Storage Warerooms on Saturday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18.--There was little diminution in the temperature to-day, and up to noon six deaths from prostration had been reported. The thermometer at noon registered 95 . There were 18 deaths from the heat yesterday and 5 on Saturday.

LONDON, July 18.--A Blue Book has just been published giving the particulars of the Egyptian mission of Sir H.D. Wolff and the text of the Egyptian convention. The despatches show that the Italian and Austrian representatives at Constantinople cordially assisted the...
BENNINGTON, Vt., July 18.--Judge Wheeler, of the United States Circuit Court, has handed down a decision in the case affecting the bankrupt Bennington Woolen Mills.

A Philadelphia paper publishes the announcement of a project to organize the men employed upon the Pennsylvania Railroad and its tributaries into a "national trade district assembly" of the Knights of Labor. How a "district" assembly can be "national" is such a question of detail as frequently arises in the proceedings of the Knights of Labor and need not specially concern us.

CINCINNATI, July 18.--At a meeting of the guarantors of the next year's Cincinnati Centennial Exposition this afternoon, the sum of $900,000 was reported as already subscribed, with $25,000 more promised, and additional subscriptions coming in daily. The Citizens' Committee reported that guarantee notes had already been executed for $785,000. The prospect is that the $1,000,000 required will be subscribed before the end of this week.

Sunday's storms, besides capsizing sailboats, tearing down trees, and blowing people off their feet, had a little fun at the expense of the different telephone and telegraph companies. Poles were blown down, wires disconnected or tangled with each other, and all business was turned topsy-turvy.
Esterbrook was released by the Metropolitan Club yesterday. The Boston-Indianapolis game scheduled for Boston yesterday was not played on account of rain.
Coroner Lindsay, of Brooklyn, began last night, at the Morgue, the inquest into the murder of old Andrew Cox, whose body was found on Myrtie-avenue...
The Symmes theory gets a boost from Prof. Vogelsang, of the Cosmos, published at San Marcos, Texas. Prof. Vogelsang says: "It is possible that there is over a hundred times more...
KEY WEST, Fla., July 18.--There have been three new cases of yellow fever since yesterday, but no deaths.
John A. Higgins, importer of laces at 480 Brooms-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edward C. Manners, giving two preferences for $3,873.

MONTREAL, July 18.--Mr. Munro, on behalf of the firm of Alexander Ferguson Co., of Glasgow, has filed in court a contestation of McDougall, Logie Co.'s abandonment of their estate. The contestation sets forth among other things that the firm have omitted to mention the...
Mrs. Henrietta Brant and her daughter Estella went to Yonkers yesterday morning, and there the final scene in the lively little abduction drama was enacted.
CHICAGO, July 18.--Local gamblers are beginning to find in Chicago a dull place since Mayor Roche closed up their houses, and the shining lights of the fraternity are seeking fresh pastures.

BOSTON, July 18.--Relatives, friends, and business associates from New-York and Boston met in St. Paul's Episcopal Church at noon today to discharge the last duties over the body of Alfred Boyce Hill, late Vice-President of the New-York Stock Exchange.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 18.--The new steamboat New-York, with a thousand passengers on board, made her first regular trip up the Hudson to-day, and was enthusiastically received at all points by shouts and cheers, bell ringing, and whistle blowing. She left New-York at 9:04, and was two minutes behind at Yonkers, twelve minutes ahead of time at Stony Point, and made West Point, 50 miles from New-York, at 11:40 A.M.
NYACK, N.Y., July 18.--A collision between two locomotives occurred on the Northern Railroad of New-Jersey at Sparkill to-day, which for several hours greatly impeded travel.

CHICAGO, July 18.--J.E. Fowler, a negro, who last Thursday evening assaulted Mrs. Jacob James, of Roseland, in the town of Hyde Park, to-day narrowly escaped death at the hands of Mrs. James's husband.

Richard Bartley, a slim handsome lad of 16, went at noon yesterday to his half brother, Charles C. Bartley, who has a harness store on the second door of 37 Clinton-place, and asked for something to do.
Of all the jubilee offerings which her Majesty has been asked to accept none have been simpler than two new-laid eggs which a poor Irishwoman sent to the Queen by a Bishop.

NELSON, Neb., July 18.--A farmer named Coonrad, who was being held in jail here for the murder, on Thursday last, of another farmer named Henry Sallen, was taken out by 100 men yesterday and hanged on a bridge near the city.
PARIS, July 18.--Laur, the member of the Chamber of Deputies to whom Gen. Boulanger wrote the letter which has caused so...
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 18.--Several prominent Sunday law advocates, who are not satisfied with the late decisions of Judge Noonan regarding that law, applied to-day through their...
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 18.--It is reported that ex-Senator Jarvis Lord is better, and that hopes are entertained for his recovery. His condition improved materially yesterday afternoon and last night.
Archbishop Corrigan Sunday confirmed 59 boys, 48 girls, and 16 adults on Randall's Island.

The movement started by Gov. HILL to secure a conference of representatives of the different States on the subject of interstate extradition is one of such manifest necessity that it is a wonder that no practical step in this direction has been taken before.
Mrs. Emma Windrum, a pretty girl of 22, who lives with her mother at 811 Quincy-street, Brooklyn, has begun a suit for divorce from her husband William.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 18.--Henry B. Chamberlain, convicted last week of the murder of the Widow Ernst, was to-day sentenced to imprisonment for life in State prison. James F. Taylor, of New-York, his accomplice, was...
John J. Alexander, of 15 Great Jones-street crossed the Thirty-fourth-street ferry Sunday night, with $5,000 in his pocket. On the boat six roughlooking fellows tried to pick a quarrel with him.

WATERBURY, Vt., June 18.--In June, 1886, Judd Depau ran away from Beekmantown, N.Y., with Edward Nelson's daughter, Elnora, aged 13. Depau was about 40 years old, and had a wife and three children at Malone.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., July 18.--John Coffee, of Philadelphia, was to-day unanimously re-elected Master Workman of Assembly No. 148, Green Bottle Glass-Blowers. William Phalen, of Lockport, N.Y., was elected Worthy Foreman;

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 18.--A big church fight has broken out in the town of Nanticoke. William Louricher, for many years a prominent member of the German Evangelical Protestant Church, about two weeks ago...
ST. LOUIS, July 18.--It will be announced to-morrow that a number of St. Louis capitalists are interested in a scheme to build a standard gauge railroad from Venice, Ill., opposite north...
Mrs. M.F. Inmann, who lives half a mile from St. Helena, has successfully carried 15,000 silkworms through the season. As it requires 300 cocoons to the pound, it will be seen that...

DETROIT, July 18.--Vincent J. Scott, a well known citizen and for many years one of the leading private bankers of the city, was found dead in bed this morning. He was a native of Aberdeen, Scotland, and was about 80 years old.

Two weeks ago this afternoon Joseph Quinn, a young athlete of high character, was deliberately murdered by a young ex-convict named Daniel Lyons, who was well known to the police, and the murderer is still at large.

A number of passengers of the Long Island Railroad, who seem to think that they were subjected to needless delay on their journey from Brooklyn to Broad Channel Sunday, have sent a protest to several of the daily papers.

Mr. Roger Dolan, of 16 East Third-street, who says he is a theatrical person, and Mrs. Roger Dolan, who has been assisting her husband to delight Bowery audiences, started for Atlantic City early yesterday afternoon, but before they left New-York they became two of the central figures in what was a good deal like a riot.

The United Labor Party of Kings County held ward primaries last night for the election of delegates to the Assembly District Conventions, to be held Thursday, at the Labor Lyceum, in Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn. Three delegates from each Assembly district will be elected to the State Convention, to be held in Syracuse Aug. 17.
The men employed by the Rockland Ice Company and other dealers who had resolved to strike yesterday if their demands were not granted sent committees in the morning to their employers.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18.--Robert Young, a son of Franklin A. Peniford, of Kenneth Square, Penn., died near Point Pleasant to-day on a train, while on his way here. The death caused some excitement among the passengers.
Sergt. Cross, of the Nineteenth Precinct, went into Delmonico's restaurant Sunday afternoon and ate dinner, including a bottle of claret.

Patrick Griffen, through his lawyer, exJudge Dittenhoefer, recently began an action in the Supreme Court for the appointment of a committee of the person and property of ex-Alderman Francis McCabe. The application was to have been made yesterday in the case, but it went over until Friday.
DETROIT, Mich., July 18.--Chief-Justice Waite, of the Supreme Court, passed through the city to-day en route to a Northern health resort, where he will remain for a fortnight or...

A grocer's horse died on Saturday in a stable on West Tenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. It was allowed to remain where it perished. Sunday it began to decompose, and the neighbors began to be interested in its removal.

Patrick Griffen, through his lawyer, exJudge Dittenhoefer, recently began an action in the Supreme Court for the appointment of a committee of the person and property of ex-Alderman Francis McCabe. The application was to have been made yesterday in the case, but it went over until Friday.

The New-York and Chicago Clubs played the final game of the present series at the Polo Grounds yesterday. About 3,500 spectators were present, and as the local nine played in fine form and won rather easily, everybody was satisfied and happy.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18.--A fatal accident occurred near Owen Township, Ind., 20 miles from Jeffersonville, last Saturday. A large force had been employed on the fruit farm of Angus Dean gathering peaches.

MAYVILLE, N.Y., July 18.--The annual convention of the Beta Theta Pi will be held at the clubhouse, Wooglin, Chautauqua Lake, next Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Gov. Beaver, of Pennsylvania, will deliver the oration.
Speculators are nibbling again at coffee. Within two weeks the quotations on the Exchange have advanced nearly 300 points, or 3 cents on Rio coffee, the speculative grade.
BOSTON, July 18.--A special meeting of the Boston and Lowell Railroad corporation was held here to-day. President Morey occupied the chair.

ST. LOUIS, July 18.--When J.M. Tuttle, of Iowa, came to St. Louis and insulted the President of the United States, he accomplished three things. He placed the Grand Army in a humiliating position; he disgusted every fair-minded man in the country, and he gained a national notoriety.
Charles Baldwin, pitcher of the Detroit Club, has been suspended indefinitely, without pay, for indifferent playing.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18.--By the Alaska Commercial Company's steamer Dora, which name in to-day from Ounalaska, information is received of the seizure of two vessels for sealing...
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 18.--News of an inhuman murder comes from Riverside, Ark. A man living near that plane had a stepson 5 years old whom he greatly disliked.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 18.--W.G. Truman, the forger, who is wanted in this city for forging a draft on the City National Bank, and who was arrested at Stroudsburg, Penn., on Saturday, has escaped. He was released on a writ of habeas corpus at Stroudsburg, and before the officers from this city arrived he was off for parts unknown.
Two old offenders fell into the hands of the police last night. One was "Bill" Johnson, who has been in prison for burglary. He was seen entering a pawnshop at Thirty-first-street and Second-avenue.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 18.-- Mrs. Eliza Griffen 62 years old, for the past 12 years a boarding house keeper on Kingsbury-street, died at midnight on Saturday from the effects of rat poison, taken with suicidal intent.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 18.--About 12:30 o'clock last night Solomon Baker, while attempting to board a train on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, slipped and fell beneath the cars.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18.--A meeting will be held in Philadelphia to-morrow to effect the consolidation of the Royal and Washington Natural Gas Companies. The former has a capital of $700,000 and the latter $500,000. The stock in the Royal Company is owned principally by Eastern capitalists, and after the consolidation it is understood that the capital stock will be increased to $2,000,000 or $2,500,000.

The point was distributed all over the Stock Exchange district yesterday that President Robert Garrett, of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, was in town, and that the long talked of "deal" was finally ready for public digestion.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 18.--W.H. Starbuck was in town to-night prepared to pay the $275,000 and sign the contract agreed upon for the city's interest in the Derby Railroad.

CHICAGO, July 18.--Michael Reirke, a maltster, until recently employed by the McAvoy Brewing Company, to-day began a suit againt the International Beer Brewers and Maltsters' Union No. 1 and Peter Jung, a "walking delegate" so called, of the union, to recover...

MONTREAL, July 18.--Fifteen members of the Ilderan Bicycle Club, of Brooklyn, arrived by the Upper Canada boat last Saturday, and are staying at the Windsor Hotel. They give glowing accounts of their reception in Toronto.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 18.--The news comes here to-night that John Sherman will attend the Republican State Convention at Toledo as a delegate.

Two young men arrived at the Manhansett House, Shelter Island, Saturday afternoon, and registered as D. McMonnies, of Brooklyn, and Charles A. Straub, of New-York. They hired a boat in the evening and went rowing. They rowed into the wake of the steamer Sunshine, and while changing seats the swell upset the boat, and both were drowned. Their bodies were recovered Sunday.

Caledonia can be stern and wild even in the midst of Summer. At Kirkwall, on Tuesday and Wednesday nights, there were, it seems, severe frosts, which, we are told, have considerably damaged the crops.

PEORIA, Ill., July 18.--Glen Miller, the grey stallion, owned by F.E. Fay, of Ohio, died at Jefferson Park last evening. His owner had refused $10,000 for him. The animal had a trotting record of 2:18, made at Chicago two years ago. He was sired by White Line, dam by Alexander's Abdallah. After the free-for-all-trot, on Friday, he was given ice water, which caused his death.

BERLIN, July 18.--Reports of crop prospects throughout Prussia are most favorable. Winter and Summer corn in Germany generally promise well. Wheat and rye are especially good. There will be a heavy potato crop.
Clarence R. Van Benthuysen, Secretary and General Manager of the Albany Day Line of steamers, died suddenly, of apoplexy, yesterday morning, at his residence, 102 Waverleyplace.

Margaret Lewis, a colored girl living at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, while in bathing yesterday dived off the trestlework of the railroad. She struck a stone, was knocked unconscious, and would have drowned had not Sailor, a large dog owned by Capt. Jacob Schmidt, caught her by the hair and towed her ashore. This is the fourth life Sailor has saved.
LONDON, July 18.--The American yacht Fortuna passed the Lizard to-day on her way to Cowes.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18.--The town is overrun with clerical-looking Professors and smartly dressed schoolmarms, attending the first annual session of the American Seaside Summer School of Pedagogy, which opened in Educational Hall this morning.
Little Kate and Will Lawless have Father Riordan, of Castle Garden, to thank for not being lost children. About two weeks ago they came over from Ireland on a Guion Line steamship.

WASHINGTON, July 18.--League Championship --Pittsburg, 4; Washington, 2. Pitchers--Morris and Gilmore. Earned runs--Pittsburg, 3; Washington, 1. Base hits--Pittsburg, 10; Washington, 7. Bases on balls--Pittsburg, 1; Washington, 2. Stolen bases--Pittsburg, 2. Errors--Pittsburg, 1; Washington, 4.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 18.--Jacob Josy, a passenger on the west-bound train of the Southern Pacific Road, got off the cars at Morgan City to purchase a bottle of beer.
WINCHESTER, Va., July 18.--Several severe electrical storms have occurred in this locality in the last 48 hours.
WOONSOCKET, R.I., July 18.--The Manville Mills, closed during the past month on account of a weavers' strike, started up this morning and all the departments, are running.

The corner in cotton appears to be yielding to natural conditions that are beyond the control of speculators. In this respect it resembles the Harper deal in wheat and the corners in coffee, prunes, and Ohio blackberries.
LONDON, July 19.--The Porte has sent a circular to the powers suggesting that Prince Ferdinand be made Governor of Roumelia and Regent of Bulgaria until a new Sobranje chooses a ruler.

CHICAGO, July 19.--The United States Government officers here have decided to purge Chicago Harbor of the dens of iniquity known as "bumboats." Steps were taken to-day to prosecute the keepers and remove the boats from the lake.
The Seventh Assembly District Prohibitionists nominated last night at their headquarters, 32 East Fourteenth-street, C.B. Cotten...
Mrs. Kessler keeps a small bakery at 138 Tenth-avenue. Her husband died suddenly about a month ago, and her son Frederick, who is 16 years old, went to live with an elder...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 19.--Mayor Samuel A. York, on the part of the city of NewHaven, and William H. Starbuck, of New-York, to-day signed the contract for the transfer of the Derby stock, held by the city, to Mr. Starbuck.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--The guests of the Bryn Mawr Hotel, a very fashionable Summer resort just outside the city limits, in Montgomery County, were horrified last night by the suicide of Allen Harp, a, boy 16 years old, who shot himself through the head over the grave of a pet dog.
BOSTON, July 19.--A four days' circuit meeting at Mystic Park was begun to-day, each of the two races bringing out a good field of horses. The weather was favorable and excellent time was the result.
William Ennis weeded gardens in Paterson, N.J., until he had accumulated a fortune of 40 cents. Monday morning he came to this city to begin life-- he is now 10 years old--as a newsboy.

Welch pitched one of the games for which he was famous yesterday against the Indianapolis Club. The New-Yorks seemed to recover their batting strength, and as a result won the game by 10 to 3. Although one-sided, the game did not lack interest. This was due to the strong work on both sides. Of the 13 runs tallied 11 were earned by good, clean hitting.
ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, July 19.--In December, 1885, the safe of the Apache County, Arizona, Treasurer was robbed of $12,000. Binicio Baco, the Treasurer, and his brother, Francisco,
Fire was discovered about 3 o'clock yesterday morning in Michael Solan's sawmill, 225 North Second-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District.
Boo Lee and Chang Woo are partners in the laundry business at 28 Elizabeth-street. Yesterday they bought several tons of coal and hired Arthur Sweeney to carry it from the sidewalk into the basement.
NEWBURG, N.Y., July 19.--The Sons of Veterans Encampment began a two days' session here this morning. Delegates are present from New-York, Brooklyn, Albany, and other cities.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 19.--A large number of teachers gathered at the various lectures and lessons given on this, the second day of the School of Pedagogy. The sessions are held in Library Hall and in the Methodist and Presbyterian churches, with Educational Hall as headquarters. Many distinguished educators are here as lecturers and teachers.

Samuel S. Brewster, the negro gambler and "fakir," who on Saturday afternoon stabbed and killed Eibo Williams, the colored dock laborer and gambler, during a quarrel in the liquor saloon of James McShane, at Grand and Thompson streets, and Charles Hicks, alias "Hicksey," a negro who was also engaged in the attack, were arrested yesterday.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 19.--Walter Irvin and two other men employed on the Monticello and Port Jervis Railroad were on a hand car last night when a passenger train approached.

ST. LOUIS, July 19.--A new freight route between St. Louis and Kansas City was opened to-day by the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad, in connection with the Kansas City, Springfield and Memphis Railroad.
Judge Donohue has granted a mandamus directing the Board of Health to furnish to applicants in future unqualified certified copies of records of marriages.
BERLIN, July 19.--Emperor William made only a short stay at Innsbruck. After reading the letters awaiting him there and dictating replies he started for Gastein.

BALTIMORE, July 19.--The threatening weather had a bad effect on the attendance at the St. LouisBaltimore ball game to-day, but about 4,000 persons paid to see one of the longest and most exciting contests that ever took place in this city.

The union longshoremen are again in the ascendant and have given notice that they want the old rates of wages for night work and work done on Sundays and other holidays.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--It rained here heavily last night, and this morning the thermometer registered only 72 , a drop of 11 from the previous morning. Clouds obscured the sun most of the day, and aided by a fair breeze gave much needed relief to weary sufferers.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 19.--Daniel L. Carlston, of Boston, Mass., committed suicide at Sierra Madre Villa, near here, last night. He was subject to severe attacks of neuralgia.
The affairs of Kauffman Runge, the failing cotton firm of Galveston, begin to assume definite shape so far as this city is concerned. C. Schumacher, a bill broker at 42...

Coroner Sutton, of Sing Sing, was called to Shaft No. 4 of the new Croton Aqueduct, near Sing Sing, yesterday morning to take the antemortem statement of Samuel Board, who had been shot by Richard Tillman during the night.
EDINBURGH, July 19.--Mr. James G. Blaine and Mr. Andrew Carnegie attended the unveiling at Dunfermline to-day of a monument of Alexander III., who reigned in Scotland from...

"I expect to sail for Europe on Saturday without fall," said President Robert Garrett, of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, yesterday, to a friend who enjoyed a pleasant confidential chat with him. And Mr. Garrett added this that will be of interest to Wall-street:
LONDON, July 19.--The Midland Derby, run at the Leicester meeting to-day, was won by two lengths by "Mr. Manton's" colt Timothy, by Hermit.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 19.--Of Lincklaen, the beautiful home of Secretary and Mrs. Fairchild, the President and Mrs. Cleveland cannot say enough in praise. Its history is the history of the village of Cazenovia. The Hollander who built it 80 years ago builded better than he knew.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 19.--The St. Anthony elevator, one of the largest in the Northwest, situated two miles east of this city on the Manitoba Railroad, caught fire...

LONDON, July 19.--To-night it is a nice question if the Tory Ministry will last the week out. Both bye elections have been heard from. Up to this hour one shows the same ratio of Gladstonian gains which marked the preceding five.
Charles D. Kellogg, Treasurer of the Bartholdi Creche, on Bedlow's Island, acknowledges the receipt of the following contributions in aid of the creche:
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19.--At a meeting of the members of the Chamber of Commerce this afternoon the following resolution was unanimously adopted:
James Farrell, an Irish laborer, who lived at 268 West Fifty-third-street, was found dead early yesterday morning on the stairs leading to the basement of 895 Eighth-avenue.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.Y., July 19.--While a number of men were working in the clay pits between this city and Sayreville to-day the bank caved...
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 19.--A petition in insolvency was filed at Pittsfield to-day for the Hurlbut Paper Company, of South Lee, and Deputy Sheriff Day was appointed messenger.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 19.--The trial of the election conspirators was called in the Federal Court to-day. Before the proceedings commenced Samuel E. Perkins, the leader of the...
WASHINGTON, July 19.--Three express companies have filed their schedules with the InterState Commerce Commission. To the others the following letter has been addressed:

PITTSBURG, July 19.--The mortality among children in Pittsburg and Allegheny during the past six weeks is something appalling. In June 569 children under 5 years of age died, and since July 1 there have been 568 deaths, making a total of 1,137 in then six weeks. Of this number nearly 75 per cent. were under 2 years of age.

CHICAGO, July 19.--Trouble is brewing among the Eastern roads, owing to the unrestricted sale of tickets on account of the National Educational Association meeting by some of the roads. The Boston and Albany, it is claimed, has flooded the Chicago market with return portions of round trip tickets between Boston and Chicago.

"Lucky" Baldwin started in with a sort of whoop at Monmouth Park yesterday, representatives from his stable then making their first appearance there. He won the Lassie Stakes, worth something over $2,500, with his filly Los Angeles, and another filly from his stable, Estrella, ran second to Dry Monopole in the Midsummer Handicap.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission gave a hearing to-day upon the petition of the Providence Coal Company for relief against discrimination in rates and practices by the Providence and Worcester Railroad. Mr. James Tillinghast appeared for the petitioners and Judge Edwin Metcalf for the defendant corporation.

Charles E. Littell, of Pinkerton's detective agency, figured as the chief complainant yesterday against Peter De Lacey, of 33 Parkplace; William Lovell, of 74 Church-street, and Ridge Levein, of 3 Barclay-street, whose places were raided by Inspector Steers and who were...

RAHWAY, July 19.--The local authorities, who have had the case of the girl found mysteriously murdered here in charge since its practical abandonment by the county officials, were greatly excited to-day over the success which has suddenly come to them in the matter of the "basket clue," an account of which appeared in THE TIMES of July 4.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that for some time past the Committee of Buildings, Estimates, and Property of the University of Pennsylvania has been considering the subject of building a new library, to be attached...
INDIANAPOLIS, July 19.--There was an exciting time last night at Wilkinson, Hancock County, growing out of the mobbing of a saloon run by a man named Wilson, which was established...
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19.--Accommodations were secured this morning for Queen Kapiolani and the rest of the Hawaiian royal party on board the steamship Australia, which sailed...

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19.--Pleasant weather prevailed here all day. August Belmont and his son, August Belmont, Jr., of New-York, visited the Island Cemetery to-day and placed flowers on the grave of the late Raymond R. Belmont, who accidentally shot himself at his father's house in New-York last Winter. To-day was the anniversary of young Belmont's birth.

CHICAGO, July 19.--The trouble had by the judges at the Washington Park races here on Thursday last with Edward Corrigan, has resulted in the expulsion of Corrigan from all tracks of the American Racing Association.

The capitalists who bought control of the Georgia Central Railroad Company some months ago, and whose movements have attracted a good deal of attention in Wall-street, have been holding conferences in this city for a day or two past. Two or three schemes of consequence are under advisement, but the men most largely interested exert themselves to wrap all their proceedings in mystery.
Crawford and Kisson, Harry Armstrong, Charles Fostelle, and Manning and Drew have been engaged for Sweatnam, Rice and Fagan's Minstrels.

Alexander Thain, a well known law lawyer, the performances of whose partner, Edward Kearney, about three months ago made a sensation, has been imprisoned in Ludlow-Street Jail and sentenced to pay a fine of $600 for contempt of court. He has procured a writ of habeas corpus from Judge Donohue, which will be heard to-day.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 19.--Henry Reum, aged 23, son of a well-to-do farmer living near Callicoon, committed suicide on Sunday.

A large number of the laboring men of the Fifth Ward met at Old Dominion Hall, 403 Greenwich-street, last evening, and effected a temporary organization for political purposes. John Hurley was chosen Chairman.

There are indications that the entire salmon output has been cornered, or at least gone into the controlling hands of one firm. It has been known for several days that the total yield would he below the usual, but it was expected that later catches would bring the numbers up. This anticipation, however, has not been realized, and there is little prospect of materially augmenting the supply.
The Harlem River improvement, for which an appropriation of $400,000 was made by Congress last session, still lingers in the preliminary stages.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 17.--The State press is very much agitated over the discovery that one of the leading county papers in the State, the Abbeville Press and Banner, is printed exclusively by negro compositors.
The sudden and agreeable change which came over the atmospherical dream yesterday had its effect upon Jacob Sharp.
Margaret Green, a colored woman, 26 years of age, was brutally assaulted last evening by her husband, Clarence, in their rooms at 210 East Ninety-eighth-street.

Effingham Lawrence, the central figure in an unpleasantness which threatens to disrupt the hitherto peaceful Niantic Club, of Flushing, Long Island, was seen yesterday at his office on Broadway. Mr. Lawrence was loth to talk about the matter, but did not deny that he should take strong measures to set himself right in the club at the meeting which is to be held Friday evening.

BOSTON, July 19.--George Lawley, the yacht builder, is authority for the statement that Gen. Paine's volunteer will be hauled out of the basin at high water on Thursday. Her centreboard will be shipped and she will then be given her maiden trial, and it is pretty safe to...
The General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines met at the office of Commissioner Fink yesterday. The business they transacted was of a routine nature.

Earlier at his task than most of the "laboring men," so called, who clamor for eight hours a day or less, could Chauncey M. Depew, President of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, have been found hard at work at his desk in the Grand Central Station.
The firemen have not yet ceased throwing water on the ruins of the Metropolitan Van and Storage Company's Thirty-eighth-street building, which was burned Saturday morning.

SARATOGA, July 19.--Something like 500 horses are here ready for the racing, which will begin on Thursday. Stable accommodations at the track are not ample to furnish room for all the racers, and many are consequently stabled in private stables near here.

The twenty-ninth annual shooting festival of the Brooklyn Schuetzen Corps began yesterday at Ridgewood Park. At 11 o'clock the company met at its headquarters, Zipp's Casino, and paraded, about 75 strong, through Bridge, Concord, Jay, and Sands streets to the residence of H. Oldenburg, the "king" of the last shooting match. Thence by cars the command, under Capt. John H. Doscher, proceeded to the park.

Mrs. Blanche Meda, or Pratt, of Delphin, was cross-examined yesterday before Justice Gorman regarding her charges that M.J.V. Mery struck her at 226 Fifth-avenue on July 13. She said that when very young she married a man named Pratt, and that he is still alive. After this she married a man named Dolphin. She did not know whether he was dead or not, and took no interest in him.

CITY OF MEXICO, Via Galveston, July 19. --The anniversary of the death of President Juarez was observed with great enthusiasm yesterday. Hundreds of buildings displayed the Mexican colors draped with black and many American flags were seen at half-mast.

Vehement odors coming from Brown Co.'s restaurant, at 302 Bowery, have annoyed the tenants of the Palma Hotel, a lodging house above the restaurant, and other residents and tradesmen in the neighborhood ever since Saturday morning, when a sign was placed on the door reading.

At the next meeting of the Park Board the Commissioners will take action looking to the discipline or 12 park keepers, whose "uncle" is Isaac L. Devoe, a glass beveler, of Baxterstreet, who, it seems, has been the banker of...
There will be racing at Brighton Beach again this afternoon. Seven races are to be run, the entries to the various events being as follows:

QUEBEC, July 19.--J.C. Brinsmaid, of Cleveland, Ohio, and Charles B. Shannon, of Lake George, N.Y., have arrived here, having ridden through from Cleveland, by way of Toronto and Montreal, on their bicycles.

Mrs. Hannah Dougan, a domestic employed by Mr. Theodore Mercer, of Perth Amboy, N.J., took a bath at that place, Monday afternoon, which resulted in her death. She was a large woman about 40 years old, and she waded out on the beach till the water reached her neck, while at this depth she was carried out by an undercurrent 10 or 15 feet, to where the water was far over her head.
RAHWAY, July 19.--The Edison Electric Lamp Company's works at Harrison were closed for two weeks on July 4.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 19.--There is some prospect of the early establishment of a new cattle market at East Buffalo, at the stock yards of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western.
ELIZABETHTOWN, Ill., July 19.--James D. Belt, one of the men lately acquitted of the killing of Luke Hambrink, was assassinated six miles above this place this evening at 6 o'clock.

The mugwump confidence in Mr. Cleveland has been generally vindicated. He was a Democrat, and he announced frankly that his Administration would be Democratic. He has taken Democratic counsel, and in the treatment of the civil service he has unquestionably disappointed the expectations of the best friends of reform.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 19.--The interest felt here in the special examination of the Continental Life Insurance Company by Commissioner Fyler is increasing. What the outcome will be cannot be foreshadowed at present. There is no question, however, that the company's valuations of the assets held have been excessive as compared with the valuations made by other insurance companies in this city holding like securities.

A proposition contemplating a syndicate in racing clubs of the different associations in the Eastern circuit for the purpose of purchasing or leasing the tract and charter of the Saratoga Racing Association is under consideration, with a good prospect of being developed satisfactorily for practical results next season.
CHICAGO, July 19.--Two hundred delegates to the second annual convention of the national retail shoe dealers of the United States assembled in convention in this city this morning.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 19.--The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher was born in Litchfield, Conn., and was always held in great honor by the citizens of that town and county.

A band of highway robbers was the other day brought before the High Court of Poltava at the head of which stood a noble lady of the name of Rustanovitch. The band was exceptionally well organized, and it appears to have...
George W. Kitchell and John Linehan, accused of sanding the track of the Sixth-Avenue Railroad on Sunday, were held by Justice Gorman yesterday for trial at the Court of Special Sessions.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 19.--A mammoth camp meeting under the management of the Pennsylvania State Temperance Union was opened at Luzerne Grove to-day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 19.--The condition of the Hon. Jarvis Lord was unchanged to-day. The slight improvement which was noticed Sunday night did not continue, and Mr. Lord is in a very critical state. His right side is entirely paralyzed. He is despondent and breaks down at the sight of old friends. Few persons are allowed to see him.

Mayor Hewitt is an ex officio member of the Board of Electrical Control, and at that body's meeting yesterday in his office he exercised for the first time his rights in that capacity. And he did it in such a heartily enthusiastic manner that the usual dull routine was somewhat disturbed.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., July 19.--The great coke strike is ended, so far as any official action can end it, and there is no doubt but 8,000 or 9,000 men will go back to work on Thursday. The Knights of Labor held a delegate convention in this village to-day, and the Amalgamated Association of Miners met in Everson, a mile or two away.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 19.--Robert Garrett, the Hon. James K. Cowen, S. Spencer, and Howard Munnikhuysen, all of Baltimore and A.B. Crane, Mr. Garrett's private secretary' arrived in two private cars at Elberon station yesterday afternoon. The party registered at the Elberon Hotel.
The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Arcade Railway Company was to have been held yesterday at the company's offices, 115 Broadway, but was adjourned to Sept. 6.

When Elisha Crawford, of White Plains, died, several years ago, he left his house and furniture, in Tanbark-row, to his wife, with the understanding that she should have it to live in until she died, and then it was to go to his children.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 19.--Giles Luther, an aged resident of the outskirts of Warren, left his invalid wife at 11 o'clock last night to...

BOSTON, July 19.--A little strike of a few lasters in one shoe shop in the town of Beverly is growing into serious proportions--shop after shop has been ordered out by the Knights or forced out by the manufacturers, until it looks as if some 2,000 people would soon be out of employment.

CINCINNATI, July 19.--The announcement but three days before the assembling of the Democratic State Convention that Congressman Foran, of Cleveland, would be a candidate for the nomination of Governor caused much surprise here. The wisdom of his candidacy is questioned by the local party managers, and his strength among the workingmen is denied by representatives of the Union Labor Party.

A fire broke out at an early hour this morning in the Standard Oil Company's warehouse at Constable Hook, near Bergen Point. The cause could not be definitely ascertained. The origin suggested spontaneous combustion.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 19.--Three new cases of yellow fever have appeared since yesterday, and one death has occurred.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 19.--The yachts of the Atlantic squadron anchored in New-Haven Harbor at 2 o'clock this morning, and sailed for NewLondon to-day The yachts Wild Pigeon. Vixen, and Isabelle, of this port, went to New-London with the squadron.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, July 19.--The Pacific Railroad Investigation Commission had a public session here yesterday. Among the witnesses examined were Francis E. Warren, exGovernor of the Territory; C.W. Rives, Mayor of Cheyenne; E.A. Slack, editor of the Cheyenne Sun; Nathaniel R. Davis, a ranchman and banker in Cheyenne; George A. Draper, Marshal...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 19.--A force of 300 Italians, fully equipped with horses and tools, began yesterday the work of grading for the proposed Delaware and Otsego Railroad, at a point about a mile south of the village of Hobart.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 19.--For years there has been more or less talk of utilizing the great water power of Niagara River, which has been going to waste at the doors of Buffalo, and many have been the plans presented for harnessing the great current and making it do work for mankind.

The court, the lawyers, and the jurors already sworn to try the big omnibus boodle case turned up all serene this morning, looking refreshed after their two days' rest and reinvigorated by the cool breezes of this morning after the enervating heat of yesterday and last week.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19.--Justice Field, of the United States Supreme Court, decided today that Mrs. Langtry would have to return to...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 19.--If it were safe to predict of any convention what that convention would do, the temptation to be a prophet now, a day and a half before the event, would easily lead one to confidently promise that Thomas Edward Powell, of Delaware, is to be the Democratic candidate for Governor of Ohio.
Two ladies, aged, respectively, 62 and 52, committed suicide on Saturday under the most tragical circumstances. The younger of the two was married and lost her husband some years ago.

Sparrows are being properly appreciated. Hundreds of them are now caught by enterprising people for sale to certain restaurants where reed birds are in demand. A German woman on Third-avenue has three traps set every day, and she catches probably 75 a week. They are cooked and served to her boarders the same as reed birds and are declared quite as great a delicacy.

Superintendent Shantz, who on Monday afternoon informed some 250 employes in Robert K. Davies Co.'s shirt factory at 536 West Twenty-third-street that they were discharged and could only go back to work after making a new engagement with the firm, stated yesterday that the lock-out was the culmination of a struggle for supremacy between the firm and its employes, which had been going on since last April.

EL PASO, Texas, July 19.--Close upon the heels of the news of the earthquake at Bavispe come the details of a still greater calamity at Bacariac, a town 20 miles from Bavispe.

ZANZIBAR, July 19.--The latest reports brought from the interior by traders show that Emin Bey was in good health in March and was projecting an expedition to further explore the Kakibbi River, an immense stream which he...
CHICAGO, July 19.--A new attempt to prevent the Illinois Central Railroad from obtaining possession of the Chicago lake front was begun to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 19.--The firm of Jacoby Maddern, of Bridgeport, Conn., have had the contract for the work on the reservoir that is to supply with water several villages and the towns of Warwick and Cranston, including...

Many inventions are made by workman in the course of their daily duties, using the time and material of their employers in the usual course of experiments necessary to the application of a new idea.

BOSTON, July 19.--Uriel Crocker, the oldest publisher in New-England, died early this morning at his Summer residence, on Jerusalemroad, Cohasset. For nearly three-quarters of a century Mr. Crocker, as senior member of the firm of Crocker Brewster, has been identified with book making in Boston.

LONDON, July 19.--The House of Commons went formally in a body to the House of Lords this afternoon, where the royal assent was given to the Irish Crimes Act Amendment bill and it was thus made the law of the realm.
Gen. John Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, has gone to the Adirondacks on a week's vacation.

ST. LOUIS, July 19.--Special dispatches to the Republican from all the leading corn-growing counties of the State show that the crop is suffering greatly from drought. In the north and northwest a large percentage of the crop is already destroyed.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 19.--A shark 20 feet long was found stranded on the beach at Savin Rock this morning.

Bernard J. Kelley, a young lawyer and notary public, will to-day answer before Justice White, in the Harlem Police Court, to a charge of certifying, as notary, to the signature of Ewald Bolt to an assignment, knowing the same to be a forgery.

George D. Lennon hired him a hall last night, and William Martin and his friends met in it. Both Messrs. Lennon and Martin are leaders in the councils of the Union Labor Party. The former derives his authority from no less a person than Joel P. Hoyt, of Jamestown, Chairman of the State Committee, and the latter heads the city forces of the party as Chairman of the County Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--It is stated at the Navy Department that notwithstanding the changes now being made to the plans for the machinery of the two 19-knot vessels, Secretary Whitney has concluded not to postpone the opening of bids, but to award the contracts, subject to the proposed modifications.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 19.--Petroleum dull and heavy; National Transit Certificates opened at 60 closed at 60; highest, 60 ; lowest 59 7/8.

There was a crash of glass at Fourth and Atlantic avenues, Brooklyn, Saturday night, and one of the big windows of the Sprague National Bank fell in pieces on the sidewalk.

Mayor HEWITT is an adept at letter writing. He has addressed a long epistle to Park Commissioner CRIMMINS, ostensibly for the purpose of accepting his resignation, tendered more than six months ago, but really for the purpose of "vindicating" him from certain charges.

The verbose and hackneyed barber was doubtless pardoned on all sides yesterday for discussing the weather, for the simple reason that the subject certainly afforded ample ground for discussion. After metropolitan sufferers had been gradually growing accustomed to sweltering in the nineties, in the same way that eels are said to grow accustomed to being skinned, they were suddenly and summarily cooled off by about 20 .
WASHINGTON, July 19.--First Lieut. A.L. Smith has been relieved from further duty at Jefferson Barracks, Missouri, and ordered to duty at Fort Myer with his troop.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 19.--"No one knows the funny things toads will do," said the Hon. James A. Sweeney, a Luzerne County naturalist and ex-member of the Pennsylvania Legislature. "On a recent cloudy day, after a hard rain, there was a cool breeze blowing.
The excess of politics in proportion to population that is stimulated in a Commonwealth that has the bad eminence of being "an October State" is strikingly illustrated in Ohio.
After the coronation the Duchess of Kent found great fault with Lord Conyngham, (who was then Lord Chamberlain) because the Queen's procession in the Abbey was too crowded,

NEW-ORLEANS, July 19.--Six bales of new cotton were received here by rail to-day from Cuero, Texas. The cotton in two of the bales was raised by Mrs. Hausemann. The remainder was shipped by Buchel Co.

CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW, LL.D., on the eve of his departure for a well earned vacation across the water, is in a happy and confident state of mind, which is extremely favorable to his chances for physical benefit.

Counsel for the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge applied to Justice Cullen, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, for the appointment of Commissioners to condemn certain property in Washington and Nassau streets and Snell's...

Recent defalcations in the departments at Washington have shown, not for the first time, that important changes should without delay be made in the administrative methods that have failed to protect the people's money.

When Mary E. Harwood entered the Fiftyfirst-street station Saturday night disheveled as to raiment and bearing unmistakable evidence of indulgence in ardent spirits, her wild story of assault, detention, and robbery at some mysterious tenement to which she had been enticed by an old woman, was regarded by the officers as the imaginings of a brain set awry by drink.

At a meeting of the full board of the Seventy-first Regiment, held at the armory last night, and presided over by Col. Stewart, of the Eleventh Regiment, in the absence of Gen. Fitzgerald, Lieut-Col. Frederick Kopper, was ...
LONDON, July 19.--Lieut, Warren, of the first Middlesex Regiment, won the Queen's prize at Wimbledon. The Dominion of Canada challenge trophy was won by the Third Lanark Regiment.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 19.--John Tinsman, of Matamoras, Penn., committed suicide last night by taking landanum. He had recently been discharged from the employ of the Erie Railroad Company.

A more contented man never lived in Jamaica, Long Island, than John H. Douglass till shortly after he made Miss Annie Petersen his second wife. Young Douglass is now the talk of the town, as he has left for parts unknown, and his friends say it is all owing to this second helpmate.
DILLON, Montana, July 19.--About 10 o'clock this forenoon Henry Grabborn shot his wife through the head, killing her instantly.

Something unusual seemed to be agitating Jay Gould all day yesterday. He went skipping around Wall-street with the liveliness of a boy of 20. He popped in and popped out of banking offices as if bent on accomplishing something of a good deal of importance. His usual leisurely walk was wholly missing.
The following is a full list of entries for the Elberon tennis tournament, which begins at 3 P.M. today, and continues Friday and Saturday:

LOGANSPORT, Ind., July 20.--The excitement over the capture of the Green brothers remains unabated. An organization of 300 men has been perfected in the Mabitt settlement, and several hundred citizens met last night and hanged Bill and Amer Green in effigy amid the wildest excitement. Mr. Mabitt has had an interview with Amer Green, the murderer of his ...

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 20.--The second day of the School of Pedagogy was well employed in the various classes. The instructors from all parts of the country are in full working order. Dr. Lunton lectured on the science of education, Miss Jessie Eldredgo, of Boston, discoursed on elocution, and Miss Wintermer gave an interesting lesson on kindergarten work.

PARIS, July 20.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Delisse asked whether the Government was ready to oppose the importation of German alcohol in the event of the increase of export bounties in Germany. M. Rouvier replied that the German drawback upon alcohol ...

GENEVA, N.Y., July 20.--Teemor, Hamm, and Bubear arrived here this morning, and will go in training on Seneca Lake for the coming races. The college boathouse has been secured for the housing of their shells.

Lord SALISBURY is not a Bourbon. On the contrary, he is an alert observer of current events and is capable of drawing conclusions from them. In deliberately throwing over what he and other Tory leaders have insisted upon as a necessary and just measure he shows that the lesson of the bye-elections has not been thrown away upon him.

John B. Kitching, well known in business circles in this country and in England, died Tuesday from paralysis, resulting from sunstroke, at the residence of his only surviving daughter, Mrs. Theodore Irving, 21 West Thirtysecond-street.

SARATOGA, July 20.--The population is being daily increased by from 400 to 500 arrivals. There were eight palace drawing room cars on the morning train from New-York City, each with its full complement of passengers. At the Grand Union 600 people spent Sunday, while Congress Hall and the United States Hotel had about the same number.

LONDON, July 20.--A financial paper this evening publishes an interview with Mr. Lown, a New-York counselor-at law, in which he imgarted a hitherto unpublished opinion on the Alien act, given by Attorney-General Garland to President Cleveland. This opinion is to the effect that the act does not apply to mines or inheritable interests in real estates; that ...

For eight successive innings the Indianapolis players were retired without a run in their contest with the New-Yorks on the Polo Grounds yesterday, but in the ninth they sent 2 men across the home base and saved themselves from the stigma of a "Chicago" defeat.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 20.--F. Gano Hill has sold to John T. Hughes, of this county, the 4-year-old bay mare Maggie H.C., by Victor von Bismarck, dam by Expert, for $2,500. H.M. Smith, of this city, has sold a 3-year-old bay colt, by Jay Gould, dam by Hamlet, to Pennsylvania parties for $6,500.

The new Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday hold the thirst meeting since their creation at the rooms of the Mercantile Trust Company, in the Equitable Building. Gen. Fitzgerald presided. Charles Gorldard, representing the New-York Underground Railway Company ...

The Vicksburg Water Works Company after vainly endeavoring to get water from bored wells, have at last concluded to serve water to their patrons from the Mississippi River. We apprehend that the problem of a water supply for the city of Natchez will be solved in the same way. Mississippi River water is good enough for anybody, being wholesome and healthful, and perfectly satisfactory to everybody who has ever made use of it.

A frightful fire swept through the little Jewish town of Botuschania, Roumania, on June 15, spreading over a mile and a quarter of the town and destroying over 1,000 buildings, occupied in the main by Hebrews. Eight thousand persons were rendered homeless by the disaster and reduced to the verge of starvation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 20.--The funeral of Mrs. Sadie Fulton Chanfrau, wife of H.T. Chanfrau, the actor, took place from the residence of her aunt, Mrs. Baldwin, in the East End, this city, this morning, and was attended by a large circle of friends. The body arrived here from Atlantic City, N.J., yesterday.

Miss Maude Hamilton, of 79 East Tenthstreet, was held for examination at Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday or a charge of larceny. Miss Hamilton, who is young and pretty, went to the Western Union Telegraph office at the corner of Broadway and Dey-street, on ...

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 20.--One of the most disastrous storms ever known in this State swept over the counties of Wirt and Wood about dusk to-night, doing damage to a large amount, besides seriously injuring a number of people.

Katie O'Brien, a pretty 16-year-old girl, living with her parents at 137 North Eighthstreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District, is missing. She was sent on an errand yesterday and has not since been seen. Her parents are inclined to believe she has eloped with a young man in the neighborhood who has been paying her marked attention. The police caused a general alarm to be sent out in hopes of finding her.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 20.--The Northwestern Miller says: "The hot weather last week worked against the mills and curtailed the product fully 20 per cent., but the output was heavier than the previous week. The flour production was 129,000 barrels, averaging 21,500 barrels daily agaiust 110,480 barrels the preceding week and 145,800 the corresponding time in 1886. The seventeenth mill is running the present week and with cooler weather the ...
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20.--Drafts--Sight, 20 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

Brooklyn Knights of Honor, of whom there are about 4,000, are indignant over the sudden, and what they term arbitrary, suspension of Williamsburg Lodge, No. 1,616. Grand Dictator Dowe is blamed for the suspension, and threats of deposing him were freely made yesterday.

KENNEBUNK PORT, Me., July 20.--The Rev. Edward Young Hincks, D.D., Professor of Theology at Andover, one of the trio charged with heretloal teaching was to-day charged marriage to Miss Elizabeth Tyler Clark, daughter of Charles P. Clark, President of the New York and New-Haven Railroad. The wedding surpassed anything ever known in this part of the State.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 20.--The annual meeting of the Northwestern Amateur Rowing Association was held this morning, all clubs being represented. George H. Lesher, Secretary and Treasurer, reported the 22 clubs in the association in a flourishing condition and that it now had $501 20 in the treasury.

CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, July 20.--At about 11 o'clock Monday night William George, a young man employed by a farmer named McLees, went to the house of another farm hand, named Scott, an old man, and asked his assistance in getting a horse out of a ditch into which it had fallen. The men procured axes and started.

CHICAGO, July 20.--J. Cairns, a wealthy and reputable real estate owner on the west side, has been held to the Criminal Court by Justice Lyon, under $5,000 bonds, charged with forgery. Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild owns much of the property bounded by Seymour-street and California-avenue and Fulton ...

The schooner yacht Rambler was sold at auction yesterday by Montgomery Co., 87 Pine-street, for the surprisingly low price of $4,800. The yacht was sold with all her spars, sails, furniture, and fixtures, and the price for which she was sold represents about her value as junk. The Rambler was bought by T.G. Sandford, of 312 Broadway, for "an Eastern ...

OIL CITY, Penn., July 20.--A little before 12 o'clock last night John McNierney, a laborer, beat his wife to death, fatally shot his son John, aged 21 years, for interfering in behalf of his mother, and then shot Officer James, who tried to arrest him, in the groin, inflicting a fatal wound. Officers Warden and Henderson then came to the assistance of James, and soon ...
