Ten of the Police Captains of this city congregated yesterday in Room No. 13 of the City Hall and earnestly sought to solve the intellectual problems laid before them. They underwent a written examination under the auspices of the Civil Service Examining and Supervisory Board, and the prize to be given to each of the two most successful of them was a Police Inspectorship.

LONDON, July 23.--The Right Hon. John Morley, in opening the Liberal Club at Hackney to-night, said that the Government had waited half a year in passing a measure that was intended to suppress the National League, but directly they obtained it Lord Salisbury changed his attitude end said he would adopt the League's policy regarding rents in Ireland.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 23.--At 9:30 o'clock last evening two barns on the premises owned by Edward Wheeler, near Smithville, were discovered to be on fire. They were consumed together with their contents. The loss is $1,000; insurance, $1,100. Mrs. Helen Wheeler, aged 65, the mother of the owner of the buildings, was at a neighbor's house, some distance away, when the fire broke out.

Levi Lovely, who has been covering third base for the Lowells, has been released. A telegram from Pittsburg announces the sudden death last night of Alexander McKinnon, first baseman of the Allegheny Club.

PITTSBURG, July 24.--The disastrous derailing of a train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in this city to-night, it is freely charged, was the work of malicious persons recently discharged from the service or the company.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 24.--The schooner Maynard Summer was hauled off Hedge fence Shoals last night by the tug Joseph Bartram, without apparent damage, and proceeded to Boston this morning.

Annie Yulka, who has been living at 136 East Broadway, was taken suddenly ill yesterday morning and was removed to Gouverneur Hospital. Dr. O'Hara found that she had very recently become a mother. Miss Yulka, who is about 20 years old and rather pleasing in appearance, refuses to speak or answer questions for the present.

Dr. Henry D. Cogswell, who has at his residence all the original plans of his monument, was asked yesterday for permission to take sketches of them. "No, Sir," replied the gentleman." "I intend to have them copyrighted for my own individual use. They have cost me a great amount of money, and I'm not going to make a free distribution of them through the newspapers."

The trial of John D. Sheahan for the murder of one Bishop, in Laurens, S.C., two weeks ago, has resulted in a verdict of not guilty. Both were young men and prominent merchants of Laurens. On the 4th of July Sheahan heard that Bishop had accused him of hiring negroes to burn a small town in Laurens County. Sheahan met Bishop in front of the Court House ...

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24.--This has been a glorious Sabbath as far as the weather was concerned. General gloom prevailed early in the morning, when the place was visited by two smart showers, but the sun came out and the dust on Bellevue-avenue was sent skyward.

The intention of Prof. Adams's work is to portray the principles which underlie the use of public credit. Starting with an account of the debts of the civilized countries of the world, the author proceeds to a consideration of the effects, political, social, and industrial, of public debts and to a discussion of national deficit financiering and local deficit financiering.

In April, 1861, Gen. Cox and Gen. Garfield were members of the Ohio Senate and were lodging together. On the day that Fort Sumter was fired on the Senate was in session when a member came from the lobby in an excited manner, and, catching the Chairman's eye, exclaimed: "Mr. President, the telegraph announces that the Secessionists are bombarding Fort Sumter."

The steamship Scotia, which went ashore last March 15 miles east of Fire Island, and stuck fast until the latter part of April, left New-York yesterday in tow. She will be taken to Wilmington and there, it is reported, altered into a coaling steamer. The bids for repairing the steamer would have been too high to make that course advisable. The lowest bid on the work is understood to have been $79,000.

The work itself calls for no comment, but in an appendix two very interesting letters are given which do not appear in the original. It will be remembered that on his eightieth birthday Carlyle, to his great surprise.

A man was arrested at 2 o'clock this afternoon who was pointed out to Officer Shine as one who had forged another man's name on an order upon D. O'Connell for wages. The man who is under arrest says he is not the party wanted; that he cannot read, much less write.

About 5,000 spectators saw the game between the St. Louis and Brooklyn Clubs at Ridgewood yesterday. Terry and Caruthers pitched in fine form, and but few telling hits were made off either. An examination of the contents of the 191 "opium" boxes found in the possession of Wo Me proves the entire lot to be sago flour. As Wo Me, while on smuggling intent, paid a fine of $500 for having this stuff in his possession, Uncle Sam can consider that for once he has get ahead of the wily celestial.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24.--The Pacific Railroad Commission has arrived in this city, and will begin an investigation of the affairs of the Central Pacific Railroad to-morrow. The chief inquiry is to be directed toward discovering how much, if any, of the earnings of the Central Pacific Road were diverted to aid in the construction of the Southern Pacific.

A well known comedian of one of the, Boulevard theatres has had some remarkable and rather amusing experiences inthe provinces. It appears that the fire at the Opera Comique has so terrified provincial playgoers that they absolutely prefer in many towns to remain at home rather than risk their lives by going into the galleries of their local theaters.

The announcement is made that Mr. William A. Freret, of this city, has been appointed Supervising Architect of the United States. The appointment will give general satisfaction, both on account of a feeling of local pride and be cause Mr. Freret will do honor to the important office he has been called on to fill.
DUBLIN, July 24.--At a meeting of campaign tenants on the Vandeleur estate, in West Clare, to-day, it was decided to accept the offer of a reduction of 30 per cent in rents.

A young man fell limp and unconscious on the street at 56 Madison-avenue yesterday afternoon. An ambulance was summoned and took him to the New-York Hospital, where it was found that the man was starving. After he had taken a little soup and brandy he said he was William Nelson.

From developments which came to light in this section yesterday it is probable that he has done something in the fraudulent pension line.

The one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the arrival at Kazan, Russia, of the miraculous image or ikon which forms the principal object of attraction in the celebrated cathedral of that city has just been celebrated there. It was in 1737 that it was removed, after a concealment of 27 years at St. Petersburg, to Kazan, by the Empress Anne Ivanovna.

AUBURN, July 24.--The new Warden of the Auburn State Prison, Charles F. Durston, shows such a decided disposition to run the institution on political principles that his movements cannot be too jealously watched by those who pay taxes for its support.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 24.--An exciting stabbing affray took place last night in a boarding house on Albany-street, in the fashionable part of the city, and may result in the death of a young man named Wayne Roberts. The Stabbing was done by William Fulton, another young man.

Some one threw the rind of a piece of watermelon last night at the son of Dominico Largo, of 74 Thompson-street. Dominico accused Ferdinando Galardi of doing it. This led to a dispute, in which Largo was stabbed in the left side. As his injury was found to be severe at St. Vincent's Hospital Ferdinando was locked up.

It is noticeable that notwithstanding the numerous cases of bites by vicious dogs which have been recorded this Summer, hardly a suggestion has been made of hydrophobia. Is it because Pasteur has robbed the disease of its terrors, or is it simply because the good sense of the people is improving?

A tendency of the present day is the laxity of conversation permitted by many ladies in society in their male friends. This latter evil is one of very rapid growth, and has spread in many cases from the married women even to the girls, who think that they can make themselves as agreeable to the men as their successful rivals, by adopting the same style and allowing the same freedom of conversation.

This week will be the busiest in cricketing circles of any this season, and some of the strongest local clubs will engage in friendly rivalry. To-morrow the strong Trenton eleven, the probable winners of the State championship pennant, will play the equally strong Manhattan Club in Prospect Park.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 24.--The Republicans of Ohio will on Wednesday and Thursday next meet in convention in this city. The delegates are asked in the call that summons them here simply to nominate candidates for Governor and for other State officers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--When Charles Willis threw open the kitchen shutters at his home, at 1,543 South Nineteenth-street, this morning he found his gray-haired father on the floor with his throat cut. The old man lay on his back with a razor in his right hand, and his white locks and snowy shirt were bathed in blood.
Two remarkable journeys in air ships have been calmly announced of late, one to take place from Chicago to the north pole and the other from St. Nazaire to New-York.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 24.--Steve Brodie, the bridge jumber, was beaten in a hard glove fight with Joe Ridge, the light weight pugilist of this city, last night. The fight occurred on a steamboat on the Monongahela River, and Brodie was knocked out in the seventh round.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 25.--Mount Holly's record and pride as a phenomenally healthy town is broken. For one season, atleaast, the town and its neighborhood have been unhealthy, so unhealthy that the fever cases have been counted by scores, and the physicians have met and consulted, and the State Board of Healtn has been called upon to make analyses and do other things to find out the cause of all the trouble.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 25.--The stockholders of the Atlanta and West Point Railroad met this morning. For the past year the gross earnings were $394,640 10; the expenses, $234,053 27; net earnings, $160,586.83.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 25.--The excitement caused by the introduction of the Glen bill in the Legislature is unabated and grows every day. The bill provides for the punishment of any teacher who instructs white and colored-children in the same institution.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 25.--Suit for divorce was begun to-day by William J. Keuhne, the well known third baseman of the Pittsburg Club, against his wife. Two or three Allegheny City county officers will appear as corespondents.

NEWPORT, July 25.--This day has been unusually hot and sultry, the thermometer almost registering 90 in the shade. The beach and cliffs were thronged with visitors and a large party assembled at the Casino dance to-night. There were many vistors at the Casino to-day.
On Wednesday evening last persons on the 6:12 train to New-Haven from Bridgeport, when just over the Housatonic River, noticed a waterspout on the Sound, which attracted much attention.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Piggot, the oldest Protestant Episcopal minister in the United States, died at his residence, at Sykesville, on Saturday night at 11:15 o'clock. He was born in NewYork May 20. 1795, and was at the time of his death in his ninety-third year.

Jay Could did not appear in Wall-street yesterday, but his son, discussing the story of how his father's Missouri Pacific Railroad had been swindled out of $1,000,000 on railway tie contracts said: "The report is untrue. The sharpers did get away with a nice little pile, but it was closer to $20,000 than $1,000,000. And father doesn't charge anybody with fraud. It was a little thing, and we've forgotten almost all about it."

NOGALES, Arizona, July 25.--Manuelio Velasso, a Mexican girl, age 16, was shot and instantly killed this morning. Corillo Guitterez was arrested, charged with her murder. He says that in taking the gun from a rack the hammer caught on something and the weapon was discharged.

BOSTON, July 25.--The father of Herbert H. Tailer, the former Harvard student who was arrested in Canada for forgery and who swindled various Harvard-square dealers, has been in Cambridge lately settling up with his son's creditors in order to avoid prosecution.
John Hooper and family, of Brooklyn, are summering at Saratoga Springs and will remain at the Kensington Hotel till Sept. 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25.--The Casino dance to-night was a brilliant affair. Among those present were Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Addison Cammack, and M. Roustan, the French Minister, and attaches of the same legation.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 25.--There is a little colored church on the Green's Ferry road, leading out from Atlanta, midway between the Chattahoochee River and Sweetwater Creek, the congregation of which is now in a perturbed condition.

Every Wall-street man who at the close of yesterday's business on the Stock Exchange had occasion to explain the speculative situation did so with the explanation that we are having a "room traders' market."

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 25.--A washout occurred on the Erie Road two miles west of Cochecton at 7:30 last night, carrying away the east track just as a train loaded with cheese was passing. The engine and several cars passed safely, but 2l cars of cheese went down the bank and were totally wrecked. Travel was delayed for about 10 hours.

The track at Monmouth Park is said to be in the best condition it has been this year, and, with the excellent card which is presented for today and the close handicapping, there will be a fine day's sport and some close finishes.

MONTREAL, July 25.--The Canadian Pacific bridge over the Ottawa, River at St. Anne's was today completed and crossed by the officials of the road in a special car. The bridge over the St. Lawrence River at Lachine will be finished by Thursday and trains will be running over it by the 1st of August.

The papers for the requisition of Daniel Lyons, who murdered Joseph Quinn, were given to Officer James Duncan, of the Twenty-first Precinet, yesterday morning by Assistant District Attorney Davis. Duncan started at once for Albany to get Gov. Hill's signature, and will thence go to Harrisburg to procure the signature of the Governor of Pennsylvania, and then to Pittsburg. It is expected that he will arrive in this city with Lyons Thursday morning.
Saloon Keeper John Wancenreid, of 432 Monmouth-street, Jersey City, was made the victim of a neat confidence game yesterday.

President John Taylor, of the Mormon Church, who is in hiding from the United States authorities, is reported to be lying at the point of death in his hiding place in Salt Lake City Anxiety and constant fear of arrest, with the confinement in his hiding place, the saints say, are wearing the old man out, and he cannot last much longer.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 25.--This morning the funeral of Mrs. J. Witherspoon Smith took place from her late residence on Thalia-street in this city. Mrs. Smith was 100 years 8 months and 20 days old, having been born in New-York City Nov. 4, 1786.

The Right Rev. Francis Silas Chatard, Catholic Bishop of Vincennes, Ind., arrived early yesterday morning on the Cunarder Aurania. This prelate is understood to have fought strongly at Rome for Archbishop Corrigan in the McGlynn case, and to him is attributed the remark that if Dr. McGlynn came out victorious there would be an end of ecclesiastical authority in this country. Bishop Chatard is stopping at the St. James Hotel.

There were great doings at Corona, Long Island, last night. A majority of the citizens were celebrating the termination of a longwinded school fight by firing of cannons and setting off of fireworks, besides the other methods of rejoicing usually adopted by rural communities on great occasions.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 25.--George Currie, of Beaver Harbor, East Halifax, on Saturday went to the house of his uncle, Henry Hawbolt, to pick a quarrel with him. Finding the door locked Currie smashed it in, whereupon he was shot dead by Hawbolt.

John C. Baptiste, the well known Chinese interpreter, went to Police Headquarters yesterday and reported that Cong Seng, a demented Chinaman, was missing, and asked the aid of the police in looking for him.
PANAMA, July 17.--A decree has been issued which suppresses the Colombian Legations in France and German, and the consulates at London, Brussels, and San Francisco.

CHICAGO, July 25.--Jameson, the steeplechase rider, who was thought to have been only slightly injured when he was thrown from the Canadian horse Willie W. on Saturday at the West Side track, is in a dying condition. It was discovered to-day that his skull was fractured, and this afternoon a surgical operation was performed, but he did not regain consciousness.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--A pretty lighthaired girl sat in a pitch-dark cell of the Twentysecond District Station House to-night and tried to keep cool by fanning her face with a towel. She was 16-yearold Lydia Davis, a giddy girl from Wilmington. She had run away from her home with an Italian laborer. The pair left Wilmington on Saturday and ...

NEWPORT, R. I., July 25.--Sunshine and shadows prevail, and while the festive dance at the Casino was in progress to-night many who were present discussed the sad fate which had befallen Miss "Becky" Hunter, who a few hours before had deliberately committed suicide by jumping into the ocean at the foot of the 40 steps on the cliffs.

UTICA, N.Y., July 25.--Frederick R. Johnson, a young married man, of the firm of Johnson Morse, roof painters, was found dead in his night clothes on his cellar door in this city this morning. He was hopelessly afflicted with Bright's disease, and it is believed he committed suicide by poisoning.

The racing at Brighton Beach yesterday produced close finishes in nearly every race. The mile handicap resulted in a dead heat between James A. II. and Waukesha. The race was not run off. The races were run with the following results:

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 25.--Gen. Phil Sheridan is visiting the various Vineyard harbors on the yacht Day Dream as the guest of the owner, Dr. Rickettson, of New-Bedford. He spent several hours at Oak Bluffs.

CHICAGO, July 25.--The escape of McGarigle gave fresh zest to the trial of the boodle Commissioners to-day, and the spectators were afforded the spectacle of two prominent contractors, moved by a hope of immunity, testifying in detail how they and the 12 defendants had, month after month, robbed the county of thousands of dollars.

Mary Oberle, the woman who kept a baby farm in the rear of 521 East Fifth-street, where an agent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children sound two 7-week-old babies, one dead and the other dying, side by side in a rocking chair, was arraigned in the Essex Market Court yesterday. She was charged with keeping a baby farm in violation of the Penal Code, which says:

The Metropolitans won a well played game from the Louisvilles at Staten Island yesterday. They batted Ramsey, who was supported in fine style, in a lively manner. Cushman, for the Mets, pitched well, but the field work of his companions was below the mark.

GRANVILLE, S.C., July 25.--Virginia Hudson, aged 7 years, a negro child, was locked up here today for murder. She killed a child 1 year old in Butler Township on Saturday and threw the body in a well. She struck her victim on the head with a board until it was dead. This is the youngest murderess ever known in this section.

The steward of stateroom 70, Cunard steamship Aurania, starboard side, had almost made up his mind to get some one to write his resignation, when the vessel reached her deck yesterday morning. He had cared during the passage over for two as queer passengers as he had ever encountered in all his long years of caring for people with tempers temporarily soured by the rough play of the Atlantic.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--There was an exciting swimming match at Gloucester this afternoon between Dennis F. Butler, of this city, and Thomas J. Riley, of Boston. The match was for a purse of $300, the terms of the races being that the men should swim three heats, one each on Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday, ...

ST. LOUIS, July 25.--John N. Simpson, the cattle king of the Southwest, was in the city to-day and very angry over the free and easy way in which the Associated Press manipulated his name last week.

Gov. John B. Gordon would make a good Vice-President, and it is proper for his friends to say so; but it must be some other time. This time the office will come West to find the man.

A German laborer named Meyer, who was one of a gang of men employed in pulling down the old wooden buildings 207 to 213 Thompsonstreet, discovered Tuesday last under one of the floors of 207 a paper parcel, which was found to contain 19 fifty-dollar bills of the issue of Nov. 10, 1863. GLASGOW, July 25.--The yacht Thistle sailed for New-York to-day. A gale was blowing when she took her departure and she proceeded under storm sails. Her crew numbers 21 men. Her owner and her designer will sail from Liverpool to New-York on the steamer City of Rome during the latter part of August.

SARATOGA, July 25.--There are 53 young ladies unmarried and more or less fair to look upon now in this village, whose marriage settlement in each case will be not leas than $1,000,000. The season is backward and the town is not half full. In two or three weeks there will ...
WIND GAP, Penn., July 25.--Mrs. William Houser, who lives at the foot of the Blue Mountain, near the Monroe County line, started to go down her collar steps a day or two ago.

BOSTON, Mass., July 25.--Reports from the towns of Berkshire County indicate the heaviest freshet since the Mill River disaster of 1869. All the rivers in that section of the State are higher than ever before known in Summer. Almost incalculable loss has resulted to property.

After a fine game the Brooklyn boys won from the St. Louis champions at Washington Park yesterday. The visitors took the lead in the eighth inning, but in the ninth the Brooklynites went to the front, and by a fine streak of batting won the game.

The scene of the wash-outs along the Harlem Railroad, between Hillsdale and Martindale, was a desolate-looking stretch of country yesterday. For nearly six miles the ground was broken up into gulches and gullies filled with troubled waters, and great pools and brawling streams of muddy water were everywhere. In six different places between the two towns. . .

The union longshoremen, who last week published a notice to steamship companies, shipowners, Captains, and stevedores that they would require 60 cents an hour for night work, have ordered no formal strikes on the docks where the advance is refused.

The bakery and stables of Louis Fleischmann, at 43 and 45 West Thirteenth-street, were burned early yesterday morning, and 43 horses were suffocated in their stalls. The building was an old three-story brick structure, owned by L. Toplitz. The baking was done in the base

WASHINGTON, July 25.--The White House presented an animated scene this afternoon on the occasion of the reception of the delegation, from Missouri to invite the President to visit St. Louis during the State Fair in October next. The delegation numbered nearly 100 persons, representing all the interests of the city of St. Louis, ...
SAN FRANCISCO, July 25.--The Pacific Mail steamer City of Rio de Janerio arrived last night, bringing Hong-Kong advices to July 1, and Yokohama news to July 9.

KEYPORT, N.J., July 25.--William G. Fairchild was arrested this evening on a charge preferred by his wife's father of deserting her the day after their marriage. When arrested Fairchild was with a young woman supposed to be his wife.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 25.--The Hon. E. E. Foster, Minister of Marine and Fisherids, has returned from the maritime provinces after spending one month on board the cruiser Acadia, in order to become thoroughly acquainted with the fisheries protection service.

J.G.K. Lawrence, the Secretary of the Coney Island Jockey Club, announces the estimated value of the great Futurity Stakes to be run at the Autumn meeting of 1888, and which closed with 752 entries, as $50,375.

PANAMA, July 17.--The boundary question between Costa Rica and Colombia is in a fair way of settlement to the satisfaction of both parties to the dispute. The Government of Spain has promised to act as arbitrator in the question.

CHICAGO, July 25.--There was published here yesterday a dispatch from New-York to the effect that there was a scheme on foot among the leading telegraphers of the country to purchase the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph line, the amount to be paid therefor being fixed at $3,000,000.
Less than one week ago the American Party was started in Denver, and there are now over 500 signers to the rolls.

WAASHINGTON, July 25.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission delivered its opinion this afternoon in four of the cases recently brought before it. The cases entitled Louis Larrison against the Grand Trunk Railroad Company and the Michigan Central Railroad Company against the Grand Trunk Railroad Company were by consent of the parties heard together. The charge is unjust discrimination.

DUBLIN, July 25.--A Nationalist convention was held at Newry to-day, attended by 60 delegates, including many priests.
The southern-bound mail train on the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad came near killing a young lady on Friday. Just beyond Margettsville ...

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 25.--Yesterday morning about 3 o'clock fire was discovered in a gambling den in Chinatown.

LONDON, July 25.--The Marquis of Salisbury in the House of Lords this evening announced the settlement of the frontier dispute between Russia and Afghanistan. The Ameer, Lord Salisbury said, retained the district of Khamiab.
Joseph A. Leggatt, a lawyer, of the firm of Leggatt Gallagher, was taken to the West Thirtieth-street police station early Sunday evening on a charge of drunkenness.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 25.--James Quackenboss started from this city to-day with his family to drive to South Amboy, where they proposed staying for two weeks. When near South River the carriage overturned in a rut made by the recent rains, and all the party were thrown out. Mrs. Quacker boss received serious injuries and her infant child was killed instantly.
Fire broke out last evening on a canalboat partially loaded with naphtha oil which was lying at Shooters Island, on Staten Island Sound, between Elizabethport and Erastina.

LONDON, July 25.--The Duchess of Edinburgh to-day launched a lifeboat at Bembridge, Isle of Wight. The temporary staging on which the Duchess and the members of her party stood collapsed during the ceremony of launching. The Princess Beatrice, wife of Prince Henry of Battenberg, was precipitated toward the sea and barely escaped being thrown into the water.

LONDON, July 25.--In the House of Commons this evening Mr. Morley asked what had happened to explain the proclamation of the whole of Ireland since the Government had assured the House that the law was as well obeyed in some parts of Ireland as in any part of Great Britain.

The new Shell Fish Commissioner, A. Sylvester Joline, for the first time yesterday joined in with the Commissioners of Fisheries at their meeting in R. B. Roosevelt's office, in the Equitable-Building. The other Commissioners met in the morning and received a communication from the Attorney-General that ...

Filemon Zalewski, the Vienna, Post Office clerk who is charged with having fled with 151,725 gulden and was caught by United States Deputy Marshal Bernhardt on the steamer La Champagne Saturday, was taken before United States Commissioner Lyman for examination yesterday, preparatory to being sent back to Austria. He had no counsel. Ex-Sen

MALDEN, Mass., July 25.--Oscar D. Brett, a builder and contractor, left this city suddenly a week ago, and it is alleged by those doing business with him that he took $3,100 in cash and left numerous creditors here and bills amounting to $10,000. It is reported that he owes one lumber firm $5,000, besides having a number of other creditors.

NYACK, N.Y., July 25.--John De Baun, one of Nyack's most respected citizens and a brave soldier in the war of the rebellion, was buried to-day with all the honors of the Grand Army of the Republic, and the burial service was pronounced the most impressive ever held in this region.

The police have been searching several weeks for Everlin Oelrichs, a young Englishman who came to New-York early in the Spring from London, where it is said he has wealthy relatives well known in business circles.
In inquest was held by Coroner Levy yesterday in the case of Christina Krieg, who was found dead from a pistol shot wound at her home, 109 Greenwich-street, on July 5.

John Hane, of Wakefield, Westchester County, who had property worth $50,000 there and as much more in Harlem, died on April 13.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 25.--Eugene, the 12year-old son of W.S. Decker, of Brooklyn, was drowned in Clove Creek, Deckertown, N.J., on Sunday afternoon. He and a cousin whom he was visiting went bathing. The current was strong and he was carried over the dam. His body has not yet been recovered.

HARRISBURG, Ill., July 25.--The latest feature of the Hardin County vendetta is an anonymous communication in writing to County Judge Jacob Hess to leave that county. Similar notices were served upon Logan Belt and James D. Belt before they were assassinated.
LONDON, July 25.--The steamship Colina, (Br.,) Capt. Bell, from New-York July 9, arr. at Plymouth yesterday.
PARIS, July 25.--M. Ferry, speaking at a tirailleur banquet at Epinal to-day, dilated upon the uses of rifle societies.
OIL CITY, Penn., July 25.--The crude petroleum market opened weak this morning at 57 . The slump of Saturday had made the trade nervous. The next sale was at 57, and ...

INDIANAPOLIS, July 25.--The evidence in the tally sheet forgery case will probably all be in by to-morrow evening. The bulk of the testimony to-day was with reference to the character of the accused parties. A score or more of prominent citizens testified that they had all always borne the best of reputations for honesty in the city.

CHICAGO, July 25.--Judge Blodgett decided this morning the seizure case against an alleged painting by Raphael called "The Virgin of the Book," but dodged the question as to whether the painting was genuine or not.

PATERSON, N.J., July 25.--James Hendricks George Garside, Charles Dolan, and Michael Mendel hired a boat above the falls Sunday night and proceeded up the river on a drinking bout. They were subsequently joined by George Roberts, who refused to sing for them. A scuffle ensued in which the boat was capsized and Roberts was drowned.

TROY, N.Y., July 25.--The Troy Times publishes reports from Northern and Eastern New-York, Vermont, and Western Massachusetts of the condition of the growing and matured crops. The yield, taken as a whole, is bountiful. The drought in May gave everything a slow start, but frequent rains, alternating ...

BESSEMER, Mich., July 25.--The Colby mine safe was robbed of $4,000 on Saturday night. The burglars gained admission by the office windows. Saturday was pay day, and over $30,000 was distributed. There is no clue to the robbers.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 25.--"Expediency," not "hypocrisy," is the name the Blaine Republicans of Ohio prefer to use in describing the course which the Republican State Convention is to follow on Thursday to gratify the desire or to appease the wrath of John Sherman. "You may call it what you please," said a strong out-and-out ...

A negro lawyer, who has recently been to New-York, found great difficulty in finding a restaurant where he could get anything to eat. If the North gets much bitterer against the darky, the colored wanderer into that region will starve to death.

The body of Mary Beattie, 17 years old, of 452 Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn, and that of George Cring, 9 years, of Canarsie, who were drowned with 23 others in Jamaica Bay on July 10, when the yacht Mystery was capsized, were found yesterday afternoon. They were taken to Canarsie and Coroner Lindsay gave permits for their removal. The inquests will be resumed this evening.

The position in which Mr. JOHN SHERMAN has put the politicians of his party in his own State is embarrassing, not to say exasperating. He insists on their presenting him now, a year in advance, as a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, and if they refuse they must take the consequences.

LONDON, July 25.--The Lord Mayor this evening gave a banquet to the members of the Conference on the Law of Nations. Among the guests were Mr. Phelps, United States Minister to England; the Hon. David Dudley Field, the Hon. Simon Cameron ...

ROME, July 25.--The Moniteur publishes the text of a letter addressed by the Pope to Cardinal Rampolla on June 15, when the latter assumed the functions of Pontifical Secretary of State. In this letter the Pope explains fully the principles which he has followed in the government of the church.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day rendered its opinion in the case of the Traders and Travelers' Union against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company.
Count Montgelas, of Munich, is at the Victoria Hotel.

The brief which Assistant Corporation Counsel Thomas P. Wickes has prepared against the application of the Metropolitan Transit Company to the Supreme Court for the appointment of Commissioners to fix the sum which it shall pay to the city for its occupation of Broadway ...

Charles J. McLean. a young man who said he was a broker and lived at 132 East Tenthstreet, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday upon three charges of obtaining money on false pretenses.
CHICAGO, July 26.--All carpenters in Chicago working more than eight hours a day or for less ...

LONDON, July 26.--Lord Charles Beresford, a Junior Lord of the Admiralty, has resigned. He has been requested to withdraw his resignation. The cause was a minor breach of etiquette at Spithead during the naval review last Saturday, when a private signal made by Lord Charles from the royal yacht was converted into a public signal.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 26.--The cottage of William B. Smith was entered by burglars last night and jewelry, , worth $300 taken.

BALTIMORE, July 26.--The Gubernatorial bee has done so much buzzing in Democratic bonnets in Maryland that half a dozen candidates are suing for Senator Gorman's favor tonight and the votes of the State Convention tomorrow.
CINCINNATI, July 26.--The Hamilton County delegation to the Republican State Convention, which assembles in Toledo to-morrow, contains 68 members.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 26.--The weather was very unfavorable for the Royal Canadian Yacht Club race to-day. There was just the faintest breeze in the morning, when the start was made, but by 2 o'clock it had died away to a dead calm.

Slowly but surely the New-York ball players are creeping up to the leaders in the League race and when they finished the game with Boston on the Polo Grounds yesterday Detroit led the Giants by only two victories.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 26.--The Grand Jury of the Criminal Court this afternoon returned two indictments against County Trustee Andrew J. Harris, charging him with paying drafts drawn on him by the Police and Fire Commissioners of the taxing district and diverting the funds from the purpose for which they were levied.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Mr. Hoffman, the brewer, has foreclosed a mortgage which he held on "Black Jack" Yattaw's bumboat. The officers did not find Yattaw at home. The boat was deserted save by a watchman, who informed the searchers that his chief had fled.
SING SING, N.Y., July 26.--Henry Maloney, a little boy who lived at Ardsley, near Dobbs Ferry, died this morning from injuries received in a runaway yesterday afternoon.
The National Bank of Deposit of the city of New-York was organized yesterday. The officers are: Lewis L. Ransom, President; Charles F. Sanborn, Vice-President; George H. Southard, Cashier.

KAUFMAN, Texas, July 26.--A mob of men took Crawford Benson, a negro boy 18 years old, from the county jail at 11 o'clock last night and hanged him, afterward riddling the body with bullets. The boy had committed an assault on a 9-year-old girl.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Ex-Senator Joseph E. McDonald, of Indiana, was in the city yesterday and was seen by a reporter. He said: "I am out of politics now and am only a private in the ranks. This is an off-year in politics in our State.

As a marine pageant the jubilee review of Saturday was an undoubted success, fine weather, a calm sea, a vast array of war vessels and yachts, and a very distinguished body of dignitaries and spectators uniting to produce a striking and enjoyable occasion.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 26, via Galveston. --A renewal of the heavy rains which the sewers were unable to take care of causes apprehension for the safety of the city in case Lake Tezcoco should overflow the low lying country between it and the city.

SARATOGA, July 26.--Whisper it low by the spring, and say it not loud on the veranda, but the greatness of Saratoga is gone. As a quiet Summer resort it will always be popular. As a great watering place, the fanfare of whose fashionable trumpets echoed all over the land, it is a thing of the past.
FORT WORTH, Texas, July 26.--The grandest demonstration ever witnessed in Texas is a truthful statement when applied to the anti-prohibition rally in Fort Worth today.
GENEVA, N.Y., July 26.--Bubear has written a reply to Hanlan's attack, and says Hanlan got a fair show in England, better than he deserved, until his churlish qualities cropped out.
WICHITA, Kan., July 26.--Mrs. Joseph Denitt, a wealthy lady of this city, was probably fatally stabbed about 9 o'clock last night by her stepdaughter, Mollie Denitt, of Hot Springs, Ark.

Odors arising from the 43 horses burned to death Monday morning in the stable over Fleischmann's bakery in West Thirteenth-street, interfered seriously with business yesterday in the dry goods and other stores in Sixthavenue and Fourteenth-street.

There was a private meeting of the American Association held in the office of W.W. Watrous, 140 Pearl-street, yesterday. Those present were Christ Von Der Ahe, of St. Louis; Zachary Phelps, of Louisville; Walter Watrous, of the Metropolitans, and F. E. Robinson, of Cleveland.
To many people Jacob Sharp represents a nightmare. Days may come and go,but the day that promises to find Sharp at Sing Sing seems to be as far off as it appeared to be weeks ago.
Frederick Viewig, proprietor of the Eden Musee, was arraigned in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday on a charge of keeping his place open on Sundays.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 26.--A schedule of liabilities and assets of the Hurlburt Paper Company, of South Lee, was filed in the Probate Court late this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, July 26.--Mr. Samuel N. Brooks, of Hyde, England, father of Hugh Maxwell Brooks, alias Walter H. Lenox Maxwell, the famous chloroformer of C. Arthur Preller, will arrive here to-morrow to make a last effort to save his son from the gallows.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 26.--The steamer Martha's Vineyard of this port, stopped at Falmouth Heights on her trip from Cottage City late this afternoon to take a party of 400 excursionists which went there from this city this morning.
Mrs. Emma Chipman, a neat-looking woman of 40 years, brought suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, for the annulment of her marriage to George Chipman, on the ground of illegality.
The demand of the union longshoremen for 60 cents an hour for night work has not been seriously considered by any of the steamship companies.

EASTON, Penn., July 26.--The attention of court to-day was entirely consumed by proceedings in the Van Heyst-Van Doren suit. The room was filled when Mrs. Van Heyst entered, escorted by Jules Van Doren, who led the little girl, Ailsa, by the hand.

The season of 1887-8 at the Metropolitan Opera House promises to be one of the most interesting of the series which has given that building a prominent place among the musical temples of the world. The director, Edmund C. Stanton, recently returned from Europe, where he visited the principal musical ...
HARTFORD, Conn., July 26.--Bank Commissioner Henry R. Wooster, who was appointed by Gov. Lounsbury in February for the term of four years from July 1, 1887, has resigned.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 26.--A mass meeting of citizens of Laurens County yesterday adopted resolutions expressing dissatisfaction with the action of the jury last week in acquitting John D. Sheahan of the murder of R. L. Bishop on July 4, and pledging themselves individually and collectively to maintain and vindicate the law of the State in the future.

PANAMA,July 26, via Galveston.--The Colombian Government has granted to the Central and South American Telegraph Company authority to establish and operate a telegraph line across the Isthmus of Panama, and to extend its cables from Colon along the Atlantic Coast of South America.

PITTSBURG, July 26.--The coke operators are demoralized. They held a meeting to-day, and as a result will shut down several of their works; not on account of any trouble with the workmen, but simply because the production of coke is in excess of the shipping facilities.
A rich Tennessee man got into financial trouble a few days ago, and yesterday, finding it impossible to carry his load of stocks any longer, he threw overboard a big part of his burden.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 26.--All the French waiters employed at the Hotel Elberon and the connecting cottages struck yesterday for higher wages just at the luncheon hour.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--The disturbed position of affairs in Samoa is seriously menacing American interests in that island. Under ordinary circumstances an extensive commerce is maintained between San Francisco and Apia.

Ever since the courts decided that hotel keepers could serve liquor to their guests on Sunday. the Excise Commissioners have been pestered with applications from liquor dealers to have their licenses changed to hotel licenses, they claiming that they served meals, had two beds, and kept a register.
LONDON,July 26.--In the first inning of the cricket match yesterday between the Durham team and the Canadians, the score of the latter was 134 for seven wickets, not 174 as reported yesterday.
The Meadow Club's lawn tennis tournament began at Southampton, Long Island,yesterday, with a large attendance.
The Commissioners of Emigration held a special meeting yesterday, and Commissioner Stephenson, who lets nothing stand between him and duty, was nearly exhausted when it was finished.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 26.--The Big Boston, a large six-story brick building, caught fire at 10 o'clock tonight. All the engines in the city were called out.
The committee of Henry George's party who are looking after the fifth inspector of election in each Assembly district, created by the law of June 1, went before the Police Commissioners yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 26.--Trouble has sprung up between the Sheriff of Providence County and the Supreme Court of the State of Rhode Island, and public interest is aroused as to which will get the better of the struggle which is impending.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 26.--The pool of carbon manufacturing companies of the United States, organized under the name of the United Carbon Companies, is broken, and its affairs were put into ...
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 26.--Owing to the rain the races which were to have been run today were postponed until to-morrow. The entries stand as already announced.
BOSTON, July 26.--Malden people are excited over a story emanating from the Jacksonville (Fla.) News-Herald of recent date.
Helena Brunold has rosy cheeks, 19 years, and a disposition to flirt, which made life miserable for George Kornick, her, until lately, accepted lover.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 26.--At 3:30 o'clock this morning Dr. E.D. Standiford died at his residence, 1,022 Fourth-avenue, in his fifty-sixth year. The immediate cause of death was an apopleptic fit, due, however, to the chronic internal troubles from which he had been a sufferer.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 26.--The Republican to-morrow will publish the results of a careful survey of the crop prospects in Western New-England as gathered by its correspondents.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Gen. C.S. Bentley, general manager of the international military encampment to be held here in October, took it upon himself the other day to announce that no colored troops would be admitted to the encampment.
The newsboys boycotted the Evening Sun yesterday because the publishers wanted to make there pay 60 instead of 50 cents a hundred for the paper.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 26.--John Taylor, President of the Mormon Church, died at 8 o'clock last night, aged 78 years 8 months and 25 days.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--The funeral of the late Gen. William McKee Dunn took place at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon from the New-York-Avenue Presbyterian Church, of which the deceased had been an officer and for many years an honored member.

The members, friends, and families of the Workingmen's Club, which is connected with the Church of the Holy Communion, enjoyed an excursion to Idlewild Grove yesterday. There were about 1,200 in all, and they were taken to the grove on the barge Charles Spear.

The election in Kentucky for State officers and for members of the Legislature which will choose a United States Senator is to be held on Monday, Aug. 1.

Collector Magone yesterday received a letter from Mr. Maynard, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, informing him that New-York is about to be honored by the presence of another royal personage. His name, as it is put in the English tongue, is: Kron Luang Devawongse Varoprakan.
Coroner Hopson yesterday held an inquest in Paterson, N.J., in the case of Enima Johnson, who was found dead in a disorderly house there on Monday morning.
LONDON, July 27.--The Porte has issued an irade dismissing the reserves.
The Board of Health at its meeting yesterday heard a report from the Summer corps of physicians who visit tenement houses in the hot weather.
The Jersey City Board of Finance and Taxation fixed the appropriations to be available by the several city departments during the fiscal year beginning Dec. 1 yesterday morning.

Michael J. Martin, one of the Executors of the will of James Harper, yesterday filed a bill in the New-Jersey Court of Chancery, asking that Cornelius S. See be removed from office as Trustee of Harper's estate, and that he be compelled to account for all moneys and property received by him since the filing of his last account.

ROME, July 27.--It transpires that the conclave of 12 American Bishops asked by the Vatican for a decision as to the advisability of the Roman. Catholic Church interfering with the Knights of Labor, voted 10 to 2 against intervention.

LIMA, July 27, via Galveston.--The public are much interested in the successful issue of the contract with the committee of Peruvian bondholders, on which great hopes of the future prosperity of Peru are based. The Executive will submit the contract for approval to Congress, which meets tomorrow.

The Board of Electrical Control held a meeting yesterday. It was held in the office of the Mayor, and before it had got well under way that sturdy official had stirred up an amount of yonthful anger which was pleasant to contemplate.

President Cleveland's private stable establishment consists of five horses, three being mates of the Hambletonian stock and purchased in New-York; one buggy horse, and one horse used for farm work at Oak View.

The North American Review for August is an unusually good number. Of late the North American has hardly kept abreast of its best traditions; some of the recent numbers have rather shown a backward tendency; but in the present issue much is atoned for.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27.--Word has reached here from Carbon that a wedding among Austrian miners on Monday night was enlivened by a dance and drunken carousing, culminating in a general row.

The work of removing the carcasses of the horses who met death in the fire which destroyed the Vienna Bakery stables, is West Thirteenthstreet, was continued yesterday with great vigor. During the day what looked like 22 charred horses were taken out of the ruins and carted away to the offal dock.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27.--The Northwestern Miller says: "The mills did not reach the market for them last week, yet the record is very creditable, the daily product exceeding 23,000 barrels.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, Long Island, July 27.--The Fisheries Commissioners met at the hatchery here yesterday afternoon.

Mrs. Amelia Dornhim, a little old German woman, acoomplished at fine needlework, was found dead in her rooms on the second floor of 123 East One Hundred and Tenth-street yesterday afternoon, by a neighbor.
CONCORD, N.H., July 27.--The railroad fight in New-Hampshire has attained gigantic proportions and totally absorbs the attention of the Legislature and, for that matter, of the entire State.

CHICAGO, July 27.--Only petty jobs of the boodle gang were exposed in the trial of the County Commissioners to-day. This class of evidence was apparently inexhaustible, and emphasized well the extent to which the thievery was carried.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., July 27.--Considerable excitement was occasioned this morning, when the Citizens' Savings Bank closed its doors.
The toilet worn by Mme. Emma Nevada at the reception given by the American Minister and Mrs. Phelps on the Fourth of July was noted as being one of the prettiest of the occasion.
Gramercy Lodge, No. 309, A.O.U.W., betook itself yesterday to Schuetzen Park, Union Hill, N.J., and held its second annual midsummer festival by daylight, twilight, and electric light.
The Grand Duke Theatre, a noted place in the days when the Five Points was the wickedest place on earth and Baxter-street had a national, not to say world-wide, reputation, is no more.

PHILADFLLPHIA, July 27.--Joseph Deacon, aged 11 years, who lives with his widowed mother at 226 South Second-street, attempted to commit suicide late this afternoon by jumping into the Delaware River from Haggerty's Landing, at Gloucester.
HAVANA, July 27.--Advices from Jamaica of the 10th inst. state that vessels arriving at the island from Cuban ports are quarantined for 14 days.

A peculiar mishap occurred to Mrs. Wood, a resident of Hamilton, the other night. She yawned so extensively that her jaw was dislocated, and her mouth remained open in spite of all efforts to return the jaw to its natural position. Finally she went to Dr. Stark, and, with his assistance, succeeded in getting her mouth shut.

FAYETTE, Mo., July 27.--William J. Baskett, one of the best known and wealthiest farmers of Howard County, residing near Estelle Station, died this morning from wounds received from a vicious bull on Friday. While driving up his cows Friday evening Mr. Baskett was attacked by a Shorthorn bull in his pasture, and was knocked from his horse and gored by the animal.

One hundred and thirty-seven Italians, employed by the Montclair Water Company in digging wells and laying water pipes in that town, struck on Tuesday.

KEYPORT, N.J., July 27.--Albert M. Knapp and Miss Illie Clail, both in their teens, of this place, were secretly married at the Baptist parsonage by the Rev. Jesse Stiles.
In truth special trains are handicapped by pronounced disadvantages, and many officers have come to regard them in the nature of necessary evils, and to be avoided when possible.
Two Italian laborers, employed on the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, were struck and killed last night by the express from the West reaching this city at 10 o'clock.

The striking shirtmakers held another meeting yesterday and denied the report spread by the firm that they were going back to work. Only two of their number had weakened, and had resumed work at the reduced rates.

Pat Hutchins, who has been a guard at the convict camp for some time, threw up his position yesterday. He is brim full of talk about the cruel treatment of the convicts. He is at his home near the Augusta factory. He said to his friends yesterday that he could not stand the camp any longer, and consequently threw up his job.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--General Secretary Litchman yesterday characterized the story to the effect that there was a gigantic wirepulling scheme in the interest of the administration and General Master Workman Powderly as pure sensational rot.

CINCINNATI, July 27.--H.B. Moorehead, of H.B. Moorehead Co., brokers, returning from New-York to-day, stated that he had been authorized by Ives, Stayner Co. to announce that the $10,000,000 of the preferred stock of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad recently authorized will not be issued.
A case which involved a young bartender and a stout, comely German lassie of 17 had a quick ending at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.
BOSTON, July 27.--John Boyle O'Reilly has just received from the Pilot's special correspondent at Rome the following cablegram:

There was something almost like oldfashioned life on the Stock Exchange yesterday. For the first time in a long while the transactions rose above 350,000 shares of stock. And the advantages that the bears gained on Tuesday were pressed rapidly and with lots of effect. Prices sagged all day and along the whole list.
Gustav Amberg, manager of the Thalia Theatre, sailed for Europe yesterday in the steamer Germanic.

There was an unexpected change in the cast at Wallack's Theatre last evening. Miss Marion Manola, to whom is assigned the soprano role of Laura in "The Beggar Student," was taken sick in the afternoon, and at a late hour informed Col. McCauil that it would be utterly impossible for her to appear last evening.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27.--Bellevne-avenue was thronged with fashionable equipages this afternoon, and among those who were out for a drive were Gov. Green and wife, of NewJersey, who are the guests of Prof. Charles W. Shieldes, of Princeton, N.J.
OCEAN GROVE, July 27.--The anniversary of the National Temperance Society commenced this morning and will continue five days.

SARATOGA, July 27.--The prettiest things at watering places are usually the conundrums. A watering place conundrum consists of two young people, feminine in gender, unusually attractive in face and elegantly modest in apparel. They are conundrums because they come without a chaperone and do not appear to know anybody.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--Washington added another to its list of tragedies this afternoon, when Henry Burgess, a colored barber, shot and instantly killed James H. Burnett, also a negro barber.

ST. LOUIS, July 27.--Five years ago Lizzie Birks, an orphan, 14 years old, secured employment in the large printing establishment of Woodward Tiernan as a press feeder.
Ike Vincent, the ex-Treasurer of the State, now occupies a spacious room on the second floor of the county jail immediately over Jailor Herbert's office.

BOSTON, July 27.--Thomas Harris and his 12year-old daughter, of Randolph, Mass., while crossing the railway track in a buggy this morning were struck by a train. Both were thrown over a wall into a field and so badly injured that they are not expected to survive. The buggy was demolished and the horse killed.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 27.--The Educational Committee of the House and Senate, in joint session last evening, reported in favor of the Glenn bill, which makes it a penalty for any teacher to teach a white child in a colored school or a colored child in a white school.

CHICAGO, July 27.--A thief kept his agreement to-day and his victim kept his word, whereby $5,000 changed hands and a quantity of stolen property was restored to its rightful owner. Who the thief was is not known, but the robbed man was Mr. Moses Bensinger, of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company.

LONDON, July 28.--On the resumption of debate on the Land bill in the House of Commons this evening Mr. Smith, the Government leader, appealed to the House to expedite the passage of the bill, which, he said, would prevent harsh evictions.

BOSTON, July 28.--The Volunteer was pulled out of the water late this afternoon at Lockwood's East Boston Dock, and gangs of men went to work polishing her bottom, an operation that was closely watched by several hundred persons.

The topic of conversation in Newark police circles is the rumor that Chief Tuite has decided to resign. The Chief admitted that there was some foundation for the rumor. He says the Police Commissioners annoy him by continually finding fault and holding him responsible for the shortcomings of the department. The Police Commissioners express surprise at the proposed action of Chief Tuite.

Edward O'Hara, a boy of 13, who lives at 337 Centre-street, East New-York, owned a billy goat. He sold the goat and purchased a lame horse from a neighbor. His father went with him Monday to get the money refunded, but the man refused. On the way back the boy slipped away and has not since been seen. The police are looking for him.
DETROIT, July 28.--Pitcher Gruber, recently of Hartford, was put in the box for Detroit to-day, and pitched a good game, but his support at times was poor.

The funeral of Mary A. and Katie Kearney, who were drowned in Distillery Lake, near Spring Valley, Wednesday afternoon, will take place from St. Peter's Church, Barclay-street, at 10 o'clock this morning.
Charles Reilly, the Commissioner of Jurors, has sent to Mayor Hewitt his first quarterly report under the amendments to the jury law made this year. The report is for the quarter ending March 1.

BOSTON, July 28.--The Republicans of Massachusetts put on their armor for the Fall campaign to-day, when the State Central Committee held its first meeting and selected a presiding officer and Committee on Resolutions for the State Convention.

READING, Penn., July 28.--The 8 o'clock A.M. express train for Philadelphia on the Pennsylvania Schuylkill Valley Railroad this morning, going at a speed of a mile a minute, when crossing the public road at Ridgewood, four miles below this city, struck a spring wagon with five occupants, killing four of them outright and seriously wounding the fifth.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 28.--George Stevens, a young man residing at North Buffalo, was shot through the heart and instantly killed last night ...

Taken all in all, yesterday was not such a very bad day, as Summer days go. The temperature increased slightly, but the humidity decreased in proportion and there was a noticeable freshness in the breeze that swept up the avenues from the Bay.
GREENVILLE, S.C., July 28.--The monument erected at Fort Madison in honor of Col. Ben Cleveland, was unveiled to-day.

A little while ago Fannie L.D. Smith, the wife of Henry M. Smith, rejoiced in the ownership of a certificate of 50 shares of New-York Central and Hudson River stock, worth, at yesterday's quotations, $5,400.
CHICAGO, JulY 28.--The Appellate Court rendered an important decision in one phase of the Wilbur F. Storey litigation yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 28.--There are signs of serious trouble ahead for the roads running north west from this city.

ST. LOUIS, July 28.--Samuel N. Brooks, the Hyde, England, schoolmaster, visited his condemned son in the city jail this morning.

The Municipal Civil Service Supervisory Board yesterday handed to Mayor Hewitt a report as to the standing of the 10 Police Captains who went through the civil service mill to test their capacity for promotion to the two vacant Inspectorships.
A meeting of the East Side Improvement Association of Harlem was held last evening at the office of J.P. E.J. Murray, 2,030 Thirdavenue.
According to her invariable custom, the earth will, on the 10th, plunge headlong into the August meteor-zone.
Leslie C. Cushman, a letter carrier employed at the Jersey City Post Office, is accused of attempting to steal a registered letter.

CHICAGO, July 28.--Nellie Maltby, an office girl in the employ of the late Dr. Ward Cadey Dunn, committed suicide yesterday morning at 300 Marshfield-avenue.

The United Labor Party of the Seventh Assembly District had no Socialists to fight at their meeting to elect delegates to the Syracuse Convention, which was held at Fifteenth-street and Sixthavenue last evening.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 28.--Col. John B. Castleman and Adjt. Roger Williams returned to-day from Morehead, where they had been sent by Gov. Knott to inquire into the propriety of sending troops there to attend the sessions of the Circuit Court, which is set to convene there next Monday. Troops have been asked for by Judge ...
PARIS, July 28.--The Courier du Soir reports that Gen. Boulanger has requested official permission to challenge M. Ferry to fight a duel on account of the ex-Premier's recent speech at Epinal.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 28.--For six or seven months numerous complaints have gone to Postmaster Shelley, of Kansas City, of the loss of letters containing money and postal notes, and for a long time special officers have been working on the case.

CHICAGO, July 28.--T.J. Potter, VicePresident and General Manager of the Union Pacific Railway Company, was in the city today to purchase equipment to replace that worn out on the company's old lines, as well as for the lines now in course of construction.
George Speineck found the dead body of a man, about 25 years old, floating in Newark Bay, near the West Meadows, yesterday morning. He towed the body to the Thirtieth-street ...

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 28.--Over 800 tired soles, foreign to this placid locality, were within the limits of Tarrytown to-night, the toes pointed to the stars, while their owners slept such a sleep as they have not enjoyed since razors became a necessity instead of a luxury to them.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 28.--D.D. Bell, an 8year-old colored boy, confesses to having set fire to a number of buildings recently burned in this city. He says he knows he cannot be punished for it by law on account of his age, and plays the incendiary for his own amusement. He is in custody, and the authorities, being afraid to turn him loose, are puzzled to know what to do with him.
The boys in the Hudson County Almshouse are causing considerable trouble to Warden Coughlin by their insubordination.

Secretary WHITNEY'S appointment of a board of naval officers to report upon the condition of the Atlanta will no doubt result in throwing all needed light upon the causes of the failure of the new cruiser's battery during the late brief trial in Gardiner's Bay.
WASHINGTON, July 28.--The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, Col. Switzler, has issued a quarterly report which contains, among other interesting matter, tables in regard to sugar and molasses, ...
BOSTON, July 28.--E.H. Lewis, formerly of Malden, and of the firm of Lewis Brothers, shoe dealers, with branch stores in Dallas, Texas, and Jacksonville, Fla., has returned to this city.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 28.--The city is gradually filling up with Mormons from adjacent towns and outlying settlements.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 28.--Papers will be filed in the office of the Secretary of State to-morrow incorporating the Poughkeepsie, Hartford and New-England Railroad Company.

"Rabbi Hirsch" as Hirsch Harris, an old resident of Brooklyn, has been known for many years, died on Wednesday at his home, 252 Adams-street. According to records in possession of his son Mr. Harris was 109 years old.
At Hunter's Point yesterday a report that Otto Nunbeck, aged 9 years, of 114 East Fourth-street, is suffering from hydrophobia, was denied.

SARATOGA, July 28.--The great event of the races here to-day was the run for the Excelsior Sweepstakes, in which Dunboyne met and defeated the crack Western filly, Miss Ford, and that very good race horse. Carey.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 28.--In his lecture before the School of Pedagogy this morning Dr. E. E. White, Superintendent of Schools, Cincinnati, considered power and knowledge as ends of teaching, and dwelt on the importance of making power the chief end of education. Miss Whitmore, of Chicago, ...

LONDON, July 28.--The Rev. Joseph Parker, of the City Temple, who is about to leave for America, where he will deliver a eulogy of the late Henry Ward Beecher, made a farewell address to his congregation to-day.

The steamship companies are at last taking action on the demand of the longshoremen for 60 cents an hour for night work. The men continued to work in the daytime at the old rates, 30 cents an hour, but since Monday they have refused to work at night because the companies would not pay the advance demanded.
The Clevelands won a game from the Metropolitan Club at Staten Island yesterday. It was a close game, and the visitors won by scoring a single run in the last inning.
WATERBURY, Conn., July 28.--Leon N. Moore, late proprietor of the Spencer House, South Spencer, Mass., has been a prisoner at the station house here since Sunday.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 28.--The National Temperance camp meeting was addressed this morning by the Rev. S.V. Leech, Pastor of the Methodist church at Saratoga.

BELFAST, July 28.--A sensation was created here to-day in consequence of the publication in several newspapers of reports that the Hon. Patrick A. Collins, of Boston, Mass., and his entire party had been arrested by the Government on their arrival from Glasgow.
Thomas Warren, of Newtown, Long Island, has begun suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, against the Queens County Board of Supervisors to recover for the county sums aggregating nearly $500,000,...
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28.--The weather was much cooler to-day. Mrs. H.L. Cole and Mrs. Hoffman, of NewYork, are visiting Mrs. J.W. Ellis.
DUBLIN, July 23.--The strikers at the Limerick docks, attended by a mob numbering thousands, hooted and stoned the imported Waterford laborers while the latter were unloading a vessel to-day.

ST. LOUIS, July 28.--The Chief of Police received two telegrams to-day which increase the mystery in the Abbott case. On July 18 the Abbotts arrived in this city penniless and took a room on Jefferson-avenue.

LONDON, July 28.--The steamship Clintonia, (Br.,) Capt. Bulman, from New-York July 13, for Dandee, passed Dunnet Head to-day. The steamship Crystal, (Br.,) Capt. Stannard, from New-York July 13, arr. at Leith to-day.

KEYPORT, N.J., July 28.--William W. Holmes, a fisherman, of this place, while repairing his nets, near Whalo Creek, to-day found the body of a man floating in the water. He brought it ashore and telegraphed to Coroner R.T. Smith, of Red Bank. The man way about 30 years of age, 5 feet 9 inches in height, weighed 160 pounds, and wore a dark suit of clothes. The body will be buried in the Potter's Field.
The Kill von Kull regatta will be rowed tomorrow. The entries are full, and the regatta promises to be interesting and exciting.
LOWELL, Mass., July 28.--Katie Callahan, Della Welch. Mattie Keating, Maggie Toomey, and Lucy Callahan went bathing this afternoon in the Concord River at North Bellerica.
By clever field work and good batting at opportune moments the Cincinnati men won a game from the Brooklyns yesterday.
BALTIMORE, July 28.--On Saturday last a man entered the office of Col. R. Snowden Andrews, on South-street, and offered to sell cigars.
NARRAGANSETT PIER, July 28.--An important suit was decided in the Supreme Court, in Providence County, to-day which involves a money value to the amount of $250,000.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 28.--For two weeks deck hands on river craft say they have seen a huge white shark in the waters of the Hudson between Haverstraw and Catskill.

Those who enjoy the contemplative pipe and those who find life's comfort by nibbling at plug cake made of tobacco and molasses will lay in a good stock of those commodities early if they are wise. Small acreage and drought have caused an advance in price, which began last month. May is the planting time.

Judge Potter looked decidedly relieved when Mr. Bourke Cockran had finished his address in the arguments on the Sharp stay of proceedings at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. When Mr. Cockran finally sat down and wiped the apparent humidity from his face and glanced uncomfortably at his still more humid linen coat, Mr. Nicoll mildly asked the Judge if he could give any intimation of the time when the decision would be granted.

Mrs. Margaret Woeshoff, who, it is claimed, has swindled the German Government by drawing a pension as the widow of a non-commissioned officer who died in 1882, was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday. She came to this country and married again in 1884. The prisoner, who was locked up pending examination, claims that she applied only for the money due her up to the time of her second marriage, none of which she has received.

CHICAGO, July 28.--Robert Hill, of the wholesale dry goods house of Storm Hill, testified to-day in the boodle trial in order to obtain trade from the county he had to present Wardens Varnell, McGarigle, and Frey with about $1,800 worth of merchandise yearly for their personal use.

It is announced that EDWARD HANLAN has decided to accept JOHN TEEMER'S challenge to row a race for the championship upon condition that the Toronto Bay course shall be chosen. Professional rowing appears to have fallen to the lowest depths of jobbery.

LONDON, July 28.--The Queen has refused to accept the resignation of Lord Charles Beresford as a Junior Lord of the Admiralty.
BERTRAM, Texas, July 28.--Three persons were killed by lightning here last evening. The flash came from a cloudless sky. The persons killed were G.W. Phenny, M.B. Sinclair, and Cain Sanford.
The New-Yorks will meet Detroit again to-day. Gruber, Detroit's new pitcher, was hit rather freely by the Giants yesterday.

Deputy Attorney-General Poste visited the city yesterday and served a summons and complaint upon Thomas C. Platt in an action begun by the Attorney-General to remove Mr. Platt from his position of Quarantine Commissioner.

CINCINNATI, July 28.--A cyclone and waterspout destroyed the grand stand of the Latonia race track last evening.

A case of very great importance to gas consumers was heard at the Wandsworth Police Court on Friday last, in which Mr. Walter Rye, the antiquarian solicitor, was summoned for non-payment of gas rates by the Wandsworth Gas Company. The rate claimed was 12 17s.

LINDEN, N.J., July 28.--The residents of Linden Township, which includes Linden, on the Pennsylvania Railway, and Roselle, on the NewJersey Central, have been more or less aroused over the statement that the accounts of Collector Mulford were to be examined by an expert.

When the Stock Exchange opened yesterday morning it looked very much as if the very bottom was getting ready to drop out of the market. The new grown bear claws did some lively scratching and prices fell off so easily that a repetition of Wednesday's slumps, or even worse, seemed sure.

"T.A."--Beer, 5 cents; sandwich, 5 cents. Gen. John Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, resumed duty yesterday, after a two weeks' vacation.
