The American Wall Paper Manufacturers' Association, which comprises 15 of the largest manufacturers in the country, is about eight years old. It was formed to maintain uniform prices and to keep control of the business in the hands of its 15 members.
James Rogers, the former coachman of Thomas H. Clifford, the wealthy Brooklyn glue manufacturer, whose fights with his employer ...
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., 28.--R.P. Clement, the absconding President of the Citizens' Savings Bank, organized himself into a syndicate three months ago, and began to bull Chicago wheat.
The official report on the Russian Army lately published contains the following particulars: On the 1st of January, 1886, there were 824,762 men, including 8,000 volunteers, in the active army.
A crowd of people filled the big room at 5 Duane-street, where the Public Administrator's sale was held yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--The Canal Union, which labors for improvements on the Erie Canal, held in the City Hall to-day its third annual convention, and, in a general way, outlined the views which it will submit to the two great political parties at their State conventions this Fall and to the Legislature next Winter. No demand is made for a legislative appropriation of any large sum for improvements.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 28.--It is announced by the Committee of Arrangements for the yacht race to occur here Aug. 26 that the sloops Volunteer, Mayflower, and priscilla will take part in the race; also, that the English cutters Galatea and Stranger will probably enter, and that the Thistle will also be hero. The first prize has been increased to $500.

TAMPA, Fla., July 28.--Since the establishment of the refuge camp at Egmont Key by aides of the Surgeon-General of the Marino Hospital Service, the yellow fever has broken out at that point, and three deaths hate already occurred, one of them a Chinaman. Information from Key West is to the effect that owing to the excessive heat at that point 11 new cases were developed within the last 24 hours. Two deaths occurred today.
One might think, from the opening remarks of Senator DAWES before the paper manufacturers at Saratoga, on Wednesday, that he really believed in the necessity of an adequate tariff revision.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The National Prohibition Party has issued a call for a meeting of the National Committee in Chicago on Nov. 16 for the purpose of fixing the time and place of the National Nominating Convention of 1888 and transacting such other business as pertains to the National Committee.
LONDON, July 28.--The race for the Goodwood Cup, run at the Goodwood meeting to-day, resulted in a dead heat between Savilo and St. Michael. Upas was third. The race was run off and won by Savile.

Looking as if that bane of mankind, humidity, had affected neither his linen nor his spirits, and with the air of one who had been able to keep cool, although sparkling with enthusiasm, Manager Morrissey sat at his desk in the office of the Standard Theatre last night, busy with arrangements for the coming season.
Andrew Allan, of Montreal, is at the Windsor Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28.--The Reading's proposition to the bondholders of the Pickering Valley Railroad Company is in substance as follows: Tho bonds of the first mortgage loan of the Pickering Valley Railroad Company, due 1900, to receive 40 per cent. in new 4 per cent. general mortgage bonds, series A. and 30 per cent. in third preference income mortgage bonds, series D, of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company.

The rehearsals of Imre Kiralfy's grand spectacle, "Lagardere," are proceeding daily at Niblo's and are so well advanced that Mr. Kiralfy says he could produce the piece on the 8th of August instead of the 15th, the announced opening night, if that were necessary.

A part of the railroad which LI-HUNGCHANG and the Marquis TSENG have induced the Chinese Government to build is to be constructed at once. This section will extend from Taku to Tien-Tsin, and the completed line will connect Pekin with the sea.
CHICAGO, July 28.--The Bank of Montreal got judgment by default to-day in Judge Gary's court against the Fidelity National Bank, of Cincinnati, for $200,000.
"At a casual glance these people look all alike, but watch them as they come up to the desk and see if they have not as marked individual characteristics as people who can see."
HAVANA, July 23.--Senior Ibanez a well known and wealthy planter, has been appointed Mayor of Havana.

The announcement that the Van Heyst Van Dooren case had been settled at Easton, Penn., proves to have been premature. It was not until yesterday that a conference was held which resulted satifactorily to all concerned.
LONDON, July 28.--Two pleasure yachts, both well laden with people, were capsized in a squall off Yarmouth to-day. Ten persons were drowned.
The Niantic Club, of Flushing, Long Island, held a meeting last night to consider the recent action of the Governors in suspending several members.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 28.--J.P. McGaughey, Secretary of the General Co-operative Board, Knights of Labor, and one of the best posted men on labor matters in the West, was asked to-day as to the feeling toward General Master Workman Powderly.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 28.--The Constitution, after an elaborate consolidation of the crop reports of the departments of the Southern States and its correspondents, sums up the situation as follows:
CHICAGO, July 28.--After 11 jurors had been drawn to try Alphonse Parant, the Canadian bank defaultor, he to-day concluded to return to the Dominion and there stand his trial.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 28.--Without an opposing vote, and without even the suggestion of a remonstrance, the Ohio Republican State Convention to-day presented Senator John Sherman as the choice of the Ohio Republicans for President in 1888.

St. PETERSBURG, July 28.--The Journal de St. Petersburg says the crusade of the German press against. Russian securities after the successful conversion of the land mortgage obligation, remains unexplained, the arguments of the German newspapers on the subject being ridiculous.
CHICAGO, July 28.--To-morrow is likely to see more excitement in the McGarigle case than any day since the ex-Warden slipped through Sheriff Matson's fingers.

The police of Brooklyn have been on the lookout for nearly a week for the wife of William H. Rust, an engineer living at 305 Fifty-thirdstreet. He visited Headquarters last Tuesday and told his story with tears in his eyes.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28.--Prominence is given here to certain facts in connection with the organization of the Casa Land Company at Cheyenne, Wyoming Territory, with capital stock of $25,000,000. Edward Stokes, of New-York; ...

A death is reported of a grazier named Pomarede from eating a steak taken from an ox belonging to him which had died of blood poisoning from the sting of a venomous fly. Pomarede had a grass farm at Fourque, near La Selve. He died six hours after having eaten the steak. Decomposition was so rapid that the Mayor of his commune judged well to authorize his burial within the time prescribed by law.
The Hon. Daniel B. St. John, of Newburg, who has in times past given many proofs of his interest in the welfare of the Episcopal Church in Monticello, is again the donor of a gift to that parish.

An explosion in the C.B. Bidwell Standard Fireworks factory in East Williamsburg, completely destroyed the building last night, and severely injured Peter Goldman and Henry Miller, the workmen. The loss on the building is $1,000.

Charles H. Schoch, of Jersey City, bookkeeper for Joseph H. Tinagero, a merchant of 12 Old-slip, was arrested last evening in Broadway on a warrant issued by Justice O'Reilly on Mr. Tinagero's complaint that Schoch had stolen $2. He was released by Justice Solon B. Smith ...

HARRISONBURG, Va., July 28.--At the election for town officers here to-day, D.S. Lewis, Republican, was elected Mayor over P. Bryan, Democrat, by 76 majority. The full Republican ticket for Councilmen was also elected.
CHICAGO, July 28.--Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, of Seabright, N.J., the Prohibition leader, was in the city to-day. Gen. Fisk is on his way from ...

Christopher Eiliott, a boy of 18, began an action for divorce yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. He alleged that he met Hattie Boyle on the street one night, and she asked him to have a drink. It must have been drugged he says, for when he awoke to conscionsness he was a married man. The Rev. Charles Miller performed the ceremony. The wife is about 32 years old.
Col. Emmons Clark, of the Seventh Regiment, who is Secretary of the Health Department, sails for Europe on the Britannic Aug. 10.
The Commissioners of Emigration devoted most of the time at their meeting yesterday to the charge of assault made by the detained immigrant, Inga Jonson, against an employe at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, July 28.--A Committee from Philadelphia representing the Constitutional Centennial Commission, and consisting of the Hon. John A. Kasson, President of the commission; Mr. Amos R. Little, Chairman of the Executive Committee, and Mr. Hampton L. Carson, Secretary of the commission, had a conference with the President at the White house to-day, and agreed upon a programme for the celebration, as follows:
An Altona newspaper publishes the interesting intelligence that a son of King Bell, of Cameroon, Alfred Bell, has been apprenticed to a carpenter of that town along with three other dusky Africans.

Collector Magone yesterday received a letter from a lumber dealer, who said he had been forced to pay a tax of 30 cents per 1,000 feet to the Canadian Government for all lumber brought through the Welland Canal.

BOSTON, July 28.--The protest of merchants of Boston against the discrimination against this city in the matter of freight rates from Chicago and the West has taken definite and formal shape in three petitions of the Boston Chamber of Commerce to the Inter-State Commerce Commission.
ALBANY, July 28.--The following is the report of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company for the quarter ending June 30:

WASHINGTON, July 28.--The order directing First Lieut. J.D. Richards, Fourth Cavalry, to proceed to Jefferson Barracks for recruiting duty has been revoked, and First Lieut. W.M. Dickinson, Fourth Cavalry, has been ordered to that duty.
Mrs. William S. Nichols, wife of the senior partner of the firm of W.S. Nichols Co., 33 Wall-street, took leave of her servant, Elsor ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 28.--Detective Gumbert, of this city, has succeeded in capturing one of the burglars who robbed Fairchild Co.'s jewelry store, in Bridgeport, Conn., about two weeks ago. The matter was put into his hands last week by the Pinkerton Detective Agency.

Few people believed yesterday when they heard the announcement that Frederick W.H. Neilson had died at Far Rochaway, Long Island, that it referred to the popular gentleman of that name who for the last 13 years has been the life of the up-town clubs and whose genial nature and frank good humor have won him a legion of friends.

Col. S.D. Bruce sold at the Monmouth Park track yesterday 23 out of the 38 head of race horses which had been advertised. The most of them were yearlings from the Brookdale and Rancocas Farms of Mr. Withers and Mr. Lorillard. Only two of the former's horses were let go, however, as Mr. Withers had set a ...

Chief Engineer Greene, of the Dock Department, explained to the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday the proposed improvement of the Harlem River front from One Hundred and Fifty-ninthstreet and Eighth-avenue to High Bridge.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 28.--Collector Foley, of Souris, Prince Edward Island, denies the report that he refused to allow the fishermen who were caught within the lines on Sunday last to ship on board American vessels going to Gloucester.

The most significant thing about the convention of the Ohio Republicans at Toledo is the sweeping victory of Senator SHERMAN in obtaining a unanimous indorsement as the candidate of the Republicans of the State for the Presidency.

TORONTO, July 29.--The most remarkable thing about commercial union is the great progress it has made during the few months the subject has been before the Canadian people. No other question affecting the fiscal policy of the country ever made such rapid headway with the electorate and eclipsed all othor public questions as this has done.

HALIFAX, July 29.--A meeting was called at the Halifax Hotel saveral evenings ago with a view to perfecting the arrangements of the Committee of Reception on the jubilee races, but owing to the unavoidable absence of several ...
CHICAGO, July 29.--The fear that the Minnesota and Northwestern, which opens its line between this city and St. Paul Aug., 1, intends to boom its new route by slashing rates was confirmed to-day.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 29.--Anthony Wilson, of Camden, and Hectured Crawford, of McIntosh, the two colored members of the House, have submitted in the House the following minority report on the Glenn bill:

MONTROSE, N.Y., July 29.--Not having made proper arrangements with the weather clock to-day the Twenty-second. Regiment suffered accordingly. At a moment when it was perspiring freely and wondering if it would ever feel cool again, the rain came down and soaked the Twenty-second as it had never been soaked before.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--In the case of W.H. Heard, the colored man who complained to the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the Georgia Railroad Company that he was refused first class accommodations and compelled to ride in the "Jim Crow car," the respondent demurs to the complainant's petition upon various grounds, ...

ST. LOUIS, July 29.--A large section of the mystery surrounding the Abbott case was removed this morning upon the arrival of Mr. John C. Coulter, of Chesterton, Ind. He is a prominent citizen of the little town, and came ...

Jay Gould's young and wicked son Eddie chose a bad day on which to give up his bear ghost and announce himself a bull. The stock market yesterday seemed on a dead run for the demnition bow-wows. Nobody had any fun but the bear raiders; then had not only fun but profits.
LONDON, July 29.--The steamship Jesmond, Capt. Hall, from New-York July 13, arr. at Lisbon yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 29.--Shortly after 5 o'clock this morning people gathered at the tabernacle waiting for the doors to open at 7. The day was beautiful but warm. People came out in holiday attire and looked more as though going to a picnic than to a funeral. The Mormons behaved shamefully, pushing and elbowing their way through the crowd regardless of women or children.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 29.--The business of the Grand Lodge, Knights of Pythias, was concluded this afternoon. Before adjourning the lodge received and adopted the final reports of the Committees on Supervision, Finance and Mileage, and Credentials.
Ex-Judge Denis Quinn, of this city, died at Saratoga last evening. He had been ill at the Adelphi for the past two weeks. His family were with him and brought the body to this city last night.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 29.--The following semi-official account of the Baltimore and Ohio deal will be issued to-morrow by John A. Hambleton Co., the bankers who have confidential relations with the Garretts:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 29.--The cases of Frank Webber and C.W. Moore, agents of the NewYork Life Insurance Company, charged with soliciting insurance without a license, were called to-day and continued. They will go over to the January term, but it is thought they will be settled out of court.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--When the British ship Prince Albert, from Rio Janeiro, Brazil, was towed into Quarantine station at the Delaware Breakwater to-day for medical examination it was ascertained that one of the crew had died ...

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 29.--John McTighe and James Dalton, two well known residents of this city, drove into a creek about nine miles from this city last night. The bed of the creek is about 15 feet below the road. McTighe was killed and Dalton sustained serious injuries. The bridge spanning the stream had recently been washed away, and both men were ignorant of the fact.
It is more than probable that most of the leather manufacturers in Newark will shut down this afternoon. They have come to the conclusion that it will be best to do so.

Rose Keenan protests she is the victim of a practical joke. Rose is a waitress at 161 East Thirty-seventh-street Many months ago a young man used to visit her. He called himself Frederick Griffin, and introduced his sister, who "lives out" in Fortieth-street.
The second installment of "fresh-air" children from De Witt Chapel started out Thursday morning. They numbered 53, varying in age from 6 to 16.

It is the purpose of the Canal Union, which has just held a convention at Rochester, to present the subject of the improvement of the canals of this State to the conventions of both political parties and if possible make it an issue before the people in the coming canvass.
It should be made clear to the President that, whereas Nashville happens to be the capiital of one State, Memphis is the commercial metropolis of three.

NORWALK, Conn., July 29.--John Ainley, a hatter, occupying rooms in the James Block, on Water-street, was found dead in bed this morning. He retired last evening at an early hour without disrobing. Death is supposed to have been caused from apoplexy.
There was frost enough at Hay Fork, Trinity County, Wednesday morning of last week to damage tender vegetables.

The members of Americus Lodge, Knights of Honor, in this city, have instituted a new scheme which is likely to find favor not only in this order throughout the United States but to be adopted by members of other similar beneficial organizations. It commends itself to all. Americus Lodge numbers 300 members.

Mrs. Theresa Deutsch, a motherly old lady, the wife of a retired merchant, died yesterday at 5:30 A.M., at her home, 329 East Fiftyeighth-street, in great agony from a dose of liniment administered internally through mistake. She was sick with rheumatism, but otherwise sound in mind and body, and 14 hours before her sudden death her physician had said to her, "You will doubtless live to a ripe old age."

The weather was very warm at Brighton Beach yesterday notwithstanding a breeze from the sea, but the track was fast, and speculation on the results was brisk. During the fifth race Red Buck fell and Rebel Friend and Tatler rolled over him, breaking his neck. He had to be killed.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 29.--The Missouri, River continues to cut the bank in front of this city, several hundred feet of valuable property having gone out of sight in the last 24 hours. The Illinois Central, Sioux City, and Pacific and Milwaukee Railroads have joined in an effort to stop the cutting and are working 300 men. Engineers say they can control it in time.

The stockholders of the American Electric Light Company met at 32 Nassau-street yesterday, and its officers reported that the company was not in good shape. Its assets were not particularly valuable, and they thought it ...

READING, Penn, July 29.--Amos Geigley and his seven children, residing at Terra Hill. Lancaster County, were this morning taken suddenly ill, vomiting and showing other symptoms of poisoning. To-night all are said to be in a critical condition. Mrs. Geigley was not made sick. It is thought some malicious person threw poison in the well, and the water will be analyzed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29.--The salmon pack on the Columbia, River is running very short, and the local trade journal estimates that the pack will not exceed 50 per cent. of last year. The same journal says that, as a consequence of ...

MONTREAL, July 29.--The officers of the American war ship Galena were entertained at an "at home," tendered by the officers of the Fifth and Sixth Military Districts last evening. The Galena left for Quebec this morning.

As Commissioner Voorhis was the only member of the Board of Police at the Central Office yesterday no action could be taken toward filling the two vacant Inspectorships. The eligible list is on file in the office of the chief clerk, and action thereon may be taken by the Commissioners at their meeting next Tuesday if all the members of the board are present.
Mass has seldom been said at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, on Barclay-street, on a sadder occasion than yesterday morning, when candles were burning upon the two white coffins containing ...
Cotton had some lively fluctuations yesterday, and August got decidedly the worst of it. The market opened with August at 10.13 cents, 9 points below the closing price Thursday afternoon.

For seven innings the Brooklyn Club held the lead over the Cincinnati team, at Brooklyn, yesterday, but in the eighth "Long" John Reilly, of the visiting nine, hit the ball for a home run when two ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 28.--The intended Kuklux raid on Mormon missionaries in Richmond County, Ga., came off on Tuesday night with rather unexpected results. The Kuklux met at Goodwin's chapel on that night.

The Riverside and Staten Island Cricket Clubs will play to-day at Livingston and the Kings County and Claremont (N.J.) Cricket Clubs will play at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The match between the Seabright and Manhattan Cricket Clubs has been postponed until Aug. 13. The Brooklyn and Metropolitan Cricket Clubs will play at Central Park this afternoon and the Cosmopolitan Club will play a club match--Capt. C.A. McCuily's side against Capt. J. Garland's.
Secretary Lamar is now wearing trousers of a rather peculiar color. One pair has a purplish tinge and the other is blue. the Secretary regards them as great additions to his wardrobe ...
The intense heat yesterday kept the attendance at the lawn tennis tourney of the Ladies' Outdoor Club, at Livingston, Staten Island, within limits, yet there were many ladies ...

Alfred Jones, a Grand Central Station car cleaner, while sweeping out Postal Car 679 a week ago last night found, behind the heater in the car, six mail service envelopes containing 78 checks amounting to $6,000 and some money orders for small amounts.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29.--The Central Pacific overland train bringing the Eastern mail for the Hawaiian Islands and the colonies was only one hour late to-day, but the departure ...
The races at Monmouth Park to-day promise to be as interesting as any yet run there. In all the contests the entries are good, and close and exciting finishes may be expected.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--Timothy and Thomas Mulkurn, burglars, who have committed over 20 robberies in South Jersey in the past few weeks, are behind the bars of the Camden Jail. To them belongs the credit of utilizing an ingenious machine in making robberies over a large section of country.

DETROIT, July 29.--"Hoodooism" does not seem to be an exclusively Southern manifestation. Charles W. Stoughton and wife were tried to-day at Lansing for assaulting an old lady, Elizabeth Lee, with darning needles last night.

Moses A. Shaw, lumberman, of 120 Broadway and at Towanda, Penn., made an assignment yesterday, both individually and as surviving partner of the firm of Shaw Co., composed of Moses A. Shaw and Nile T. Childs, to Winfield S. Simpson, of Towanda, and Samuel D. Patterson, of New-York.
SARATOGA, July 29.--The attendance today was light on account of the sultry weather. The track was dusty but fast, and the racing of this, the first extra day of the season, was good.

The subjoined letter, now published for the first time, is interesting as exhibiting the extreme sensitiveness of Thackeray's nature. As Thackeray did not carry out his threat to stop his contributions to Fraser's Magazine, it is to be assumed that his demand was complied with, or that other means was found of healing his wounded susceptibilities:

CINCINNATI, July 29.--E.L. Harper, through his Trustee, Mr. H.P. Lloyd, to-day filed two suits againsts Joseph W. Wilshire and Howard Eckert, doing business as Wilshire, Eckert Co. The first is for $60,000, on two notes by the firm to E.L. Harper, given early last November. The second is for $47,500, ou four checks indorsed by Joseph W. Wilshire and dated last September. These claims are mixed up with the wheat deal affair.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 29.--The boiler of the Houston Lumber Company's saw and planing mill exploded yesterday, wrecking one-half of the building and killing R.G. Wells, general manager of the company, aud Andrew Henry, the engineer. Frank Wilson, a laborer, is dying from his injuries. One man and two boys are missing. The damage to the building is $6,500.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 29.--The Evening Journal has interviews with more than one-half of the members of the Republican State Committee and they appear to be practically unanimous in favor of an early State Convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29.--The examination of President Leland Stanford, of the Southern Pacific Railroad, was continued before the Pacific Railroad Investigating Commission this morning. The following question was propounded ...
NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., July 29.--At 2 P.M. the thermometer registered 101 , with scorching hot winds from the south. A number of persons were overcome by the heat, but none fatally.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 29.--The writ of error asked for last Saturday by counsel for Barclay Peak, the condemned murderer of Katie Anderson, has been allowed by Chancellor McGill.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 29.--The Little Rolling Mill, the largest industry in East St. Louis, closed down to-day on account of a strike among the stokers. The grievance is that too much work was exacted of one man. Joseph Moon, who has been engaged as a stoker.

Something of a sensation has been caused at Long Island City by the new rolls filed yesterday by the City Assessors. They show an increase in the assessed valuation of personal property of over $2,000,000, and a large increase in realty valuations.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., July 29--Calvin Rigg, a a School Tax Collector for the borough of Conshohocken from 1882 to 1885, is short $10,000 in his accounts for the years 1884 and 1885. The Auditing Cummittee of the School Board began an inspection of Rigg's accounts last Saturday, and Rigg was requested to be present, but he disappeared. From a pair of shoes found near the river bank suspicions point to suicide. He has four bandsmen.

So abnndant have startling stories been in Wall-street lately, so energetic have the bear rumor committees been, and so great has been the freedom taken with financial reputations that few who watched the tape in Stock Exchange offices late yesterday afternoon were astonished to see recorded there an announcement of the failure of the brokerage firm of Gould Henry, of 67 Exchange-place.
Chu Ming Mey Soo, a Christian Chinaman, died at the Presbyterian Hospital last Wednesday of consumption, and was buried yesterday in Evergreens Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--The President did not visit the White House to-day. News was received there of more delegations on the road to invite his presence in their respective cities. Col. Lamont states that the President will probably remain at Oak View until the present torrid weather moderates.

The man who thanked his stars for a change of weather, when he felt the south wind wafted into his windows yesterday morning, changed his mind when he got outdoors, for the weather was the same old chestnut. It became damp, hot, and sticky right after breakfast, just as it had been doing all the month, and kept moving along that line with a devotion worthy a better cause.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 20 cents: telegraphic, 30 cents.

Justice Gorman established yesterday the precedent that while a dentist cannot practice medicine and surgery a physician and surgeon can practice dentistry. He did thin by discharging Dr. O. Emery Bradford, who though a graduate of the Eclectic College, had been arrested for pulling teeth without being registered and without the sanction of the New-York State Dental Society, which does not recognize the Eclectic College as orthodox.
Quite a number of the residents of the city have adopted Major Eugene Weigel's suggestion, made several months ago, and now have their lawns decorated with flower beds in the ...

It is probable that the longshoremen's strike on the dock of the National Steamship Line will be settled to-day. Yesterday morning most of the bag sewers on the steamer Canada refused to work while the negroes employed Thursday were on the dock.
RICHMOND, Ind., July 29.--A terrible accident occurred near this city to-day in which three persons and two horses were killed and a fourth person badly injured.

"I've got my brother," exclaimed Herman Haff as he entered Superintendent Cleary's office this morning. The young man's face was wreathed in smiles, and he plainly showed how happy he felt over his success.
Our Governor has been so causelessly and unjustly slandered that he has determined to make a few speeches during this campaign, and give an account of his stewardship.

BRUNSWICK, Me., July 29.--A severe thunderstorm passed over this region at about midnight last night. Lightning struck and set fire to the house and barn of Wellington Jedford, a farmer, and to the honse of John Whitehouse, a farmer, of Topsham.
CHICAGO, July 29.--At 2:40 o'clock this morning fire was discovered in the bakery of Chriss Heffen, at 3,165 Archer-avenue, a threestory and basement and brick tenement.
NYACK, N.Y., July 29.--The second accident within less than two weeks occurred this morning on the Northern Railroad of New-Jersey, aout eight miles below this place, making wrecks of two engines.

A horse attached to one of John Detchening Co.'s coal carts was sunstruck while standing at Sumner and DeKalb avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday, and in falling knocked down a small tree. The tree in turn struck Patrick Creegan, of 178 Sumner-avenue, knocking him to the ground and fracturing his skull. He was removed to his home and may die.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 29.--It is perfectly evident that the Blaine men in Ohio will take Sherman at his word, and will adopt the privilege of the district rule in the National Convention of 1888 to voice their preference for Biaine rather than Sherman for President.

MONTREAL, July 29.--The "ticker" has been taken out of Messrs. Doran Wright's office by the order of the Chicago Board of Trade, and that firm consequently has some difficulty in obtaining Chicago quotations.

Mr. J.R. Huntington, a citizen of Amesbury, Mass., on the Merrimac, has decided to erect on the public square of that town a heroic bronze statue of his maternal ancestor, Dr. Josiah Bartlett, one of the signers of the ...

ST. LOUIS, July 29.--The ex-Brigadier from Iowa who stepped out of his way to insult the President appears to have a dubious spot in his civil as well as his army record. Charles Rousch, formerly bookkeeper for the commission firm of E.L. Chamberlin Co., said today:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 29.--Several months ago Isidor Freedman, of the firm of Mendel Freedman, had his name proposed for membership in the Utopia Club, an organization made up of wealthy Hebrew residents of this city.
HAZLETON, Penn., July 29.--A Lehigh Valley passenger train and a New-Jersey Central coal train collided to-day at Pond Creek Junction, about four miles north of here.

CHICAGO, July 29.--Mrs. John A. Logan is recovering from the effects of the injuries she received in the accident at Carbondale, and traveled to this city to-day in company with her son and his wife. No callers, however, have been received by Mrs. Logan, and she remains in her room constantly.

Dr. Hubbard W. Mitchell, who lives in a handsome house at 747 Madison-avenue, was examined before Franklin Bien yesterday, in supplementary proceedings instituted by Louis Schlessinger to collect a judgment of $507 37, which he recovered of the doctor in the City Court in November, 1877.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 29.--Nine new cases of yellow fever have been reported by the Board of Health since yesterday, but no deaths.

CHICAGO, July 29.--The Sheriff and some of his Deputies had a wild-goose chase out toward the northwest to-day on a trip which does not seem to have amounted to much, although nothing could be learned about it by inquiry.

Any one who imagines that the weather has given a vacation to theatrical managers ought to meet Manager David B. Henderson, of the Chicago Opera House. Described in the vernacular of his native heath, Mr. Henderson comes from Hustleville, near the head of the creek.

CINCINNATI, July 29.--About 4:30 o'clock this afternoon a fire broke out in an old dairy stable on the north side of Gest-street, near Harriet-street. This quarter was covered with an old distillery stable and little frame shanties and was known as "Slop Town."

Richard J. Hinton is a disappointed representative of labor. He wanted to control the labor element in this city, but it would not be controlled. He tried to get the management of the Leader, but it eluded his grasp.

How does it happen that consumers derive no benefit from the prevailing low prices of live cattle in the West? For two years or more the ranchmen have been complaining about these prices. The recent heavy failures at Fore Worth and Henrietta, in Texas, are said to have been caused by this continued depression of values.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29.--The local wheat market continues to exhibit increased strength daily. Prices are advancing steadily, with the "bull" traders apparently in full control of the market.

Guatemalan political matters are becoming more hazy every day. Principally this fact is owing to the confusion existing respecting internal affairs and to the policy to be adopted respecting the other Central American States being as yet not definitely determined.
LONDON, July 29.--The race for the Goodwood Stakes Handicap was won by Mr. Somers's 4-year-old b.c. Carlton. Mr. Leopold de Rothschild's Beaver was second, and Mr. E. Benzon's Stanislas third.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 29.--In Hopatcong Township, Warren County, several petrified bodies have just been exhumed from an old burying ground, where the ancestors of the Feit family lie buried. In one instance the grave clothes were still intact. The bodies were so rigid that they could be lifted out of the graven by one person taking hold of the head and another by the feet. The coffins were found to be filled with water.

BOSTON, July 29.--To-day closed the most successful circuit meeting ever held at Beacon Park. In the 2:23 class only three horses started. Rex took the lead and held it through the first heat, Breeze Medium breaking badly.

Rudolph Schalk, a well known young resident of Newark, was taken to the State Asylum at Trenton yesterday, a raving maniac. About two years ago he attempted, to commit suicide by shooting himself in the head. The ball remains there yet. A young lady of whom he thonght a great deal refused to marry him, and this, with his other trouble, made him insane.

PORT HAWKESBURY, Cape Breton, July 29.-- The American man-of-war Yantic arrived here today from Halifax, and sailed for North Bay to see how the United States fishermen are faring at the hands of the Dominion cruisers.
The Union Labor Party is making active arrangements for its State Convention, which is to be held at Rochester Aug. 10, one week earlier than that of the United Labor Party.
PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--John O'Brien, the showman, was fined $50 and costs by Magistrate Gillespie to-day for cruelty to animals.
PARIS, July 29.--Gen. Ferron, Minister of War, has forwarded a circular to the different commanders of the army forbidding military bands to play Boulangist airs.

Reports circulating in this city last night represented a leading Philadelphia bank in trouble. The bank named was the Columbian, and the official announcement of its failure was declared ready to be made this morning.
John Brennan, a self-confessed tramp, was held in the Harlem Conrt yesterday for swindling Mrs. Kate Williams, of 400 East One Hundred and Fourth-street, out of $60 worth of clothing.

Dr. Mulcahy, of Newark, well known there as a practicing physician, and whose name has been prominent in Irish revolutionary movements here and in Ireland since 1866, has just come into possession of a snug little fortune, which reaches its rightful owner after such strange and romantic vicissitudes as to make the story worth telling.

ST. LOUIS, July 29.--At 7:30 this morning James C. Flynn, a well known contractor of this city, shot and killed Patrick Smith, a teamster, who had been instructed to haul away a pile of rocks in front of a block of houses Flynn was building.
It is no secret that more than one Canadian has been compelled to accept knighthood through the pressure of the female members of his family.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 29.--Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Thompson and General Superintendent Kimball, of the Life-Saving Service, are in this city inspecting the Custom House and life-saving station.

Camp Meeting John Allen, of Maine, is attending his three hundred and seventy-third camp meeting at Middleborough, Mass. He is 92 years old and one of the most earnest exhorters on the grounds.

LONDON, July 29.--In the House of Commons this evening, on a motion that clause 4, as amended, stand as a part of the Land bill, Mr. Dillon moved its rejection. He said if the rest of the bill was altered so as to do substantial justice to the tenant the objections to the clause would, to some extent, be met, but the Parnellites had no assurance that this would be done.

Madeleine F. Montross and her daughter Annie, who keep boarders in a handsome house at 132 West Twelfth-street, a very respectable neighborhood, went in terror before Justice Gorman yesterday afternoon. They said Ellen Rowley, wife of Officer Andrew H. Rowley, of the Broadway squad, was bent on doing them serious harm.

Ex-Fire Marshal A.B. Thorne, of Brooklyn, who was arrested some time ago, charged by George Simonson with obtaining $70 from him by means of a worthless check on the Nassau Bank, was honorably discharged yesterday by Justice Massey.

The reading room and library of the Cooper Union is to be closed for two weeks, beginning Monday.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., July 29.--Warrants were issued to-day for the arrest of Mayor Jones and the members of Select and Common Councils of this city to answer a charge of neglecting for several years past to keep East Third-street in proper repair. The street extends from the crossing of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad to the city line. August Nast, a resident of the street, makes the complaint. Defendants will havs a hearing tomorrow.

Daniel Lyons, who shot and killed Joseph J. Quinn, the young athlete, on the evening of July 5, and who was arrested in Pittsburg a week ago, left that city Thursday evening and arrived here yesterday morning in charge of Officer Duncan and Detective Malarkey.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 29.--The Western NewYork Association decided yesterday to advance the price of anthracite coal on Aug. 1.25 cents per ton.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29.--This was the closing day of the grand circuit races. The weather was fine, the track fast, and the attendance 10,000. The feature of the day was the defeat of Harry Wilkes in three straight heats ...

The Rev. William P. Bruce, Pastor of the Greenville (N.J.) Reformed Church, returned from his vacation yesterday, accompanied by his bride. The couple were escorted to a neat two-story and basement house on Linden-avenue, where they were met by a large gathering of friends. Mr. S.L. Hearney, after a speech of welcome, informed the clergyman that the house and all the furniture it contained were a gift from his congregation.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 29.--Gen. Phil Sheridan will be tendered a reception on board the United States Coast Survey schooner Eagre, at Nonquitt, to-morrow. The Eagre is expected to arrive in this city from Cuttyhunk to-night, and will be towed from here to the seashore resort.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 29.--A Sheriff's posse has been organized here to capture John Pickett, who shot his wife on Wednesday and is now at large. He declares he will not be taken alive.

The Socialists in this city and Brooklyn are making a hard fight to get control of the United Labor Party. In this county they have elected 14 delegates to the Syracuse Convention and 4 in Kings. The delegates and other Socialist leaders will soon hold a caucus to determine upon some plan of action upon which all the Socialist delegates from all parts of the State will act as a unit.
LIMA, July 29.--The installation of Congress took place yesterday. Dr. Don Francisco Rosas was elected President of the Chamber of Senators, and Dr. Arenes, President of the Chamber of Deputies.

CINCINNATI, July 29.--The meeting of the Exposition Commissioner and Citizens' Committee this afternoon was transformed into a jollification by the report that notes for $1,028,000 for next year's centennial exposition guarantee fund had been executed. The work of erecting buildings will now proceed at once.

CHICAGO, July 29.--The opponents of General Master Workman Powderly are using lots of printers' ink in their fight against him and his friends. A circular from Washington signed by such well known labor leaders as John Morrison, F. Foster, G.E. McNeil, Archibald and George Dunn has been received by the Secretaries of several local assemblies in Chicago.

GENEVA, July 29.--At the opening of the international rifle meeting here a speech was made by M. Droz, the President of the Federal Council. He said that owing to the wisdom of the leading European Cabinets peace was now assured.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 29, via Galveston. --Grave fears are felt here regarding the possible inundation of the capital. There have been exceedingly heavy rains for the last few days, and last evening many of the streets were submerged, the sewers not being able to carry off the floods.

Lottie, the 10-year-old daughter of Mrs. M.L. Rawson, reposed in her mother's arms yesterday, a contented and somewhat wiser child. It seems that on Thursday the little miss was corrected for some trifling indiscretion.
LONDON, July 29.--The report is confirmed that Russians are fostering the republican movement in Bulgaria to increase the anxieties of the Bulgarian Government.
Jacob Hertz, of 441 Sixth-street, and his friend Charles McCarthy hired two horses on Wednesday from Newburger Hartvigson, liverymen at 237 Rivington-street, for a drive to Coney Island.

About 100 laborers handle the heavy goods in the Government Public Stores at Washington and Hubert streets. They receive $2 a day and 25 cents an hour for overtime, their regular work lasting from 8 in the morning till 5 at night.

Mary Oberle, the woman who took children to board and let them starve to death while she went visiting all day attired in a silk drees, was convicted in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday and sentenced to the penitentiary for six months.

TORONTO, July 29.--Some of the players in the Toronto baseball team are Catholics and some Protestants. There is much opposition between the men of different religions.
OMAHA, Neb., July 29.--News reached here to-night that a small cyclone struck David City, a town on the Burlington and Missouri Road, 100 miles west of this city, and did a large amount of damage.

It has for some time been evident that some check upon immigration and upon naturalization would shortly be demanded by a general sentiment too strong to be resisted. The reports in regard to the performances of the new sloop Volunteer are unquestionably much exaggerated. She has been credited with logging 17 knots an hour, which is absurd. If she can sail at this rate she can beat the Mayflower about four knots an hour.

Yesterday, as a number of fishermen were engaged in netting for salmon and sea bass on the bay between Alcatraz and Sancelito, their attention was directed to a terrible commotion under the surface, in close proximity to their nets.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--Capt. Joseph T. Haskell, Twenty-third Infantry, has been detailed to visit the camps of the National Guard of Ohio, vice First Lieut. A.P. Blocksom, Sixth Cavalry, who is relieved of that detail.

BOSTON, July 29.--The Directors of the Atchison, Topeko and Santa Fe Railroad Company held a meeting to-day and voted to make a new issue of $10,000,000 of stock.

Mayor Hewitt and Commissioner Gibbens had their weekly argument at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Electrical Control. The session was opened by the consideration of a number of applications from electric light companies for permission to erect new poles upon which to string additional wires.

James Abbott, of Elmira, Chairman of the socalled Union Labor Party, has arrived in this city to try and patch up peace among the four factions of the party here. The party claims to have 15,000 members on their roll, but their enemies, the United Labor Party men, say their membership is in the neighborhood of 50.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 30.--Mrs. Catharine Melville, who was burned yesterday while trying to kindle a slow fire with kerosene oil, died at the Rhode Island Hospital to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., July 30.--Charles H. Winfield, counsel for Jeannette M. Thurber, filed a bill in the Court of Chancery to-day to have the National Opera Company declared insolvent. The bill prays for the appointment of a Receiver to wind up as speedily as possible ...

A singularly incomprehensible murder and suicide occurred last evening at the Bancroft House at 922 Broadway. One of the factors in the double tragedy was liquor, but there is a hidden motive that may never be divulged. It is certain that the victim, Charles E. Greer, 19 years old, was a dyed-in-the-wool Orangeman, and it is suspected that the murderer and suicide, John E. Emerson, 40 years old, was a Catholic and a Nationalist.

CINCINNATI, July 30.--The east-bound passenger train on the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad this evening about 8 o'clock broke the axle of the tender while running at full speed just west of Cochran, Ind., about 30 miles from here.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 30.--A heavy rainstorm set in here about 9:30 o'clock to-night. Lightning struck several houses, in one case setting fire to the building and in another putting out the lights. No loss of life is reported. It was the severest storm that has visited this section in some time.

The report of the select committee on the Rabbit Nuisance act is not pleasant reading. The evidence goes to show that the present system for the destruction of the rabbits has been a complete failure.

PARIS, July 30.--Fashions in Winter colors are deciding their tints, and the great favorite is to be dark moss green trimmed with black. Black braiding is placed either around the extreme edge of jupe or in panels at each side pointing up toward the waist. Of course, the black moire vest is worn as usual. John Potter, James Lent, and Charles Pearsall went to Croton Lake from Mount Kisco on Friday to have a day's fishing.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 30.--Hanlan has accepted Teemer's challenge to row a three-mile race for $1,000 a side. The race will be rowed on Toronto Bay on Aug. 12 or 13. Hanlan sails for Australia on Aug. 15 to row Beach.
When young Daniel Lyons went out to shoot Joseph Quinn on July 5 he probably did not think or care about the effect his act would have upon his own family.
DECATUR, Ill., July 30.--The annual camp meeting, under the auspices of the National Prohibition Association, was held to-day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 30.--Judge Cole, of the Rowan County Circuit Court, met Gov. Knott in this city last night, and by an earnest solicitation induced him to reconsider his de termination to not send troops to Morehead.

Five months after the production of "L'Avare," on Feb. 5, 1669, "Tartuffe," written as long ago as 1664, but played for one night only in public exactly 18 months before, was reintroduced on the boards of the Palais Royal. There is not much humor in "Tartuffe." The play is too serious, the attack on hypocrisy is too direct to admit of humor.
To-morrow is the anniversary of B ranger's death. A very small number indeed of admirers will lay wreaths on his tomb in P re la Chaise.

COLUMBUS, Ga., July 30.--This city is about the centre of the district damaged by the rains which set in four days ago. The loss to the farmers in the region referred to cannot be less than $1,500,000. Woolfolk's Bend is entirely submerged. Woolfolk Walker has 100 acres under water, from which he would have gathered 50 bales of cotton.

BOSTON, July 30.--The Concord Railroad met with its first disaster to-day. It occurred at the little town of Hookset, N.H., where an accommodation train leaving Boston at 7:30 A.M. and the mixed train from the Suncook Valley Road met in collision and two persons were killed and several injured. The mixed train from Pittsfield had reached Hookset where the passengers disembarked and the coaches were left on a siding.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 30.--Joseph, the 10year-old son of J.E. Chamberlain, of New-York, while playing in the cow stable of his grandfather, at Chester, fell from the hay loft and broke his arm.
The Second Battery, Flying Artillery, which is attached to the First Brigade, started for the State Camp at Peekskill yesterday morning, under the command of Capt. Ferdinand P. Earle.

ROCKPORT, Miss., July 30.--Deputy Sheriff Anthony De Long, William Bostwick, and G.G. Bostwick attempted yesterday afternoon to arrest Con and Charlie Franklin, horse thieves, who escaped from jail in Holt County Thursday night.
NEWPORT, Ark., July 30.--Regarding the hanging of Mrs. Lemuel Boyd by her own hands it now turns out she was killed and then hanged to conceal the crime.

For years prior to her death at Jersey City in 1884 Mrs. Ann Dyer had been a mendicant. During half of each week she sat on a corner near the Barclay-Street Ferry soliciting alms.

SARATOGA, July 30.--This week there have been no less than seven hops at the large hotels, all of them brilliant affairs. Next week, if all goes well, there will be nine. To-night one had the choice of four--at the Grand Union, United States, Kensington, and Clarendon. Those at the first two hotels were rather formal affairs. All were well attended.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30.--The Columbian Bank, at 433 Chestnut-street, did not open its doors for business to-day. A notice posted on the door said the bank had been closed by order of the Directors, and that an assignment had been made for the benefit of the creditors. The branch savings bank in Germantown also suspended. The liabilities are said to be between $200,000 and $300,000.

COTTAGE CITY, July 30.--The heat here during the last day or two has been simply intolerable, and a cool wave will be eagerly welcomed. On account of the warm weather there has been but little dancing during the week and the attendance at the hops has been light.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 30.--Edward J. Symonds, a well known sporting man, was found dead this morning at the Revere Hotel. Death is supposed to have been caused by apoplexy.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 30.--A report has reached here that the outgoing and incoming stages between San Marcos and Dripping Springs were robbed last night. Considerable booty is said to have been obtained from rifling the mails and registered packages, but no particulars are at hand.
MONTREAL, July 30.--A.D. Parent, defaulting Cashier of the Hochelaga Bank, has returned here from Chicago, because, as he himself says, he will be dealt with more leniently here.
KINGSTON, N.Y., July 30.--The tide of travel to the Catskills is very heavy, and the hotel and boarding house men unite in saying the season has been the gayest and most remunerative in 10 years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 30.--Interest in wheat speculation was strong again to-day. Seller, 1887, opened at $2 12 , dropped to $2 09, but advanced rapidly and closed firm at $2 15 per cental. For each cent the market advance a call of $20 per ton is made upon those already cornered.

The passengers of the steamer Circassia, which sailed from New-York on July 9, adopted at the end of their journey a series of resolution expressing their high appreciation of Capt. Campbell and his officers. The Captain was especially commended for his vigilance, which kept him on the bridge night and day during eight consecutive days of fog.

The conclusion reached by the Army Regulations Board on the disputed question of Sunday ceremonies is a compromise between the extremes of conflicting opinions. They recommend the continuation of the Sunday morning inspection and the abandonment of the Sunday evening dress parade.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 30.--The 14 American fishermen belonging to the Gloucester fishing schooners Argonaut and Col. J.H. French, who were captured by Canadian fishery cruiser Critic, Capt. McLaren, master, while watching their seines off Souris, Prince Edward Island, on Sunday last, arrived in Halifax this morning on their way home, and left in the afternoon by the steamer Worcester for Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 30.--Frank Thomson, Vice-President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, had an interview yesterday with the managers of the important railway lines leading south from Washington, and concluded negotiations for one of the most important railway traffic arrangements ever entered into by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The steamship Glenshiel, of the Glen Line, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing 5,000 chests of the new tea crop. And she not only brought the tea, but she has beaten her competitor, the Monmouthshire, which is also bringing a cargo of tea.

Frank Holman, a sporting man and bookmaker, arrived from Chicago three days ago and went to the Colemen House. Friday he was acting strangely about the hotel, and a physician was called in, who found that he was suffering from paresis.
SANDWICH, Mass., July 30.--Reports from all parts of Barnstable County are to the effect that the cranberry crop this year will be much lighter than usual.

WEST END, Wis., July 30.--A farmer of Germantown named Arnold was awakened from his after-dinner nap yesterday by a little daughter, who told him his barn was burning.

Dr. Hamilton Williams, of 130 Huronstreet, Greenpoint, made a statement yesterday regarding Mrs. Deutsch, who died Friday morning at her home, 329 East Fifty-eighth-street. "I was called to attend Mrs. Deutsch," said he, "about June 10. She had chronic rheumatism. I prescribed, as preliminary treatment, an alka line mixture to be taken internally, stating that when it was finished no more liquid internal medicine would be required.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 30.--A boat containing 12 persons was capsized at the mouth of the Merrimac last night, and two of the party, Albert Stevens, aged 11 years, and Mina Goodwin, aged 14 years, were drowned. Half of the party were under 12 years of age, and it was a narrow escape from drowning by all.

A French-Canadian conemporary disposes of the disallowance question by saying that the Manitobans "are nothing but a lot of annexationists." As a matter of fact the Manitobans are quite as loyal as the rest of us, but if they are to be deprived of their constitutional rights there is no telling what they may become.
In a jeweler's shop window on Sixthavenue hangs a trophy that draws a crowd every few moments. It is the five-hundreddollar diamond billard cue presented as a championship trophy away back in 1869.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 30.--The militia which has been in camp at Oakland Beach, broke camp to-day and this afternoon left for home. Contrary to the custom of the past few years no parade was made in this city, the brigade being dismissed on the field.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--The Treasury Department has decided that certain receptacles for waste paper, made of paste board and hexagonal in shape, having a bottom, but no top, are dutiable at the rate of 35 per cent. ad valorem under the provisions for paper boxes.
Sawdust swindlers have been lately sending out large quantities of letters to people in the West, South, and Canada, to work a new game upon rural innocents.
DETROIT, July 30.--An exciting battle was the last game of the Detroit-New-York series, and it was decided by the sharp playing of the home club at critical points.
PARIS, July 30.--Gen. Boulanger's seconds have had an interview with ex-Premier Ferry, and have formally presented the General's challenge to fight a duel.

The reception accorded "The Beggar Student" during the past week at Wallack's has fully justified the hopeful anticipations of Col. McCaull, and it will be continued for at least two weeks longer. The weather has been intolerably warm, and poor houses might naturally have been expected, but the house has been well filled at every performance, and "The Student" has done the best business of the Summer season thus far.

BOSTON, July 30.--The twelfth annual regatta of the Corinthian Yacht Club, sailed today off Marblehead, had one feature at least that was exceedingly interesting. The Riersides, by the aid of a freely hit 33 of Sherrington's, made 85 and, when 8 of the Islanders wickets went down, it looked a foregone conclusion that the Riversides would ... win.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 30.--Stoeum De Graff lumber dealers, of Tonawanda, have made an assignment to James A. Roberts, of Buffalo. Their liabilities are $50,000 and their assets $30,000.
George Clark, of Otsego County, who recently went into bankruptcy to find out how much land he owned, has assets nearly sufficient to cover his liabilities of $1,476,587.20.

INDINAPOLIS, July 30.--After deliberating 24 hours the jury in the election conspiracy case came into court at 5 o'clock this afternoon and at their request were discharged, being unable to come to an agreement. With the permission of the court the standing of the jury on the general issue and as to the defendants severally was made known.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 30.--Eliza Ann Lockwood died at Fallsburg, Sullivan County, a few days ago, in her eighty-first year. In her youth she was a lady of great beauty, was highly accomplished and was the belle of her native town, Newburg.

LONDON, July 30.--The committee of the Federation League held a meeting to-day, at which Lord Rosebery presided. A resolution was adopted affirming the importance of the British mail service between Vancouver and Hong-Kong. The resolution will be submitted to the Government.

Charles H. Reed, who for 12 years was State Attorney of Cook County, at Chicago, Ill., and later became more widely known as one of the counsel for the defense of Guiteau, yesterday morning flung himself into the North River from the forward deck of the ferryboat Chicago, of the Pennsylvania line.

BALTIMORE, July 30.--Judge Bond heard final arguments to-day in the ease of Thomas Wiggins or Blind Tom, the celebrated pianist, against Gen. James N. Bethune, which has been before the court for some time, and passed an order which takes Blind Tom out of the custody of Gen. Bethune.
GREENWOOD, Miss., July 30.--George Evans, colored, who killed Bob Harris on Monday was lynched last night by negroes.

MONTREAL, July 30.--The opening of the Canadian Pacific Railroad bridge at Lachine took place this morning in an informal manner.

TOLEDO, July 30.--During the Republican State Convention here it was reported that the opposition to the Sherman indorsement was withdrawn because of a telegram from Representative Boutelle, of Maine.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Capt. C.F. Palfrey, United States Engineer, in his annual roport, says, with respect to Sackett Harbor, New-York, that the present depth of water in the harbor is ample for the present needs of its commerce, the usual draft being from 7 to 9 feet.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 30.--The Munson family, embracing all the descendants of Capt. Thomas Munson, one of the founders of New-Haven, have been called to meet for a reunion at New-Haven on Aug. 17.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Consul-General Raine, of Berlin, now here on leave of absence, is of the opinion that there are entirely too many consular representatives of the United States in Germany. Assistant Secretary Porter, after looking into the facts, is inclined not only to agree with Mr. Raine's criticism as far as regards the German Empire, but also to extend it to other countries, notably to the British dominions.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 30.--Daniel Bosworth the missing dining room clerk of the steamer Pilgrim, is now known to be in Chicago. He had no financial difficulties, but left in quest of better employment.

CHICAGO, July 30.--P.B. Weare, Receiver for the firm of C.J. Kershaw Co., has not yet finished his statement of the condition of the affairs of that house. Mr. Kershaw, however, after considerable figuring, has arrived at a conclusion which he says is very nearly correct.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 30.--Representative McCord has a bill before the Legislature limiting the hours of work in factories to 10. There is much difference of opinion among the operatives, as they want the labor of their children. The mill men, however, are coming up in favor of the measure, and it will likely pass. The Knights of Labor favor the bill.
BOSTON, July 30.--An interesting bit of political gossip emanates from Republican headquarters, and indicates the respect of the party leaders for John F. Andrew as a leader of the Democracy.

BOSTON, July 30.--If the stories of fishermen are to be credited, the sea serpent has once more been seen in his old haunts. It was yesterday afternoon and off Nahant that the monster was seen, and the occupants of the Relay House, at Nahant, are ready to swear to the authenticity of this snake story.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 30.--There was erected in St. James's Church, Elberon, yesterday, by George W. Childs, A.J. Drexel, and others, a tablet in honor of Gen. Grant.

Judge Knapp yesterday made known the names of the Commissioners to act under the Martin law in enforcing payment of the tax arrearages due Jersey City. Some $6,000,000 is due the city, and this law is modeled after the Brooklyn act.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 30.--Miss Anna Husaboe filed papers in a breach of promise suit against the Rev. Mr. Roberts, Pastor of the Plymouth Congregational Church, of this city, in the Prothonotary's office yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 30.--A young, aeronaut named Charles Williams made a successful ascent in a balloon and descent in a parachute, at 6 o'clock this evening from a resort 10 miles up the Ohio, known as Coney Island. The great heat in the city, and the novelty of the attraction led some ...
MONUMENT BEACH, Mass., July 30.--The Beverly Yacht Club sailed its twelfth regatta off Tobey Island this afternoon in a fair southwest breeze.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 30.--President Charles P. Clark, of the New York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, has bought the John C. Anderson place on Orange-street, this city, and will move his family here from Newton, Mass., in the Autumn. It is understood that he paid $40,000 for the property.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30.--The famous cabin yacht Minerva, owned by the Minerva Yacht Club, of this city, was capsized in the Delaware River, off Boulston-street, Camden, this afternoon, and sank. Thomas Kennedy, a member of the club, and William White, the colored steward, were drowned.

ABELENE, Kan., July 30.--The Gazette to-day prints reports from in large number of counties in Kansas, mostly in the Eastern portion and going to show that the corn crop will, in some instances, fall below the average. Nearly all reports say that rain later on would be of vast benefit. The acreage, it is said, will be at least 50 cent. larger than that of 1886.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 30.--The reported macious poisoning of the family of Amos Geigley, of Terre Hill, this county is untrue. Mrs. Geigley and 10 children have been ill since Wednesday with typhoid fever, but are now reported to be improving. The exact cause is unknown, but it is attributed to impure water.
KANSAS CITY, July 30.--W.L. Powell returned yesterday from a prospecting trip in Kansas. He was accompanied by G.H. Neely, of Ohio; A.P. Beemis, of Chicago, and G.N. Sanderson, of Boston.
SARATOGA, July 30.--The attendance at the race meeting here to-day was by far the largest of the season. The weather was warm and the track in fine condition.

CHICAGO, July 30.--The Pullman Company is about to try the experiment of lighting its cars by electricity generated from the revolving car axles on a system that is pronounced both simple and perfect.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 30.--Five new cases of yellow fever since yesterday have been reported by the Board of Health and two deaths.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 30.--At the Republican County Convention last Fall Thomas C. Evans, a prominent ward politician of Nanticoke, was one of the delegates.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 30.--Ernest Lecourt escaped from the State prison to-day. He was serving the seventh year of a 15-year sentence for an outrageous assault. A keeper had taken him outside the walls to put him to work in an icehouse. He got a fair start, as the keeper spent the first moments after he missed him in getting the other men in the gang back in the prison.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Second Lieut. Francis J. Kernan, Twenty-first Infantry, has been relieved from further duty at the Thatcher Institute, Shreveport, La., and is granted four months' leave of absence.

HALIFAX, July 30.--The steam yacht Meteor arrived here to-day from the St. Lawrence on her return to New-York, having been unable to get through the canals to the lakes on account of drawing too much water.

It is expected that the attendance upon the annual cruise of the New-York Yacht Club, which will begin Wednesday next, will be large and that the sport meted out to the yachtsmen during their 10 days of vacation will be above the average. Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry, on the flagship Electra, will be in command.

READING, Penn., July 30.--Misses Mary and Ida Beamenderfer and Mrs. Mary Lane were arrested this afternoon charged with infanticide. The two young women board with Mrs. Lane. Mary Beamenderfer, who is but 17 years of age, gave birth to a child about a month ago and to-day the body of the infant was found buried in Mrs. Lane's yard. The three women were sent to jail.
The funeral services of Robert D. Livingston yesterday noon at the Church of the Redeemer, Park-avenue and Eighty-first-street, was attended only by members of the family and a few friends.
Harry Leeds, an Englishman, excited the sarcastic comments of a party of Irishmen Friday night by drinking "half and half" in a saloon at Port Chester.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 30.--A young man named Adam Smyth, who is wanted in New-York for embezzlement, was arrested here to-day. He tried to swindle Miller, Griener Co., wholesale grocers in this city, but was detected.
The fifth annual reunion of the First New-York Lincoln Cavalry Association takes place Monday, Aug. 1, in Lion Park, Ninth-avenue and One Hundred and Eighth-street.

PITTSBURG, July 30.--The flint glass factories on the south side will start on Monday. The chimney glass houses will also start on the same day named. The will put to work about 2,000 men.
The funeral of the Rev. John W. Schermerhorn, who died suddenly of heart disease last Wednesday, took place yesterday at his residence, 200 West Fifty-second-street.

BOSTON, Mass., July 30.--The steamer Stamford, plying between Boston and Plymonth, had a collision in the harbor this morning with the schooner Grace Webster, of Portland. There was a dense fog at the time.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 30.--James Fenner, a bookkeeper of the International Grain and Stock Exchange, has been arrested on a charge of embezzlement. It is alleged that he is $10,000 short.
OSWEGO, N.Y., July 30.--The 20 years' contract between the city and the Oswego Water Works Company is about to expire.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 30.--The Customs Department at Shelburne seized the New-York ship Bridgewater on the grounds that as the condemned foreign ship was sold here the department should recover 25 per cent. on the amount realized by such sale.
WASHINGTON, July 30.--The weather in Washington continues warm and oppressive, and many persons engaged in outdoor work have succumbed to the heat within the past few days.

LEOMINSTER, Mass., July 30.--A terrible shower passed over this town last evening. Lightning struck the house belonging to George W. Whitney and tore the chimney in fragments. Bricks were strewn over the lawn.

Those politicians who remained in this city over last evening were greatly interested in a story to the effect that Corporation Counsel Morgan J. O'Brien had intimated to Corporation Attorney William A. Boyd that his resignation would be very acceptable. Few of those who discussed the matter were surprised, because it has been generally understood that Mr. Boyd's hold on the office had been much weakened during the past few years.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., July 30.--This morning a south-bound freight train on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad jumped the track near Shamokin. Twenty cars were wrecked, the roadbed torn up, and the bridge damaged. Traffic was delayed six hours. The damage is great.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 31.--Intelligence has been received here that the schooner Joshua H. Marvell, Capt. Shaw, from Cedar Keys for NewYork, with a cargo of lumber, struck on Tortugas during a cyclone on the 25th inst. and became a total loss. The crew were all saved.

A convention of Longshoremen's Unions Nos. 1,2,3, and 5 of New-York, and of Nos. 1 and 2 of Brooklyn was held yesterday at 73 Madison-street. The recent strike at the pier of the National Line was the subject discussed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 31.--Manager Mutrie and the New-York Giants arrived in the city at 1 o'clock to-day from Detroit. Mr. Mutrie was asked what he thougut Von Der Ahe's chances were for getting into the League with the American Association champions in case he wanted to make a change of base.

PARIS, July 31.--The duel between Gen. Boulanger and ex-Premier Ferry will probably take place to-morrow. M. Ferry having the choice of weapons, pistols will probably be selected. The friends of Gen. Boulanger take a serious view of the affair. M. Ferry's seconds are absent from Paris, and he may be obliged to appoint others or postpone the duel until Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31.--The last day of the month was no exception in the matter of hot weather, and the month goes on record as the hottest ever known. There have been but two cool days, and these were only cool in comparison with the sweltering days that had already been endured.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 31.--Mr. Benedict's steam yacht Oneida arrived here this afternoon, having on board her owner and his guests, Edwin Booth, Lawrence Barrett, Lawrence Hutton, of Harper's Magazine, and Mr. Bisham, a friend of Mr. Booth's. They will remain several days and then resume their cruise eastward.

Antonia Caba, a rather comely Italian woman living at 27 Mulberry-street, caused the arrest of her husband, Francisco, on a charge of cruelty and abandonment. He was arraigned at the Tombs Court yesterday, when Antonia suprised the Justice by begging piteously for her husband's discharge, and asked that she be committed to prison in his stead. The man was discharged.

John Duff, the pensioner whose medals and Victoria Cross were reported in these columns yesterday as having been stolen from him, states that he had three five-pound notes and $20 in his pocket, which he is thankful were not stolen also.

Our dispatches from Paris say that only one-half of the Panama Canal Company's new loan has been taken by the people. DE LESSEPS called upon them for $42,500,000, promising to repay $100,000,000 and to allow interest at the rate of 7 per cent. upon the money actually loaned.
The stars of the Anti-Poverty society did not shine at the Academy of Music last night, and, as a consequence, the audience was much smaller than usual.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 31.--There have been four new cases since yesterday and no deaths. The record stands now: Total cases to date, 191; total deaths, 43; total discharged cured, 90; now sick, 58.

DONALDSVILLE, La., July 31.--Last night a difficulty occurred on the Duran plantation, in Assumption Parish, which resulted in the stabbing and killing of E. Geautreaux by Frank Berthelot. Both were young men in good standing.

Mrs. Fannie Greenwood came from Waterbury, Conn., to this city on Saturday intending to seek admission to a maternity hospital. She was without means, as her husband, who was said to be a worthless fellow, had abandoned her some months ago.

Mary Carroll, a nurse girl employed by a family named Maverick, stopping at the Colonnade Hotel, on Broadway, was taken sick there yesterday.

The rumor that Bishop Loughlin, of Brooklyn, had been summoned to Rome to answer for disobedience to the mandate of the Vatican requiring him to restore the Rev. J.J. Crimmins to the pastorate of the Church of the Immaculate Conception only excites smiles among the priests who know the real facts of the affair.

The steamship Umbria, of the Cunard Line, arrived in port yesterday after a voyage of exceptionally rough weather and fogs. She met with what is called a cyclonic squall and tidal wave early in the week, which carried away part of her bridge and forward hatch, and did other damage by flooding.
Major George Aery, the seventh Ward baker, who was buried on Sunday, his funeral being attended by many German organisations, buried his first wife about 18 years ago with great pomp.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31.--President Phillips, of the Columbian Bank, which suspended payment on Saturday, was seen this afternoon at his handsome home upon the hill, at Walnut-lane and, Hancook-street, in Germantown.
In passing the tug Effort a huge brownish kind of a fish was seen tied to the gunwale. Quilte a crowd was gathered about surveying the fish, which lashed the water angrily with its tail.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 31.--While a party composed of two men and seven young ladies were cut in a sailboat off Prospect, West Halifax to-day, the craft was capsized, and two of the ladies, Bessie Powers, of Boston, and Anna Christian, of Prospect, were drowned.
The icemen held a meeting yesterday afternoon at 52 Union-square to hear reports as to what success the employes of the various companies had met in their struggle for higher wages.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 31.--A local paper reveals another scheme by which it states than Jay Gould and the Missouri Pacific Railway Company have been swindled ont of a large sum of money.

The famous land-locked sea serpent which has long been said to inhabit the depths of Skiff Lake was seen during the past week by at least three reputable eye witnesses disporting itself on the bosom of the lake.
Twenty stakes for the Autumn meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will close on Aug. 15, for which there is $27,500 of added money.

We recently spoke of the tremendous drain of Maine funds for Western speculation. One of our Maine savings banks reports $50,000 of funds drawn out within a short time by men who are going wild on this Western wild-cat business.

The field sports this week around the metropolis will be few. The Staten Island Cricket Club has defaulted to the Manhattans, of Brooklyn, in the match that was arranged for Wednesday.

A lightly clouded sky, from which the untiring sun shone with man-prostrating force, looked down upon New-York yesterday morning at daybreak. The atmosphere was almost stagnant. Hour after hour was rung off from steeple after steeple, and hotter and hotter became the town and the townspeople.

CHICAGO, July 31.--The following crop summary will appear in this week's issue of the Farmers' Review: "The continued drought in many of the States has materially damaged the corn crop. Where local rains have fallen the injury, however, is not as yet serious. The oat crop at this date is turning out light, as was expected.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 31.--Heavy rains and rising rivers have caused some injury to crops and mill dams. The injuries to railways are generally slight. The rice crop to endangered, but the Santee planters have abundant warning.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 31.--Prof. Henry Drummond, of the University of Glasgow, author of "Natural Law in the Spiritual World," lectured this morning in the Hall of Philosophy on "Doubt," drawing a distinction between honest doubt and willful disobedience.
Three so-called mad dogs were killed by policemen in different parts of the city yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 31.--A heavy thunderstorm, accompanied by a wind having a velocity of 36 miles an hour, passed over this city at 5 o'clock this evening, flooding streets and cellars and doing great damage to trees, fences, and small buildings.
There will be a plentiful supply of peaches in our markets this week. The Troth's Early is now in prime condition in all the orchards of the peninsula below Harrington, Del.
Having decided to tolerate gambling, Leadville does so in the most open-handed manner. Some of the best locations on the avenue are given up to the votaries of fickle fortune.

PITTSBURG, July 31.--Mrs. Michael McMullen, of the West End, assaulted Patrick Heiber with a club this afternoon, fracturing his skull and inflicted fatal injuries. Mrs. McMullen has been arrested. She claims that Heiber insulted her. Heiber is still living, but the physicians say he cannot recover.

ALBANY, July 30.--Below are given abstracts of the official semi-annual reports of eight of the New-York City savings banks, as made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department, showing their condition on July 1.

NYACK, N.Y., July 31.--Lightning yesterday struck and destroyed a dwelling belonging to Supervisor William P. Hammond, at Stony Point, and also damaged a house at Haverstraw. A thunder shower this afternoon did considerable damage.

The body of a young man was found yesterday afternoon in the East River at the foot of Pier 27. In his pocket was a telegram directed to A.D. Hannaboy, Kelly's Hotel, Oliver-street, corner of New Bowery.
The Metropolitans, by well placed hits just at the time the Brooklyns made their errors, placed a game to their credit at Ridgewood yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 31.--A severe thunder and hail storm, accompanied by a high wind, this afternoon, did great damage to corn, tobacco, and other crops in South Glastonbury and the neighboring towns. Large trees were blown down and the river road was badly washed, rendering it impassable.

Pranzini has been removed from the Conciergerie to the prison of the condemned, La Grande Roquette; but although he has entered the gloomy portals of that grim establishment he has not abandoned all hope of a reprieve.

A book which promises to have a wide popularity has just been issued, its author being Mr. Henry. T. Finck, a Harvard graduate of the Class of '76. It is on "Romantic Love and Personal Beauty."

The Hon. J.F. Casanova was the victim of one of the most singular accidents we have ever heard of last Monday. He was sitting in his office reading, when he suddenly heard a sharp click and immediately felt something enter his right eye, but felt no pain.
