In October last the Trustees of the Phelps Mission decided to consolidate with the Presbyterian church on East Eighty-fourth-street, in order to advance the best interests of that institution. All of the Trustees agreed to the consolidation except W.E. Dodge Stokes, who brought a suit to have the consolidation declared void. The defendants demurred to his complaint, principally on the...

Lawyer M.H. Reynolds, of Jefferson, went to his Friend Dr. D.B. Fonda's house, in that town, early Sunday afternoon, to help in making out some business papers, and together they worked for several hours.
The Sommerfest of the Deutscher Liederkranz was celebrated last night at Bowery Bay, and the Silver Springs Casino was crowded with about 2,000 people.

Jacob Kolle, a young German carpenter, married a pretty servant girl eight months ago, and quarreled with her shortly afterward because she would not go out to service again. The quarrels because very frequent and bitter, and two weeks ago Mrs. Kolle left her husband and went over to her sister's home, 89 Grand-street, Brooklyn. Since then Kolle has been despondent,

SOURIS, Prince Edward Island, Aug. 8.-- Capt. McDonald, master of the detained fishing schooner J.H.G. Perkins, of North Haven, Me., seems to have had a series of misfortunes very recently. He is the owner of the schooner, but this was his first visit to North Bay in some years.
The Sheriff's jury yesterday evening found that Christian August Kramer, who has been confined in the insane asylum on Ward's Island since April 30, is sane, and he was allowed to go at large.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8.--The Reading Railroad officials say they do not intend to concede the points asked for by the men and will insist rigidly upon the color test examinations. The officials are unanimous in the belief that there will be no strike, and on this point General Manager McLeod said to-day:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8.--William H. Bliss, exUnited States District Attorney, entered suit in the Circuit Court to-day against the United States for fees remaining unpaid. The fees claimed are for services in prosecuting cases in...

"I spent the Fourth of July," said Sergt. McComb, "in a part of Illinois where the farmers hadn't any rain for a month and were praying for it to come. I was in the house of one of these farmers, a strong believer in the efficacy of prayer, and he told me he thought that the Lord was sending them the drought to punish them for their wickedness.

"Manny" Kohnstamm has been in trouble and is out of it, but he is not happy. It seems that "Manny" went with a party of friends to the Brighton Beach races last Friday and speculated heavily. When about to start for home, a man calling himself John Dunn stepped up and asked for $30, which he claimed to have given Kohnstamm to invest in pools for him.

LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 8.--On the authority of President Bennett, of the Erie Telephone Company, It is stated that the differences between the American Bell and Erie Telephone Companies have been satisfactorily adjusted, the American Bell granting the Erie Company a perpetual contract for its Northwestern division, on the basis of a 30 per cent...

BOSTON, Aug. 8.--Councilman W.B.F. Whall, who achieved some distinction a short time ago by his attendance on Queen Kapiolani during that royal personage's visit to this city, covered himself with glory to-night when he clasped the great ten-thousand-dollar belt around Pugilist John L. Sullivan's burly form on the Boston Theatre stage.

BROCKTON, Mass., Aug. 8.--The fight of the lasters' unions against lasting machines has fairly begun, and this city is to be made the battle ground for the conflict. Today the Lasters' Union posted a notice requesting all lasters to keep away from W.L. Douglas's factory, as the men are out on a strike.

NARRAGANSETT, Aug. 8.--In the cozy private dining room in the north tower of the Casino to-day the banquest table was set for 12, and at 2 o'clock in the afternoon a party assembled there that, though few in number, from the character and the purpose of the men composing it, made it probably the most important gathering of its kind that Rhode Island has known since war times.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8.--A syndicate of New-York and Pittsburg capitalists have just closed a transaction by which then become the owners of near1y 100,000 acres of the finest pine forests in the South. The lands are along the northern line of South Carolina and the southern boundary of Georgia, must of it being in the latter State. The price paid was $1,000,000 in...

The total receipts during July from the promenade, carriageways, and railroad of the Brooklyn Bridge, and from rents and interest, as shown by the statement submitted by the Treasurer yesterday were $62,751.35. The expenditures were $45,984.63. This leaves a profit of $16,766 72. This, added to $179,002 41--cash...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--Assistant Secretary Porter is of the opinion that the Halifax dispatches as to an important conference held between Consul-General Phelan, the Canadian Ministers, and Admiral Luce, in command of the United States Atlantic squadron, should be received with many grains of allowance.

Most of the innovations which science in its various branches has made during the past 12 months are to he discussed at Columbia College at sessions covering a week and commencing to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock. The college buildings will be given over to the members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, who are honoring the metropolis with their presence this year.

The Leather Manufacturers' Association of Newark held a long meeting yesterday morning and discussed the present trade difficulties. The result of the meeting was the adoption of the following circular:

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Three men were stabbed, one seriously, during a row in church-street last night. Six arrests have been made. One of the prisoners is a German, one a Frenchman, one a Canadian, two American, and one an Irishman. The most severely injured is James Haley, who has a bad wound in his neck.
Senator C.P. Vedder, of Ellicottville, N. Y., is at the Morton House. Commodore James A. Greer, United States Navy, is at the Gilsey House.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 8.--Charles Greetham, of Castalia, this county, was kicked in the forehead by a vicious horse to-day and killed. The entire front part of his skull was crushed. He leaves a family.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 8.--Chief of Police Charles F. Bollman, who was so terriby assaulted yesterday by Edward McDermott, was in a comfortable condition today, and his physicians say that unless some unexpected complication sets in he will pull out all right.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8.--The body of M. Katkoff was conveyed to this city from Znamensky, a distance of 20 miles, for interment. The coffin was borne the whole distance alternately upon the shoulders of relatives of the dead editor, workmen, students from the university, members of the press, and peasantry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--The President has appointed the following named Postmasters: Ambrose W. Mullen, at De Smet, Dakota, vice J.H. Carroll, resigned; George W. Farrelly, Chanute, Kan., vice J.B. Beatty, resigned; Lee H. Way, Luverne, Minn., vice Charles O. Hawes, resigned; John Goetz, Greencastle, Penn., vice H.P. Prather, resigned.

While Gen. Fairchild was in the East recently he paid a visit to Mount McGregor and entered the cottage where Grant died. He says that it is a structure large enough for the accommodation of a good-sized family. It remains in exactly the condition in which it was when Gen. Grant died. Even the clock stands there, with...

There was a large crowd at Brighton Beach yesterday, and the racing was good, although disastrous to favorites. The weather was fine and the track in excellent condition. The various races were run with the following results:

A.P. George went to Police Headquarters a few days ago and stated that the death of Milton Dunn in Watson's clothing store, 813 Broadstreet, Newark, on June 10, was not a case of suicide, but that Dunn was murdered by Clarence Watson, a son of the proprietor of the store. Young Watson is now in Europe.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 8.--Judge David R. Murray, of Cloverport, is in the city to-day in the interest of persons who have discovered a fine vein of cannel coal.
The New-Haven Cricket Club sent an eleven to Livingston, Staten Island, yesterday, where the Captain of the Staten Island Cricket Club had arranged a good eleven to meet them.

STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Jay Gould was born within 15 miles of this village, and when it was noised around that George Gould was here, and he was going to New-York on the night train last evening, the entire population turned out to see him off.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 8.--A.B.F. Veal was acquitted by the Coroner's jury to-day, and the killing of Charles S. Horne will have to be recorded as an accident. Before the jury the story of the killing was briefly stated by John E. McClellan, who said: "I arrived in Atlanta from Stone Mountain Saturday afternoon.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Recent public events have drawn the attention of the people and the press to the Grand Army of the Republic. The country is seriously inquiring how it is possible that an organized body of veteran...
COLUMBIA, Penn., Aug. 8.--There is in the possession of a physician of this county a portion of a woman's skull which was plowed up in a field near the foot of the Chickies Hills many years ago.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8.--William Samson and James Herron, employes of the Chartiers Valley Natural Gas Company, were suffocated by escaping has this afternoon while repairing a regulator under Chartiers-street, in Allegheny City. The regulator is in a small subterranean apartment, six feet below the street.

LOCK HAVEN, Penn., Aug. 8.--Intelligence was received here this evening that an old man and his wife named Culby were murdered in their home on the mountains south of this city last night. The motive for the crime is supposed to have been robbery.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 8.--It was announced in financial circles to-day that a regular Stock Exchange will be opened here in September by members of the present Bolsa Mercantil, and that operations will embrace dealings in Government securities, the foreign and domestic debt of the country, all Mexican railway shares and bonds, and stocks of local corporations.

It is not easy to give satisfaction in a theological professorship. In Congregational institutions this is being proved on both sides of the Atlantic. At Andover the Professors have been in peril because of their advanced thought, and one has been doposed for his "new theology."

Mary Watson, a domestic employed at the Hotel Normandie, was taken to the New-York Hospital Sunday night suffering from typhoid fever. How she contracted the disease has not been ascertained. The manager of the hotel said yesterday that the girl complained of sickness on Sunday, and during the evening became so ill that an ambulance was called. Her room at the hotel has been fumigated and disinfected.

I have not seen an account given publicly of the scene which led to the sudden departure of Holkar from London. The disagreement arose, or rather reached its climax, before the laying of the foundation stone of the Imperial Institute, and sprang out of a question of precedence.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--The four boodlers who were merely fined appeared in court this morning for sentence. Action, however, was deferred until Thursday, except in the case of Commissioner Geils. He was anxious to have the matter closed at once.

The New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad runs into Paterson, N.J., below grade, and a portion of the cut is occupied by a siding in which cars are kept from which local passenger trains are made up. Conductor Duffield, one of the oldest conductors on the road, yesterday morning made up the 5:37 train.

Daniel Kerns, a liquor dealer at Twenty-ninth street and Seventh-avenue, who, on Friday, at the Jefferson Market Police Court accused Policeman Martin Fay, of Capt. Williams's command, of knocking him down in front of his store on July 24 and so injuring him as to confine him to his bed, withdrew his complaint yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 8.--The Massachusetts Commission on contagious diseases among domestic animals sent to-day to the Board of Health of this city the following:

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 8.--The steamer Zealandia, from Australia and Honolulu, brings Honolulu advices to July 30. Nothing of a startling nature has occurred since the signing of the Constitution by King Kalakaua and the departure of ex-Premier Gibson for the United States.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 8.--To-day's train from the East brought United States Senator John Sherman, of Ohio; Gen. J.S. Robinson, Secretary of State of Ohio; Col. Charles H. Grosvenor, member of Congress; Amos Townsend, ex-member of Congress, and Judge A. Thompson, or Portsmouth, Ohio.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8.--Mrs. Brennan, of this city, and her 10-year-old son were drowned at St. Helen's Island to-day. The boy was bathing in the river and was being swept away by the strong ourrent, when the mother went to his rescue and was herself carried away.
A fire broke out at 6:30 o'clock last evening on the third floor at 400 Broome-street, which, with the second floor, is occupied by the Hecht Novelty Company, manufacturers of clasps, buckles,
PARIS, Aug. 8.--Baron Billing, late French Ambassador to Sweden, while visiting friends in Alsace, was expelled from the province.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 8.--A collision occurred to-day one mile from this city between a switch engine and a passenger train of the Eastern Tennessee Railway. The engineer, John Burgees, saw the engine, but the air brakes were defective, and the speed of the train...

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 8.--Nine new cases of fever have been reported by the Board of Health since yesterday. There have been no deaths. The last 150 cases have been nearly all children, with less than 2 per cent. of mortality, and unless this is understood the bulletins of the Board of Health convey a wrong impression.
Mme. de Valsayre, a well known Parisian lady, has addressed the following petition to the French Chamber of Deputies:

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 8.--The Virginia campaign has fairly opened. The recent Democratic convention made up the issues upon which that party proposed to conduct the fight. To-morrow Mahone's State Republican Committee will meet in Petersburg and determine upon the policy that side is to pursue.

On the matter of "Food and Feeding" for dogs Dr. Stables has spoken words of gold. He permits you to fill your pets from the table; but he does not permit you to stuff them with "dainties and sweets."

WINCHESTER, Va, Aug. 8.--The remains of the widow of Col. Benjamin Edward Stiles, of Savannah, Ga., were brought here to-day and buried in the same grave with those of her husband, in accordance with a request made before her death. She died on Friday at Livingston, Nelson County, Va. Col. Stiles, aged 28 years, fell at the head of...

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Fires and overcoats were necessities in the Catskill Mountains this morning. The atmosphere to-day has been intensely clear, and the views obtained by the naked eye from high peaks of the Hudson River Valley were the finest in many years.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8.--Three French Canadians, Gauthier and Lalonde and one whose name is unknown, were drowned while bathing in the Back River yesterday.

Prince Devanwongse and the young nephews, sons of the King, who are doing the city with him, got some instruction and a good deal of pleasure out of yesterday. Then opened the day with a visit to the county institutions. Commissioners H.H. Porter, John T. Agnew, Consul-General Smith, and Chief Engineer Haswell served as the escorting party.

Gold medals have been presented to Lorenzo Pinaglia, John McLain, and William Scadden, for their services in rescuing men from the Gould and Curry fire, as a well-deserved tribute to individual bravery. These men faced the deadly gas and smoke of the burning mine at a time when stout hearts and iron nerves quailed at the dangers presented.
Below will be found details of a somewhat novel device by which it is expected a large sum will be raised toward erecting a worthy memorial to Gen. Grant:
VIENNA, Aug. 8.--The price of wheat in the Vienna market fell to a lower point on Saturday than known in 23 years, a metrical centner selling at 7 florins.

When Mr. Lincoln heard of the scattering of the Confederates under Hood by Gen. Thomas he was reminded of the following anecdote: "Out in Lower Illinois, in a little village, there was a butcher named Sykes, who had a large, wicked, mischievous bulldog, which was regarded as a town nuisance.

The window of the furnishing goods store of James Gemminani, at 173 Prince-street, was broken in early Sunday morning, and 400 pairs of socks, valued at $125, were stolen. When the robbery was reported, Capt. McDonnell, of the Eight Precinct, remembered that while going through Prince-street on his...

CHARLESTON, S.C. Aug. 8.--A representative meeting of professional and business men to-day adopted unanimously a series of resolutions expressing the desire that the President and Mrs. Cleveland should visit Charleston, and requesting the City Council to extend an invitation to them, and obtain, if practicable, an early acceptance.

The injunction granted by Judge Donohue on July 12 against the congregation of the Gates of Hope restraining them from taking action against Rabbi Browne was vacated yesterday by consent of both parties. Mr. Simpson, of the counsel for the complainant, said the action...

Six races are on the programme to be run at Monmouth Park to-day, including two stake events--the Camden Stakes, for 2-year-olds, at three-quarters of a mile, and the Eatontown Stakes at a mile--and both have a good lot of entries.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 8.--Manager Caylor, of the Metropolitan, has signed Edward Hogan, the right fielder of the Nashville Club. It is rumored that he will take Roseman's place. He is expected to play in the game here on Wednesday.

Justice Massey, of Brooklyn, received a letter yesterday from Mrs. Leontine Lake, of 110 Twelfth-street, asking that her husband, Edward Lake, be bound over to keep the peace and to support her while she is suffering from injuries received at his hands on Saturday.
SARATOGA, Aug. 8.--This was the fifth extra day of the race meeting here. The attendance was good for an extra day, the weather was magnificent, and the track fast. The races resulted as follows:
The annual general meeting of the subscribers to the National Dog Show was held at Birmingham yesterday, Lord Aylesford presiding.

Encouraged by the wonderful success which has attended the planting of the cinchona tree in India, the Indian Government has just determined to make a similar experiment by undertaking the cultivation of the ipecacuanha plant.

PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y., Ang. 8.--The body of John P. Hutchinson was found on the Mount Sinai beach last night. One arm and the head were gone. The body was identified by his brother-in-law by the clothing. Hutchinson was drowned last January by the capaizing of a boat while going from Port Jefferson to Stratford Light. The boat was found at the time.

Everybody at Northport, Long Island, is talking about a "faith cure" effected in the case of Miss Carrie Webb, who has been visiting her brother, the Rev. Thomas M. Webb, Pastor of the Northport church. She is a member of the Hanson-Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, and a teacher in the Sunday school there.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 8.--George Beckel, a painter, of 219 Dixwell-avenue, fell headlong 40 feet to the sidewalk from a ladder staging on the Street Building, at State and Chapel streets, this afternoon. He struck on the side of his head and his shoulder, and was picked up nearly dead. He was taken to the hospital, and died soon afterward.

In examining candidates for the Wesleyan ministry this year at Richmond, England, 27 out of 52 were rejected, and three of the rest were so alarmed that they ran away rather than run tho risk of rejection. We should be glad to know of any young man being enough afraid of an ordaining council not to venture before it.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8.--Clear skies and a heavy northwest wind prevailed here all day. There were many visitors at the Casino, where George Riddie gave some excellent readings at noon. The other events included some brilliant polo games and a well attended hop at the Casino to-night.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Aug. 8.--Burlington County is getting considerably excited over the mystery surrounding the death of the young woman whose body was found in the woods near here two weeks ago.
John W. Mackay, the "Bonanza King," who arrived from Europe by the Servia on Sunday, attended strictly to his own business yesterday and intimated indirectly that others should do the same.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--It is reported that a complete change in the traffic departments of the Union Pacific Railway is about to be made. General Passenger Agent J.W. Moore and General Ticket Agent C.S. Stebbins, it is said, will step down and out, and the General Western Freight Agent,

About two weeks ago a well-dressed white man and a Chinaman visited the Adams Express office in Newark and inquired for three barrels marked "flour" which had been received at the office. The visitors examined the barrels and left the office. The white man returned alone shortly afterward and had the barrels removed. It has been learned within the past few days that the barrels contained...
The Baltimore Sun is disposed to shield HIGGINS, THOMAS, and RASIN against the accusations of the Baltimore Reform Associations.

Three very weary and disgusted citizens of Cincinnati trudged out of Wall-street last evening. They are big men at home, these citizens of Cincinnati. But New-York isn't exactly like Cincinnati, so these good men agree. For this lesson, learned very thoroughly, they are indebted particularly to Mr. Henry S. Ives.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug, 8.--Some very exciting and well played polo games were witnessed on the polo grounds this afternoon in the presence of many of the leading cottagers. All the games were hotly contested, and, judging from the heated discussion which took place between the players, it was surmised that a private bet of considerable magnitude was settled at the Casino during the evening.
ALBANY, Aug. 8.--Jonathan Robie, the defaulting Treasurer of the Bath Soldiers' Home, to-day forwarded his resignation as Trustee to Gov. Hill, who returned to the Executive Mansion to-night.

John Gilges, a deck hand on the steamer Pleasant Valley, was brought before the Jefferson Market police Court yesterday charged with abducting the 17-year-old daughter of John Wagner on July 14. Gilges swore that he did know where the girl was, and wanted Wagner to apologize to him for annoying him.

LONDON, Aug. 8.--In the House of Commons Mr. W.H. Smith announced that the Government declined to propose that Parliament guarantee any loan in aid of colonization schemes. He did not see that any good would be obtained by inviting the colonial Governments to co-operate in raising a colonization fund.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Aug. 8.--Gen. A.W. Doniphan died at 9:45 to-night at his home in Richmond after an illness of about two months. A severe cold contracted last May developed into congestion of the bowels and caused his death. His relatives from this city and a number of friends from different parts of the State had been with him for several days.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 8.--William E. Goodwin was committed this morning for a hearing, charged with shooting Charles Hipkins with intent to kill. Charles Hipkins, a laborer, was taken to the Maryland University Hospital at 12, o'clock last night suffering from a wound...

William Kelly, a contractor, who is doing repairs upon Thirty-eighth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, and Hugo Krammer, a baker, who is doing business on that block, went before Justice Duffy yesterday. Krammer complained that when he tried to get his wagon to his store for his bread the contractor would not let him, saying that the street was closed al both ends.

William C. Schramm, an insane man, who way arrested on Broadway, Brooklyn, Saturday night, when he proclaimed that he was King of the United States, created a disturbance in Justice Naeher's court yesterday. He kept quiet until he in some way obtained possession of a padlock, when he attacked Officer Miller. A fierce tussle followed, but with the assistance of three other officers the man was secured. He was afterward sent to Flatbush Asylum.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 8.--Register Porter, of the United States Land Office at Des Moines, has been instructed by Land Commissioner Sparks to open for entry the 26,000 acres of land unearned by the St. Paul and Sioux City Road, and which, under the act of the Iowa Legislature, were receded to the General Government last January.

Edward Roemer, a builder, obtained from William J. Merritt, architect and builder, of 152 and 154 West One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, loans amounting to $6,390 on property which he owned at One Hundred and Twelfth and One Hundred and Thirteenth streets and Manhattan-avenue, on his representation that there were no judgments against him on which this property might be levied upon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8.--The State Board of Agriculture give estimates based upon 1,000 reports from various parts of the State. These reports indicate that the wheat crop will probably reach 31,938,037 bushels, falling short of last year's product about 8,000,000 bushels.

BISMARCK, Dakota., Aug. 8.--Ex-City Treasurer Reed returned to the city yesterday and is completing arrangement for the payment of his shortage. He has been warmly welcomed by his friends, who said all along that he would return.

What is expected to be the largest meeting of the American Bar Association ever held will take place at Putnam's Music Hall, Saratoga, on Aug. 17, 18, and 19. On Wednesday morning, Aug. 17, Thomas J. Semmes, of NewYork, will deliver the President's addrees, officers will be elected, and the report made last...
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8.--The Planters' Monthly, of Honolulu, estimates the sugar crop of 1887 at between 90,000 and 100,000 tons, as against 108,000 tons last year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8.--The official majority of Buckner over Bradley in 99 counties heard from is 17,039. The remaining counties are Adair, Boyd, Bracken, Breathist, Daviess. Floyd, Harlan, Jackson, Jessamine, Leslie, Letcher, Lawerence, Magoffin, Morgan, Owsley, Perry, Pike. Trigg, Union, and Wolfe. The estimated total majority is 17,500. These 20 counties, not yet officialy reported, gave Cleveland a majoriry of 4,347.

John Sweeney, a laborer, and his wife Ellen had a drunken quarral last night in their rooms at 581 Grove-street, Jersey City. The couple made considerable noise, and finally the other inmates of the house sent for the police.

A number of houses reported recently by one of the New-York papers to be in bad sanitary condition have been inspected by order of President Bayles, of the Health Department. Dr. Roger S. Tracy, the Chief Sanitary Inspector, submitted a detailed report yesterday on each of these houses.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 8.--Frederick A.S. Perry entered the Day office this morning and fired two shots at E.C. Whittlesey, the business manager. One shot took effect in the left breast and one in the left side, and it is feared Mr. Whittlesey cannot recover.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8.--The remains of Mrs. James P. Scott, who died in London on July 20, arrived here to-day in the steamer British Kind, accompanied by Mr. Scott and his child. The body was taken to the late residence of the decreased, where the funeral services will be held to-morrow.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 8.--A wall six feet high at the edge of the sidewalk on Central-avenue, at the cathedral property, was pushed over upon the sidewalk to-day by a quantity of sand piled against it. Three persons passing at the time were struck by the falling wall and seriously injured. They were B.W. Young, Fred Wessell, and Josie Corcoran. The last named will probably die.
Neither Henry George nor Edward McGlynn nor John McMackin turned up last night at Webster Hall to discuss with the Socialists the Socialistic schism in the United Labor Party. Mr. George wrote:

In answer to a correspondent who asks "Shall I say $1,000 was raised or $1,000 were raised?" the Examiner says, "Both forms are in good usage and justifiable." The Gospel Age would say that if $1,000 "were" or "was" raised for a good object the verbs are quite a matter of indifference. The officers of any of our societies certainly will not care about the grammatical announcement if the money only reaches their treasury.

Our Ogdensburg letter, published yesterday, throws a good deal of light on the methods by which a certain class of politicians in this State work for their personal ends and manage to override the people to compass them. Mr. ERWIN, of St. Lawrence County, while holding the important position of Chairman of the Ways and Means...

A syndicate of prudential insurance companies is expected to be engaged in active business within two months, each starting with a paid-up capital of $200,000 and a company being placed in each of five cities--New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, and St. Louis.
A story is told in club circles of the losses suffered by two of the brethren in an up-town church congregation. One of them had lost his wife, the other a boat.

James Sweeney, the engineer of the "wildcat" locomotive which caused the accident on the Greenwood Lake Railroad at Montclair, and caused the death of the engineer and fireman of a passenger train, was taken to Newark yesterday morning from Port Jervis, N.Y., where he resided, and placed under arrest.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 8.--The Hertogen forest between Verviers and the German frontier is ablaze. The fire extends over an area of several kilometers.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 8.--William J. Gaffey and one or two friends went bathing in Lake Whitney this afternoon. They had been drinking, and Gaffey and one of his friends got to a how small flat-bottomed boat and tried without submerging it.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 8.--The killing of James Scott by George Tarroll, the Japanese, yesterday at Mount Holly has created intense excitetment throughout this section of the country. Tarroll has not been captured, but it is stated here to-day that unless he gives himself up to the authorities to-morrow a posse of men...

The Socialists are concentrating their efforts on an attack upon Henry George and his pet land theory, and they expect, by holding him and his theories up to ridicule, to crush him and gain control of the Labor Party.

Property owners on West Forty-eighthstreet, between Broadway and Eighth-avenue, have for the last three weeks been much interested in the curious proceedings of eight men, apparently laborers, who frequented the street and occasionally pulled up paving stones and afterward thumped them down again.

The time was rapidly approaching--in Decembar, 1860--when the Ohio House of Representatives, of which I had been chosen Speaker, was to begin its session. Every day the threatening attitude of the South became more alarming, and the wisest heads began to fear that armed collision between the North and the South was inevitable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--The resignation of First Lieut. F.J.A. Darr, Twelfth Infantry, has been accepted by the president to take effect Sept. 1, and he has boen granted leave until that date. Capt. D.J. Young, Ordnance Storekeeper, has been relieved from duty at the Watervliet Arsenal, NewYork, and ordered to duty at the Watertown Arsenal, Massachusetts. Capt. Henry P. Perrine...

PITTSBURG, Aug. 8.--The 200 employes at Oliver Roberts' wire mill who struck six weeks ago for pay for tonnage work, instead of by the day, will resume work to-morrow at the company's terms. The firm had decided to import workmen from NewYork, but the action of the strikers will render this unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--Bids were opened at noon to-day in the office of the Secretary of the Navy for the construction of the cruisers last provided for by Congress, namely: The Newark, No. 1, 4,000 tons displacement; cruisers Nos. 4 and 5, 4,000 tons each, and gunboats Nos. 3 and 4. 1,700 tons displacement each.
NYACK, N.Y., Aug 8.--Frost appeared in two or three places in the interior of Rockland County this morning. Light overcoats were necessary in driving last night.

MASCONOMO HOUSE, MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 8.--Here, where the cool green woods be, here where there is no roof save the dome of the azure measureless, and no walls but the far wide walls of the world, shall this day be done a play of him who for all place and for all time did write. The noon is three hours gone. The maples nod to odorous winds that whisper gently.

Capt. Gastlin went before Justice Duffy, at Jefferson Market, yesterday, with Robert Sinkler, ex-steward of the Guyandotte. He is a tall, handsome colored man, and it was supposed that he could identify Mooney, the man who set fire to the steamer The Queen, as the person who put the infernal machine on board the Guyandotte last Winter.

BOSTON, Aug. 8.--Up rose the sun and up rose the yachtsmen of the New-York Yacht Club squadron in Vineyard Haven this morning. A keen eye cast to windward swept a vista of curling white flashes upon an expanse of blue.

Col. John H. Cochrane, details of whose disappearance from his home, at Newark, were published yesterday, is again with his family. He started for Washington, as was stated, in the expectation of getting a department clerkship, but says he was robbed on the way and met with other mishaps, so he did not get beyond Philadelphia. The loss and disappointment are said to have made him somewhat irresponsible. Friends found him at Philadelphia.

Mr. Henry Watterson, of the Louisville Courier-Journal, having accepted an invitation from the New-York Press Club, will attend an informal reception in the rooms of the club, 120 Nassau-street, to-morrow afternoon at 3 o'clock. A large attendance of members to greet the Kentucky journalist is desired.

Little Henry S. Ives still continues big enough to menace the whole stock market. A new position that he suddenly took yesterday, as told elsewhere in THE TIMES'S columns, raised a lively rumpus in some quarters and depressed a host of hopeful bulls.
With King KALAKAUA'S signing of the reform Constitution the resolution in the Sandwich Islands has probably come to an end.

Gen. John Newton went to Saratoga yesterday by order of his physician. Charles Jullien and Henry Perrier, French engineers, are inspecting the work on the new aqueduct.

Justice Duffy had disposed of a score of excise cases at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday when one of the defendants, Moses Fletcher, who had been put up on the tiers in the prison and was brought down to be bailed out, told him that the keepers were blackmailing the prisoners.

Great writers, as well as minor mortals, are liable to errors of fact, which, however, do not detract from their genius. Victor Hugo was responsible for many mistakes in his works; but the recent publication, "Choses Vues," is a proof that he could be as correct as a special Commissioner or a painstaking statistician when he liked.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8.--Counsel for the Pullman Palace Car Company this morning filed in the United States Circuit Court a copy of the record of the suit begun in the Dauphin County Court to recover taxes on the company's property in Pennsylvania.

William Purbs, an apprentice boy in the office of the New-Yorker Zeitung, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of having set the numerous recent fires in the building on Frankfortstreet occupied by his employers. Purbs, who was generally known as "Fritz," is 18 years old, and did not seem to be frightened when he was led away to Police Headquarters.
The following circular has been issued by M. Leon Somzee, President of the Executive Committee of the "Great International Competition of Sciences and Industry," to be held next year:

The following circular has been issued by M. Leon Somzee, President of the Executive Committee of the "Great International Competition of Sciences and Industry," to be held next year:

Alexander R. Murray, 68 years old, committed suicide last evening at his residence, 211 West Thirteenth-street, by stabbing himself in the abdomen with a carving knife. He had been a patternmaker and was in easy circumstances.

ALBERT LEA, Minn., Aug. 8.--An investigation of the natural gas discovered a few miles west of here shows that three wells on differen, farms, lately sunk, produced a flow of gas that was immense in volume and which forced itself into the air a distance of from 10 to 50 feet making a roaring that was heard nearly a half mile.
NOGALES, Arizona, Aug. 1.--One of the events of September will be the presentation to Gen. Nelson A. Miles of a gold sword by his admirers in Arizona.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8.--The tobacco trade of this city held a meeting to-night, and sent out circulars to the tobacco men in all the other markets of the State, requesting them to co-operate with them in signing a petition to President Cleveland, asking, in view of statistician Dodge's recent tobacco report, that he be removed from his position in the Department of Agriculture.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--The W.O. Tyler Paper Company, doing business at 169 Adamsstreet, failed to-day with liabilities estimated at $35,000. The nominal assets are reported to about equal the liabilities, but as a large proportion of the assets consists of book debts and doubtful paper, the creditors will probably be glad to settle at 50 to 60 cents on the dollar.

Merit is the source of fashion. Some things may attain a temporary popularity, but unless they possess merit their life is brief. This is true of bonnets, dresses, and costumes. It is still truer of things far more important.

The trades unionists, who are largely in the majoirty, want a blue flag and detest the red banner. They passed a resolution that the blue flag...

The Brushmakers' International Union of America met in convention at noon yesterday at Odd Fellows' Hall, 327 Bowery, delegates being present from the unions in New-York, Brooklyn, Jersey City, Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Portland. Chicago, and other important cities of the Union, as well as Montreal, Canada.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 9.--The City Council has adopted resolutions inviting the President and Mrs. Cleveland to visit Charleston as the guests of the city.
The Rev. Father McHale, who had recently been doing work in the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, Brooklyn, and who died on Monday, will be buried to-day in the Holy Cross Cemetery, at Flatbush.

Columbia College presented a somewhat unusual aspect yesterday in the wealth of information to be found on its external walls. In all directions were signs showing visitors where agriculture, entomology, geography, paleontology, and various other ologies are to be discussed to-day, and indicating the precise room by the conventional hand.
The Monmouth Park Association, in addition to the six races to be run to-morrow, announce an extra race--a handicap sweepstakes, for 3-year-olds and upward, at a mile and a quarter.
Dockstader's Minstrels will reopen their hall in this city Sept. 5.

"I have no complaint to make against the newspapers for what they say about me so long as they confine themselves to the truth," remarked ex-Senator John C. Jacobs to a TIMES reporter yesterday, "but there have been several statements printed of late that are entirely destitute of foundation.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 9.--Alexander Theimer, a German, 23 years old, committed suicide to-day by taking an overdose of opium. His offer of marriage had been refused by a young woman with whom he was in love and he became desperate in consequence. When found he was sleeping under the effects of the drug and it was impossible to revive him.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 9.--The Railroad Commissioners to-day rendered a decision in the mileage ticket case against the Boston and Maine Railroad.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9.--The stockholders of five Gogebic iron mines, known as the Burton properties, to-day transferred them to the Bessemer Consolidated Iron Company, of NewYork, of which ex-Senator Stephen W. Dorsey was elected President, Jesse R. Grant Secretary, and ...

The Attorney-General is preparing for another move against the combination which for years has controlled the Quarantine Service of this port and used its revenues as a political corruption fund. Proceedings are to be instituted for the removal of Health Officer SMITH on a charge ...

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--The Directors of the Boston Consolidated Street Railway Company to-day voted to unite with the West End Street Railway Company upon the latter's terms, which are to exchange its preferred 8 per cent. stock for the stock of the Boston Consolidated Street Railway Company in the proportion of one and fifty-three sixty-eighth shares of said preferred stock for each share of the stock of the Boston Consolidated Street Railway Company.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 9.--News has been received that at Indianola to-day a negro named Aleck Bell had a quarrel with a white man. The negro used vile language, and Robert Lowry, a nephew of Gov. Lowry, disliking the language, brought out a Winchester rifle and shot the negro through the lung, inflicting a mortal wound. Lowry was not arrested.

The larceny of a two-hundred-and-fiftydollar sealskin sacque was the charge on which William F. George, who claims to be the proprietor of a dressmaking and dresscutting establishment at 387 Sixth-avenue, was arrested yesterday and arraigned before Justice Duffy, at the Jefferson Market Police Court.

Capt. Alexander S. Williams has attained the reward long deserved by his services as the city's most stalwart and energetic guardian of the peace and of the law. For yesterday the Police Board decided to promote him and Capt. Peter Conlin to the rank of Inspector. More popular action could not have been taken, and last evening the numberless friends of both Captains heaped up the congratulations until the recipients could hardly see over them.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug.9.--The mangled remains of Addison Stewart, of Georgetown, N.Y., were found on the railroad track at Cortland this morning. He had been struck by a train during the night.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 9.--Baltimore and Ohio stock took the biggest tumble to-day that it has known for years. It went to $147 50, at which figure 11 shares were sold. In a few minutes, however, 150 shares went at $148, and soon afterward 60 more shares sent the price to $150.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Aug. 9.--An attempt was made yesterday to wreck the east-bound train on the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Road, near Iowa City.
Secretary Lawrence, of the Coney Island Jockey Club, announces the following arrangement for the stake races and fixed handicaps to be run at the Sheepshead Bay meeting this Fall:

PARIS, Aug. 9.--Le Paris announces that the English Government has requested of M. Flourens, Minister of Foreign Affairs, that France name a date for the evacuation by France of the New-Hebrides, and that M. Flourens in reply declined to do so until France shall be informed of the nature of England's policy in regard to Egypt and as to the neutralization of the Suez Canal.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9.--Contractor L.M. Shute, of this city, and those interested with him are preparing to continue the work of constructing the Ontario Pacific Railroad.

The seizure of the fishing boat Gold Dust by the Dominion cruiser Intrepid at Fair Haven, Deer Island, brings up anew the question that arose last year in the case of the American boats warned away from St. Andrews by the cruiser Middleton. In that case, as in the present, the boats concerned...

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Aug. 9.--The murderers of the Nehrwein woman have not yet been found. The people living in the vicinity of the tragedy are now satisfied that the girl whose decomposed body was found in the pines near Atsion, on the New-Jersey Southern Railroad, did not die from exposure. It is asserted that she was the victim of foul play, and was not only killed, but assaulted and robbed.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 9.--The freshet which flooded Augusta 10 days ago, and which has been hurrying down the river for over a week, reached the rice plantations along the lower waters of the Savannah yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--Mr. Henry Hastings, the well known ship owner and one of Boston's prominent merchants, died at his residence, in West Medford, this forenoon. He was born in Townsend, Mass., Sept. 2, 1818, and was the son of Col. Walter Hastings and Roxanna Warren, cousin of Gen. Joseph Warren, of Revolutionary fame.
Chicago, Burlington and Quincy is likely to learn something about bear target practice very soon.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Aug. 9.--The monument of the Fifth Connecticut Regiment was dedicated this morning by about 90 survivors with appropriate ceremonies. The stone is of polished granite, appropriately inscribed and stands on Culp's Hill, a short distance from Spangler's Spring. The rest of the day was spent in visiting the field, and in the evening a reception was held by the regiment at its headquarters. The visitors will leave to-morrow morning.
Six athletic young men stood stripped and in line on the New-York Athletic Club's boathouse float, on the Harlem River, at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street, yesterday afternoon.

Prince Devawongse, his nephews and cousins, and all the royal Siamese are to say their final farewell to New-York this morning, when they will go up the Hudson to West Point on the Albany day boat. After the day at West Point they will go directly to Niagara, and thence to Vancouver by the Canadian Pacific route.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--First Lieut. Robert W. Dowdy, Seventeenth Infantry, is granted two months' extension of leave. Col. Edwin F. Townsend, Twelfth Infantry, is detailed to attend the encampment of the Dakota militia from Sept. 1 to 6 at Huron, Dakota. The detail of Second Lieut. Harry Freeland, Third Infantry, for instruction at Fort Leavenworth is revoked, and Second Lieut. Erneste V. Smith, Third Infantry, is detailed in his stead.

The Brushmakers' International Union closed up the business of its annual session yesterday and adjourned about 5 o'clock.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 9.--Alexander Themeier, a good-looking and well educated German, aged 23, committed suicide at an early hour this morning by swallowing a large dose of opium.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 9.--Suit was entered today in the United States Circuit Court by the West Virginia, Central and Pittsburg Railroad Company against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, claiming $50,000 damages for violation of contract. The plaintiff claims that a contract was made in 1881 with the defendant to transport coal in plaintiff's own cars from Piedmont to Baltimore.
MANASQUAN, N.J., Aug. 9.--The first of a series of regattas was sailed on the Manasquan River this afternoon by the Manasquan Point Pleasant Yacht Club.

VIENNA, Aug. 9.--M. Natchevitch, the Bulgarian Foreign Minister, accompanied by Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha and retnue, has started for Bulgaria. It is officially announced that Prince Ferdinand has been permitted to retire from the Austrian Army.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 9.--Last Thursday's vote was officially counted yesterday. Up to to-night official returns have been received by the Gazette from 132 counties.
LONDON, Aug. 10.--The steamship Rosse, (Br.,) sld. from River Plate for New-York Aug. 5.

The Long Island Live Stock Association having increased its capital stock from $12,000 to $20,000, Austin Corbin and J. Rogers Maxwell have subscribed for 40 shares. The association grounds are situated at Huntington, and extensive improvements are being made, including stables for horses, sheds for cattle, and a grand stand. It is the intention to hold a semi-annual live stock fair, with trotting and running races, but no betting.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--The big dining rooms on the second floor of the Parker House look more like manufacturing establishments than like banquet halls. The famous dining hall, No. 12, is crowded with electric motors in operation.

It isn't Sing Sing. It's Fifth-avenue. Henry S. Ives is smiling some more. He has all the money he wants, and the creditors who pursued him yesterday morning were listening to him as he dictated terms of his own last night.

Judge O'Gorman, of the Superior Court, demolislied yesterday the claim of Sydney F. Shelbourne, President of the New-York Electric Lines Company, to the exclusive right to lay electrical conduits under the city's streets.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9.--While other cities are contented with one Mayor, St. Louis enjoys the distinction of having three heads to her municipal Government. D.R. Francis was elected Mayor, but the laws set forth that during his absence from the city G.W. Allen, President of ...
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 9--The new President of the Hartford and Connecticut Western Railroad, James W. Husted, of NewYork, will meet the stockholders here for the first time on Tuesday, Aug. 16.
ROME, Aug. 9.--Signor Bove, the explorer, who was an associate of Nordenskjold in the latter's arctic expedition, has committed suicide at Verona by firing a bullet into his brain.

SARATOGA, Aug. 9.--The pleasant weather and a very attractive programme resulted in bringing together the largest crowd of the season here to-day, and the spectators had the privilege of seeing a fine lot of racing.
The following weights to be carried in two of the stake events at the Cedarhurst Fall meeting were yesterday announced:
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 9.--The deed of sale of all the Nickel Plate Railway's property between Buffalo and Chicago was filed here for record to-day.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 9.--Mahone's Republican State Committee met here at a late hour to-night, and from present prospects will not dispose of the work for which they were called until 3 or 4 o'clock in the morning. The meeting is quite well attended.

Miss Mary Frances Parker, daughter of Cortlandt Parker, of Newark, who displayed great heroism about three weeks ago in rescuing a drowning woman at Perth Amboy, has been rewarded for her act with a large gold medal, presented by the NewYork Life-Saving and Benevolent Association. The medal bears the name of the society and an appropriate inscription giving lady's name and reciting the deed of bravery.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 9.--A conflict has arisen between the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the other trunk lines regarding the interpretation of the Inter-State Commerce act. Since the expiration of the suspension of the long and short-haul clause granted to the transcontinental lines an arrangement has been ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--A large number of moonlight excursionists had a narrow escape from drowning last night. The steamer Ivanhoe and the schooner Scotia came into collision in the river just as the excursion boat was leaving on its evening trip on the lake.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 9.--Gov. Green to-day appointed J. Watts Kearney, a son of Phil Kearney, Inspector-General of the National Guard of NewJersey to till the vacancy caused by the resignation of Gen. Willoughby Weston.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, Aug. 9.--A Nogales special to the Democrat says: "The sloop Sara, 18 tons register, owned and commanded by Abraham Bajarim, left Mulejo July 25, loaded with 20 tons of tan bark, consigned to Selender Vandetter.

COLUBIA, S.C., Aug. 9.--Reports of 271 township correspondents to the State Department of Agriculture, covering every county, show that on Aug. 1 cotton, which is two or three weeks earlier than last year, had a full bottom crop, and if the season continues ...
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 9.--Mother Caroline, of Milwaukee, was to-day elected Mother Superior of the Sisters of Notre Dame at their sexennial convention.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 9.--A.J. Alexander, proprietor of the Woodburn Stock Farm, has sold to G.W.Beverly, of Providence, R.I., the fine bay yearling stallion Arapahoe, by Lord Russell, full brother to Maud S., dam Tweedle, by Woodburn Mambrino. The price was better than $2,000.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 9. --Mayor Sutton, 19 Councilmen, and the Street Commissioner were arrested this morning on complaint of citizens residing in the Third and Sixth Wards for failing to keep the streets in those wards in order and for allowing stagnant water to accumulate, from which foul smells arise, ...

Glenn, the author of the measure, also received copies of the resolutions. Tonight he was asked what he thought of the resolutions, and he replied:

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Naylor, who built the Berachah Mission at 463 West Thirtysecond-street, with the aid of the Hon. John H. Starin, Charles E. Crowell, and W.M . Onderdonk, gave a free excursion yesterday to Alpine Grove, on the Hudson, for the mothers, children, and old and young men of "Hell's Kitchen."

Persons who went to Rockaway Beach by train or boat yesterday afternoon saw a big inflated balloon anchored on the Jamaica Bay side of Brosnan Brothers' hotel. From a distance the balloon looked in color and shape like an abnormal Bartlett pear with the stem end down. It had been in the yard since noon spectators were told, and between 5 and 5:30 o'clock would be ...

LONDON, Aug. 9.--A prolonged sitting of the Cabinet was held to-day to consider whether or not to proclaim the Irish National League. The meeting was adjourned until Thursday, when a decision will be given. The majority of the members are against proclaiming the League.

SARATOGA, Aug. 9.--Sunday morning there was a sudden and delightful change in the temperature here in Saratoga. The thermometer dropped about 20 , and since then more perfect weather could not be desired than that which we have had.
LANCASTER, Wis., Aug. 9.--For the last two years a gang of roughs have infested the township of Waterloo, Grant County, a thriving farming community.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--The Delaware Boat Club of Chicago sent a challenge to-day to the Metropolitan Boat Club of New-York for another race between the double scull crews of the two organizations. The Delawares scull are dissatisfied with the outcome of the recent contest at Chautauqua Lake. They desire a race to be rowed at Pullman, Ill., and, if that course is selected agree to pay the trip expenses of the Metropolitans.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9.--Frederick Gerard Pagels, better known as "Tiny" Pagels, who was to suffer the extreme penalty of the law next Friday, cheated the gallows this morning by severing an artery in his left arm.
Prop. J.O. Russell, who is at the head of the public school system of Williamstown, Victoria, British Columbia, accompanied by Mr. Lawrence Worthington, of the same city, was in the city yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--A new movement has been started in this city among the workingmen founded on the principles of harmony and cooperation between employers and employes opposed to strikes and all labor demonstrations not in harmony with civil government.
A policeman was called into the St. Nicholas apartment house, 39 East Eighteenth-street, last night to discover what ailed Miss Sarah Catherine Carpenter, an aged woman who lived on the third floor.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 9.--Harvest is here and new wheat has already arrived at country elevators. The wheat so far received from the thresher justifies all previous predictions as to a large crop, and it really looks now as if the Northwest would have more wheat to sell this year than for the past five years.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 9.--Loose fielding, coupled with the inability of Indianapolis to hit safely at the right time, gave New-York a game to-day.
THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 9.-- The President of the Thousand Island Park Association furnishes the following card in reference to the charges of smuggling brought against the association:
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aut. 9.--William Wells, aged 14 years, a son of Isaac Wells, was drowned yesterday while bathing in a small pond near his home.
There will be racing at Brighton Beach this afternoon, for which the following entries are announced:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 9.--Corp. More Landers and Private John Hitchcook, both of Company C. Sixth Regiment, and residing in Camden, have been arrested at the State camp at Sea Girt and sent home to await trial by court-martial on a charge of grossly insulting lady guests at Boldt's Beach House. Both men were intoxicated at the time the offense was committed.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9.--An amusing scene took place on St. Gabriel-street last night. It appears that a young woman who resides on that street is engaged to be married, and her lover has a rival in the person of the son of an Italian watchman.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 9.--David Gifford, a miller, was caught in some tangled belting and whirled 40 times around a shaft in Whitney's Mills this morning. He cannot recover.

Eddie Miller, a little White boy, living at 329 C-street, southeast, was kicked in the stomach about a week ago by a playmate, and died yesterday from the effects of the injury. The boy refused to state who his assailant was for fear he would be prosecuted.

The third annual convention of the Journeymen Tailors' National Union was begun at 9 o'clock yesterday morning at Turn Hall, in East Fourth-street. President Frederick Jensen occupied the chair, and delegates from 25 different unions were present, representing, all the principal cities of the United States.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 9.--The trial of ex-State Treasurer the Vincent, who defaulted in January, 1883, to the amount of over $230,000, and was captured in Texas last Spring, commenced in the City Court of Montgomery yesterday morning. Eight witnesses were examined, but there were no startling developments.
WASHBURN, Wis., Aug. 9.--The sidewheel steamer City of Ashland, owned by the Superior Lumber Company, of Ashland, was burned about three miles out from this port yesterday.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Aug. 9.--One of the worst freight wrecks of late years on the Camden and Amboy Railroad happened early this morning at White Hill, a small station one mile west of Bordentown, resulting in the death of one person and seriously injuring several others. The extra city freight, west-bound from Jersey City, collided with the east-bound freight, ...

Local Association No. 35 of the International Association of Journeymen Plumbers, Steam and Gas Fitters in this city has issued a secret circular to the trade complaining against Local Assembly No. 1,999--the Knights of Labor association of plumbers in this city.
Justice McKinney, of Newark, was waited upon yesterday by a young couple who desired to be married. The young man gave his name as James Ambrose.

The largest bronze casting ever attempted in America was made at E. Favy's works, on Forsyth-street, yesterday. It is the mammoth buffalo head designed by Kemeys, the sculptor, for the east portal of the new Union Pacific bridge across the Missouri at Omaha, the model of which has long attracted attention in one of Tiffany's windows.

The Police Board passed a resolution yesterday asking the Corporation Counsel for an opinion as to whether candidates for the office of Chief of the Bureau of Elections are exempt or not from a civil service examinations after the expiration of the incumbent's term of office. This action is taken in consequence of the Mayor's recent action in deciding that the office must be filled by competitive examination.

Nathan Hanson, an old ice peddler, attempted to shoot himself yesterday at 85 Second-avenue, but although he discharged a revolver at his head four times the bullets were so small that they inflicted no grave hurt. He was taken to the Bellevue Hospital. The explanation his friends gave of the act was that he was ill and lonely, his wife having gone to the country on Saturday.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Aug.9.--On last Saturday Mrs. Mary Rawlinson, aged 71 years, arrived in Oswego from Augusta, Kan., intending to reside with her daughter, Mrs. Harvey Willis.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 9.--The National colored Press Association met here this afternoon, with some of the leading colored newspaper representatives of the country present. One of the most prominent members of the association in attendance is Prof. P.H. Murray, editor ...

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 9.--Judgments to the amount of $25,495 were entered to-day against the Fearey Manufacturing Company. The company succeeded Thomas Fearey Sons in 1882 with a capital of $250,000. The competition of prisonmade shows and labor troubles are said to be the chief causes of the present embarrassment.

DETROIT, Aug. 9.--A mortgage held by W.O. Tyler Co., paper dealers, of Chicago, on the paper mill at Plainwell, in this State, owned by B.F. Lyon Son, paper dealers of Kalamazoo, was recorded yesterday, and Lyon Son suspended to-day.

Collector Magone did not get back to New-York from Ogdensburg yesterday, but the official axe fell just the same. The victim was Samuel Hopper, a first class clerk and Acting Deputy Collector of the navigation division, who has been in the Customs Service nearly a ...

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 9.--Eighty-one reports received by the Augusta Cotton Exchange from 7 counties in South Carolina and 20 in Georgia show that the crop is damaged from excessive rains, causing rust, shedding, and, in some localities, worms.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Aug. 9.-- Senor Zuniga, who is enacting the role of a Mexican Wiggins, has predicted a terrible earthquake for this city to-morrow, and considerable alarm is felt among the lower classes who accept his predictions as being founded on superior knowledge.

The funeral of Russell H. Knevals, who was found dead in his bed last Sunday, took place yesterday afternoon from his residence, 62 East Fifty-eighth-street. The Episcopal funeral services were read by the Rev. E.W. Babcock, of All Souls' Church.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 9.--Burglars entered the station of the Providence and Worcester Railway at Millbury last night and the coal office of J. E. Powers, but stole nothing therefrom. Entering the section house they stole tools stored there, and then broke into the stable of Tyler Waters and stole a horse and wagon. No clue to the thieves has yet been obtained.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The following railroad reports for the quarter ending June 30 have been received by the State Commission:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 9.--The American schooners Frank Butler and Hattie D. Linnell arrived at Arichat to-day, from North Bay, bound home. The former has 120 and the latter 45 barrels of mackerel. Both Captains and crews are disgusted with the fishery regulations that prevent them fishing within three miles of the shore. They report fish scarce outside but plenty inside the limit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--An important revision of the rules and regulations of the civil service is in progress, and is receiving the careful consideration of the President. Changes in the rules have been made from time to time, until at last the regulations which were intended to fit them are no longer adapted to that purpose.

NORWOOD, Mass., Aug. 9.--Charles Whalper has left town and has not been seen for several weeks. He received sheepskins on consignment and was guaranteed by local parties. His indorsers have taken legal measures to protect themselves.
No Sheriff's jury will investigate Mary Irene Hoyt's sobriety or drunkenness unless Judge Donohue decides against Miss Hoyt's motion to quash, which was argued before him yesterday morning.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 9.--There is a little haven under a hill where the fisher lad shouts to his sister at play, and the blithe dory springs like a thing of life over the emerald waves. There is a quaint old town, reminiscent of auld lang syne, full of reminiscences of Tom Bowling and Long Tom Coffin, crowded with sweet-eyed, patient-faced women and budding girls.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 9.--To the long period of warm weather has succeeded a spell of cool tem perature intensified by the suddenness of the change. This has resulted in producing diphtheria to such an extent that the Health Officer to-day pronounced its spread alarming. The number of new cases reported to-day suggests danger of an epidemic.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 9.--The report of the Hudson's Bay exploration expeditions, sent out last year, has just been issued. It contains a narrative of the trip, dealing with the ice and meteorological observations as well as the resources of the region. Commander Gordon calls attention to the monopoly the Americans enjoy ...

The Socialist leaders held a caucus last evening in First-avenue and decided to call a mass meeting of citizens under the auspices of the Socialistic Labor Party to condemn the action of the County General Committee of the United Labor Party in expelling them from its ranks, and also to denounce Henry George.
NEWPORT, R.I. Aug. 9.--The weather to-day was delightfully cool, and there were many arrivals at the hotels and cottages.

CHARLESTOWN, West Va., Aut. 9.--Charles Williams, who was confined in the jail of Logan County for the murder of James Aldridge, Surveyor of the county, a few days ago, was taken from jail last evening by citizens and hanged to a tree.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--Another issue has been raised by the accounting officer of the Treasury against the Quartermaster-General's office. The officers of the War Department have always claimed and insisted that the orders of the President and the Secretary of War are to be obeyed, nolens volens, ...

The Coffee Exchange is talking of opening correspondence with the new Exchange just beginning operations in Hamburg for the purpose of exchanging daily quotations and other matters of interest to the trade everywhere.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9.--Informations has been received here to the effect that the date for the Citizens' Cup race has been positively fixed for Monday next.
GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 9.--Harvey A. Kasson, for 12 years manager of the Nonotuck Silk Company, recently went on his vacation.

DUBLIN, Aug. 9.--The National Bank of Killarney, which acts as the Treasurer to the Killarney Poor Law Union, has dishonored a number of checks given by the union to relieve evicted tenants. The union is already indebted to the bank to the amount of 2,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 9.--A sensational jail incident is exciting the city to-day. Some time ago a young man named Bradley, alias Thomas D. Franklin, whose parents live in Illinois, was arrested here for attempting to pass a forged deed for $5,000 upon a local real estate dealer.

DETROIT, Aug. 9.--Quite an epidemic of fires has broken out in different parts of the State. This is largely owing to the prolonged drought, which renders everything as dry as tinder, so that the work of fighting the flames is exceedingly difficult, especially if the wind happens to be blowing.

It is rather a pity that Gen. BOULANGER did not have the assistance of his seconds in composing the letter which he has promulgated to them through the press. They have shown themselves capable of putting him in a much more favorable attitude than that in which he exhibits himself.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 9.--About two months ago the miners employed at the Alden Coal Works, at Alden, struck because the docking boss docked the men more than they thought was right. The places of the strikers were filled by other men, mostly Polanders and Hungarians who had just arrived in this country.

John Joyce, a highwayman, known as "Yellow," was placed on trial in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Gildersleeve, Monday, for robbing William H. Williams, of Newark N.J., some three years ago.

The misfortunes which have followed the Fairfax Stable of race horses culminated yesterday when Deputy Sheriff Cunningham, of Brooklyn, attached such horses as belonged to Mr. A. F. Walcott, owner of the stable, as were at the Sheepshead Bay and Brighton tracks.

The riot between the members of the First Hungarian Schuetzen Bund and Alois Brommer, proprietor of Union Park, One Hundred and Thirty-third-street and Southern Boulevard, and his waiters on Aug. 1, was investigated by Justice Welde at the Harlem Police Court yesterday afternoon.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The circuit races opened here to-day with over 2,000 persons in attendance. The track was in good condition and the weather moderately cool.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 9.--The roof of Chatterton's Opera House fell in about 2 o'clock this afternoon, carrying a huge mass of debris into the centre of the building, and damaging it to the amount of about $6,000.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--The race for the Redcar 2-year-old stakes, run at the Redcar meeting to-day, was won by F. Mansfield's filly Venus by two lengths from Fitzadam, with Zuyder Zee third and Parisian last.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 9.--News has been received from the United States Fish Commission schooner Grampus, engaged on the expedition to Funk Island in search of specimens for scientific purposes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--The great drought prevailing all through the West does not seem to scare Chicago business men. They know that the grass has been burned up in much of the territory that supplies their trade and that the corn crop in many sections is only barely sufficient to furnish Winter fodder to the farmers' stock.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 9.--About 2,000 persons from the Wyoming and Lackawanna Valleys assembled at Mountain Park to-day, the occasion being a meeting of Prohibitionists.
William Purb, the boy arrested for firing the New-Yorker Zeilung building, is suspected of having had a hand in several fires which occurred near his home, 290 Wythe-avenue, Brooklyn.

John Phillipson, a clerk, of 172 West Broadway, was arraigned at the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. He was charged with deserting his wife and three small children.
The National Council of the Order of American Firemen began its session yesterday at 141 East Eighth-street.

WINONA, Minn., Aug. 9.--The tent in which the Rev. Messrs. Hosler and Schulz, Seventh Day Adventists, from Nebraska, were holding revival services was attacked by a mob of about 200 Germans and Poles on Sunday night and pulled down. The congregation resisted and a free fight ensued, in which several persons were hurt. The villagers refused to allow religious services to be held.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The annual meeting of the Saratoga Monument Association was held this morning at the United States Hotel.

Yesterday morning a handsome flag was hoisted at the top of the factory of Messrs. Mark W. Mahon Siedenbach, leather manufacturers, of Newark, as an emblem that the shop was free, and that the Knights of Labor would not be recognized as representatives of the workmen employed in the shop.
A number of citizens of the town of Newtown, Long Island, have preferred charges against Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue George S. Jarvis, and have requested his removal.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 9.--The Board of Health reports one case of fever since yesterday. This was an infant 2 years old, and recovered almost before the board could catch his name. There have been no deaths.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 9.--A professional regatta takes place on Seneca Lake on Aug. 24 and 25, under the auspices of the Watkins Regatta Association.

Stanley Mortimer's chestnut horse Duke of Westmoreland, which he bought in June, 1886, from a jockey, William Higgs, was a returning passenger from England yesterday by the National Line steamer England, looking none the worse for his trip, and apparently sound.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 10.--Emanuel Buch, a farm hand in the employ of John Gross, of East Hempfield Township, died this morning from the effects of a kick from a horse, received last Thursday when he was washing the animal's legs. Mr. Buch was 42 years old and leaves a widow and three daughters.
Mr. GLADSTONE, in a published letter, has said with regard to the modifications in his original scheme of home rule that he has "no objection to enumerating the delegated powers."

A young married man from Birmingham, Ala., is crazy at a hotel in Spartanburg, S.C. He is said to be a raving maniac, and the doctors attribute the cause solely to his excessive indulgence in the cigarette.
As the bulls and bears were on their way home yesterday afternoon, those of them who happened to be passing the corner of Broad and Beaver streets at about 4 o'clock saw a regular Italian fight.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10.--For at least four years the question of abolishing the "bridge arbitrary," or charge for transporting freight between St. Louis and East St. Louis has occupied the attention of merchants and railroad men in this city.
HAVANA, Aug. 10.--A man and a child have been kidnapped near Nueva Paz by six bandits.
All three of the candidates for Governor, Pewell, Democrat, Foraker, Republican, and Sharp, Prohibitionist, are Methodists.
The Norfolk and Western Railroad reports its earnings for the first week in August as $83,433, against $60,893 in the same week last year, an increase of $22,450.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 10.--The body of a man found floating in the bay here was to-day identified as that of Lewis E. Stowe, of Toledo, Assistant Auditor of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and Northern Michigan Railroad. He left Toledo last Saturday and had $80 when he left. The coroner found 48 cents on his person. It is supposed he was robbed and thrown into the water.

The young man who is clerk in a bank, a store, or who holds any place of trust should read current history in the daily press and be content with his poverty or moderate circumstances, and continue to enjoy life. There is misery untold ready to overwhelm him the moment dishonesty begins. Be honest in little things, and the great temptations will disappear.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 10.--The greatest farmers' gathering ever held in North Carolina finished its second day's exercises at Mount Holly to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10.--The commission appointed by Postmaster-General Vilas from among the corps or inspectors in the Post Office service to devise a graduated scale of clerical and other allowances for second and third class Postmasters has nearly completed its labors.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 10.--It is reported to-day that a number of Chicago capitalists are negotiating for 675 acres of land at North Buffalo.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 10.--Willis McDearmon, a school teacher near Babattia, Jackson County, found his schoolhouse guarded by a mob yesterday morning, and was refused admission on the ground that he was a prohibitionist. McDearmon opened another schoolhouse. The anti-prohibitionists installed a new teacher, and the pupils divided according to their parents' views on the question.

ST. JOHNS, Newfoundland, Aug. 9.--News has just been received here that the cruise of the United States Fish Commission schooner Grampus on the Newfoundland coast has been highly satisfactory in its results.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 10.--An incident occurred on board the American war ship Richmond this afternoon, which, in view of the present relations between the United States and Canada, causes considerable amusement.

Acting Mayor Beekman yesterday issued a theatrical license to Alfred Reichell, of the NewYork Amusement Company, who has leased the old Koster Bial place on Twenty-third-street, west of Sixth-avenue, from George Ehret, the brewer. Theatrical entertainments will be given there this Winter.

OWENTON, Ky., Aug. 10.--J.M. Bourne, during the hearing of a case in court, charged his nephew, James Bourne, Jr., with false swearing On their way home the nephew demanded a retraction, which was refused. An altercation ensued during which J.M. Bourne shot and killed his nephew.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 10.--The babe which was born into the Union Labor Party in Elmira on June 15 was put on exhibition here to-day.
BELLEVILLE, Mich., Aug. 10.--Forest fires are raging two miles south of here, and many acres of timber have already been destroyed.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 10.--Mahone's Republican State Committee, which met at the residence of the ex-Senator in Petersburg last night, did not get down to work until after a late supper.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--Deputy Sheriff Graves levied on the property of the Current Publishing Company to-day to satisfy a judgment for $792 in favor of the paper house of Price Longley. An hour later he dropped it as if it had been a red hot iron. The reason was that the property under his charge had previously been taken care of by another creditor, who holds a seven-thousand-dollar mortgage.

A young man formerly in business took a young lady driving yesterday afternoon, and was passing Justice O'Neal's office, when Constable McCully seized his horse and refused to let him go until a bill against the young man was paid. As the young man did not have the money the lady settled the account, and the pair went on their way without interruption.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday had two nice little stories credited to "Ben: Perley Poore, in the Boston Budget." One was told by Mr. Lincoln and the other by Thaddeus Stevens. As they appear to be new stories we are left to suppose that Major Poore has just heard them.

Coroner Rooney, of Brooklyn, is investigating the death of the newly born child of Mary Quigley, who was driven in a coach to the City Hospital, Brooklyn, with a dead baby. The hospital people refused to receive her, and she was driven away.

It is astonishing how many head of stock a half acre sand ridge will accommodate during a freshet. There was one on Ogletree's place, in Crawford, the only dry land within a long stretch of swamp. It was reported that on this half acre 105 head of cattle, about 50 head of goats, and as many hogs had congregated to escape drowning.
Coroner Levy was summoned to Roosevelt Hospital yesterday noon to take the ante-mortem statement of Valentine Menikel, a patient who entered the hospital in the forenoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 10.--Drafts--Sight, 15 and 10 cents; telegraphic, 20 and 15 cents.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 10.--At New-Philadelphia, Ohio, while Christian Baum was attempting to rescue a deaf son from in front of a railroad train, was he run, over and killed, together with the boy.
