Mr. Cassatt's famous race horse, The Bard, still lives, and yesterday had a somewhat easier day than he has had since he was taken ill. Drs. Stanley and Sheppard are in constant attendance, but have little hope of the horse's recovery, as his ailment refuses to yield to the ...
Paul Bauer, West Brighton's magnate and general ruler of Coney Island's sunset end, was 41 years old yesterday, and the circumstance was celebrated throughout the length and breadth of his realm.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 18.--"Boss" Cooper's brass band, that supplied most of the Blaine enthusiasm in yesterday's Republican Convention, tooted and banged about the streets of Harrisburg until nightfall, and then, when there was scarce a vestige left of the little body that had given consent to the ticket and platform of the "bosses," it folded its tromb ones and its cymbals and stole away.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 18.--Gov. Sawyer, through the Secretary of State, submitted to the House of Representatives to-day a proposition signed by Austin Corbin, of New-York City; John L. Farwell, and Robert K. Dow, offering to pay $500,000 for the interest of the State of New-Hampshire in the Concord Railroad.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18.--A collision occurred last night on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. One cast-bound freight train ran into the rear of another freight train, and 17 cars were wrecked. The collision was about three miles west of Ellicott City, on the main stem, near Hollifields station. The engineer and conductor of one of the trains were severely and, it is believed, fatally injured. The firemen are also probably fatally hurt.

LOUSIVILLE, Ky., Aug. 18.--Six hundred coal miners in Laurel County, Ky., are out on a strike. They demand an increase of cent a bushel for mining coal. A strike is expected at the Jellico mines also.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 18.--The races here this afternoon drew the largest crowd of the season to the Maple-Avenue Park. The sport consisted of three races, which were fall of excitement, except the first, which proved an ...

Walton Storms, Chairman, and J.P. Sullivan, W.G. Hegeman, N. Halpin, and C.H. Ebbels, of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Athletes, met in the Grand Union Hotel last evening to ...
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 18.--Intense feeling has grown out of the recent scandalous debate in the Georgia Legislature between ex-Congressman Felton and Mr. Simmons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--Fireman James W. Smith, who lies at the Providence Hospital in a badly injured condition, has made the following statement regarding the accident at the "Y" yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18.--The steamer St. Paul arrived from Behring Sea to-day, and reports that great fears are expressed in Ounalaska for the United States revenue cutter Bear, commanded by Capt. Maclay.
KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 18.--Two new cases of yellow fever have been reported by the Board of Health since yesterday, and one death--an infant.

It was demonstrated yesterday morning in the double building at 49 and 51 Mercerstreet that an elevator can fall from the third story to the basement, a distance of 30 feet, without killing everybody upon it.

Finally (and thankfully!) we hear from the long-lost Bad Boy Eddie Gould, who until a fortnight ago boldly and openly "coppered" all his Papa's bull points--and made money at it. He turned up in court yesterday.

If the culvert at Piper City had been built of stone instead of wood, it could not have been destroyed or weakened by fire, and nearly eighty lives would have been saved. Ought railroad companies to be required to make all of their bridges and culverts of iron or masonry?

Malcolm W. Ford, the athlete, who was reported to be lying at the point of death in the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, was a very healthy looking sick man when a TIMES reporter visited him last night. He laughed heartily when the story was told him, and said: "All such talk is nonsense. My physical condition is as good as ever.
The will of Cornelia Pastor, mother of "Tony" Pastor, the theatrical manager, was filed yesterday for probate. Mr. Pastor receives the house and lot at 521 Broome-street, and his sister.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18.--Two hundred lawyers were present at this morning's session of the Convention of the American Bar Association. Thomas J. Semmes, President, of NewOrleans, was in the chair. The annual address was delivered by Mr. Henry Hitchcock, of St. Louis.
Yesterday was the third and last day of the seventeenth annual convention of the County superintendents of the Poor at Babylon, Long Island.

There was some comment yesterday upon the position in which Whittlesey D. Searls, VicePresident of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, stands to defaulter Scott, who robbed the Manhattan Bank of $160,000, and in turn charges John R. Dunn with robbing him of the larger part of the plunder.
The Veteran Volunteer Firemen's Association of Brooklyn took out their old engine yesterday and dragged it around to the City Hall steps.

John Nelson, of Moline, was overcome by the heat Thursday afternoon while at work east of Sylvan Island, where preparations are making for the putting in of the new water power flumes. He had headache nearly all the afternoon, and could not force himself into a perspiration. He drank plenty of ice water, and kept on wheeling away loads of earth, not feeling alarmed.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 18.--A singular freak of ligtning, with fatal results, is reported from the neighborhood of Marion, Ark., a few miles across the river from Memphis.
There will be racing at Brighton Beach to-day, the following horses being named as starters in the various events:

CHICAGO, Aug. 18.--The Tribune this morning says the fruit dealers of the United States have been placed in an unprecedented situation. Except in California, the fruit crops throughout the country virtually have failed.

HAVANA, Aug. 13.--The decree suppressing the export duties on sugars, molasses, and rum on and after the 1st inst. was published in the Gaceta. It is generally expected that the sugar market will now obtain a better tone.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 18.--Eight Socialists in name were by ninety-odd Socialists in fact excommunicated from the United Labor party to-day. Eight delegates who confessed their Socialism were denied fellowship by George delegates, who are concealing their Socialism for the purpose of seducing the farmers and small tradesmen of the State.

Milton G. Barlow, the burnt-cork artist, who has been in Ludlow-Street Jail since Feb. 12, has obtained a writ of habeas corpus from Judge Donohue ordering the keeper of the jail to show cause in the Supreme Court, Chambers, next Tuesday why Barlow should not be set at ...
Mary Stuart Macdonald, mother of Dr. A. E. Macdonald, Superintendent of the City Insane Asylum, died Thursday in her son's apartment in the asylum on Ward's Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--First Lieut. E.E. Hardin, Seventh Infantry, has been ordered to West Point for duty at the Military Academy. Lieut. Col. J.C. Bailey, Assistant Medical Purveyor, has been granted one month's leave, and Capt. Harvey Johnston, Medical Storekeeper, has been ordered to perform his duties in New-York during his absence.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 19.--Crop reports represent that the latest storms have resulted in considerable damage to wheat, more particularly from bleaching. Some sprouting is also reported.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 19.--Yesterday, while the steamboat Mabel Comeaux was landing at Webb's plantation, opposite College Point, St. James Parish, a difficulty occurred between Frank Smith, white, the second mate of the boat, and Robert Simms, a rouster.
ZANZIBAR, Aug. 19.--Well-informed people here regard as baseless the report that Henry M. Stanley has been murdered after having been deserted by his escort.

Mrs. Rosie Arndt, who was married to Frederick Arndt Saturday last, as a cure for the mental trouble from which she was suffering, was removed from Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon to the asylum on Ward's Island.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 19.--The miners at Ramey's coke works struck to-day because the 12 per cent. advance granted during the last strike was cut off. The employes of Frick Co. will also be reduced to the wages now paid at the other mines. About 300 men quit work at Ramey's. If Frick's men strike there will be nearly 4,000 idle men in the coke regions.

The reply of M. FLOURENS to the English Government's request to name a date for evacuating the New-Hebrides may seem to partake more of diplomatic, repartee than logical rejoinder. To make that date dependent on England's evacuation of Egypt or on the neutralization of the Suez Canal ...

My friend Bras de Fer is much exercised by the appearance of the Prince of Wales at Goodwood in a pot hat and a country suit, and I have seen unkind references to the subject elsewhere, but for my own part I am not disposed to agree with them.

Andrew O. Johnson, an undertaker, living in Hempstead, Long Island, was in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday as defendant in a suit for separation brought by his wife Ann, who accuses him of several kinds of cruelty.

David Orr, first baseman of the Metropolitan Baseball Club, was held in the Yorkville Court yesterday to answer a charge of assault preferred by a law clerk named Curtis Turner, of 359 East Sixty-ninth-street.

Margaret Dowe, an old German woman who lived at 219 Pond-street, Newark, was found by her husband early yesterday morning suspended from the limb of a peach tree in the back yard by means of a strip of calico which she had torn from her dress. The husband permitted her to hang until the arrival of an officer, three hours later.

Several serious railroad accidents which have occurred within a few days might have been averted if the brakes in use on the trains had been trustworthy. There is in these days no excuse for the use of poor brakes, and the cars of a company that does not protect its patrons by equipping its trains with good braking apparatus should be shunned by travelers.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug, 19.--It is stated by authority that the Boston syndicate has concluded to take the bulk of the construction bonds of the Honduras North Coast Railway the franchise for which was granted ...

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Thirty thousand visitors to the State Firemen's Tournament are in this city. The weather is cool and delightful. The Durkee Hose Company, of Fort Edward, won first prize in the drill.

"Kid" Miller, Thomas Fowler, alias "Capt." Taylor, and William Barlow, the three "bunko" men arrested Thursday on Broadway, were taken before Justice Duffy at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. A charge of vagrancy was made against them, but could not be sustained, as each of the prisoners was well dressed, had money in his possession, and claimed to have a home. As no other charge was made against them they were discharged.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 19.--The steamer Sylvan Stream arrived here last night with an excursion party from Charlotte and left this morning on her return trip. It was rumored that she had been seized by the customs authorities, but there was no foundation for such a report.

ROCKLAND, Me., Aug. 19.--The schooner Addie M. Bird, Capt. Cushman, of this port, bound from Windsor, Nova Scotia, with plaster for New-York, struck on Campo Bello in a storm yesterday and lies sunken in five fathoms at low water, one mile from West Quoddy Light. The crew were saved. The vessel is owned by John Bird, S.M. Bird, A.J. Bird, and others, of this city. There is very little insurance.

Michael Reele, of 181 Madison-street, was held for trial in $1,500 bail at the Essex Market Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon Harris, Brother Co., paper manufacturers at 69 Duane-street, missed a bale of twine from the sidewalk in front of the store.
Charles D. Kellogg, Treasurer of the Bartholdi Creche, on Bedlow's Island, acknowledges the receipt of the following additional contributions in aid of the Creche:

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--John Stetson says today that the story regarding the Fifth-Avenue Theatre is true--that he will not renew his lease after the present one expires on May 1, 1888. Mr. Stetson said: "It is quite unnecessary for me to tell the reasons which led to my allowing the lease to pass through my hands.

William McGregor, a conductor on the De Kalb-avenue road, in Brooklyn, has left his wife and family, at 156 Humboldt-street, and eloped with Emily Schwiegler, the daughther of a dyer living at 1,333 Myrtle-avenue. The two families formerly resided in adjoining houses, and Emily and Mrs. McGregor became very intimate. Thursday morning Emily left home dressed in her best clothes, and Saturday this note was received from her:
Kittie Cling and John W. Van Wickel were married in Newark three years ago, when the girl was 15 and the boy 18 years of age. He soon left her, and she found that he was living in Brooklyn.
The people of the Nineteenth and Twentyfirst Wards are tired of the complex odors from the fertilizer factories and slaughter houses that line the East River in the vicinity of Fortyfourth-street.
LONDON, Ang. 19.--Mr. Joseph Chamberlain and Mr. T. W. Russell have withdrawn from the Unionist Party in consequence of the proclaiming of the Irish National League.

Charles P. Miller and his wife died at New-London, Conn., yesterday morning of pneumonia. Mr. Miller was taken sick at his cottage there about two weeks ago. He appeared to have passed the crisis favorably Monday, and it is supposed that the sickness of his wife, which was attributed to exhaustion, as she was constant ...

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The Vice-Consul of Portugal at Boston had an interview with Mayor O'Brien this afternoon that was interesting. The representative of Portugal presented a formal document in which inhumanity was charged against the officers of the ...
The Steamship Trave, of the North German Lloyd Line which arrived yesterday from Bremen, was towed to her pier at the foot of Third-street, Hoboken.
There is one peculiarity of American as contrasted with European railroads which is not without bearing on some of the accidents which have recently proved so fatal.
MASSOWAH, Aug. 19.--The Abyssinians have released Count Savoioux, who has returned to Gen. Saletta's camp.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19.--Prof. Orson Squire Fowler, who died at Sharon Station, Litchfield County, yesterday, in the seventy-eighth year of his age, was probably the pioneer of American phrenologists. He lectured for years on phrenology and physiology, and wrote many books on those subjects. At one time his popularity here was so great that a book store in which his books only were sold was established. Mr. Fowler graduated at Amherst in 1834.
Miss Carrie Smith, a rather prepossesing young woman, went to Recorder McDonough, in Hoboken, yesterday, and asked him to issue a warrant for the arrest of Charles Durnbach, of Union Hill, N.J.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19.--A party of New-York and Brooklyn gentlemen have organized under the name of the Westcalong Lake and Delaware River Park Association, and have purchased 5,000 acres of wild forest lands in Pike County, Penn., for the purpose of establishing there a game and fish preserve and an attractive pleasure resort.

CARMEL, N.Y., Aug. 19.--F.A. Hoyt, Cashier of the Putnam County Savings Bank, is a defaulter in the amount of $25,000.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 19.--The schooner Frank A. Nelson, of Calais, Capt. Thompson, from Lubec for New-York, with a cargo of sardines and herring, and E.L. Watts, of Thomaston, from Smithtown, Me., for Philadelphia, with a cargo of ice, met in collision yesterday morning between Chatham and Nauset in a thick fog.
King Pomare, the fifth ruler of the Society Islands and the lands that lie adjacent thereby, has instituted an action in divorce against his wife, Queen Johanna, who is aged about 15.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19.--There is a row on the Niagara River at Youngstown over the apparent favoritism shown the steamer Chicora against the smaller crafts and ferries in landing at American points in succession without first touching at a ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--Some time ago a dispatch to THE NEW-YORK TIMES called attention to the fact that some of the wheat in store in this city was in very poor condition. The statement was denied by interested parties, while others admitted the truth of the allegation, but said the wheat would all be taken care of without hurt to the trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--The Constitutional Centennial Commission has issued thousands of invitations to citizens of the different States inviting them to be present at the ceremonies commemorative of the first centennial of the framing and promulgation of the Constitution of the United States, ...

A liquor store adorns each of the four corners at the crossing of Myrtle-avenue and Adams-street, Brooklyn, Policeman Benjamin McMahon, of the Tenth Precinct, visited the northeast corner yesterday on his way to begin duty and drank some of "Ike" Duffy's liquor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--The Hon. J.M. Weston, of Grand Rapids, Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee of Michigan, was in the city to-day. The interviewer's first question, naturally, was in reference to Don M. Dickinson.

The interest Helen Dauvray shows in sports is not of recent birth. The New-York Club pardonably take delight in hailing the actress as their mascot. Yet she has not always been so partial to baseball as now. Billiards once wooed and won her. She was so constant in her attendance upon public contests at Cooper Institute and Tammany Hall that reporters conferred upon her the title of "The Diamond Lady."

TUSCOLA, Ill., Aug. 19.--The young Catholic priest and scientist of Charleston, Ill., who was recently created Lieutenant in the French Army for valuable discoveries in the art of making and using a powerful explosive for war purposes, claims to have made a still more valuable discovery, or rather rediscovery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--The announcement this morning that Henry Sheridan is mysteriously missing is believed to be the first of a series of sensational denouements in connection with a coming wholesale prosecution of bribe taking members of the Chicago Board of Aldermen.

St. John's Guild will give another "Fresh Air Excursion" on the Floating Hospital to-day, the expenses of which have been assumed by the Singer Manufacturing Company. Contributions for the continuance of the Guild's ...

Up to the moment when the State Convention of the United Labor Party decided to exclude the Socialistic delegates whose seats were contested the Socialist leaders in this city had hoped against hope and were almost sure that such a step would not be taken.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 19.--The body of J.E. Marples, the well-to-do Englishman who was drowned while bathing at Cockenoes Island on July 5, has been recovered. It will be taken to Saugatuck. The young man's parents have been notified of the finding of the body and are now on their way to this country.

I have been misunderstood about my proposals for the reorganization of the War Office. I am represented as being in favor of the German system, whereas the system which I advocate is the French system. There is a wide difference between the two.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19.--Mr. and Mrs. August Belmont, of New-York, have just placed a beautiful altar in their new memorial mortuary chapel which they have erected in the island cemetery. It is seven feet in length and is composed of Caen stone and different marbles, with onyx columns, the latter polished like gems.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, rendered a decision in the case of Matthew Cuming, the Scotch dairyman, who landed in this country July 17 under contract with W.A. Sudduth, of Flemingsburg, Ky., his fare being paid by his future employer, ...

The Volunteer Boat Club has been organizedat Sag Harbor, with these officers: Commodore-- Ferdinand H. Cook; Vice-Commodore--Julian Hawthorne; Secretary and Treasurer--Paul Weilbacher, Jr. The flag will be a dark garnet, swallow-tail in shape, with "V.B.C." in white. Mr. J.H. Aldrich has presented two cups, one to be called the Maycraft Cup, to be open to challenge, and the other to become the personal property of the winner of the Maycraft Cup.

Rumor says that she was good-looking, but such detailed information as can be obtained tends to throw a doubt on the point. If she had lived in the present day she would probably have figured in the divorce court, and might have ...

WASHINGTON Aug. 19.--Prof. Spencer F. Baird, head of the Smithsonian Institution and the United States Fish Commission, died at 3:45 o'clock this afternoon at Wood's Holl, Mass., where he had been sick for some time. His body will be brought here for burial.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19.--Yesterday's magnificent storm has cleared and, singular as may appear, many regretted it, as they desired to see the wild, angry sea, and to witness the commotion at the Spouting Rock.

The fuss at St. Martin's Vestry about the "tramps" who sleep in Trafalgar-square is the greatest possible nonsense. If the "tramps" slept there in the day time I could understand that they might be a nuisance; but inasmuch as they only sleep at night, when "all decent people" are asleep, too.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19.--Mullane's fine pitching, hard batting, and daring base running enabled the Cincinnatis to win from Brooklyn with ease. Toole was erratic, and was hit hard at critical times, each one of Corkhill's hits bringing in runs.
RJEFF, Russia, Aug. 19.--The sky was completely overcast with clouds to-day, so no observations of the sun's eclipse could be taken at this, the point of greatest obscuration.

Entries for the United States National Lawn Tennis Association's open tournament for champion singles closed on Wednesday with 24 subscribers. These include all the noted players in this country, besides a couple of cracks from England, and some interesting competitions may be expected on Monday at Newport, where the meeting will be held.

George Mentzel, a well known resident of Brooklyn's Sixteenth Ward, sent his wife to Germany on a visit recently, and on Thursday eloped with his niece, Amelia Weiss, who had been keeping house for him. He took with him $1,300 which he had deposited in local banks, and left Mrs. Mentzel is poverty. Yesterday Mrs. Mentzel obtained a warrant for his arrest, and a detective is after him.

ENFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19.--The Eighty-seventh Illinois Regiment, the survivors of which are scattered through White and Hamilton Counties, has been holding a reunion here for the past three days. The festivities were to conclude to-day with a sham battle and barbecue.

The Berlin Statistical Office has issued some interesting returns relative to marriage in that city. It appears that of the 13,866 marriages which took place in 1885 only 100 were between blood relations--namely, 95 between ...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Following are the summaries of the races of the Northern New-York meeting here to-day:
Manhattan Elevated was the cheering feature of affairs in Wall-street yesterday. It went smashing down from 111 all of a sudden to 107.

The report of the Committee on Immigration made at the annual convention of the County Superintendents of the Poor on the benefits and evils of the enormous tide of immigration that has been pouring into this country is receiving much comment, especially the part of the report referring to the paupers sent ...

Charles Tucker, clerk in the New-York Post Office, living at 251 Marion-street, Brooklyn, sends us the following: "For several years I have suffered almost constantly from dyspepsia, receiving little or no benefit from the treatment ...

A splendid lot of races are a certainty at Monmouth Park this afternoon where seven races, including a run over the full steeplechase course, are to be run. The race that will attract the greatest attention is that for the rich Omnibus Stakes for 3-year-olds, for which a half dozen candidates are announced as probable starters.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19.--There is now no doubt that Stock Broker William Lorman Roberts is in Canada, and has no immediate notion of returning. Business circles continued ful of rumors to-day, and gradually the facts in the case are coming out.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--The Inman Line steamer City of Montreal has been destroyed by fire at sea. All of her passengers were saved except 13, who are missing. The news of the disaster was learned upon the arrival at Queenstown this morning of the British steamer York City, Capt. Benn, which left Baltimore on Aug. 4 for London. This steamer rescued the passengers and crew from the burning vessel and brought them to Queenstown.

George Martin, an old man who lives in Brooklyn, took yesterday a case containing two small violins of peculiar make to Edward Tubbs, a maker and repairer of musical instruments at 394 Bowery, and offered them for sale.

CALAIS, Me., Aug. 19.--Daniel Mooney, of Dublin, Ireland, and William A. George, of Machias, were suffocated by smoke from a fire in the forecastle of the schooner Lugano this morning. They retired last night while intoxicated and, it is supposed, the bedding ignited from a pipe. The schooner was not badly damaged.

The biggest surprise of the year in racing turned up at the Brighton Beach track yesterday in the second race, a selling race at a mile, which was won by Harved. But eight tickets were sold on him, and these tickets, when the pool came to be divided, were worth $760 each to the holders.

Capt. Barr, the commander of the Scotch yacht Thistle, awoke yesterday morning to a sudden sense of the fact that the yachting reporters of New-York could see the points of a vessel without asking questions.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 19.--The dispatch from Glenwood Springs received here last night purporting to have come by courier from Meeker and stating that Sheriff Kendall and a party of nine men had been attacked by Indians, who wounded four men, has not been confirmed by to-day's dispatches.

Herman Buchte died at his tenement, 113 Fourth-street, Hoboken, Tusday night, and it is common report in the neighborhood that his disease was Asiatic cholera. He was taken sick last Saturday night, complaining of pains in his limbs.

Queen Margaret, of Italy, is very anxious not to appear too youthful. At the beginning of the Summer she asked King Humbert whether she was not growing too old to wear her favorite style of dress--white muslin.

EAST STOUGHTON, Mass., Aug. 19.--During a row at an early hour this morning over a game of cards at P.J. Murphy's boarding house, John McManus, of Natick, struck John Minnehan a blow with his fist, and the latter fell dead to the floor.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Daniel Curry took place yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock in St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Madisonavenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixthstreet. Seldom has any event in this city brought so many clergymen together under the roof of one church.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--The Philadelphias had to-day's game with New-York well in hand up to the seventh inning, when the Giants scored 7 runs on a muff by Farrar, a single by Welch, scratch hits by Gore, Tiernan, and Ward, an illegal pitch by Buffinton, and Connor's ...

SARATOGA, Aug. 19.--The programme for the thirteenth regular day of the meeting here, which was to have been run off on Thursday and was postponed because of the rain, was run off here to-day. The track was heavy in consequence of Thursday's rain, yet the racing was fair, and in spite of the cloudy weather a good crowd was on hand to enjoy it.
A representative of a playful contemporary called to see Sarah Bernhardt the other day, and was informed that she could admit no journalists.
I recently animadverted on the fact that the Empress of Austria had been shamefully and persistently mobbed at Cromer. Several papers thought fit to contradict my statement on the subject.

An important move has been taken by the keepers of pleasure parks and other resorts in this city to resent the recent course of Mayor Hewitt in imposing what are claimed to be prohibitory restrictions on their business.
A dispatch from London announces the death there yesterday of John Palgrave Simpson, the playright and author. A. native of Norflok County, he was educated at Corpus Christi College, ...
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 19.--The reception aboard the Yantic this afternoon was a very brilliant affair. Great pains had been taken with the decorations and the deck looked like fairyland.

What are known to the liquor trade as "high wines" are the products of the first distillation of corn mashed and fermented. When the high wines are run through charcoal a pure spirit is obtained. This is next passed through a still and column, and there results a product called finished goods, or French spirits.

Mr. W.H. Gillette's dramatization of H. Rider Haggard's most successful romance, called "She," is shortly to be produced at Niblo's Garden, in this city, Mr. E.G. Gilmore having signed contracts on Thursday to that end with Mr. Charles Frohman.

PHILADELPHIA, Ang. 19.--A freight train on the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad dashed around the curve a short distance east of Wynnewood at 4:45 o'clock this morning and crashed into the rear of another train standing on the track directly over the crossing at Cherry Lane.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 19.--Samuel N. Wortham shot himself through the head, dying instantly, this evening, because of insomnia. He was 40 years old and leaves a widow and two children.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The American Bar Association closed its annual session this morning. After debating on resolutions in favor of establishing the whipping post for those guilty of wife-beating and certain other classes of violence, the whole subject was laid on the table.
Julius Weisbaden, a miser and monomaniac, was found dying in his room on Wednesday and was taken to Bellevue Hospital. He had not, as far as was known then, a friend or relative in America.

Some months ago the parish church of St. Giles's, Camberwell, was restored, and a buttress standing at the western corner was ornamented with five gargoyles. Those figureheads represent five statesmen--Lord Salisbury, Lord Randolph Churchill, Mr. Gladstone, Mr. Bright, and Mr. Chamberlain.

The summons in the divorce suit against Gen. Richard Busteed, ex-Corporation Counsel, ex-Commissioner of Records, and ex-United States Judge, was served several days ago. The petition is for absolute divorce and alimony for Mrs. Cordelia Busteed. Her lawyer, Herbert F. Andrews, says that the complaint will be ready Monday. He gives the following as the allegations upon which the suit is based:

White Plains defeated the Eccentrics 7 to 2 yesterday, at White Plains. The Glendales beat the Stuyvesants 14 to 8 yesterday on the Halsey-street ground, Brooklyn. The Queens and Olympic Athletic Clubs will play a match at Queens, Long Island, this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--The Hon. Bayless W. Hanna, United States Minister to the Argentine Republic, stopped over here to-day en route to Baltimore, where he was to take the steamer for Buenos Ayres. It was a busy day for the Minister, as he had matters of much importance to settle with the Administration concerning his mission.

William R. Crawford, of 2,036 Second-avenue, an employe of the Second-avenue elevated railroad, fell from the track last evening at One Hundred and First-street and received injuries which resulted in death.

BOW ARROW POINT, Lake Champlain, Aug. 19.--Yesterday was a dismal day in the camp of the American Canoe Association. A drizzling rain prevented any kind of sport on the water. This has been as fine a day as could be wished, and although a heavy sea rolled in from ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 19.--After the downpour of last night the air this morning was exhilarating. The sun shone out long before noon and with a splendid breeze combined to make perfect yachting weather. Green Bank, off which point the jubilee yacht races were started, was crowded with spectators, and different available points all along the shore were black with people anxious to get sight of the white wings.
"Here is a little man 12 years old," says a Saratoga letter, "probably the youngest and wealthiest juvenile race horse owner in the world. His name is D.J. McCarthy, of San Francisco.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 19.--Tarleton Steele, a negro, charged with the murder of Lou Anderson, his alleged wife, was convicted in the City Court to-day, and the jury fixed the penalty of death by hanging. The date of execution will be fixed when sentence is passed. Steele murdered the woman and then burned her body to conceal the crime.

During the progress of a family quarrel last morning John Fitzpatrick a cooper employed by the Standard Oil Company at Constable Hook, kicked his wife so brutally that she now lies at St. Francis's Hospital in a critical condition. Her assailant is in jail and has been refused bail.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--The local leaders of the Socialist Labor Party are watching the actions of the Syracuse Convention with great interest.
Frederick Willcox, who keeps a bakery at 2,140 Third-avenue, was held in the Harlem Court yesterday to answer a charge of maliciously obstructing traffic on the Third-avenue surface road.
One more step in the master's track. Henry S. Ives is still industriously making Jay Gould his exemplar.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 19.--The arrest of Charles Parker, the cowboy and highwayman, who last Spring robbed Paymaster Bash of 8,000 at Antelope Springs, Wyoming, has developed some very sensational features. Parker was arrested in Logan County, Neb.

LONDON, Ontario, Aug. 19.--The Bank of London suspended payment this morning. It had a subscribed capital of $1,000,000 of which $223,588 was paid up. Very little loss is anticipated by the bill holders.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 19.--The tournament games of the National Croquet Association are progressing finely. The day is clear and warm and it is hoped to close the first series of games to-night. Seven games were played this morning. In the second division Jacobus and Germond have each won five and lost one.

The steamship Atlas, of the Atlas Line, left here Wednesday afternoon, bound for Port Lemon with a cargo of general merchandise. She had no passengers, but carried her full crew, commanded by Capt. Tobin. At the start they had fair weather, but a thick fog settled down about midnight.

AYLMER, Ontario, Aug. 19.--Two freight trains met near this place this morning. The engine and several cars of the east-bound train were completely wrecked and the engine of the west-bound train was badly damaged. No one was injured except a brakeman on the east-bound train. He was not hurt fatally.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--Two big passenger engines ran away in the yard of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company last night, and one engineer received fatal injuries while another was hurt. The locomotives were almost totally destroyed.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19.--Hogan made the star play to-day by a running catch of a long hit. The game was well played, and both pitchers did well and were well supported.

Mr. Henry E. Abbey arrived yesterday morning from Europe by the City of Richmond, of the Inman Line. He was accompanied by Mrs. Abbey, Marcus Mayer, and Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Matthews. Mr. Abbey said he had been hard at work during his three months' absence upon the various enterprises of the new firm.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--The schooner Nettie Champion, hence for Boston with coal, while at anchor off Brandywine on the 18th inst., was run into by the schooner Edwin A. Gaskill, from Kennebec for Philadelphia with ice. The former has all her headgear carried away and broke her anchor stock. The damage to the latter is unknown. The Champion returned here for repairs, and will sail tomorrow for her destination.

The Colorado beetle promises to cause trouble this Summer unless, indeed, the vigorous measures which the authorities are taking should succeed. The pest has appeared in two places, Dommitzsch and Hochmoor, covering in the one case an area of three and in the other an area of twenty hectares. A vigilant lookout is being kept in other potato-growing districts. Illustrations and descriptions of the beetle are being widely circulated.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 19.--George's convention, after three days' labor, has brought forth a platform broad enough for all socialists, American and European, to stand upon, and a ticket whose strength he fondly hopes will prove sufficient to boost him into a Presidential nomination one year hence.
There is not much doubt now that the peach crop is really short. Only three or four out of 30 packing establishments in Baltimore are now in operation.
BOSTON, Aug. 19.--Alvan Clark, the founder of the great telescope works at Cambridge, died at his home in that city early this morning.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The closing day of the midsummer races at the Maple-Avenue Park attracted another large crowd.

"Did you see Lawrence Barrett when you were in Boston?" asked a neighbor of Mr. and Mrs. Billkins when they returned to their Arizona home after a tour of the States made on the proceeds of a real estate boom.

Edward Farrell, the walking delegate of the Journeyman Plumbers' Union, who was arrested Thursday night in a civil suit brought by Thomas Cochrane, a master plumber, who alleges that Farrell caused him $500 loss by ordering strikes on his jobs, and also extorted $300 blackmail from him, was yesterday morning released on bail.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 19.--Burglar Feyth, confined in the Bridgeport jail for the cracking of Jeweler Fairchild's safe a few Sundays ago, has made a confession. It was supposed that the cracksman secured $10,000 worth of diamonds.

Six sons, 1 daughter, 36 grandchildren, and 3 great-grandchildren gathered yesterday around the dinner table-at 199 Essex-street, Brooklyn, to celebrate the seventy-fifth birthday of Mrs. Louisa Essig. She lives with her son Heinrich, and is in excellent health. Yesterday she took great pleasure in carrying the youngest of her great-grandchildren about on her shoulder.

Eugene B. Sanger, Mutual District Messenger boy No. 1,222, craned his neck over the shoulders of his fellow-passengers on the deck of the big steamship (Germanic, of the White Star Line, yesterday morning about 7 o'clock, as she was slowly brought alongside her pier.

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The Hon. George M. Stearns, who has resigned the office of United States District Attorney for Massachusetts, says he never wanted public office, and never so little as at the present time.

EAST BROOKFIELD, Mass., Aug. 19.--One hundred feet of the dam at Forbes's woolen mill was washed away this morning. The road was gullied to the depth of 10 feet. The dry house was badly damaged, and George E. Forbes's dwelling was demolished. The fences were carried away, and some time will elapse before the mill will be again in running order.

Mrs. Jane Ward, who lives near the south entrance to Greenwood Cemetery, went yesterday to Mayor Whitney, of Brooklyn, and asked him to help her get her adopted daughter, Emily Samond, out of the Essex County Insane Asylum, at South Orange, N.J., where she said the girl was detained against her will by her uncle, Mr. E. Williams, of Montclair, N.J.
George M. Durham was arrested at Newark last night on a charge of assaulting his stepdaughtar, Selina Rice, a girl of 15.

We have been disposed to congratulate ourselves for the last year or two that new vigor had been infused into the execution of justice against crimes that had become too common and flagrant. We were inclined to think that a check would thereby be put upon embezzlement, bribery, and corrupt conspiracies which had grown to alarming proportions.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 19.--The steam whaler A.B. Nickerson has killed and towed in a sulphur bottom whale about 65 feet long. This variety of whale is very rare in these waters, none having been taken here in 20 years. They are frequently caught near the Cape de Verde Islands.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19.--Story Fox, general finishers to the printing and lithographing trades of New-York, are looking for a site in Buffalo, intending to move their concern here. This is the first practical result of the Buffalo boom.

SARATOGA, Aug. 20.--Another gay week has swiftly slipped by, and the height of the rush is close at hand. The number of arrivals this year is unprecedented. Standing room at the hotels is at a premium, and at some of the hotels it is three hours before all the guests can get served at any meal.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 20.--Gov. Lounsbury has appointed Edwin C. Murphy, of this city, a member of the State Prison Board of Directors, in place of Gen. Thomas McManus, who is now in the Treasury Department at Washington. Mr. Murphy is connected with the Colt Firearms Company's works here.

Michael Nathanson was sent to prison in 1875 for 10 years for highway robbery. When his term expired the Prison Association found him a situation as salesman in a clothing store. Yesterday Nathanson was before Justice Duffy and Joseph Newborg, of Newborg, Rosenberg Co., clothiers, of 620 Broadway, said the man had admitted stealing about $100 worth of clothing.

LONDON, Aug. 20.--The British steamer Martello, Capt. Jenkins, from New-York Aug. 7. which arrived here to-day, lost 50 head of cattle on the voyage.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20.--The British steamer Gardenia, from Shields, passed a small vessel bottom up on Aug. 17, west half south, distant 10 miles from Five Fathom Bank. The schooner Harry Landell returned to Philadel- phia with loss of jibboom. She was run into on the 19th inst., while at anchor below New-Castle, Del., by the schooner Hattie Berry, from New-Bedford, now at this port and lost jibboom and headgear. The Berry sustained slight damage.

Jacob Sharp was very weak all day yesterday, but there were manifest signs of improvement in his condition. He had no further attack of his heart trouble. Dr. Loomis visited him in the afternoon and prescribed a sedative, but offered no information concerning his patient's state of health.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--At the Chemung County Prohibition Convention, held at Horseheads this afternoon, a full county ticket was nominated. George McCann, a prominent farmer of the town of Elmira, was nominated for member of Assembly.

Torney, Assistant Surgeon, and First Lieut. Erasmus M. Weaver, Second Artillery, Recorder, has been appointed to meet at Fortress Monroe, Va., on Sept. 14...

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20.--The week closing to-night has been exceptionally gay. Entertainments have been numerous. Both of the Casino dances have been well attended.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 20.--The largest three-masted schooner ever built in the State and the largest three-master now on the Atlantic coast was launched at 12 o'clock to-day at Gesner Mar's shipyard, in West Haven. She was baptized with a bottle of champagne, which Miss Annie Stahl, of this city, broke over her bow and named the H.H. Olds, after one of the owners.

The "Fall of Babylon" continues to draw its immense crowds to St. George's nightly. People flock to the great show from this city, Brooklyn, Jersey City, Newark, and the remote suburbs. The enterprise has had a run of eight...

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 20.--A Times-Democrat Yazoo City special reports the shipment to-day of 12 bales of new cotton from the James Bee Lake plantation by the Mississippi Valley Railroad Company, consinged to R.E. Craig Co., New-Orleans. This is the largest shipment of new cotton this season from any plantation in the Mississippi Valley.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Hop picking of the early varieties will begin in the Mohawk Valley next Monday. The picking will become general one week later. The crop was never of a finer quality, and the predicted one-half crop as compared with 1885 is assured. Early hops have been sold at 25 cents per pound, and it is believed 20 cents will be the ruling price for the general variety.

A crowd of laughing damsels stood outside the Polo Grounds, at One Hundred and Tenth-street and Fifth-avenue, yesterday, presenting their tickets of admission and chattering in the most voluble manner.

QUEBEC, Aug. 20.-- Sir William Devoe, the new Governor of Hong-Kong, arrived here this morning by the steamer Parisian. Lord Herschell and party are also in this city.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 20.--A coaching parade remarkable for its brilliancy took place to-day on Bethlehem-street, participated in by 24 six-in-hand coaches and numerous private equipages. The steamer Columbia, running between this city and Rockaway, was seized at Jewell's Wharf, Brooklyn, last night by Deputy Marshal Biggart on a charge of overcrowding of passengers. The suit is to recover a penalty of $14,000, and the informant claims $7,000. Bonds were given immediately and the vessel was released.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 20.--Two freights on the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad collided near Massillon, Ohio, to-day. Two locomotives and six cars were destroyed and 15 head of cattle killed. Loss, $150,000.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 20.--From the very first of the week things have been lively here. On Monday the Casino was crowded by 10:30 o'clock to witness the tennis tournament. Four of the courts were to be used and around the sides were seated the spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that facts were gathered to-day regarding the career of Emil L. Schoenberg, or whatever his name may be, which adds much interest to the career of that picturesque forger.

Tessie Dean, the 14-year-old daughter of Thomas Dean, a bookbinder, living at 33 Market-street, was seen crying and struggling in the hands of two men Friday afternoon on the Bowery, near Bayard-street.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20.--Secretary Whitney visited the Richmond this morning. Admiral Luce, in citizen's dress, with the other officers of the flagship, received him. A salute befitting the Secretary's rank was fired from the war vessels in the harbor as he mounted the steps.

ALBANY, Aug. 20.--Goodwin Brown, Gov. Hill's pardon clerk, has been appointed by the Governor as the delegate to the inter-State extradition conference which will convene in the City of NewYork, on Aug. 23.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 20.--Leading sportsmen to-night posted $500 for a 100 yards' foot race open to the world, and to take place in the second week in September day not yet fixed. The money is in hand and the race will take place.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--The affairs of Informer Nic Schneider, the boodler, were to-day placed in the hands of a Receiver on the application of one of his creditors. An order was issued requiring M.C. McDonald and others to render an account of any dealings they may have had with Schneider. As contractor, Nic was merely a dummy for the boodlers. The answers are awaited with considerable interest.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The racing here to-day furnished a big surprise in the defeat of Los Angeles for the Misses Stakes, which Geraldine won, and another in the knocking over of Saxony by Grisette. The track was quite dry and dusty, the weather warm and hazy, and the attendance quite large.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 20.--Russia has, through Marshal Chakir Pasha, proposed to the Sultan that Russia and Turkey jointly occupy Eastern Roumelia and Bulgaria.

Edward Giles, the son of Dr. W.H. Giles of Mount Vernon, succeeded two weeks ago in rescuing from drowning a boy named Frank Cooper, who, while fishing in East Chester Creek, fell into the water and came near drowning. Residents of Mount Vernon and East Chester procured a gold badge for the boy, who is only 14 years old, and on Friday evening presented it to him.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20.--The great tidal wave of opposition to Mr. Powderly and the other general officers of the Knights of Labor which has been sweeping over the country irresistibly for the past two weeks in the elections of delegates to the Minneapolis Convention has brought consternation and terror into every stronghold of the reigning administration, and nowhere so noticeably as into the General Headquarters in this city.

The Eleventh Regiment will go to Creedmoor for rifle practice Tuesday, Sept. 20. A company composed of veterans in the late war is being formed to take the vacant letter E. C.H. Lutzeris is the promoter of the scheme.

BOSTON, Aug. 20.--The regatta of the Beverly Yacht Club, announced for to-day, did not take place on accouut of unfavorable weather. There was a large attendance of yachts at Marblehead to witness the race on account of the rivalry between the cutter Shona and Burgess's new sloop Papoose. The races will be sailed on Monday, weather permitting.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The new suspension bridge at Niagara Falls will be rebuilt to accommodate double track for teams. The only old part left will be the towers. The work is expected to be finished by April 1, 1888.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Details received here of the final illness of Prof. Spencer F. Baird indicate that the fatal result was at least both sudden and unexpected. Ex-Alderman Anthony Hartman, better known among local politicians as "Tony" Hartman, died late Friday night at his home, 679 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth-street. Two weeks ago, while at City Island with his wife, he was made ill by a carbuncle on his back. He returned home and went to bed, never to get up again. The effects of the carbuncle, complicated by heart disease, caused his death.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The fight between the Chautauqua Assembly management and the cottage owners came to a head to-day in the arrest of President Lewis Miller and Policemen Taylor and Bemus, charged by A.C. Wade, attorney for the cottagers, with false imprisonment. Wade claims $10,000 damages. Bail was fixed at $2,000 each.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20.--The polo match this afternoon was placed while raindrops fell and while the heavens plainly indicated the subsequent downpour. However there was a fair attendance, and at least 300 people witnessed the sport from Deadhead Hill.

--Log huts are com monly called "shanties," and a curse of the bush districts of Australia is the "grog shanty," an institution only too common. A hand employed on a sheep or cattle station, when he receives his periodical check from his employer, will often forthwith "make tracks" for the nearest "grog shanty," and remain there until the whole of his hardly earned pay is consumed in drink.

John Harris, a negro, of 61 Thompson-street, stole a dressed sheep belonging to J. P. Scanlon, of West Washington Market, Friday night, and was arrested while carrying off his booty by Officer Culhane, of the Eighth Precinct. When the policeman arraigned his prisoner before Justice Duffy he could not produce the stolen property and admitted that he had allowed its owner to take it. The magistrate lectured Culhane and discharged Harris.

The body of Patrick Stanton, a young man who boarded at 447 Kent-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was found in the East River at the foot of youth Ninth-street yesterday. There was a slight wound on the forehead, and some people think the man was murdered.

The Rev. Dr. Alfred J. Hutton has decided to resign the Pastorate of the Reformed church on the Heights, Brooklyn, in order to accept a call from St. Peter's Presbyterian Church, of Rochestor, N.Y. Dr. Hutton is at Lake George, with his family. NYACK, Aug. 20.--A thorough reorganization for the better has taken place in the Nyack Baseball Association, and it is intended to make the team the strongest along the Hudson River. CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 20.--The statue of Cuathemoc, the last of the Aztec Emperors, will be unveiled to-morrow on the Pasco de la Reforma with imposing ceremonies. It is intended to make a great patriotic holiday of the event.

LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 21.--Bradford Burrill, the man who shot Mary Ellen Kerrigan on Thursday night because she had refused further companionship with him, committed suicide at the jail last night by tearing up the sheets in his cell and hanging himself to a spike in the wall. The Kerrigan woman is able to be about and will recover.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21.--The reception on board the Galena yesterday afternoon to the ladies of Bar Harbor surpassed any entertainment of the week. The reception was tendered by the officers of the North Atlantic squadron.

Adam Helmer, a discharged workman in Clausen's brewery, in East Forty-seventh-street, attacked Foreman Henry Emer with a hammer on July 30, and, striking him on the head, made a depressed fracture. Paralysis set in and Emer died Saturday night.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--Theodore Manke and his wife have not been living together for a year or so. The latter has been doing housework at the house of Mr. John Thomas, a horseshoer, living at 235 Eustis-street, Roxbury.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug., 21.--The City of Savannah, which arrived to-day 12 hours late from NewYork, reports passing through a violent hurricane on Friday night at 9 o'clock, out that night the wind was blowing a gale.

MONTREAL, Aug. 21.--Mr. W.L. Roberts, the Baltimore defaulter, is seriously ill to-night. His friend Mr. Madden says that Roberts has intruste the matter to a prominent Baltimore lawyer, and that the affair will probably be settled in a few days without any one losing a cent.
Pythagoras Hall, the headquarters of Assembly No. 49, was crowded all yesterday afternoon and last evening, for the election of delegates to the coming General Aesembly at Minneapolis was going on.

CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 21.--Dr. Duryea of Boston, preached before a large congregation this morning. Prof. Henry Drummond, who made so fine an impression in July, has returned, and speaks frequently. Dr. Nathaniel West of Minnesota, preached the sermon this evening.
DALLAS, Ga., Aug. 21.--Persons visiting this place from Paulding County report great damage from recent waterspouts in the Blue Ridge valleys of that country.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 21.--There is much agitation among the truckers and farmers of the lower Peninsula on account of the great discrimination in railroad freight rates.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--Two apprentice boys from the training ship New-Hampshire deserted last night and stole a large catboat belonging to Mr. Charles Fairchild, a Boston cottager, in which to make their escape.

William Jones, a negro jockey, went to Peter Sanger's shoe store, at 610 Eighth-avenue, Saturday night, and selecting a pair of shoes worth $3, told the boy in charge that he had no money, but would pay if the boy could go home with him.
Theodore E. Tomlinson died last evening at his residence, 28 West One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, after a three weeks' illness, caused by rheumatic gout.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21.--Dr. N.A. Randolph, Professor of Physiology at the University of Pennsylvania, was in the best of health and buoyant spirits at noon to-day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 21.--The Union Straw Board Company, a pool representing 95 per cent. of the output in the country, has been working some time to prevent over-production, but, in spite of frequent "shutdowns," about 50 per cent. more straw board has been made than could be marketed.

In a quarrel which occurred in front of Robert Ernst's saloon, at 127 West-street, on July 1, Michael Reagan, a tramp, struck John Corrigan, a laborer, of 101 Washington-street, so hard that he fell and died of concussion of the brain.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 21.--W. Stanley Day, one of the most prominent and wealthy citizens of this region, committed suicide early this morning on his farm, about one and a half miles from Spencer, Tioga County, N.Y. Mr. Day had been working very hard lately and it is believed that his brain was seriously affected when the deed was committed.

LONDON, Aug. 22.--The Daily News, commenting on Mr. Chamberlain's speech on Saturday evening, says: "Mr. Chamberlain must choose whether to be a Liberal or a coercionist. We rejoice to see him moving in the right direction."

The Correctional Court of Dieppe has just tried six men and women of Varangeville for stealing from the corpses washed ashore from the wreck of the Victoria the jewels on them and the money in the pockets of their clothes. FORT KEOGH, Montana, Aug. 15.--The destruction of large game in the Northwest of late years has been something appalling to contemplate. How many giant elk have fallen beneath the deadly rifles of the pot hunters within the past decade will of course never be known, but Montana has furnished her quota, and the number cannot be far from the tens of thousands.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 21.--Jacob Eisler, a German, started from this city to visit his daughter at Haledon this afternoon. On the way he sat down by the roadside, drew a revolver, and shot himself through the heart. He was suffering from aberration of mind. No other cause for the suicide is known.

The Socialist leaders held another caucus yesterday to deliberate over what their plan should be for the coming campaign. Nothing definite was decided upon. They do not intend to act hastily, and the section of the Socialistic Party will hold meetings daily to deliberate.

However much the prohibitionist may delight in water, there was nobody present at the Sing Sing camp meeting yesterday who would not admit that it was possible to have too much of a good thing. Water attended the meetings in utter disregard of the proprieties, too unanimously, too inopportunely, too boisterously to merit the respect of even the most ardent of its friends.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 22.--A severe storm here this afternoon flooded the streets, and the deep sewer trenches caved in in many places. The new embankment of the Consolidated Railroad at Westport was badly washed away, and a large gang of men are now at work repairing the damage, while trains are delayed at that point. Telephone reports say that the crops are seriously injured in all directions.

ALTON, Ill., Aug. 22.--The Directors of the St. Louis, Alton and Springfield Railroad passed a resolution to-day to issue bonds to the amount of $1,200,000. The object of the issue is mainly to extend the road from Elsah to Alton.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 22.--A meeting of union molders was held to-night to discuss a secret circular just received from the Executive Board of the International Union proposing that all molders support a demand for 10 per cent. increase in wages to be made by stove molders Aug. 25 or 29. After a lively debate the meeting voted 45 to 25 to support the stove molders.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 22.--Visiting yachtsmen were entertained at lunch this afternoon by the Royal Nova Scotia yacht squadron. When the prizes were presented to the winners in the jubilee yacht races a number of speeches were made on the occasion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22.--The call board opened this morning for the first time since the collapse of the wheat corner three weeks ago. When the board closed the price of wheat, seller year, was $2.17 per cental, and buyer, season, was $2.10. First sales of buyer, season, this morning was $1.60 and it then dropped to $1.59 5/8.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 22.--THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day had an interview with Morris Dreyfus, a cattle man, who owns a large cattle ranch near Meeker. He left there on Friday last and reached Denver to-day. He came by way of Rawlins, and brings the latest and most direct news from the Ute troubles.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 22.--Prof. Drummond gave his last talk this morning before a large audience, which had assembled in spite of the rain. Comparatively few people are leaving here.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 22.--A special from Hornellsville, says there is a strike at O'Connor's tannery on account of the wages of 40 men having been cut $1 per week. Fifteen of the men quit work this morning, and they are trying to induce a general strike. The police are in charge of the tannery.
Henry S. Ives spent an hour or so in court yesterday, having hired a new lawyer to succeed those who lately had the chance to get real well acquainted with him.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 22.--The steamer City of Richmond, of the Portland and Machias Line, started for Machias at 4 o'clock this morning. Going into Millbridge, she struck on a ledge and stove a hole in her bottom. She was immediately beached and now lies half full of water. Her passengers are all safe. A tugboat and diver have started from here to go to her aid.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 22.--W.L. Simmons, of this city, has sold to J.W. Bethel, of Danville, Va., Charley Friar, bay colt, 2 years, by William L., dam Mother Lump, by Pearsall, for $2,400.

Charles F. Stabler died of smallpox yesterday at 236 East Third-street, a crowded tenement house. Stabler, who was 17 years old, had been sick for two weeks, and had had no medical attendance.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 22.--W. Stanley Day, of Spencer, Tioga County, who killed himself yesterday, committed the deed because his wife refused to get up at 5 o'clock to get his breakfast. He was about 35 years old and owned a twelve-thousanddollar farm. He leaves a child. His father hanged himself a few years ago because the Geneva, Ithaca and Sayre Railroad was built across his farm, contrary to his wish.

LYNN, Mass., Aug. 22.--F.M. Breed has posted in his front and back shops the following notice: "This shop killed by the union." Mr. Breed's men say that he declares that the unions have ruined his business in Lynn and that he proposes to move out of town.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22.--Mayor Francis to-day received definite information from the White House on the subject of the President's visit to St. Louis. The Presidential party will arrive here on Saturday evening, Oct. 1, direct from Washington.

She was rescued with great difficulty in an unconscious condition and rolled on a barrel until she recovered. The water in the ditch was four feet deep and the current strong, all caused by the heavy storm.

These are days of speed. A letter written in London, England, July 9, was received in an interior village in this State by the morning's mail of the 18th, the reply written and mailed in the evening of the same day, and reached London on the evening of the 27th, thus making but 18 days between the writing of the letter and receiving the reply.

The great demand for North River steamship piers and the crowded state of West street, below Chambers, has decided the Dock Board to push the work of widening West-street to 100 feet in that section, early in the Spring by the removal of West Washington Market.
BOSTON, Aug. 23.--When the Portuguese fishermen were evicted from Long Island recently, it was charged that the officials of the city used unnecessary violence in carrying out the law.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--In the House of Comthis evening Mr. E. Robertson, (Liberal,) member for Dundce, referring to the proclaiming of the Irish National League, said he had examined the returns upon which the proclamation was issued and he failed to find any mention of the League.

While some children were playing at Grand and Warren streets, Jersey City, last evening, Clarence Armstrong, a colored boy 11 years old, who lives at 136 Grand-street, passed by and the children began to annoy him. Armstrong drew a knife, and, running into the crowd, caught Edward Black, 10 years old, of 204 York-street, and stabbed him in the back, injuring him severely Armstrong was arrested, and claimed that he stabbed the boy in self-defense.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Judge Potter is not giving all his time to the consideration of the Sharp case. He spent some time in Saratoga, and it is reported that he is taking an active interest in the contest for the Supreme Court vacancy caused by the retirement of Judge Bockes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--Gen. Chettain says that he has received news from Belgium that her representation at the October jubilee and National Guard encampment will consist of 1 general officer, 10 staff officers, and a detachment of 40 picked non-commissioned officers ...

MONTREAL, Aug. 23.--Messrs. Lefevre and La Fleur, accompanied by three ladies and four children, were crossing the river near Boucherville yesterday when their boat upset. The men swam ashore, but the women and children were drowned. Six bodies of the victims have been recovered.

The sports of the Ancient Order of Foresters at Broadway Park, Brooklyn, were better attended yesterday than the first day. The management had a hard task to get 16 events out of the way in a circumscribed time, but they did it.

LONDON, Ontario, Aug. 23.--A tornado passed over the country north of here this morning, doing considerable damage to fences and telegraph lines, unroofing houses, and blowing down chimneys and trees. The storm, which was accompanied by hall, lasted only a few minutes, passing on eastward.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--Civil Service Commissioner Oberly sat in his office this afternoon with two bundles of mental fodder before him, from which he was expected to make a selection.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 23.--Jefferson Borden, one of the leading manufacturers of this city, died at a late hour last night. He was born Feb. 28, 1801, in what was then known as the village of Freetown, Mass., being a descendant of Richard Borden, who settled in Rhode Island early in 1638.
OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 23.--The Fisheries Department has received information of the seizure of more Canadian sealing vessels in the North Pacific Ocean by a United States cruiser.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 23.--The third annual session of the Supreme Lodge of Daughters of St. George began here to-day, Mrs. M.A. Fletcher, of Philadelphia, presiding. Mrs. Frazier, of Cleveland, the Secretary, reported the recent instituting of Perseverance Lodge in Rhode Island, and Britannia Lodge in California. Officers will be elected to-morrow. The Supreme Lodge will meet next year in Philadelphia.

The beautiful grove on the hill at Sing Sing, where the Prohibitionists are holding their camp meeting, was more than usually pleasant yesterday, though torrents of rain had drenched it the day before.

SOFIA, Aug. 23.--Prince Ferdinand arrived here at 5 o'clock last evening. He received the usual offering of bread and salt, and was presented with an address of welcome in behalf of the municipal authorities. The route which he took through the city was crowded with people who greeted the Prince enthusiastically.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Aug. 23.--Capt. Anderson and four sailors, composing the crew of the schooner Gessine, were found this morning clinging for life to the outer breakwater with seas constantly washing over them.

The report to the State Board of Charities on the insane asylum on Ward's Island, which was summarized and briefly noticed in yesterday's TIMES, deserves the careful attention of every taxpayer and of every humane person.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The peach crop along the Hudson River has reached that stage that it is a certainty that not only will the yield be large all through September and October and the first two weeks of November, but that the fruit will be the finest ever shipped.
DOVER, N.H., Aug. 23.--Martin, French Co.'s big shoe factory is closed, and the firm says it will move out of town before it will submit to dictation from the Knights of Labor.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 23.--There are few signs visible to-night indicating that a State convention of Prohibitionists will be held here on the morrow. Not one-third of the 650 delegates are yet here, although numbers are dropping in on each train, and they will continue until to-morrow afternoon.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 23.--The inclosed letter from Gov. Lounsbury is in answer to a numerously signed request that he be present at the important grade-crossing hearing before the Railroad Commissioners at Westport to-morrow forenoon and at Norwalk to-morrow afternoon.
"Lagardere" will run at Niblo's until November. The ballet of the Seven Ages has caught the popular fancy.
James F. Keating, of West Milford, Conn., went to Coney Island yesterday and lost his way. He asked three young men to direct him to Paul Baner's.

The Thistle's crew continued the work of scraping the cutter's spinnaker boom yesterday. She will probably be in readiness for the bending on of her canvas by Friday, and may go out for a short sail on Saturday, though this matter has not yachts, some of which anchor over night in the path of the Staten Island Ferry boats and are liable to collision.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 23.--The old troubles over the proprietorship of land which have resulted in numerous suits in the southern part of this State are likely to be revived in Cape May County.

Young Henry S. Ives has managed to score a partial triumph over Assignee Cromwell, and although the latter has succeeded in getting the missing books incident before a Referee, yet the scope of the investigation is limited, and it is by no means the far-reaching, deep-delving, and wide-sweeping proceeding which Mr. Crom well hoped it would be.
The Guion steamship Wyoming, which arrived last night, encountered Sunday afternoon a hurricane, which sent wave after wave sweeping over the deck, and occasionally even over the companion way.

Creditors of Mitchell, Vance Co. were thrown into the slough of despond yesterday when they read that the assets were only $750,000 to meet liabilities of $775,000, with further contingent liabilities of $550,000. It was apparent that the entire capital of $1,200,000 had been sunk.

The Boston-Chicago game was prevented by rain yesterday. Getzein pitched strongly against Washington yesterday.
A crowd of men were made the victims of some practical joker yesterday by the old device of an advertisement announcing that two watchmen were needen at 32 Wall-street.

BOW ARROW POINT, Lake Champlain, Aug. 23.--The tandem paddling race was won by the canoe Dawn, owned by Leys, of Toronto, who was assisted by Barlow, of the Shattemues.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 23.--For several weeks past the sentiment of the Republicans throughout the State has been crystallizing upon Walter B. Brooks, of Baltimore, for the Gubernatorial nomination.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 23.--A telegram from Mery says the Ameer of Afghanistan's life is despaired of. One of his feet has been amputated owing to gangrene, and it is feared the shock will result in his death.
The Board of Managers of the Manhattan Athletic Club has been investigating some charges made against track members of competing with professionals.

BOSTON, Aug. 23.--A call has been issued, signed by many leading labor agitators, for a convention to be held on Sept. 10 to organize a new political party. Delegates from Knights of Labor assemblies, trades unions, union labor clubs, and other organizations of similar purposes are invited.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--Through shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from this city to seaboard points by the various railroads increased about 3,000 tons last week, the total shipments by eight railroads amounting to 19,644 tons, ...
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 23.--Mr. John S. Barbour's new Democratic State Committee, chosen at the Roanoke Convention, is holding its first meeting here to-night.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 23.--It is a long time since this small city has received such a surprise as that caused by our National Express Agent absconding with a package of $6,000.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 23.--No telegraphic communication has been had with the mainland since Saturday evening last, and it is feared that the Government cable across Vineyard Sound is broken.

GARDNER, Ill., Aug. 23.--Sarah Dodge may know how Walter S. Babcock received his death wound, but if she does she proposes to keep the knowledge to herself for the present.

CAMP GREEN, SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 23.-- The damp weather of the past 24 hours has made things exceedingly disagreeable at Camp Green. The dress parade last evening was abandoned, and the hundreds of visitors who were on the grounds were compelled to seek shelter under the soldiers' tents, while the rain fell in torrents.

One of the prettiest, sharpest, and best games of baseball of the season was played on the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the NewYorks won from the Pittsburg men by a score of 2 to 1. Welch, the popular little pitcher of the home team, was in the best possible condition, and he proved a complete enigma to the heavy batters of the visiting players.
Hundreds of spectators always go up to the Harlem to see the annual championship swimming races of the New-York Athletic Club.

From the time when first Mott-street and Chinamen became known to each other there has seldom arisen a question of more vital importance than one which stirred the depths of the Mongolian nature yesterday. It seemed, too, a question which might concern the whole American Nation as well as these sons of the Celestial Empire.

"Mein Gott, mein Gott, I vish I vos dead, too!" moaned a decrepit, toothless, and palsied old man yesterday afternoon as he sat in the back office of the police station at East NewYork, Long Island, and glanced fearfully at the blue-coated guard near the door.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 23.--For some weeks the colored people residing in the vicinity of Monroe and Wellington streets have been much exercised over the position of a clored girl about 12 years of age, who is living with a white man named McAllister.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 23.--A court-martial has been ordered by Commander Sampson, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, to convene this week and try Cadet E.E. Lang, of Ohio, a Third Class man, charged with hazing Cadet Long, a Fourth Class man. The hazing took place on shipboard and consisted of an attempt to force Long to make a meal on soup. He preferred to fight, and his plucky resistance attracted the attention of the officers.

Stock market prices continued to droop yesterday just as they did the day before, till the very close of the day, when there was a soda-fountain fizz all along the line, and quotations started upward at a lively rate. There are more bulls than there were.
MAYVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 23.--On the thirtyeighth ballot the Republicans of the First Chantauqua Assembly District to-day nominated S. Fred Nixon, of Westfield, for member of Assembly.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--The race for the Yorkshire Oaks for 3-year-old fillies at the York August meeting to-day was won by the Duke of Beaufort's ch. f. Rave d'Or by a length and a half, beating Douglas Baird's b.f. Maize, the only other starter. Four to one was offered on Reve d'Or.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 23.--Notwithstanding the mandates of the court, the threat of the Federal Government and the Canadian Pacific Railway, the people of Winnipeg still continue to build their new railroad to the boundary, and defy all to stop them.

Among others largely interested in the recent terrible Western railroad disaster are the life and accident insurance officials.
NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 23.--Judge Baker adjourned his section of the Criminal Court to-day, and leaves to-morrow for his Summer residence at Lyme, Conn.
WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 23.--The old South Meeting House, which stands on the common near the City Hall, was sold this morning at public auction to Benjamin S. Fenner, a veteran truckman, for $320.
The series of concerts now in progress at the Madison-Square Garden has met with popular favor, and accordingly the audiences have been of encouraging proportions.
Health Officer Lever, of Flushing, has made his report to the Board of Health in the cases of three employes in the Kleinert Rubber Factory at College Point who recently became insane.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--Gen. John M. Parke, of the Engineer Corps, arrived in this city last night, and will leave this week for West Point to assume the duties of Superintendent of the Military Academy.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 23.--Mrs. Julia Lockaby, the wife of a poor farmer of Greenville County, has recently developed extraordinary powers, similar to those possessed by Lula Hurst, the celebrated electric girl of Georgia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--The Supreme Council of the American Legion of Honor held the first session of its biennial convention in this city to-day at the building of the Law School of the National University.
OZARK, Mo., Aug. 23.--The Bald Knobbers are again in Ozark and the first day of the trial found the court room crowded with anxious spectators.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23.--The hop given on board the flagship Richmond this afternoon was the closing one of the series of entertainments given aboard the different vessels of the squadron in return for numerous kindnesses extended by the Summer residents ashore.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 23.--Among the passengers on the German steamer Rhine, which arrived here this morning, were two young persons who might have passed on the trip for a newly married couple.

The funeral of Frederick Clinch, who died last Sunday, took place yesterday at the residence, 62 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh-street. The service was performed by the Rev. W.C. Bitting, of Mount Morris Baptist Church. Among those present were James W. Todd, Dr. James A. Bennett, Alfred Marling, Dr. Harris, William Lalor, the Rev. Dr. George W. Samson, E.J. Chaffee, Henry L. Slote, and Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Dietz.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Another rainy morning made the track very heavy here today, and to that cause is attributed the very general defeat of the favorites in the various events.
