The new railroad in Manitoba, from Winnipeg to the northern boundary of Minnesota, will be ready for the ties and rails before the end of this week.
LONDON, Aug. 23.--The steamship Chicago, (Br.,) Capt. Jones from New-York Aug. 10, for London, passed the Scilly Islands to-day.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 23.--The dead body of Nicholas Landis, aged 18, was found hanging to a tree in the woods in Madison township, this county, ...

A suit was commenced yesterday by Morris Bimberg and Myer R. Bimberg, proprietors of Nilsson Hall, through their counsel, ex-Judge Dittenhoefer, against the city and Board of Po lice to test the question whether a theatrical license is required by the owners of ballrooms and parks where dancing is permitted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--The President to-day appointed Almer F. Dickson, of Massachusetts, to be Consul at Gaspe Basin; Henry P. Kitfield, General Appraiser of Merchandise for the port of Boston; Michael P. Curran, Assistant Appraiser of Merchandise in the district of Boston and Charlestown, Mass.

Oakland Rink, on Jersey City Heights, which has so often resounded to the fascinating burr of the roller skates, yesterday exhaled the seductive aroma of a mammoth greenroom. Scattered over its floor, piled in masses up to its very ceiling, were the scenic and other properties of the defunct National Opera Company.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23.--For many days the talk of society has been the musicale to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at their palatial residence, The Breakers.
The employes of J.S. Nugent Co. had an excursion to Elm Park, Staten Island, yesterday.

FRANCONIA, N.H., Aug. 23.--This is the busy season in the White Mountains, August and September being the liveliest months, and some of the largest hotels are actually turning people away for lack of accommodation.
PARIS, Aug. 23.--Prime Minister Rouvier will go on a tour through Switzerland. He will travel incognito.

The parties on whose application the last Rapid Transit Commission, now holding its sessions in the Equitable Building, was appointed are the present owners of the old New-York Underground, otherwise, known as the Vandenburgh, charter.

The censure of the Brooklyn Athletic Association for harboring professionals is only a beginning. Messrs. Halpin, Heggeman, and Sullivan, the Games Committee of the National Association of Amateur Athletes of America, have determined to sift to the bottom all charges made against amateur athletes of competing against professionals.

ABINGDON, Va., Aug. 23.--While Mr. S. Scott and Miss Broyles, of Lynchburg, visitors at Mongles Springs, were out driving, the horse became frightened and ran over an embankment 20 feet high into the Holstein River. Mr. Scott swam to the nearest shore, but the young lady staid in the buggy and forced the horse to swim to the opposite side of the river, where she was rescued by friends.

Forty-two men and women, who were captured in the seven houses on Thirty-second-street raided by the police Monday night, were arraigned yesterday at the Jefferson Market Court. The proprietresses of the establishments were released on $1,000 bail each. Of the others the men were fined $10 each and the women $5 each, except Edna Lenox, who, having offended Justice Duffy by laughing at him, was sent to the Island for six months.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 23.--There is talk among Knights of Pythias in this city of preferring charges before the Supreme Chancellor against State Chancellor Henry C. Housell. Mr. Housell is also Recorder of the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23.--Gov. Washington Bartlett, who has been in a precarious condition for some time, was stricken by paralysis last night, and little hope of his recovery is entertained.

MADISON, Ind., Aug. 23.--At Swan's Mill, Hanover Township, a young man named Rena Ellenhass, accidentally fell back ward to-day on a circular saw, which cut him open from the shoulder down and diagonally across his back.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 23.--What appears to be an uncalled-for strike was begun here today at the works of the Newark Lime and Cement Company, many quarrymen going out because walking delegates of the Knights of Labor ordered them to do so.

The action of Division No. 3 of the Ancient Order of Hibernians in asking Dr. McGlynn to lecture for it, without first securing the consent of the County Board of Directors of the order, and the expulsion of the division later, are causing much talk.

A woman about 30 years old, neatly dressed and attractive in appearance, was seen yesterday walking rapidly along Broadway, in Williamsburg. She waved her arms wildly and shrieked in a heartrending manner. An officer took her to the Bedford-avenue station house, where it was found that she was insane.

SOUTH FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 23.--It is reported here that the Clinton Yarn Company, of Clinton, Mass., is embarrassed with about $65,000 liabilities and $45,000 assets. It is stated that an as signment has been made to E.A. Brown Son. cotton brokers, of Boston, who, it is alleged, have a claim of $20,000 against the yarn company.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 23.--There is much activity in Watkins to-night on account of the regatta that is to take place at that village on Seneca Lake to-morrow and the next day.
At a meeting of the stockholders of the National Bank of Coxsackie, held at the Cummings House, 2,134 shares were represented by person or proxy.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The struggle for the possession of Annie Elizabeth Perkins, the 6-weeks-old child of Lieut. Con Marrast Perkins, of the flagship Richmond, now with the North Atlantic squadron off Bar Harbor, continues.

BOSTON, Aug. 23.--A convention of delegates from the various trades unions and organizations of Massachusetts was held to-day for the purpose of forming a State branch of the American Federation of Labor.

CRONSTADT, Aug. 23.--The Czar and family sailed for Copenhagen to-day on the imperial yacht Dershana.

Daniel O'Key, chief of the Mercantile Marine Department of the Treasury, sat in a little room in the Custom House yesterday and asked numerous questions tending to throw light upon the workings of the Commissioners of Emigration and their method of conducting affairs in Castle Garden.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 23.--A strange freak of lightning was reported from the town of Ramapo, Rockland County, yesterday. The house of August Bolger stands alone in a remote part of the town, nearly surrounded by large trees.
LENOX, Aug. 23.--The Summer visitor to Lenox usually spends his first Sunday with the Shakers. The Shakers inhabit a village nine miles from here, called New-Lebanon.

FALL RIVER, Mass. Aug. 23.--Mrs. Cleveland, accompanied by Gen. Greely and her mother. Mrs. Folsom, arrived here to-night in a special train from Marion, and left for New-York on the steamer Pilgrim.
BOSTON, Aug. 23.--Remly S. Sidelinger, President of the local Barbers' Union, and a leading labor agitator, recently trusteed a man's wages for debt.
The funeral of Henry Milford Smith, of the Grand Hotel, took place yesterday afternoon at 36 West Thirty-fourth-street. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Ormiston, of the Collegiate Church.

If the school boys and girls of this city could have been in the examination room at the Board of Education building on Grand-street yesterday their hearts would have rejoiced at the spectacle there presented.

PARIS, Aug. 23.--The Russian Prince, Pierre Wittgenstein, has died at Kenleon, near Brest, of grief for his wife, the daughter of a Breton fisherman, whom he had educated. He leaves his vast fortune to Princess Hohenlohe.

The crockery dealers propose to make it hot for the tea men who persist in giving away or selling crockery below cost. A meeting at the Cosmopolitan Hotel was attended yesterday by 14 crockery dealers representing New-York and Brooklyn.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 23.--Campbell Langley, the father of the once notorious and not yet forgotten Bill Langley, removed to Bell County, Texas, from near Lexington, Lee County, Texas, 12 years ago. During his residence in Lee and Bell counties he has been known as a well-to-do farmer and an upright citizen.

The mysterious Mrs. Fitch, who was taken to Bellevue Hospital about 10 days ago suffering from acute insanity, was removed from that institution yesterday morning by a man who gave his name as Frederick Masten.
The fifth annual State Convention of the New-York Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association was held yesterday in the Brooklyn Athenaeum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--Lieut. McC. Derby, Corps of Engineers, has submitted his annual report upon the river and harbor improvements under his charge in New-Jersey.
COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 24.--Gov. Hill, of New-York, arrived at Edgartown yesterday on the steam yacht Nearis and came up to Oak Bluffs by the noon train to-day.

DETROIT, Aug. 24.--The Rev. Dr. John G. Atterbury died in this city to-day at the age of 76. Born in Baltimore, he graduated at Yale, and studied law in New-York City, where he was admitted to the Bar. He came to Detroit in 1836, and was for six years engaged in the active ...

A smash-up occurred at 4 o'clock yesterday morning on the New-Jersey Central Road above Cranford. It blocked all travel over the road for nearly four hours. The locomotive of a coal train, owing to some defection in the signals, crashed into the rear of another coal train ahead of it on the down grade.

It is earnestly to be hoped that the Mayor will accede to the request of the State Board of Charities and cause a bill to be prepared for the next Legislature which shall establish a temporary reformatory for the older boys and girls of a vagrant class in this city.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24.--Rain has fallen nearly all day, and it proved to be one of the most disagreeable days of the season. The lawn tennis tournament was postponed, as was the polo match for the Cornelius Vanderbilt Cup. The storm, which began on Monday, has entailed a heavy loss, especially at the Casino, where the lawn tennis tournament was arranged for the entire week.
A kettle of fat in the kitchen of Vincent's Hotel, at Broadway and Third-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, boiled over yesterday and set fire to the building.
Bark America, Armstrong, from Barbadoes, Bark Belle Wooster, Higgins, from Cardenas.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 24.--Mr. John S. Barbour's State Democratic Executive Committee, at its session here today, made preparations for at once opening the Virginia campaign in the most vigorous way. A sub-committee was charged with the preparation of a reply to Mahone's recent, address, so far as that paper relates to the attitude of the Democratic Legislature on the debt question and other important State legislation.

The impairment in the capital of the Fire Association of New-York, the discovery of which was announced in yesterday's TIMES, promises to be immediately made up, with a resumption of business by the company under circumstances that are already brightening. A meeting of the Directors of the company to consider the situation and take action was held yesterday morning ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Mr. Allen Rutherford, a lawyer of high standing and extensive practice in this city, formerly an Auditor of the Treasury Department under President Grant, was arrested today upon a charge of receiving certain records stolen from the Pension Office.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--It is said that the dispatches sent out from the headquarters of the Iron Molders' Union at Cincinnati fail to explain the true situation. A strike has not been ordered, and cannot be until a vote has been taken upon the question by all the local unions in the association.

Acting Chief Dunwoody, of the United States Signal Service, telegraphed from Washington yesterday that "the cyclone previously reported is apparently central over the South Atlantic coast, and moving slowly northeast, causing dangerous gales."

BUFFALO, Aug. 24.--Until the "boom" shall have spent some of its terrific midsummer force politics will receive but comparatively little attention in Buffalo and the other towns of Erie County. All that one hears of now is "the boom." Everybody cannot know about it, though Buffalonians are astonished and indignant that a knowledge of it is not universal. In this instance it is a home-made, patriotic affair, ...

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--The Rev. William Franklin Davis is determined to be a martyr. He has been arrested many times for preaching on the Common without having obtained a permit, as required by the city ordinances, and this morning he was in the Municipal Court again on a charge of preaching on the Common last Sunday.
Two old war-ships--the Tennessee and the New-York--are to be sold at auction at the navy yard on Sept. 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Secretary Fairchild to-day opened the third lot of proposals for the sale of 4 per cent. bonds to the Government under the terms of the recent Treasury circular. The offers received to-day were as follows:

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--The Republicans are a little worried over the political standing of Essex County, because in recent years the Democratic vote has been an unpleasant thing for them to contemplate. To-day the leaders in the Republican Party had a love feast at the Essex House, Salem. Fully 150 persons were present.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 24.--Drafts--Sight, 10 cents; telegraphic, 15 cents.

HINTON, West Va., Aug. 24.--Information received here from McDowell County is to the effect that a dreadful state of affairs exists in that portion of the State and Southwestern Virginia. The drought has made the water very low, and the peculiar disease that has several times previously followed this ...

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 24.--It is rumored that a powerful syndicate of American capitalists, headed by one of the Vanderbilts, is negotiating with the Government for permission to work the Ural gold mines. The syndicate, it is said, will pay a yearly rental to the Government and will greatly increase the production of the mines. The Borsen Zeilung says that Berlin financiers think there is some basis for the report.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24.--Weidman received a warm reception from the home to-day. Four singles and five bases on balls were secured in the first inning. After that he settled down and pitched a very steady game.

A basket was found in the hallway of 284 West Twelfth-street last evening by Albert Kennedy, one of the tenants. When he opened it he was surprised to find nestling in it two little babies--a girl and a boy--apparently about a week old.

Steamship Richmond, Boaz, Newport News and Norfolk, with mdse. and passengers to Old Dominion Steamship Co. Bark Frank Stafford, (of Windsor, N.S.,) Smith, Kobe 151 ds., with mdse. to order--vessel to J.W. Parker Co.

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--The new lessee of the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, in New-York, who will take possession of that house next Spring, succeeding Mr. John Stetson, is Mr. Eugene Tompkins, of the Boston Theatre. Mr. Tompkins said to-night: "I have taken the Fifth-Avenue Theatre for a term of years. The lease was signed over a week ago. I have not made any plans for the future.

The Stock Exchange air was loaded down with sensational whispers all day yesterday. Up town and down town--if the circulating tales were to be believed--mercantile and banking firms of consequence were in serious trouble.

Oscar Schreiber, who keeps a barber's shop in Bethel, Conn., was at Police Headquarters last evening looking for his son, Oscar, 9 years old. Schreiber had in his employ for about a week a journeyman barber named Charles Riel.

At midnight Tuesday the steamer Pomona, while passing through Staten Island Sound, near Elizabethport, ran down a rowboat containing Alexander Maury and Joseph Shearer, employes of the Tidewater Oil Company, who were closing a valve of a bursted pipe line. Maury was drowned and Shearer had his head crushed by the paddle of the steamer.

If a cucumber, which is proverbially the type of what is refreshingly cool, had been in ex-Judge Noah Davis's office, in the United States Bank Building, yesterday noon, it would, despite the high humidity, have broken out into a profuse prespiration and resigned its Office, ...

Track laying has just begun with the view of extending the wheelbarrow trains of the Harlem Railroad from William's Bridge and Woodlawn to Tuckahoe, Westchester County, which is six miles beyond Woodlawn, the latter being the northern limit of the city.

ST. JOHN'S Newfoundlaud, Aug. 24.--Two ocean steamers, one in tow of the other, were signaled and arrived at 3:30 o'clock to-day. One of them, the Eagle, is disabled by the loss of her propeller and the breaking of her propeller shaft. She was bound from St. John, NewBrunswick, for Glasgow, and was lumber-laden.

Mrs. Cleveland did not make any stay in this city on her way home to Washington. She came in on the Fall River steamer Pilgrim, which arrived early in the morning. She was accompanied by Gen. Greely, of the Signal Service Department, Mrs. Greely, and Mrs. Folsom.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--League Championship--Philadelphia, 10; Indianapolis, 9. Batteries-- Maul, Ferguson, and Clements, Leitner and Hackett. Earned runs--Philadelphia, 7; Indianapolis, 6. Base hits--Philadelphia, 16; Indianapolis, 12. Bases on balls--Philadelphia, 8; Indianapolis, 2. Stolen bases--Philadelphia, 6; Indianapolis, 4. Errors-- Philadelphia, 2; Indianapolis, 5.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 24.--Reports from the interior of the river counties show that the heavy rains for the past month have resulted in much damage to the crops, including corn, potatoes, grapes, and plums. Almost daily showers have washed roadways and destroyed small bridges in every direction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--The convention of colored Masons reassembled to-day. J. Hugo Johnson, of Virginia, presented an interesting paper on "The True Status of Negro Masonry in America." Several equally well sustained orations were delivered. Then followed the routine work incident to a first convention.

There is a great and growing complaint among the dwellers on the banks of the Rhine and its tributaries, the Swiss tributaries especially, that the scarcity of salmon is increasing in so marked a manner that it will soon be virtually extinct in the waters in question.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 24.--Daniel Miller was arrested here to-day by Sheriff Waters, of Cooke County, Tenn., for horse stealing. The case illustrates a woman's infatuation for an unworthy object. Near Newport, Cooke County, Tenn., there lived Mrs. Martha Waters, a handsome widow with four children, a home, and $2,000 in bank. Near by lived Daniel Miller, a good-looking ...

PARIS, Aug. 24.--Disgusting scenes are taking place on the Place Roquette, where 5,000 roughs are camping out, awaiting the execution of Pranzini. The mob are singing indecent songs in reference to Pranzini, who, on being awakened by the noise, asked a warden the cause of it, and was told that it was occasioned by a strike.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--The Great Ebor Handicap, which was run at the York meeting to-day, furnished a big surprise to the betting fraternity, as Brydges Willyams's 5-year-old mare Silence, against whom 15 to 1 was laid, won it in a canter by five lengths from Oliver Twist, with Agitator a bad third, and Prince Rudolph, a hot favorite at 5 against 2, unplaced. Four others ran.

MONTREAL, Aug. 24.--The first meeting in favor of commercial union with the United States in the province of Quebec was held to-day at Shefford, in the richest and most fertile agricultural district in Quebec.

MONTREAL, Aug. 24.--Sir William Desvuoex, who has recently been appointed Governor of Hong Kong, left for that place to-day by the Canadian Pacific Railway. He was formerly Governor of Newfoundland and was instrumental in getting the British Government to allow the bait act. Speaking to THE TIMES'S correspondent on the subject, he said: "The act does not come into operation till next year, and ...
Bishop William L. Harris, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, was feeling much better yesterday afternoon and is so much improved that he will go to his home to-day.

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 24.--Emigrant train No. 83 coming west on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad this morning at 3 o'clock ran into freight train No. 88 at Easton siding, 20 miles east of this city.

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--The Boston Medical Library Association has just received from the University of Tokio, Japan, a collection of 210 Japanese medical works. The books are all in Japanese characters, and were shipped to this country 18 months ago.

Daniel Okey, of the Mercantile Marine and Internal Revenue Division, continued at the Custom House yesterday his investigation into Castle Garden abuses. David Schnitzer, the voluble little editor of the Emigrant, was the first witness examined. He had frequently been in Castle Garden, and had seen a great deal of the methods employed in handling immigrants' baggage.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--An open air meeting was held at Westminster this evening for the purpose of denouncing the Government's action in proclaiming the League. Mr. Biggar, member of Parliament for West Cavan, delivered an address, and was followed by Sir William VernonHarcourt. The latter quoted Mr. Chamberlain's statements of Saturday, to the effect that Ireland was free from crime.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24.--Two bases on balls, a fumble by Smith, and O'Brien's muff of a foul fly filled the bases with Cleveland runners in the first inning to-day, and then Allen brought in 3 runs by a hit to the left-field fence. Two more runs were earned in the same inning and Cleveland had the game won.

The sensational story started by a Newark paper to the effect that dysentery had become epidemic in Orange turns out to be a gross exaggeration. Dr. Buttner, a member of the Orange Board of Health, sailed for Germany yesterday, but Dr. Tiesler, the druggist, will attend his patients during his absence.

Cables to the Coffee Exchange and many firms yesterday told of a successful corner in German beet root sugar in London for August delivery. It is the work of a syndicate of German capitalists who operate through London houses.

An exceptionally attractive programme for the three days' racing under the auspices of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association has been prepared. Racing will begin on Saturday next, when five races on the flat and three over the sticks are to be run.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 24.--The American fishing boats belonging in Eastport, Me., recently seized near St. Andrews, New-Brunswick, which were loaded with fish and which were allowed to go on condition that after the fish were taken care of the boats should return and be given up, have been released on paying a fine of $20 each.

District Master Workman Dodd, of Newark, has at last acknowledged the authorship of the political boycott letter shown George A. Halsey last week, although at first he denied knowing anything about it or its author.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 24.--Compared with last year's, to-day's convention was tame as to personal antagonisms. The platform utterances for added severity toward liquor dealing were rather unexpected in view of a local bolt here, threatening the loss of two Assemblymen and evidence of dissatisfaction in several other localities.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 24.--Mr. Fred J. Ireland, a court stenographer of this city, has just returned from attending the convention of the New-York State stenographers at Alexandria Bay. This trip was the result of a controversy that has been in progress for the last two years between the shorthand man of the East and the West growing out of some correspondence between Mr. Ireland and the New-York association, in ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--The announcement that the President contemplates spending but one day in Chicago on his Western trip has thrown the Presidential Reception Committee into a fit of genuine consternation, and already steps have been taken to prevail upon Mr. Cleveland to change his plans and induce him to remain here two days at least.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--The committee representing the bondholders and stockholders of the Chester Valley Railroad have consulted with Austin Corbin, President of the Reading Railway, in regard to the reorganization and ...

The Extradition Conference reassembled yesterday morning in the rooms of the Bar Association, with delegates from 20 States present. Mr. Montgomery, of Georgia, Chairman of the Committee on Legislation, presented a report recommending enactments which the conference should ask Congress to embody in a law. It was agreed to take up each separately for discussion.

A test of the electrical currents that run Stephen Field's new electric motor on the Thirty-fourth-street branch of the elevated road was made yesterday, and the motor ran up and down a couple of times.
The New-York Poultry Exchange, which was organized in March last, and of which M. M. Pomeroy is President, H.C. Frink Secretary, and L.N. Clark Treasurer and General Manager, ...

SARATOGA, Aug. 24.--The rains of the past few days put the track here in very poor condition for racing, and the contests to-day were of but an indifferent character. The programme had little in it to attract any but regular racegoers who go to see the sport for what they can make out of it.

ROCKLAND, Mass., Aug. 24.--The Rock land Shoe Company has now a small strike on its hands which promises to develop into a serious affair. This morning the hand-sewers all left in a body because they had been refused an advance of 2 cents per pair on plain and captoes.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--The City of Montreal's missing boat was picked up on the l5th inst., and the seven passengers and six members of the crew who were in it are safe and well. The rescue was made by a German brigantine named the Mathilde, from Campeachy, which arrived at Falmouth to-day with the l3 survivors on board.
J.H. Wade, of Cleveland, is at the FifthAvenue Hotel. Columbus R. Cummings, of Chicago, is at the Windsor Hotel.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 24.--The Prohibition State Convention was called to order at 10 o'clock this forenoon by Chairman Stevens, of the Executive Committee. After half an hour spent in devotional exercises, in which a number of hymns were sung, including the long meter doxology, "Nearer, my God, to Thee," "Jesus, lover of my soul," "He Leadeth Me," ...

The chances of a reconciliation between the United Labor Party and the Socialists become daily more and more improbable. Although the Socialistic Labor Party has not yet formally declared against the United Labor Party, skirmishing between the factions began over two weeks ago. The main bodies of the two armies are approaching each other, and a pitched battle is imminent.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 24.--Among the curiosities of which Michigan can boast are two counties, each of which has a township that contains among its inhabitants a man and a woman who are over 100 years old. In Jackson County, in the township of Blackman, resides John Buchelder, his home being in the household of a son aged 75.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24.--The Northwestern Miller says:

About this time almost every year there comes down from the Cumberland mountains news that hundreds of the people in that region are dying of a peculiar disease. Our dispatches this morning show that the inhabitants of the counties which have suffered so severely in the past will not escape this year, for 200 persons have ...

Mayor Hewitt returned to this city from Bar Harbor yesterday. He said he had not yet read the report of the State Board of Charities on the management of the insane on Ward's Island. He had been informed, however, that the report stated that the members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment had been summoned before the investigating committee.

BOW ARROW POINT, Lake Champlain, Aug. 24.--The three-mile paddling and sailing combination race on the triangle outside, not limited, for Classes A and B, paddle and sail alternately, one half mile, a record event, resulted as follows:

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 24.--At daylight this morning the city stables, adjoining the City Hall, were destroyed by fire and four horses burned. While the firemen were examining the ruins the body of a man almost entirely consumed was found.

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--Col. L.W. Winchester, of New-York, Vice-President and General Manager of the National Express Company, and J. W. Hutt, of Albany, General Superintendent, were in this city to-day negotiating with Pinkerton's Detective Agency for the capture of ...

A Parliamentary paper has been issued containing a return for comparative monthly statements of the number of paupers of all classes (except lunatics in asylums and vagrants) in receipt of relief in England and Wales on the last day of every week in each month of the several years from 1857 to 1887, both inclusive, together with a statement of the number ...

Secretary Lawrence, of the Coney Island Jockey Club, has announced the weights for the three big handicap events to be run at the Fall meeting at the Sheepshead Bay track, which will begin on Thursday of next week.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 24.--The vessels of the North Atlantic squadron, which were to have left this afternoon for Southwest Harbor, were, on account of the approaching storm that had been signaled as coming up the coast, forced to remain at their anchorage, and a signal from the flagship caused them all to bank their fires and await the clearing of the weather.

OZARK, Mo., Aug. 24.--This was a day of great excitement among the Ozark Hills, as it was expected that the cases of the Bald Knobbers under indictment for murder would be reached. This little town was in an uproar all day. Nearly 2,000 persons assembled here, many of them being witnesses and friends of the accused.

Secretary Fairchild proves a lively thorn in the side of Wall-street's Government bond speculators. They started in to rig the market and levy a big tax on the Treasury. The result is that they find themselves loaded with securities they do not want, and Secretary Fairchild keeps on week by week making purchases at prices that grow regularly lower and lower.

Judge Donohue announced last evening that he would appoint Thomas F. Gilroy, Deputy County Clerk, to be the Receiver of Mitchell, Vance Co., and would fix his bonds at $100,000. The appointment will be made this morning, and it is expected that Mr. Gilroy will at once qualify and enter upon his duties.

Mr. OBERLY, of the Civil Service Commission, placed the principle of requiring reasons for removals in the public service on exactly the right basis when he said that it was demanded by the fact that public office is a public trust. "The civil service law," he stated in his interview with the correspondent of THE TIMES on Tuesday, "required that only men who ....

GARDNER, Ill., Aug. 24.--The veil which was lifted from the mystery surrounding the shooting of Walter S. Babcock long enough to see that Sarah Dodge held the weapon, has fallen again, and it is quite likely that it will never be lifted. Miss Dodge naturally prefers that it should remain down, and Babcock's friends will move heaven and earth to prevent Miss Dodge from ever being ...

Racing at Brighton Beach was brought to a close yesterday by the expiration of the 30day limit allowed by law to any one association. There was a good crowd present in spite of the threatening weather, and all hugely enjoyed the rivalry between jockeys Garrison and Jimmy ...

The wine, liquor, and beer dealers having sufficiently recovered from the exciting episodes which marked the closing scenes of Tuesday's convention, indulged yesterday in a parade through New-York and Brooklyn streets, followed by an alcoholic picnic in the faraway recesses of Ridewood Park.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 24.--Quartermaster Sergeant Smith passed through here yesterday from Mount Vernon Barracks, in this county, escorting Indian buck Roume and his wife Souni to imprisonment in Fort Pickens. The Indians at Mount Vernon Reservation are comparatively the free, and have the range of the country, although all are encamped inside of the reservation and are under official supervision.

In spite of the bad weather yesterday a large number of persons assembled on the Polo Grounds to witness the last game of the series between the New-York and Pittsburg Clubs. It was a repetition of the game of the previous day as regards clever work, but the scores were reversed and Pittsburg won by a solitary run.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 24.--In the House to-day the majority and minority reports of the Railroad Committee on the Hazen and Atherton bills were presented, with new drafts of the bills. The Hazen bill was reported by a majority of the committee.

HAVANA, Aug. 24.--The Intendent of the Treasury has tendered his resignation. In spite of the Governor-General's prohibition of a demonstration in his honor about 800 persons paraded the principal streets last night until they reached the palace, where they separated, after giving cheers for Spain, for the Governor-General, and for Gen. Salamanca.

Dr. Moreau Morris, Chief Inspector of the Summer Corps of Physicians, has written a letter to Secretary J.P. Faure, of St. John's Guild, in which he extolls the results obtained in the restoration to health and saving of life among sick children by the trips upon the guild's floating hospital.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24.--John K. Cowan, the fearless leader of the Citizens' Reform League, hurled a bombshell into Gorman's Democratic ring camp to-day and created a tremendous sensation in Republican political circles by entering the Republican State Convention and assuring that body in an eloquent and, forcible speech of the support of every independent Democrat in the State. It was the greatest political sensation Maryland has had for years.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24.--the Directors of the St. Louis, Alton and Springfield Railroad, better known as the Jerseyville Branch of the Wabash, have determined to issue bonds of the company to the amount of $1,200,000, for the purpose of completing the purchase of the road from the ...

WEIRS, N.H., Aug. 24.--Gen. John C. Black, Commissioner of Pensions, who is a guest of the New-Hampshire veterans, is reported quite sick with inflammatory rheumatism at the residence of the Hon. Stilson Hutchison on Governor's-street, and has been attended by three physicians.

The story is going the rounds that a young lady, wishing to have another good look at the Prince of Wales recently, walked up to the door of his carriage, when, much to her amusement, she saw his Royal Highness, before he was fairly seated, produce a little ivory-backed hair brush, with which he carefully arranged his remaining hair.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 24.--The scheme for the annual Worcester Music Festival, Sept. 26 to 30, has just been completed. The leading artists are Mme. Giuila Valda, Mme. Pappenheim, and Mrs. Maud Starkweather, sopranos; Mme. Zelie Trebelli and Mrs. Hattie J. Clapper, contraltos; Max Alvary, Jules Jordan, and ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 24.--Capt. James P. Murphy, one of the oldest and wealthiest citizens of Kittanning, was struck by the Buffalo express on the Allegheny Valley Railroad this morning and instantly killed. Capt. Murphy was born in 1796, and resided in Armstrong County nearly all his life.

The public will be gratified by the announcement that Messrs. OLMSTED and VAUX have been engaged to revise and complete their plan for the construction of Morningside Park. Some of the property owners immediately affected do not seem to share this general gratification. They are naturally anxious to bring their property into the market at the earliest date possible.

The Thistle's crew continued their work of scraping and polishing spars yesterday till everything aboard the handsome clipper shone like new brasswork. The work of bending on racing canvas was begun, but the wet weather sadly interfered with it, Capt. Barr being afraid of getting his canvas damp and exposed to mildew.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Civil Service Commissioner Oberly this forenoon completed and transmitted to the President his review of the conflicting reports of his two associates on the Chicago Custom House and Post Office investigation. He concurs generally in the views of Commissioner Lyman and combats the position taken by Commissioner Edgerton on the ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 24.--A light opera company which has been filling an engagement all Summer at Uhrig's Cave gave "Skipped by the Light of the Moon" last night with realistic effect. It is an old story of managers deserting a company, but in this instance the company deserted the manager, and left him in a very embarrassing situation.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 24.--Rough water prevented the rowing of the trial heats in the professional regatta at Watkins to-day. The heats will be rowed to-morrow, the position being the same as previously announced. Teemer is a strong favorite in the trial heats. Hamm, who expects to win in his trial heat, will work hard to win. The principal contest will be between Courtney and Bubear in the trial heat.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 24.--Grade crossings, their dangers, the responsibility therefor, and the necessity of separating the grades of railroads and highways were exhaustively discussed before the State Railroad Commissioners to-day at two hearings, at Westport in the forenoon and Norwalk in the afternoon. The Consolidated Road was represented by the Hon. ...

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The Knights of Labor strike at the Newark Lime and Cement Company's works here is a failure. Business was conducted pretty nearly as usual to-day with now hands. The strikers offered no violence and now are anxious to resume work.
Rain prevented the Boston-Chicago game yesterday. Rainey will probably play for the New-Yorks to-day. Ferguson, of the Philadelphias, is once more in good form.

Any assemblage other than the enthusiastic Prohibitionists now holding a camp meeting at Sing Sing would have become discouraged yesterday with the reverses they have had in the way of weather. Yesterday again leaden skies and a cold and exceedingly wet rain compelled the retirement of the hammock and the substitution ...

Shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning a boy ran up to Policeman Phillips, on Fortyfourth-street, near Second-avenue, and said that a young fellow down on the corner had tried to shoot him. Recognizing the boy as a son of Police Captain Ryan, Phillips went with him to First-avenue, where they found Daniel W. Dineen leaning nonchalantly against a lamp post.

Dentist John F. McAuliff, of Glen Cove, had a lady patient call on him one day last week to have her tooth pulled. He found that it would not give readily, and he then took the lady's head under his arm and pulled for all he was worth.

Two young persons of the Hebrew race attracted general attention as they sat in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday morning. One was a plump and comely brunette of about 19, whose round face and red cheeks made her resemble an Irish girl more than a damsel of "the people." The other was a man of 25, whose form, features, and gestures were Hebrew in the extreme, with the exception of his ...

The contract labor system, abolished by statute in 1883, goes out of existence in Sing Sing Prison at the close of this month, with the expiration of the contract of the Bay State Shoe and Leather Company.

Commodore Joseph H. Tooker, one of the leaders of the Irving Hall faction of the Democratic Party of this city, accompanied by his brother-in-law, Billy Florence, called at Police Headquarters yesterday.

WINNEPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 24.--Argument on the injunction restraining the Red River Valley Road from constructing their line to the boundary was postponed this morning for two weeks. Another bill of complaint was filed by George Jenkins. Matters are quieting down now and it is thought will be fought out in court.
LONDON, Aug. 24.--The steamship Hermann, (Belg.,) Capt. Meyer, from New-York Aug. 10, for Antwerp, passed the Lizard to-day.

OSTEND, Aug. 24.--Two of the men wounded in the affray yesterday between Belgian and English fishermen have since died. A number of the Belgian fishermen to-day seized two English boats and refused to give them up. They were fired upon by the police and four of them were wounded, one fatally.

Three members of the "bridge gang" were arrested late on Tuesday night in Jersey City. This is one of the worst gangs in the city, and has given the police considerable trouble for some time past. Recently they devised a new scheme by which to obtain money and were doing a thriving business until Tuesday night.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 24.--The Mineral Range Railroad, which runs from Hancock to Calumet, Lake Superior, had an election yesterday for a new Board of Directors. This action was owing to the recent failure of Henry S. Ives, of New-York, who was President, and had ...

Stern Myers, the Manhattan Bank's lawyers, made their second move yesterday in the fight to secure the $150,000 which Richard Seaman Scott store from the bank. Their first move showed on Scott's confession that Lawyer John R. Dunn had received and kept $140,000 of the stolen fortune, and though he swore he had lost it in speculation, they sued him for it.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 24.--Direct news from the seat of the Indian war would lead to the belief that a long drawn out conflict is unavoidable, but the feeling in Denver is that the situation is exaggerated. Gov. Adams is constantly in receipt of telegrams both from official and private sources requesting that more troops be sent in. He has also been officially requested to to declare martial law in Meeker and portions of Garfield County.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--The Philadelphia Times will say to-morrow that facts came to light to-day which illustrate anew the desperate things that stock gamblers will do in the hope of putting money in thier pocket. Severa of the most prominent of the Knights of Labor asserted that there was a clique of stock gamblers in Philadelphia and New-York who were egging on the Reading Railroad men to strike, in order to depress Reading stock.

WINNIPEG, Aug., 25.--Letters from Frazier and Stewart, dated Fort Chippewyan July 5, state that they reached that point after many hardships. Forest fires had been numerous and destructive. The destitution at Fort Chippewyan last Winter was terrible, and several cases of cannibalism are reported. One old woman at Little Red River admitted having killed and eaten her whole family. Starvation and cannibalism are also reported from Mackenzie River.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--Mr. Gladstone was greeted with cheers in the House of Commons this evening when he arose to move his resolution "that a humble address be presented to the Queen, representing that the Viceroy of Ireland has proclaimed the National League a dangerous association; that no information has been ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 25.--Jane Perry, a colored servant in the employ of Dr. Holmes, of Cranbury, was taken suddenly ill Tuesday night. She had gone to her room and soon after the doctor heard a heavy fall.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 25.--The steam yacht Nearis, of the New-York Yacht Club, arrived this evening en route to Bar Harbor, having on board Gov. Hill, of New-York; Gen. George J. Magee, John C. Noyes, Frederick Lovejoy ans wife, Austin Lothrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, and others. The party came ashore and visited various places of interest.

CAMP GREEN, New-Jersey, Aug. 25.--The weather has been delightful at Camp Green to day, and the military display was more extensive than at any time during the week. An Immense throng watched the review this evening.

HOUGHTON, Mich., Aug. 25.--The officers of the Calumet and Hecla Mine feel positive that the they expect to open the shaft again on Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--The race for the Great Yorkshire Stakes, for 3-year-olds, run at the York meeting to-day, was won by Lord Zetland's colt Panzerschiff, with Gallinule second, and Cactus third.

BOSTON, Aug. 25.--The funeral services over the remains of Rear Admiral Thomas J. Craven, United States Navy, were held at Charlestown yesterday, Chaplain Royce, of the United States receiving ship Wabash, officiating. All the officers attached...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 25.--Several Mormon families have settled near Medicine Hat, Northwest Territory. They have intimated to the authorities that then do not propose to carry out the principles of their religion, at least in as far as marrying more than one wife is concerned. The government will therefore not molest them. The Northwest papers have welcomed the new arrivals.

Every follower of baseball in this city could be distinguished last night by the happy look that adorned his face, and the vicinity of the Polo Grounds, the scene of many a well fought diamond field battle, was pervaded by an air of peace and contentment as the sun went down behind the tall trees in Central Park.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25.--Miss Lina Harrison, daughter of ex-Mayor Carter H. Harrison, is to be married to-morrow to Mr. Heaton Ousley. The ceremony will take place in the old Trinity Church, New-York.

MILLER, Ind., Aug. 25.--The schooner Clara, of Manistee, was driven ashore yesterday and hot wreckage is strewn along the beach for miles. Capt. Brokers Grovesteen Pell made an assignment yesterday, and Phil Harding, Assignee, says the liabilities rise to $1,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--Much difficulty will be experienced in filling the place of Prof. Spencer F. Baird as Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries. The law authorizing the appointment of such an officer is an exceptional one, made to fit one person and one person only--the late Prof. Baird. The duties of the office are defined...

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 25.--The Union Medical Association, which includes physicians of Pennsylvania and Maryland, held its annual reunion at Mount Gretna Park to-day, and about 300 physicians were present with their wives and families.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 23.--According to official advices the number of Canadians engaged in the mackerel fishing industry has doubled since the opening of this season. The catches have been remarkable ...

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Aug. 25.--The Directors of the St. Louis, Kansas City and Colorado Railroad Company, the name under which the Santa Fe Company will construct its new line from St. Louis, by way of this city, to Chanute, met in the parlors of the Huntington House today and formally transferred the road to the representatives of the Santa Fe Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25.--Those of the creditors of Maurice Rosenfeld Co. who agreed to accept a final settlement of 25 cents on the dollar want their money badly, and do not see why they should be kept out of it so long.

He then explains the long time he has allowed to elapse before promulgatiug his decision.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 25.--District Attorney Martine was seen at the Octagon Hotel, Seabright, to-night, by a TIMES reporter. The Public Prosecutor had received notice of the decision by Judge Potter in the Sharp case, but had not read the opinion. Its essential points were explained, and he was asked if the Whitehall Judge's notion was not a surprise.

DETROIT, Aug. 25.--Judge Daniel Goodwin, the Nestor of the Michigan Bench, died last night at his residence in this city, after an illness of some months. He was born in Geneva, N.Y., Nov. 24, 1799. HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 25.--The Prohibition Convention got down to business this morning. Mr. Black, of Lancaster, named S.B. Chase, of Northampton, for Supreme Judge, paying him a glowing tribute, and Mr. Chase was unanimously nominated, the delegates rising and cheering as they made the nomination.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 26.--Prof. H.S. Whitney, of the Excelsior Academy, on the shore of Lake Minnetonka, was drowned in the lake yesterday. Three children were playing on a raft, which went to pieces, and he, swimming out to save them, became tangled in the weeds and was drowned. Two of the children were rescued, but the third was drowned.

NEWPORT, Aug. 26.--The weather is very cool, and thick clothing was brought out to-day. As was to be expected, the attendance at the Casino dance to-night was rather light, society having had enough dancing this week.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26.--Recorder of Voters H.W. Williams makes public the statement that he has discovered that nearly 20,000 of the names now on the registration lists are fraudulent.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--It is reported in Berlin that a fresh attempt to kill the Czar was made on the 20th inst. A Nihilist disguised as an officer of the Guards approached the imperial carriage on a journey from St. Petersburg to Krasnoe Sels and fired a revolver twice. The first shot missed the Czar, but the second perforated his coat. The Czarina has since been suffering from nervous prostration.

Mrs. Bertha Schaul complained at Police Headquarters last night that her husband, Adolph, had deserted her. She had lived with her husband and their two children, aged 19 months and 4 months, at 188 Orchard-street.

PIERRE, Dakota, Aug. 26.--Douglass F. Carlin, chief clerk at the Cheyenne Agency, was married to-day to Madien Duprest, the wealthiest Indian heiress on the Sioux reservation. Carlin is closely connected with prominent army officers and with the Carlins of Illinois. Over 1,000 Indians witnessed the ceremony, and the festivities will last three days.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 26.--To-day's news from the scene of the Indian troubles shows the situation to be more precarious than ever. A portion of the militia under Major Leslie came upon the Indian camp, and the Utes and the soldiers are now encamped near each other. Major Leslie claims that he has the Indians in a position where he has the better of the situation.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 26.--At 5 o'clock yesterday morning the schooner Winnie, Capt. Cann, from North Sydney, for Halifax, with a cargo of coal, sprang a leak off Canso and was run on Frying Pan Ledge. The crew were saved but the vessel is a total wreck.

HAVANA, Aug. 26.--The excitement over the removal of officers at the Custom House here by the Governor-General continues unabated. Last night a crowd of over 2,000 persons assembled in the park to hold another demonstration over the affair. The police, reinforced by troops, vainly attempted to disperse the crowd, and were finally compelled to make a charge, wounding seven persons.

James Gumbleton sat in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday until all the business had been disposed of, and then, approaching Justice Duffy's desk, untied a bulky package of documents with trembling fingers. "Your Honor," he said. "I apply for a warrant for the arrest of Henry A. Gumbleton for fraud. I am his brother, and he cheated me out of many thousands of dollars."

Owosso, Mich., Aug. 26.--During last night's storm the house of W.G. Ketchum was struck by lightning and shattered in almost every part, without injuring any of the eight persons who were eating supper, although all felt the shock.

Receiver Gilroy began work at the store of Mitchell, Vance Co. yesterday morning by discharging Manager and Treasurer Smith. He also retained Secretary Bonner to assist him in the work of taking the inventories.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 26.--On account of the unfavorable condition of the water the regatta which was to have taken place on Seneca Lake has again been postponed until Sept. 6 and 7. The full programme will be rowed on those days, and a consolation race will be added, with an extra purse of $225, divided as follows: One hundred dollars to the first, $75 to the second, and $50 to the third.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26.--The Rev. Charles F. Goss, Pastor of Moody's Tabernacle, withdrew his resignation last night, the congregation voting not to receive it. Several members of the Board of Trustees not in accord with Mr. Goss were removed, and complete harmony in the church was restored.

FAIRMOUNT, Ill., Aug. 27.--The Wabash detectives succeeded until yesterday in keeping quiet an attempted train wrecking near Danville last Wednesday morning.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 27.--The Hon. John A. Elliott died suddenly early this morning of peritonitis, arising from an unsuccessful operation for hernia. He was born at Armagh, Indiana County, Penn., Sept. 24, 1824.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 27.--A telegram received from Rangley, Col., at 8 o'clock to-night shows that the Indian war is over for the present at least.

The Richmond County Republican General Committee met yesterday at Schmeiser's Hotel, Stapleton. A large amount of important business was trasacted and the primaries throughout the county were set for next Saturday. The county Convention will be held on Saturday, Sept. 10.

William Hayes, who won't tell where he lives, went on a fishing excursion on Friday night in Harlem. He fastened a wire hook to a leather strap and wandered along the streets until he came to F.C. Gleason's jewelry store, at 2,346 Third-avenue.

The Kings County Republican General Committee will hold a special meeting next Thursday, at which it will be decided to hold the ward primaries on Sept. 6 and the Assembly District Conventions on Sept. 8.

A great fire broke out at Scutari on Sunday afternoon, and, owing to the strong wind, spread with tremendous rapidity. The fire lasted about 10 hours, and as nearly the whole of the quarter consisted of wooden houses, there was no stopping the flames. Over 1,000 buildings, including several churches, mosques, and schools, were destroyed. More than 5,000 people are homeless and destitute. The Sultan has sent 3,000 to the sufferers.

The results of the survey and last census of India are that the area of the peninsula of Hindostan is 1,382,624 square miles and the population 253,891,821. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 28.--ExMayor Thomas L. De Russey, a prominent and wealthy resident of this city, was attacked with paralysis at 6:30 this evening, while riding on a horse car. He was taken to the Railroad Hotel, where he died half an hour later without recovering consciousness.

According to intelligence from Askabad the construction of a road for vehicular traffic to the Russo-Persian frontier has been begun. The object in view is to attract the trade of Khorassan to Askabad. The road starts from the railway station of the town of Askabad, and the work is being actively pushed forward.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--Judge McCue, Solicitor of the Treasury, designated by the President to act as Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, without extra compensation, it is said, is disposed to accept the appointment and go to work in dead earnest to master the duties of the office if the President so desires.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28.--The mountainous section comprising Tennessee, Southwest Virginia, Eastern Kentucky, and Western North Carolina has at present only meagre railroad facilities, but promises to soon be the scene of the greatest activity in railroad building ever known in the United States.

SARATOGA, Aug. 8.--It is expected that there will be a very full representation of Democratic State Committeemen at Tuesday's meeting. Jndge Muller, who represents the Chemung District, is at work trying to breed mischief in the party, and a very close eye will be kept on his movements.

The Rev. Jacob Whitehurst, of the First Baptist Church at East New-York, resumed his pastoral duties yesterday after his midsummer vacation. The little brick church, with its brightly decorated interior, was made doubly attractive by a profuse and tasteful arrangement of flowers.

Yesterday was the last day of the great Plattdeutache Volksfest, at Schuetzen Park, New-Jersey. About 10,000 people crowded into the park yesterday afternoon. The streets in its vicinity were thronged all day with vendors, and every street car which ran between Jersey City and the picnic grounds was crowded to its utmost capacity.

BOSTON, Aug. 28.--Jesse Pomeroy, the child torturer and murderer, who is serving a life sentence in the Charlestown State Prison, made a second attempt to secure his freedom a fow nightsago. It was by the merest accident that Pomeroy's plans were discovered.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 28.--A stranger, apparently a cigarmaker, was run over and killed this evening. The initials "G.C.T." on the man's shirt collar are the only clues to his identification. His age is about 35. He has black hair and mastache.

None but professional toreadors, matadors, and picadors, however, will be permitted to give entertainments, and the public are to be rigidly excluded from the arena proper.

DECATUR, Ga., Aug. 28.--The funeral of the victims of yesterday's riot toot place before an immense crowd to-day. Rumors are thick of a negro uprising, but they are without any foundation except the fears of the people. The roads in all directions are picketed to-night for several miles out.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--The opening week of the Chicago dramatic season presented nothing in the way of a novelty. The attendance at the different houses was, however, vary large, showing an avidity on the part of the public for theatricals, which promise well for the coming...

Mrs. Sophie Heidelberg, the wife of John Heidelberg, an employe in a soda water factory, attempted yesterday afternoon to commit suicide in the hallway at 129 First-avenue. She is now in Bellevue Hospital and probably cannot recover.

Bishop O'Farrell, of Trenton, yesterday morning dedicated the new Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual help, at Highlands, N.J. The edifice is frame, with stone and brick foundation. The dimensions are 30 feet front by 67 feet deep by 25 in height inside the roof.

The past month, so the reports of the Board of Health show, has been very healthy, healthier than the previous July. This improvement has been marked for some time last Summer showing fever deaths than the previous one, and the warm season having become, for some years, the healthiest portion of the year.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 28.--Jennie Knight and Annie Raymond quarreled and fought in a saloon on the corner of Sixth and Elm streets at a late hour last night and Annie killed Jennie with a dagger.

The Fourth Auditor of the Treasury has informed the Paymasters of the navy that they are not entitled to a clerk when there are less than 175 men aboard their respective vessels, the law to the contrary notwithstanding.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 28.--The theory that the body found on the banks of the Raritan River, Wednesday night, is that of Frank or "Winkie" Conover, has been practically abandoned. Conover was caught in the Bound Brook Post Office, last February.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--The second section of passenger train No. 53 on the West Shore Railroad collided with freight train No. 102 near Port Byron this morning. The express messenger was killed, and Engineers Miller, of the passenger train, and Ludwig, of the freight train, were injured.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 28.--The scene of Thursday's battle with the Utes is one of intense excitement. There are now on the battle ground in the neighborhood of 600 Indians.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 28.--M. Vulkovitch, the Bulgarian representative here, has informed the Porte that the Bulgarian Government is ready to pay 150,000 on account and to negotiate for the remainder of the Roumelian tribute and contribution to the Turkish debt charge.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 28.--The Times will publish to-morrow answers received to inquiries sent out through Kansas and Missouri as to Presidential preferences. In Missouri 270 answers from Democrats were received. Of these 251 were for Cleveland, 3 for Thurman, 1 for Wade Hampton, and the rest scattering. The Republicans sent 261 answers, of which 125 were for Blaine, 77 for Sherman, 41 for Lincoln, and the rest scattering.

A work for specialists, the manual industriously compiled by the Curator of the National Museum at Washington, should not be overlooked in the press of books which appeal to a wider circle. It is a book of reference, of course, but one peculiarly needed by the professional ornithologist and the amateur of collects birds and eggs.

George Charles Spencer Churchill, Duke of Marlborough, Marquis of Blandford, twice an Earl and twice a Baron, arrived from England on the Umbria yesterday morning and stepped for the second time upon American soil. The Duke is a medium-sized unassuming man of about 40 years.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 28.--A great deal of feeling has been developed over the proposed ordinance granting some 3,000 feet of water front to the Illinois Central Railroad. The labor organizations are pronounced in their opposition to the grant, but it is held that a sufficient vote has been obtained to pass the ordinance through the Council on Tuesday night.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 28.--Mrs. Anna Degraw, of Brooklyn, was horsewhipped to-day at Morgan Station, Summer resort near South Amboy, by Mrs. Mary Snyder. Mr. Snyder had loaned Mrs. Degraw a horse and phacton, and his wife, hearing of the fact, became jealous and waited until the lady retunred, when the horse whipping took place. Mrs. Snyder was arrested and taken before Justice Mount and released on bail.

Prof. Meyer Aaron Goldschmidt, whose death was telegraphed by our Berlin correspondent yesterday, was a distinguished Danish poet, novelist, and journalist. He was of Israelitish origin, being the son of Aaron Goldschmidt an Leah Rothschild, and was born at Vordinborg, in the Isle of Jutland, on Oct. 26, 1819.

PHELPS, N.Y., Aug. 28.--Prof. Brooks, of the Red House Observatory, obtained a good abservation this morning of the new comet recently discovered by him in the eastern heavens. The comet is note in constellation Cancer, 1 east of the star Iota. It is moving less than 1 daily toward the sun and becoming brighter.

Rockaway Beach and Canarsie were unusually quiet yesterday, although thronged with people until late at night. There was a tub race at Canarsie in the afternoon. The event of the day at Rockaway was a drowning case. Saturday evening a middle-aged German hired a boat at Holland's Station and went out fishing.

It will be interesting to compare the two works. Mr. Rossetti's book will probably be ready in September.

That success was viewed with envious eyes by men interested in other tracks hereabout. Midsummer race meetings at tracks which can be more easily reached than the Monmouth track are a certainty next year.

John McMahon is only 15 years old, but he acts as bartender for Mrs. Margaret Delaney, a widow who keeps a small drinking place at 180 Eleventh-avenue. He was arrested yesterday morning for having the place open and the bar exposed. Justice Duffy thought the testimony insufficient to make out a case and the complaint was dismissed.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 28.--Mr. William C. Glenn, whose co-education bill has attracted so much attention, is not at all pleased with the Calvin resolution withdrawing the eight-thousand-dollar appropriation from the colored college unless satisfactory evidence is furnished that white children will not be educated there. He has given public expression to the rumor that influence from a high source has been brought to bear against his bill, but he proposes to push it nevertheless.

DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 29.--Young Colburn, who found a package of greenbacks in an old feed trough in a tumble-down barn last week, still refuses to disclose the amount of his find. From some careless remarks he has dropped it is generally believed that the package contained upward of $20,000.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 29.--Crawford and Daly's opera house walls, 150 feet high, collapsed this morning at 11 o'clock. Nobody was hurt. The accident was due to the inferior quality of brick used. The loss will amount to about $15,000. The house was to have been opened Sept. 15.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 29.--The United States Marshal here received to-day from the United States court of the Western District of Michigan a copy of the indictment against the notorious "Blinkey" Morgan, under which he was imprisoned in the Grand Rapids Jail, from which he mysteriously escaped before trial.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 29.--Archbishop Corrigan is determined that German Catholics shall neither dance nor drink beer at picnics held under the auspices of the church after 6 o'clock in the evening. Mr. John McKeown, of Oil City, Penn., struck it rich. On the 22d of last June an oil well that he had been boring came in. It was a good well from the start. At first it yielded 80 barrels an hour. After producing at this rate a few days it was drilled deeper into the sand.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Aug. 29. --A brisk earthquake shock was experienced here about 7 o'clock this morning, agitating houses and making the people dizzy. In some streets people ran out of their houses and fell on their knees praying.

The first performance of "The Still Alarm" at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre will be given to-night. Mr. Rosenquest decided to postpone the opening of his house for a day yesterday morning, so as to secure additional rehearsals of the mechanical scenes in the new melodrama.

Prof. T.S. Baldwin made another leap from his balloon at Rockaway yesterday afternoon and a great crowd had assembled on the beach to see him do it. The balloon left its moorings behind the museum at 4:20 o'clock.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29.--The weather is charming and Newport is as gay as ever. Fully 1,500 people entered the Casino to-day and witnessed the exciting lawn tennis matches. Ten steers were found dead in the stables this morning.

MOREHEAD, Ky., Aug. 29.--Cal Tolliver, the lad who was spared by the Logans during the massacre, was fired on yesterday from ambush near town. Several of Logan's followers who have been indicted for supposed participation in the massacre, are hiding in the mountains near town, heavily armed, and can not be arrested. Troops will leave when court adjourns, and it is expected that fighting will begin then.

BERLIN, Aug. 29.--The Socialists have issued a circular to members informing them that a conference of the leaders of the society will be held abroad in the Autumn. The date for holding the conference and the place where it will be held is kept secret.
LONODN, Aug. 29.--The steamship Vorwarts, (Ger.,) Capt. Kron, from New-York Aug. 15, for Bremen, passed the Isle of Wight to-day.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--Sir George Stephen, Sir Donald Smith, and W.C. Van Horne, arrived from the Pacific coast this afternoon. Mr. Van Horne,when asked by THE TIMES'S correspondent what course the Canadian Pacific Railway intended to pursue in reference to the Red River Valley Railway scheme, replied.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 29.--Considerable alarm is felt in the upper part of Middlesex County over the spread of pleuro-pneumonia. It is said that the farmers conceal the existence of the disease in their herds and sell their cattle to prevent loss when condemned by the State Inspector.

State Fish Commissioner E.G. Blackford received a dispatch yesterday stating that Judge McCue had declined the United States Fish Commissionership. He expressed much regret. While the appointment, he said, had been only a temporary one, Judge McCue's friends would...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--The superintendent of the Recruiting Service has been ordered to send 30 recruits to Fort Snelling, Minnesota, for assignment to the Twelfth Infantry, and 15 colored cavalry recruits to such points in the Department of Arizona as the commanding General of the department shall designate for assignment to the Tenth Cavalry.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Aug. 24.--The schooner Mabel F. Staples, Dickson, from New-York Aug. 2, for Caibarien, arrived here in distress Aug. 21. On Aug. 18, latitude 24 43. longitude 73 18, she experienced a hurricane, during which she sprung her foremast badlY and lost foretopmast bowsprit, and some sails and rigging.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 29.--The Scotch yacht Mohican, owned by the Clarks, of Paisley, arrived here last night from the Clyde, bound for NewYork. She has on board the crew of the St. John shipLillian, who ware wrecked in a hurricane on Friday, and taken off by the Mohican after five hours' work on Saturday. The Lillian was bound from Rotterdam to New-York.

When the case of young William Purbs was called in the Tombs Police Court yesterday Justice Murray said: "I am sorry, gentlemen, but I shall have to put you off for another week. Our official stenographer has not returned from his vacation, and this is a case that can't be tried without a stenographer.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 29.--The railroad and warehouse commission has received a letter from Frank M. Johnson and W.S. Jackson, of Streator, who were on the passenger train going south on the Streator branch of the Wabash Railroad, which was wrecked between Conell and Manville Station, on the 9th inst., turning the car with 20 passengers over on its side.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 29.--Albert Howell, aged 30 years, a letter carrier, was arraigned to-day on a charge of embezzling letters, and was held in $1,500 bail for the September term of court. Howell never stole the letters on his own route, but, took letters from the boxes of other carriers before they had been put in the pouches. Howell is a church member, and carried his religious zeal into his business, always...

ST. JOHN'S N.F., Aug. 29.--Gen. Dashwood, who has just returned from Labrador, publishes a letter in to-day's Colonist, disputing the claim of the Hudson's Bay Company to the salmon fishery in Sandwich Bay and other parts of Labrador. He says the company exacts 10 per cent. toll on salmon caught at their posts.
LIVERPOOL, Aug. 23.--The Caledonia corn ring has collapsed. SIMLA, Aug. 29.--News from Afghanistan reports that the Sotaks have abandoned the rebellion and returned home.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 29.--The Hon. Frank H. Hurd, of Toledo, passed through this city to-day on his way to Montreal, and tarried long enough to be interviewed. "Of course," he said, "everybody understands that I am heart and soul in sympathy with everything which tends in the direction of free trade. That has been my life work.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 29.--The Government of British Colombia has forwarded to the Dominion Government a memorandum calling attention to the importance of the seal fishery industry of British Columbia, which is in danger of being wiped out, owing to the action of American cruisers in Behring Sea, and urging that a settlement or the whole fisheries dispute between Canada and the United States should be effected at once.

MONROEVILLE, Ind., Aug. 29.--The child so brutally abused by its stepfather, John Waterside, at Smiley, near here, died yesterday from the effects of the cruel treatment it had received, and for which he is now in jail, and his wife will be as soon as the others can find her.

During the present week Gen. JOHN G. PARKE, the new Superintendent of the Military Academy, will assume his duties at that institution in place of Gen. WESLEY MERRITT, who, on his promotion to the grade of Brigadier-General, was relieved...

OTTAWA, Aug. 29.--The tremendous storm predicted by Prof. Wiggins, of this city, and announced in the Detroit Free Press of Aug. 22, 1885, is due to strike America on the 19th of September next. Prof. Wiggins expects it to the most violent blow of the century.

James Conlin, aged 18, who lives at 492 First-avenue, was one of a crowd of boys who last evening devoted themselves to annoying Charles Wellbrook, a grocer at 405 East Twentyninth-street. LOUISVILLE, Aug. 29.--The game with the Mets this afternoon was witnessed by a fair crowd. Up to the soventh inning the contest was a very pretty and close one, but at that point the home team began to pound Mays unmercifully, running up 7 rune. In the next inning O'Brien took Mays's place.

"Will John Swinton run? The Socialists will nominate him against Henry George. They say he will accept and will beat the United Labor leader out of sight," These were some of the head lines in a morning paper to which Mr. Swinton's attention was called yesterday.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 30, via Galveston. --The Government is giving serious consideration to the subject of cheapening interior postage. Up to last June the receipts of the Post Office Department for the fiscal year were $748,000, against $681,000 for the previous fiscal year.

LAURENS, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The Second Assembly District Republican Convention met at this place to-day. Newton A. Marcy was chosen Chairman and J.E. Parshall and Tilly Blakely, Secretaries. ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30.--Brooklyn gave the Champions another hard fight to-day. The fielding on both sides was clean and sharp, and the game abounded in pretty plays. Toole, however, was not very effective, and the Browns got in their work when hits were most needed.

Robert L. Fernald, a son of Daniel F. Fernald, the President of the Montauk Insurance Company of Brooklyn, was the plaintiff in an action for absolute divorce in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. His young and pretty wife, Annie, is the defendant. She was not in court yesterday.

The tug Imperator left Bayonne early yesterday morning for the Erie Basin. While half a mile of Robbin's Reef Light the schooner H.N. Havens was sighted near at hand. A deck hand on the Imperator had been cleaning the windows of the pilot house. Capt. Christopher Nelson was steering.
"Reader."--Accent on the second syllable. The Board of Aldermen failed for want of a requisite number of votes yesterday to pass the tax levy and will meet again to-day for that purpose.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--The Arbitration Committee of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company's employes, appointed at the Tamaqua convention, met the Receivers and chief executive officers of the company to-day. The vexed question of the color test examinations was not settled in all its details, but it can be definitely stated that there need be no strike.

CLARION, Penn., Aug. 30.--Mrs. Belle Feely, an insane inmate of the county jail, was burned to death in her cell yesterday, the result of a fire she had kindled with paper torn from the walls. The flames communicated to her clothing, and before assistance arrived her flesh was burned to a crisp. Mrs. Feely seems to have sought death by this horrible method, since she told the nurse in attendance that she wanted to die.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--Mr. W.S. Chisholm, general counsel of the Southern Express Company, has submitted to the Inter-State Commerce Commission a printed answer to the circular communication of the commission, in which answer the company argues that it is not legally bound to furnish schedules of rates.

JOLIET, Ill., August. 30.--Mail Agent Henry Morgridge, of Milton Junction, was killed to-day on the Rock Island Railroad, near where Express Messenger Nichols was murdered, half way between Joliet and Minooka. The train was going toward Chicago, and Mail Agents Brant and Morgridge occupied the mail car. Upon the arrival of the train at Joliet Brant notified the train hands that Morgridge was missing.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 30.--About 200 delegates from all parts of the country are attending the ninth annual meeting of the American Library Association at the Round Lake House. The first meeting was held here this afternoon.

Surrounded by bric-a-bric, stage properties, and a great collection of curiosities picked up during his trips in different parts of the world, Augustin Daly sat yesterday in the cozy little study on the stage of his theatre, where the hard work of his managerial life is done, when a TIMES reporter approached him.

The war in Long Island City between Mayor Gleason and the police authorities on the one hand and Police Justice Delahanty and his cohorts on the other degenerated into a sort of guerrilla affair yesterday.

In a Chatham-square liquor saloon may now be seen, at any time of day, "the real original Claimant, Sir Roger Tichborne." The proprietor says he will give $500 to any one who can prove that he has not secured the veritable Sir Roger.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--There was a further improvement in east-bound freight shipments last week. The total shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from Chicago through to seaboard points by the various lines during the week amounted to 23,542 tons, against 19,644 tons for the week previous.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30.--Although the President has declared that he did not desire any political demonstrations during his visit to this city, the leading Democratic organization is making arrangements to tender him a big reception, in which they propose to have 10,000 Democrats in line.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30.--The Manufacturers' Record of this week contains about five pages of special reports from the entire South as to the crops and the condition of business. The corn crop of the South is unprecedentedly large, exceeding the yield of 1886 by over 50,000,000 bushels, the yield of 1885 by 70,000,000 bushels, and the yield of 1884 by 107,000,000 bushels.

A sale of old junk and some new articles took place at the navy yard yesterday. The gain to the Government was not made known, but it will not be a large sum. That great interest was taken in the sale was apparent from the crowd that surged about the auctioneer.

Jesse Combs, a wealthy feed dealer living in Brooklyn, was the plaintiff in a suit for absolute divorce which came up for trial before Judge Clement, in the Brooklyn City Court, yesterday. The defendant was Mrs. Zillah Combs, who at present is lving with her husband's cousin, Frank P. Harris, at 622 Hooperstreet. It was this cousin, Mr. Combs testified yesterday, who caused all the trouble. There was no defense and the divorce was granted.

DOVER, N.H., Aug. 30.--Mollie Hussey, a beautiful girl, 15 years old, is missing from her home in Rochester, and almost the entire village is out hunting for her. About a year ago her mother died and Mollie took the sad event very much to heart. Almost every pleasant day since she has visited the cemetery and placed fresh flowers on her mother's grave.

Emigration Commissioner Edmund Stephenson began suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against the New-York World to recover $50,000 damages for libel. The alleged libelous article was published in the issue of the World of Aug. 23, and charged Mr. Stephenson with gross corruption in office.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 30.--Up to 7 o'clock to-night no news has been received concerning the steamer Knickerbocker, which is now four days overdue. LONDON, Aug. 30.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Lessing, Capt. Barends, sld. from Havre to-day for New-York.
PARIS, Aug. 31.--Henri Pranzini, the Rue Montaigne assassin, was executed at an early hour this morning.

All the seats in the meeting room of the Faith Home, at 103 West Twenty-seventhstreet, were filled yesterday afternoon when the funeral of its founder, Miss Margaret Strachan, was held there. Those who had helped Miss Strachan in her work and those who had been helped by her sat side by side, and the grief of each seemed equally sincere.

DAYVILLE, Conn., Aug. 30.--During a storm this afternoon hail piled up in places like snow banks. Lightning struck and consumed a barn of Fred Childs, in Pomfret, the loss being between $2,000 and $3,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 30.--To-night a mass meeting of Knights of Labor was held in Lafayette-square, opposite the City Hall, where the Common Council was in session, to protest against the granting by the Council of the application of the Illinois Central Railroad Company for 1,600 feet of wharfage on the river front.
