It was a perfect day at Cedarhurst yesterday. Had the club had a day made to order it could not have had a better one. There was an exceptionally large crowd there to enjoy the delightful Summer air and the cool breezes that were never too cool, and there was some firstrate sport.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 30.--The proceedings of the fourteenth annual meeting of the United States Hay Fever Association, which was held here to-day, were highly interesting, and the attendance was unusually large. Many new members were admitted. Prof. Samuel Lockwood, of Freehold, N.J., was chosen President, and the Rev. John Peacock, of Holmesburg, Penn., Secretary and Treasurer.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 30.--State Treasurer Quay's resignation, dated Aug. 24, was accepted by Gov. Beaver to-day and ex-State Treasurer Livsey has been appointed in his stead.

BOSTON, Aug. 30.--At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee held to-day the Hon. Edward Avery, of Braintree, was chosen Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions for the State Convention.

Mayor Hewitt said yesterday that in a recent visit to Boston the streets, although not as clean as those in this city, looked better because they had no centre bearing rail tracks. HEMPSTEAD, Texas, Aug. 30.--The county officers have returned from Reid's Prairie, the scene of the late terrible outrage on John Schultz and wife, Germans, over 60 years old, and report the perpetration of a crime that would shame a savage. Soon after dark on Friday night last four men, masked and otherwise disguised, entered the house and demanded all the money about the premises.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Aug. 30.--An east-bound and a west-bound freight train were in collision near Shannonville to-day. No one was injured, but both locomotives were wrecked and a great many cars were badly damaged, entailing a heavy loss.

LEWES, Del., Aug. 30.--On Aug. 20, the British bark Armenia, from New-York for Java, encountered a hurricane in latitude 38 , longitude 71 , lasting eight hours, throwing the vessel on her beam ends, washing off her hatches, filling cabins and causing the loss of part of her cargo and all personal effects, together with the chronometer and compass. The second mate was lost overboard during the storm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--The appointment of Prof. G. Brown Goode, the present Assistant Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, as Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, complies alike with law and with the requirements of the office. FLINT, Mich., Aug. 30.--While farm hands were thrashing on the farm of Lyman Curtis, five miles east of this city, to-day, the grain stacker caught fire, and while the men were fighting the fire the steam boiler exploded, killing Daniel Steeger outright and severely injuring William Rockwood, John Bennett, and three young women who were assisting.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 30.--In the Eastern Police Station this morning Clinton E. Williams faced Louisa H. Keyser, whom he married in 1884, and Nellie Hewitt, to whom he was married on the 25th of last July under the assumed name of Charles B. Edwards.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Saratoga's most successful racing season for years was brought to a close to-day. The weather was perfect, and the crowd at the track the largest of the season. The track was fast, too, and the racing excellent. But "Snapper" Garrison, who came up here expressly to add to his string of victorious mounts, made a failure of it, failing to get a place with either of the two horses he rode.

Margaret Knowlton, of 1,914 Third-avenue, purchased $45 worth of furniture of Patton and subsequently $55 worth more.

BINGHAMTON, Aug. 30.--At the reunion of the soldiers and sailors of Broome county this afternoon a feature was the descent of an aeronaut from his balloon by means of a parachute. He dropped 3,000 feet with a rapid swinging motion, and landed in safety.

SOFIA, Aug. 30.--It is reported that M. Strausky, formerly Minister of the Interior, will undertake the task of forming a Cabinet. The people are strongly opposed to the proposal of Russia to send a General and a commissary to Bulgaria.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 30.--The Dominion Rifle Association shooting contests took place today. Good scores were made at the rifle ranges. The Rideau match, 600 yards, was concluded with the following result: First, Private Wilson, 27 in a possible 35 points; Second, Private Harrison, 26 points; Third, Staff Sergt. Pain, 25 points.

The young woman who was found wandering along West Fourth-street, Monday, and who was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where she was found to be insane, was yesterday identified as Mrs. Jessie F. Vail, daughter of Dr. E. Stewart, a dealer in medicines at 205 West Twenty-fourth-street. Dr. Stewart went yesterday to Bellevue and claimed her. He says his daughter, who has been insane for four years, escaped from his house while unwatched.

The nineteeth annual games of the NewYork Athletic Club will be held at the Mott Haven grounds Saturday, Oct. 1, entries for the various events closing Sept. 21, with Otto Ruhl, the Secretary of the club. The handicap events include races at 100 yards, 880 yards, one mile, and three miles; a 120 yards' hurdle race, and a two mile bicycle race.

Welch pitched another good game yesterday against the Indianapolis men, and the result was that the Giants not alone won, but they administered that which proves distasteful to all ball players, a coat of "whitewash." In spite of the fact that the visitors failed to score, the game was a good one, and the spectators, judging from the manner in which they applauded the work of both teams, enjoyed the contest.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 30.--Ex-Gov. Foster, in behalf of himself and the other stockholders of the Mansfield, Coldwater and Michigan Railroad Company, entered suit in the United States Circuit Court here to-day to set aside the sale of that road, ten years ago, under foreclosure. The road has been since than practically in the possession of the Pennsylvania Company, whose secretary bid it in at the sale.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30.--There was much hammering of stocks on the Cincinnati Exchange to-day. Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago Railroad, for which 76 was offered yesterday, and upon which 5 per cent. dividends are paid, was sold at 69 , and there were offers at the close to sell at 70 . Several local bank and insurance stocks were hammered down from 2 to 5 cents on a share.
The Bostons have fallen off greatly in their work of late. Cushman's curves were batted very freely in Louisville yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 30.--The police order forbidding the Socialists to celebrate the death of Ferdinand Lassalle did not have the desired effect, as thousands of the followers of the great labor union organizer made the pilgrimage to Grunan yesterday. A row occurred during the day, and several arrests were made by the police.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30.--For the past few days lumber circles have been excited over a large shortage which was discovered in the accounts in the office of W.W. Tyler, the well known lumber dealer and vessel owner.

The enormous losses in the ranch cattle industry since last Fall direct attention to the barbarous and inhuman way in which that industry is carried on. In Montana, Wyoming, and Idaho alone 800,000 cattle starved or were frozen to death last Winter.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30.--An exciting scene was witnessed in the Theatre Francaise this evening. The audience became enraged when the manager announced that some of the performers were unable to appear, and started to wreck the theatre, which amiable intention they were only prevented from fulfilling by the timely arrival of a body of police who had been summoned when the affair began to look serious. The theatre had to be closed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30.--To-day's principal society events were the lawn and court tennis matches and the coachihg parade. The weather was decidedly cool, and the ladies were obliged to bring out their wraps.

The oyster season begins to-morrow. Oyster edulis and his family have already begun to come to the city from the seashore, and are present in sufficient numbers to guarantee a successful opening, even though no more should succeed in getting packed in time to catch boat or train.

Albert Netter, the failure of whose firm, Natter Co., in Wall-street, in December, 1877, caused great excitement, and the results of which have been cropping up at divers and sundry times ever since, was engaged last night, under the watchful eye of a Deputy Sheriff, in trying to secure bail.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Aug. 30.--Before another day has passed, the Pennsylvania Democrats will probably agree upon a platform, the leading plank of which will reaffirm the Chicago tariff utterance of 1884, supplemented by the utterance of the President in which he recommended a reduction of the tariff on raw materials.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The Yonkers Yacht Club have started out on their annual cruise, and anchored in Newburg Bay yesterday afternoon. There are 15 or 20 yachts in the fleet. Last evening they were all handsomely illuminated, and fireworks were set off from all the boats, then display being a fine one.

The representatives of the Eastern coal trade and the Western Anthracite Association met in this city yesterday, and agreed that it is not yet the proper time to advance the prices of coal. The state of the trade was the chief factor which led to this conclusion, but the agitation among the workmen for an advance in prices was also a reason for non-action.

This one, however, is remarkable. No amatory cinder track in the country can in the least compare with it.

NYACK, Aug. 31.--The sequel to the assault on Lawyer Gowdey, at Sparkill, on Sunday evening, came last night, although not in a very heavy form. There will he another splendid day's racing at the Sheepshead Bay track this afternoon. The card includes six races at distances of from three-quarters of a mile up to a mile and a half. The starters are of a high class in all the events, and the result should be a lot of sensational races.

Bishop William L. Harris, one of the most highly esteemed members of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died at his residence, 33 East Eighty-first-street, at 5:05 o'clock last night. For a number of years past he had been in ill health and subject at intervals to severe attacks of heart disease.

To steal 5 shillings' worth of goods from a shop was punishable by death. A girl of 22 was hanged for receiving a piece of woolen stuff from the man who had stolen it. In 1785 96 persons were hanged at the Old Bailey.

The preparations for the Central Labor Union Parade to-morrow have boon completed. Grand Marshal John Morrison issued a proclamation yesterday requesting all workingmen and working women to assemble at their respective places of meeting, whence they will march to take their places in the parade.

The last Legislature did two very foolish things when it established the first Monday of September as a holiday to be known as "Labor Day," and when it enacted that every Saturday afternoon should be a half holiday. Gov. HILL has more than the usual executive share of responsibility for the former of these performances.

SALISBURY, Aug. 1.--The solitary fact respecting Salisbury which seems to be within the comprehension of the ordinary tourist is that it is somewhere near Stonehenge, and if you question him concerning Stonehenge you generally find the sum of his knowledge regarding it to be that it is somewhere near Salisbury.

The ladies' fishing season is now at hand. It requires large inducements to tempt women to go fishing, and hence the early days of September are assigned to them in these waters. The reason is that then the festive snapping mackerel, as it is called in Long Island Sound, or the young bluefish, as it is termed along the Jersey coast and at the Long Island seashore, becomes ravenous.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3.--The championship lacrosse match between the Brockvilles and Shamrocks this afternoon drew about 6,000 spectators to the Shamrock grounds. As the Brockvilles have lately earned an unenviable reputation for coarse play their visit here today was looked forward to with considerable interest, but it is only just and fair to thorn to say that they played good lacrosse.

BERLIN, Sept. 3.--Much speculation over the meeting of Emperor William and the Czar will be checked by the announcement that the Emperor has abandoned his intention to go to Konigshertg. It gas determined to-day, after a long consultation of his physicians, that instead of venturing to attend the army manoeuvres, it was urgent that the Emperor should return to Babelsberg.

It is rather an infelicitous preliminary to the proposed settlement of the fishery dispute by negotiations at Washington that the cruiser Intrepid has just captured another American vessel plying her vocation within the prohibited waters.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3.--August went out in a blaze of glory, and September comes in under the most favorable auspices. Newport was very gay in August, and the first two weeks in September promise to be quite as lively from a social standpoint, at least. A live Duke and an Imperial Prince from India are in town, and these visitors are to be dined and wined.

At night in early Spring peculiar effects are proper to the woods. No bird moves. The first weak peep has not yet risen from the little choristers in the marsh. The trees live, but their existence is internal. Too absorbed in reviving their benumbed limbs with sap from the stores within their roots and opening wider the tight bands of bud and bark they pay no attention to the outer world.

Rehearsals for "The Great Pink Pearl" are well advanced at the Lyceum Theatre, and Manager Frohman has great faith in the success of the play, although it can be placed on the stage for a season of about six weeks only.

Yesterday was not observed as a general holiday in this city. It was a special holiday, and carried out very fairly the purpose of its institution, if that purpose was to enable Labor "to show its power."

No hint of its intention was given its competitors, and the action of the Wabash was considerable of a surprise. RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 5.--On the 20th of August last the National Bank at Glens Falls, N.Y., deposited with the National Express Company at that place $6,000 in currency in a package addressed to the Gallatin National Bank of New-York City. J.E. Merwin was the express agent at Glens Falls.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Eight boys, whose ages range from 10 to 13 years, were arrested to-day for burglary. They broke into the residence of the Superintendent of Police yesterday and stole a sum of money and some articlas of value.
William Warren, the comedian, is at the Windsor Hotel. His Highness, the Thakore Saheb of Morbi, is at the Hotel Brunswick.

The Central Turn Verein has grown very rapidly in wealth and numbers in its 20 months of life, and it had yesterday an enthusiastic crowd of from 7,000 to 10,000 persons at the laying of the foundation stone of its building in Sixty-seventh-street, near Third-avenue, which is to cost $400,000.

GREENVILLE, Darke County, Ohio, Sept. 5.--The County Treasurer's safe doors were found open this morning and $48,000 missing. The Treasurer, John S. Simon, was not at home, but it was said that he only went to Versailles last night to visit his father.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The elopement from New-York in May last of Leonard H. Wager, of this city, and Miss Nellie Nugent, daughter of a contractor in the metropolis, and their subsequent marriage in this city were duly chronicled at the time.

PESTH, Sept. 5.--A terrific conflagration is raging in the town of Veszprem, Hungary. Reports received here at a late hour to-night say that 200 houses have been reduced to ashes.
BUFFALO, Sept, 5.--J.S. Whipple, of Salamanca, was nominated to-day as the Republican candidate for member of Assembly from the Second District of Cattaraugus County. He is an able attorney.
LONDON, Sept. 5.--The steamship Gleadowe, (Br.,) Capt. Mehegan, from New-York Aug. 19, arr. at Leith yesterday.
John G. Egger, who has a saloon at 136 South Fifth-avenue, was accused in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday of violating the excise law.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 5.--It was decided to-day to send Samuel Denmead, the hermit to the State Insane Asylum, and unless the changeable authorities come to another decision before Wednesday this will be done. Drs. Newell and Riva have declared the man insane.

Policemen, for an obvious reason, ride free in the elevated railroad cars. Working girls, tired and weak after their hard day's work, also ride on the elevated trains, but are obliged to pay fare. Sympathetic people fancy that the latter have a better right to accommodation than the former.

A handsome young woman who, under the name of Emma Van Ness, taught the children of a wealthy Brooklyn man, has begun an action to annul her marriage to one Charles Arroby, whose real name is Jacob Ishim Smith. The applicant tells a peculiar story.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5.--The Bay State runaways, George A. Sears and James F. Howe, Jr., were located by a TIMES reporter today. Sears and Howe left their homes on the 28th of July last, and sailed from Dorchester Bay in the sloop yacht Merele. They were supposed to have been lost in a terrific squall which swept over the bay a few hours after they started.

LONDON, Sept. 5.--In the House of Commons this evening Sir James Fergusson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Foreign Office, said the Government had no information concerning the latest, reported seizures of British vessels in Behring Straits, but they had received advices regarding seizures made by American revenue cutters on Aug. 2, 12, and 17.

Little difficulty was encountered by the New-Yorks in defeating the Washington team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. There were over 7,000 persons in attendance, and they watched the Senators fall easy victims to the superior skill of the Giants.

NEWBURG, Sept. 5.--When the train with the veteran firemen of New-York reached this city on the West Shore Railroad this afternoon, it had a very narrow escape from collision with a switch engine that bore down on it on the same track.

The steamship Persian Monarch, once in the fleet of the defunct Monarch Line, arrived from London Sunday evening, consigned to the agents of the Wilson Line, which has purchased the Persian, Lydian, and Assyrian Monarchs, at a total cost of $180,000.

J. Buichi, H. Rosee, and A. Traguia are natives of Switzerland who have been in this country only a few weeks. Late Sunday night they visited "Joe" Prendergast's hotel at Clifton, Staten Island, ordered liquor, and then refused to pay for it.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 5.--A Republican State League, similar to the leagues in Ohio and Connecticut, is to be formed in New-Jersey.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 5.--The Porte has learned that the Austrian Government is strenuously trying to arrange for Prince Ferdinand's withdrawal from Bulgaria.

DETROIT, Sept. 5.--Congressman Ben Butterworth, of Ohio, in an interview published here to-day, states his impressions of some things that are stirring in men's minds. Being asked. "On what lines will the next Presidential election be fought?" he replied, "Mainly on the old lines.

J. Frank Bennett, a recently elected Assessor of Monmouth County, N.J., committed suicide by taking Paris green Sunday night. His death occurred last evening at Eatontown. Financial troubles drove him to insanity.

Labor Day did not empty Wall-street by a good deal. Lots of brokerage offices were open, though with the Stock Exchange closed and all the tickers silent there was not much liveliness anywhere. Quotations came from other cities and business between this city and London was of consequence. Big orders were booked to buy and sell in Europe to-day, so the representatives of arbitrage houses explained.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The Buffalo Jockey Club have decided to give a five days' running meeting, commencing Tuesday, Sept. 13. About 200 horses will be here.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 5.--A special meeting of the stockholders of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company was held here to-day to vote upon the proposition of the Directors to increase the capital stock to $75,000,000.
The New-Yorks will play the Washingtons again to-day. All of the runs in the Athletic-Cincinnati game were earned.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The announcement of the decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the Anarchists may be expected any day, and will probably be filed this week. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5.--At Philip Fresenius's brewery 11 brewers were refused permission to lay off to-day to celebrate Labor Day, but they laid off, with the understanding that if they did so they could not go back to work. A silent boycott against Fresenius's beer is already in progress.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5.--The Wisconsin Leather Company, one of the oldest houses in the city, confessed,judgment to-day on four notes amounting to over $90,000. The company was declared insolvent by the Judge of the Circuit Court, and all of its property was sequestered with E.K. Miller as Receiver. The Sheriff is in possession of the tannery and other property of the company. No statement of the amount of assets and liabilities has been made.

At a meeting of the American Association held at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday it was decided hereafter to give visiting clubs a percentage of the gate receipts instead of the $65 guarantee, the system now in vogue.
OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 5.--This city is noisy with enthusiasm to-day. The Nebraska Grand Army of the Republic opened their ninth annual reunion this morning, and the Omaha District Fair is in progress.

The Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday afternoon adopted a new racing rule, which will serve to materially improve the quality of racing in the overnight handicaps and purse races. The rule printed herewith was concurred in by the Brooklyn Jockey Club, and will go into effect at once.

A great many old acquaintances are renewed at the Ocean Grove camp meetings, Monday morning two clergymen, one the preacher of the day before, met for the first time in 40 years, though classmates when young.

A line of small passenger steamers is to be established next month on the Tiber, at Rome. They are to run for about four miles, from a pier above the Ponte Molle, on the old Flaminian Way, to the Church of St. Paul, and will stop at the principal bridges. This will be a horrible innovation in the opinion of old habitues of the Eternal City.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--Mr. Thomas W. Keene opened the regular season of the Chicago Opera House, and practically his own season, this evening, appearing in Chicago for the first time in two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--Mr. George W. Thobe, whose name, by the way, is spelled Thobe, and not Thoehe, as usually printed, the Labor candidate in the Sixth Congressional District of Kentucky, whose contest against Speaker Carlisle was supposed to be outlawed, has come to the front again.
Chief-Justice Charles H. Van Brunt, of the Supreme Court, arrived From Europe on the Normandie yesterday, after a tour through France and Switzerland.

The expectation that the year 1887 would be signalized as a period remarkable for railway extension was so plainly warranted by previous reports in these columns of construction projected, in progress, and completed, is still further justified by the returns which we have collected for the eight months ending Aug. 31.
Divine Burtis died at his residence, 65 Second-place, Brooklyn, yesterday morning from pneumonia. Mr. Burtis was born in NewYork in 1811, and at an early age took up the trade of boatbuilding.

The various documents submitted to the President in the matter of the Chicago Collector, Mr. SEEBERGER, are not only interesting, but important. They mark an advance in the treatment of questions arising in the civil service on some points comparatively novel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The first business session of the German Roman Catholic Central Union of America was opened this morning in St. Michael's Hall with prayer by the Rev. Dr. William Tappert, of Covington, Ky. About 300 delegates were present, and all the available room on the main floor and in the spacious gallery was occupied by people who came to witness the proceedings.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 5.--Philip Schembs, a baker of this city, committed suicide this morning white confined in the county jail by cutting his throat and the main artery of his left arm with a tin bucket.

The Dwyer Brothers, finding that there is no probability of Tremont's ever coming into racing form again, have decided to sell that famous and unbeaten son of Virgil and Ann Fife to some reputable breeder for use in the stud.
Just on the outskirts of the pretty village of Arlington, on the banks of the Passaic River, is the copper mine which at one time furnished considerable wealth to many of the old residents of Newark.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The Republican Convention for the First Assembly District of Oneida County was held to-day. The Hon. James S. Sherman, Edward M. Brown, Samuel H. Budlong William J. Millard, and John W. Seaton were elected delegates to the Republican State Convention.

A clothing dealer in an interior town had occasion to visit the city to purchase goods. While he was gone a young man entered his store to buy a coat. A salesman waited upon the customer and showed him a coat plainly marked $7.

A clergyman officiated at the funeral of a, man whose widow was a Spiritualist. Scarcely were the exercises concluded when she began to berate the minister in a mesculine tone of voice. To reassure him a by stander informed him that the spirit of her husband was holding forth. Our friend says that in all his experience it is the only time he was over "sassed by the corpse."

MOBILE Ala., Sept. 5.--The trouble at Biloxi between the canning factories and the Knights of Labor was settled by arbitration Saturday, on the basis of $3 25 per barrel for shrimp. The demand that no persons but Knights should be employed was resisted by the packers and was apparently abandoned.
BERNE, Sept. 5.--The treaty powers have ratified the literary and artistic copyright convention.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 5.--Patron and Clingstone, each of which trotting celebrities has beaten Harry Wilkes, were matched to-day to trot here on next Thursday for a purse of $5,000. This is expected to be the star trotting event of the year. Clingstone has not been on the turf this season, but is said to be in racing form. Both horses are owned in Cleveland, and both have enthusiastic backers.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Sept. 5.--The police have been unable so far to get to the bottom of the mystery surrounding the bloody boat found on the beach. A sailor, who gave the name of Gordon, landed at Carleton soon after midnight Saturday. His face and hands were bloody, and blood was flowing from a wound over the eye.

WINNIPEG Manitoba, Sept. 5.--There is great rejoicing here over the announcement that Norquay, the Premier of Manitoba, who is now in NewYork, has succeeded in getting New-York capitalists take bonds for the new road from Winnipeg to Boundary.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Lewis Lent, the advance agent of the Joseph J. Sullivan theatrical company, is locked up in a cell in the Ulster County Jail here. Lent tacked a lithograph in front of the business place of Hasbrouck Alliger, shoe dealers, in Rondout to-day.

BERLIN, Sept. 5.--To-night's special press confirms the statement made on Saturday that there will be no meeting of the Czar and Emperor William. The North German Gazette says: "The repeated statements that a meeting is about to take place at Stettin emanate from Austrian and French sources and are based upon pure conjecture.
Adam Oechslin and Robert Cenmer live at 157 Ewen-street, Williamsburg, and work in Breen Parker's box factory on Kent-avenue, near South Second-street.

All day yesterday the toilers in the Chinese laundries drove the polishing iron over the starchy surface of the shirt bosom and squirted water over the garments of the rich and poor, looking happier than they usually do.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--Major Robert M. Reilly, Surgeon, has been ordered to proceed from this city to Fort Niagara, New-York, on public business. Capt. Allen Smith, Fourth Cavalry has been appointed to act as inspector of certain Quartermaster's stores at St. Louis. The leave of absence granted Second Lieut, H.L. Roberts, Ninteenth Infantry, has been extended two months.

No one would imagine that Mlle. Mary Pirard, the pretty little lady who arrived in this city from France yesterday on the steamer La Normandie, was French. She has wavy, blonde hair, a complexion suggestive of an Anglo-Saxon peasant, and rosy, laughing lips.

That city people are coming home from the country in large numbers is apparent not only from the length of the trains rolling in on the trunk lines but from the increased express business of the last few days.

Labor Day brought a great crowd of pleasure seekers to the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday afternoon, and it was a crowd that labored hard, first to pick the winners from the big fields, and second, to try and back them in the betting ring, which was packed almost to suffocation.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5.--A meeting of the Board of Directors of the Merchants' Terminal Company was held this morning at the rooms of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association. There is a Board of Directors of the Terminal Company, although few outside of the board knew it.

On both sides of West Fiftieth-street, from Tenth-avenue down to the North River, stand tall stone and brick tenements, each accommodating from 20 to 27 families. In the five-story house at 522 West Fiftieth-street, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, the cry of fire was raised.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5.--Business circles in this city were thrown into the greatest excitement late this afternoon by the announcement that E.S. Wheeler Co. had failed, with liabilities of a million or more, and assets not stated.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5.--Everybody is praising the weather, and it is the means of doing wonders for Newport from a financial point of view. The Duke of Marlborough is enjoying himself riding, walking, and driving. He goes to the Casino and to the Casino Club daily, and to-day he escorted Miss Beckwith, of New-York, to the Casino grounds.

Racing will be continued at Sheepshead Bay to-day with two particularly good races in the Belles' Stakes and the Omnium Handicap. The character of the entries assures good sport all around, and the big events ought to furnish some exciting finishes. Eolian will in all probability win the opening race with Gleaner second.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 5.--To-day Tom Connors, the wrestler, was refused a license for his match with Matsada Sorakichi, the Jap, which had been arranged to take place in Allegheny on the 19th inst. Mayor Pearson declined to grant a license for the event for various reasons.
The Thakore Sahib, ruler of the State of Morvi, in the Province of Kathiawar, India, arrived in this city yesterday by the Cunard steamer Servia.
All doubt as to the truth of the statement made by Mrs. Mary Ford, the California widow, that she had three children with her while traveling on the Pennsylvania Railroad, was removed yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 5.--Local politics took an interesting turn to-day, the result being the utter discomfiture of the Chairman of the Democratic state Central Committee, who managed the Spring campaign. The present Sheriff of Providence County. Mr. Daniel B. Pond, was said last Spring to be an aspirant to the Gubernatorial chair, but after the convention had ...

Labor Day was honored in this city yesday more in the breach than in the observance. The variation of a large and miscellaneous parade served only to impress on the public at large so far as could be observed, the unfitness of the season for a general holiday. Of course many stores were closed and there were vast numbers of people on the streets.

The decennial celebration of an athletic club, though a somewhat new idea, appears to be a good one, to judge from the number of women and their escorts who attended that of the Staten Island Athletic Club yesterday.

A decree has been issued by the Empress Dowager of China ordering that the ceremonies at the approaching marriage of the Emperor [the date of which, however, has been postponed] are to be conducted on as cheap a scale as possible.
Examining Physician Shepard and Coroner Rooney held an autopsy yesterday on the body of Robert R. Phillips, the Brooklyn broker who died Saturday from the effects of a fall Thursday morning.
PUTNAM, Conn., Sept. 5.--While pitching pennies in the woods near North Grosvenordale on Sunday afternoon a boy of 17, named Anderson, detected the other player, a Swede, named Neilson, cheating.

A small army of energetic "supers" arriving near the stage door of the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, just before 10 o'clock, found yesterday morning that in order to reach it they would have to literally plow their way through an army of goats, painfully frolicsome and hideously friendly.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 5.--Another Sunday law decision was handed down to-day, this time in the Circuit Court by Judge Valliant. Two months ago Judge Noonan, of the Minor Court, decided that the law which applied to the whole State did not, on account of special legislation, apply to St. Louis.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, the head of the American Museum of Natural History, arrived on the Servia yesterday, after a six months' trip in Europe, Asia, and Africa. The journey was made with a view to acquiring information to be used in the illustrated lectures on Egypt, Palestine, Turkey, Greece, Italy, Spain, India, China, ...
The second annual regatta of the Long Island Amateur Rowing Association took place on Jamaica Bay yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--William Hagg Wolsely Markham, ex-Paymaster of the British man-of-war Espoir, who was arrested by the Pinkertons in Kansas City for embezzlements committed in China, was yesterday handed over to Inspector Mathewson, of the Hong-Kong imperial police.

CAPE VINCENT, Sept. 2.--Two weeks ago the fishermen here and for 20 miles around were discouraged at the poor outlook. For nearly three months the black bass were biting at a curious rate, and catches of 30, 40, or more per day were not uncommon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5.--There was an unusually large gathering at the opening of the Naval War College this morning, so that the lecture room was well filled. Quite a number of ladies were present to add their influence toward encouraging the scheme of the advanced course of study as proposed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5.--The Hibernian Society of this city some time ago invited President Cleveland to be present at its quarterly dinner on the afternoon of Saturday, Sept. 17, the closing day of the Constitutional Centennial celebration, and have just received the following acceptance:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Thirteen dwellings were entered by burglars in the eastern part of the city during last night and this morning. No large amounts of plunder were secured, but an absolute reign of terror exists in that portion of the city, Several houses and stores were entered on the night previous.

WATKINS, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Nearly all of the oarsmen announced to take part in the regatta tomorrow and Thursday have arrived. Courtney reached here on the evening boat. Teemer, Bubear, Hamm, Plaisted, Lee, and others arrived this after noon. The lake is like a mirror, and every indication points to a successful regatta, both in attendance and in the skill of the oarsmen. Three trial heats are set down for to morrow's programme.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--Napoleon Barsaloux, the furniture dealer who was indicted with the county boodlers, failed to-day. For a brief period Sheriff Matson was in charge of the store on West Madison-street, and then the stock was turned over to a Receiver.

LONDON, Sept. 5.--The Theatre Royal at Exeter took fire this evening during a performance of "Romany Rye." The occupants of the pit, after an awful struggle, escaped, but many of them were greatly injured. There was only one exit from the gallery and the rush there was terrific. Scores were trodden under foot and suffocated.

The air about the Veteran Firemen's Association headquarters, in East Tenth-street, yesterday morning was one made up largely of expectation and brass bands. The Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday announced to Messrs. Gratz and Morrissey, whose horses, Elkwood and Banburg, are matched to race for $5,000 a side to-morrow, that they would give $1,000 additional to the winner of the match.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5.--The American will say to-morrow: "The question as to who shall succeed President Garrett is settled. Mr. John King, Jr., who was looked upon favorably, cannot take the position because he is virtually Trustee of the Erie Road as well as its President. Mr. A.J. Cassatt was mentioned, but his intimate relations with the Pennsylvania Road were against his acceptability.

PARIS, Aug. 23.--M. Laisant, Deputy of the Department of the Seine, has recently published a pamphlet, in which, under the title "Pourquoi et comment je suis Boulangiste," he gives his reasons for his consistent support and defense of the late Minister of War.
Messrs. Charles Bowser and Samuel Sothern will be in the cast of "Baron Rudolph" at the Fourteenth Street Theatre next month.

On the old baseball grounds beside the East River and between One Hundred and Seventh and One Hundred and Ninth streets, yesterday, half a dozen or more jockeys risked their necks on the six-laps-to-the-mile track on which the races of the Turf Club Racing Association are held.

The New-Yorks won another, game from the Washington team on the Polo Grounds yesterday in the presence of 2,500 persons. Gilmore, who pitched for the visiting team, was wild and erratic, giving five men their bases on balls.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6.--Something akin to a panic has seized upon the small holders of Baltimore and Ohio stock, and to-day's big tumble in prices, following yesterday's decline, has intensified the fright. On the first call this morning 5 shares went off at 146, 10 shares followed at 145; 11 shares were then offered, ...

The seventh annual tournament for doubles of the United States Lawn Tennis Association begun yesterday on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Mountain, N.J. The forest trees that surround the ground prevented a breath of air from reaching the players and they constantly had to stop to wipe the perspiration from their hands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.--No confirmation has been received at the State Department of the telegraphic dispatch published from the Pacific coast about a week ago, stating that some additional sealers had been seized in Behring Sea.

The charge has been made within a few days that the representative of Germany in this city has been making a recruiting station of his office. If true, it would be a serious matter, for the neutrality law would be infringed upon. But just to what extent the law has been or is being violated can only be determined by an official inquiry.

John Thomson, who served as expert and engineer for the old Board of Subway Commissioners from September, 1885, to September, 1886, was brought suit in the Supreme Court, Kings County, against State Controller Alfred C. Chapin, Roswell P. Flower, Theodore Moss, and Jacob Hess for $3,000, salary claimed for his services.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Although the statement of shipments of flour, grain and provisions from Chicago to seaboard points for, the week ending last Saturday shows a further increase of a little over 2,000 tons, yet east-bound freight affairs are far from satisfactory.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6.--The cut made in Missouri River passenger rates by the Chicago roads will demoralize the St. Louis rates to-morrow. The Missouri Pacific and St. Louis and San Francisco are the roads whose business has received a severe blow by the Chicago cut.

WASHINGON, Sept. 6.--A general order has been issued by the War Department proclaiming, by authority of the President, a tract of land within the limits of the Uintah Indian Reservation a military reservation for the post of Fort Duehesne.

Every fire in a theatre points a moral that ought to be practically applied in every city. The anxiety to save money on the part of the owners of theatres remains a much more powerful motive than the anxiety to save life on the part of the authorities, even where a special department exists for the official inspection of buildings.

At the meeting of the Board of Electrical Control, to be held in the Mayor's office tomorrow, one of the most important questions which has yet come before the commission will be taken up and very probably disposed of.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 6.--Smith Wicks, tin can manufacturers, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of their creditors. The bond of the Trustee is $100,000 indicating $50,000 of assets.

The schooner William H. Jones dropped anchor yesterday off Red Hook, almost a wreck. She had encountered the terrible hurricane along the coast which put even great steamers in peril, and had just managed to escape. First Mate Schultz was in command.
The Virginia Democrats who visit Washington are reported in the dispatches of the Post to "feel considerable assurance of the success of their party."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.--President Davis called the International Medical Congress to order at 11 o'clock this morning, and introduced Dr. Austin Flint, of New-York, who proceeded to read his paper on fever, its causes, mechanism, and rational treatment.

Owners of property in this city and the multitude who want to stand in their shoes for a longer or shorter term are girding themselves for the coming season. At present they take satisfaction out of each other in talk.

LONDON, Sept. 6.--The victims of the burning of the Theatre Royal at Exeter last night were mostly working people. As soon as the flames were extinguished a large force of men began searching for bodies. The stairway leading to the gallery was literally packed with bodies, while at the head of the stairs there were scores of others piled one on top of the other.

A rupture may take place between District Assembly No. 49 and General Master Workman Powderly over the recent action of the assembly in pledging to the condemned Chicago Anarchists its moral and financial support.

An inquest in the case of Mrs. Jane Lynch, who was killed by the falling of the elevator at Sidenberg Co.'s factory, at 47 Mercerstreet, on Aug. 18, was held by Coroner Nugent yesterday. The court room was crowded.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--The resolution denouncing the Knights of Labor was to-day re ported back unfavorably to the Convention of the German Roman Catholic Central Union. The committee to which the matter was referred gave as a reason that the time was not opportune for any such resolution.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6.--As indicated in this morning's TIMES, the firm of E.S. Wheeler Co., tin plates, , made an assignment in the Probate Court here this morning, and named Samuel A. Galpin, Secretary of the New-Haven Wire Mill Company, as Assignee.

The high waists, scant skirts, and prodigious ruffles seen in "Allan Dare" make such a pretty showing on the stage that some enterprising manager may be encouraged to revive one of the comedies of the last days of the Georgian era, with all the "archaeological accuracy" so much prized in the theatre nowadays.
James Poindexter, the colored Pullman car porter, arrested Monday on the charge of abducting the three Ford children, was examined yesterday morning before Police Justice Stilsing, in Jersey City.

Although the Episcopal cathedral project, in common with many other matters of popular interest, has been kept very quiet during the vacation season, progress of a satisfactory character has been made in the matter of subscriptions and bequests.

WATKINS, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The trial heats of the Watkins regatta were rowed on Seneca Lake to-day. A strong breeze from the southwest caused the white caps to roll on the lower part of the course. The crowd was light in comparison with those of former regattas.

Yesterday's stock market opened with a big hurrah, and the first prices seemed indicative of such a bull movement as ever the most optimistic speculators had not dared to hope for, In the first half hour over 100,000 shares were traded in.

The Thistle took aboard yesterday stores for a three days' cruise. She went to Sandy Hook in the afternoon and anchored in the Horseshoe. Capt. Barr was not quite sure whether he would remain there until the City of Rome, with James Bell, the Thistle's chief owner, aboard, should be sighted or not.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 6.--To-morrow's Prohibition State Convention promises to be the largest the party has ever held in this State, and the Republican Party managers regard its outcome with considerable apprehension. The programme for to-day at the Sheepshead Bay track is a most excellent one and will furnish good sport. To add to the interest will be the match race between Elkwood and Banburg, which will be run only in case the track is dry and in good condition.

William Belden filed his complaint in the suit which he has brought against D.G. Yuengling, Jr., in the County Clerk's office yesterday morning. He asks for the dissolution of the special copartnership which exists between them under the name of D.G. Yuengling. Jr., the appointment of a Receiver, and an injunction to restrain Mr. Yuengling from longer managing the business.

Kings County Republicans held their primaries last night and elected delegates to the Assembly conventious to be held to-morrow night. At these 66 delegates to the State Convention and members of the State Committee will be chosen. Harmony prevailed in nearly all the wards, and a general desire was evinced to send good men to the conventions.

The Count Eugene Mitkiewiez, who looms up in Washington, claiming to be the possessor of valuable concessions from the Chinese Government, is believed to be the same person who has a record in the Police Department of this city and whose history Inspector Byrues has had occasion to look up several times for persons whose auspicions were aroused.

Fire broke out in the Edison machine works, 115 and 117 West Thirty-seventh-street, just before 9 o'clock last night. An engine attached its hose to a hydrant near the Casino, and sparks and smoke from it and the fire reached the Casino roof garden.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 6.--Toil held another State Convention to-day. This is its third and positively last appearance in public as the slayer of the two old parties solely by the use of jawbone. Henceforth its shoulder must be applied to the wheel if it is to grind the Republican and Democratic organizations to their destruction.

Mayor Hewitt will to-day begin a warfare against the Manhattan Railway, and he will base his action upon a carefully prepared statement of Corporation Counsel Morgan J. O'Brien on the relations of the company to the city of New-York.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The steeplechase run here as the last race of the day resulted fatally to Jockey Warder, who rode Lucy Lightfoot.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 7.--A severe storm passed over Worcester, Otsego County, to-day. Amos Cornoll was lifted off his feet by the wind, thrown against a barrel 25 feet distant, and killed.

NORWICH, N.Y., Sept. 7.--A cyclone passed over the valley a few miles north of here this afternoon. Its track was about a mile wide. Many apple trees were blown down and numerous hop fields were devastated.

Charles H. Storm, of Bergen County, N. J., was yesterday appointed a Custom House clerk at $1,000 a year.

Charles Malone and Michael Sullivan pleaded guilty yesterday in the Court of General Sessions to an indictment for a burglary committed on Aug. 1 at the Hudson Coffee Mills, in Cherry-street, and were sentenced each to four years and one month in State prison.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--It can be stated with a good deal of positiveness that the proposition of taking the tax off fruit brandy, which is alleged to be a part of the tariff programme at Oak view, has never for a moment been entertained either by the President or Secretary Fairchild.

Among the extension buildings of the Grand Locomotive Works, at Paterson, N.J., was a brick structure on the north side of Marketstreet, near Spruce, about 225 feet front and 230 feet deep, the front portion three stories high, and the rest four stories.

One of the most noteworthy points of difference between the organized citizen soldiery of the United States and that of foreign countries is the comparatively small proportion of artillery found among the former.

James C. Savery Co. have filed a long complaint with the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the railroad pool in CastleGarden.
HAMILTON, Ohio, Sept. 7.--The opening meeting of the State campaign of the Democratic Party was held here this evening. It was a very large and enthusiastic meeting.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 7.--The 45 delegates to the convention of the political branch of the State Workingmen's Assembly concluded their labors this afternoon.

The Detroits bettered their condition materially yesterday. At Staten Island the Mets and Louisvilles will cross bats to-day.

Mr. Dockstader's second season in NewYork seemed to have an auspicious beginning last night. Negro minstrelsy is still popular, and the entertainment given at the cozy little house on Broadway has many of the features of old-time minstrelsy at its best.
Intermittent showers, with occasional gleams of sunshine, made the foliage of the trees surrounding the Orange lawn tennis grounds yesterday sparkle as if covered with diamonds.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 7.--The last act of a tragedy begun 18 years ago was concluded in the Circuit Court at Bolivar, Tenn., last night, when Guy Smith was acquitted of the charge of murder.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8.--The Milk Shippers' Union of the Northwest held an important session to-day. One of the principal matters considered was the formation of a great company or "trust" to monopolize the entire milk business of Chicago. DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 8.--Ex-Gov. H. P. Baldwin announces his intention of resigning the Presidency of the Detroit National Bank next month, a position which he has held for 24 years. ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9.--Spade Sunshine, a Cherokee Indian, will be executed at Tahlequah, Indian Territory, to-morrow for the murder of Long John, another Indian, on Christmas night last in the Cherokee Nation. Sunshine has been respited three times by the Exeutive, and on one occasion his coffin was on hand, the grave dug, and the rope stretched, but at almost the last moment a reprieve was received.

DULUTH, Sept. 9.--The steamer Spokana has arrived at Two Harbors, and reports that she cast the big schooner David Dows, of Toledo, adrift in the gale of Tuesday and Wednesday, and that the vessel has not been seen since. TUCSON, Arizona, Sept. 9.--Heavy rain last night washed away bridges on the Southern Pacific Railroad in Cremieno. It will require several days to repair the damages. One and a duarter inches of rain fell in three hours.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--Sir James Fergusson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Foreign Office, replying to Mr. Gourley in the House of Commons to-day, said that the Government had no information with reference to the seizure of the Pathfinder by the American Government.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 9.--The Department of Customs has been apprised of a trick which has just been played on the American authorities by the Captain of the Alfred Adams, a British Columbia sealing schooner.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Sept. 9.-- The Creek national election for Chief, Second Chief, and members of the houses of Kings and Warriors occurred Tuesday. Returns come in slowly, but so far indicate the election of Legus Perryman, of Tulsa, as Chief over Joe Perryman, the incumbent.
PARIS, Sept. 9.--The Journal des Debats says that Prince Bismarck will not consent to act as a mediator on the Bulgarian question unless he is requested to do so by the powers.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 9.--The Indian Department has no official reports of the emigration of the Metlakahtla Indians to Alaska, but from private sources it is understood that only a part of the tribe has removed there. The impression prevails here that those who have gone will be glad to return to Metlakahtla before long.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9.--The sixth annual reunion of the veteran Union soldiers of Sullivan County, held at Livingston Manor yesterday, drew together 6,000 persons. The affair was under the management of Purvis Post, G. A.R., Eli Starr, editor of the Livingston Manor Times, Commander.
The State Committee of the United Labor Party met last evening at Cooper Union to fill the vacancy on its State ticket caused by the declination of Mr. Sweet to run for State Engineer.

William and Walter Ramsey own the land at the northwest corner of Ninth-avenue and Fifty-third-street, and William Bradley, a contractor, is excavating there preparatory to the erection of buildings. Yesterday morning John Ring, one of the workmen, filled a drill hole in the rock with dynamite.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Interest in the elopement case of E.J.F. Marsh and Miss Sarah Smith, of this city, was intensified to-day by the announcement of the fact that the lady in the case was engaged to Edward Wilkinson, Jr., of this city, who started yesterday in pursuit of the runaway couple.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9.--The present indications are the Pimlico will hereafter be in the trotting circuit and there will be meetings annually. Frank Brown, President of the association, has made application for membership in the circuit, and promises purses amounting to $25,000 for the meeting of 1888. The meeting next week will be the first trotting season in Baltimore for many years.

Col. F.K. Hain said yesterday that the report that first class or "reserved" cars were to be run on the elevated road as soon as they could be built was unfounded. The company has all the cars it needs, and does not propose to put on any reserved ones for which extra fares would be charged.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 9.--Col. Thomas O. Sully fell into the fish pond at the Exposition Grounds this afternoon, and was drowned. He was 70 years of age, and was for many years a cotton merchant.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 9.--The Indians of the Northwest once looked upon the mounted police as their friends, but now look upon them as deadly enemies. The Government, it is reported, intends to hold a thorough investigation into recent acts of the police, with the view of putting things on a peace footing between them and the Indians, who are now decidedly hostile.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 9.--The sloop Priscilla arrived here from Beverly this afternoon with Commodore A. Cass Canfield, ex-Secretary Tams, and Mr. Newbold, of New-York, on board. The yacht sailed at 4 o'clock for Provincetown; thence for Newport.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9.--The casting of the stem of the new United States cruiser Charleston, now being built here, has been successfully accomplished. The steel storn post was cast June 22, but the casting of the stem was a greater feat, as it weighs fully 16,000 pounds. It is said to be the largest casting ever made on this continent.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Sept. 9.--It is reported that the cruiser Intrepid captured an American schooner of 17 tons within the three-mile limit off Campobello Thursday and took her into port. CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--John J. Dickey, Martha Ann Wallace, Charles H. Dickey, and Virginia Belle Wallace, children of the late T. Lyle Dickey, Judge of the Supreme Court of Illinois, to-day filed a bill against Beulah C. Dickey, his widow, to set aside his will. SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Edward West, the colored light-weight jockey of "Lucky" Baldwin's stable, died here this morning. While riding Colonel Zeb Ward in a race here on Aug. 29 he was thrown from his horse in a collision with Music and Sadie Mac, who fell on the track ahead of West's mount. The fall resulted in very serious internal injuries, and West has been in a semi-conscious condition nearly all the time since the accident.

TUCSON, Arizona., Sept. 9.--Gov. Zulick has declared quarantine against the Coutineut of Europe and the Republic of Mexico and all bovine cattle from said locality, though there is no infectious cattle disease in Mexico. The proclamation creates much comment, as the coming 90 days is the season during which the stockmen of Mexico drive large herds for sale into the United States, and their stock is in good condition.

QUEBEC, Sept. 10.--Deputy Minister of Marine Smith has just returned from a trip to the Island of Anticosti. He says there are 350 persons now resident on the island. LUMBER CITY, Ga., Sept. 16.--Seven prisoners escaped from jail at noon here to-day. One-prisoner confined himself behind the corridor door, through which Jailer Hayne had to pass in giving dinner to the prisoners. When Mr. Hayne entered the concealed prisoner jumped on him, the others closing in. They locked him in the cell and left. Four hours later some school children passing by heard the jailer crying for release, and spread the alarm.

Brennan was arrested and lodged in jail tonight.

MONTREAL, Sept. 16.--The Post Office authorities are investigating still another mail bag robbery. It appears that a bag of registered letters from Valley Field has mysteriously disappeared in transit and not the slightest trace of it can be found. The authorities cannot fix the blame on any one, and in view of the series of similar robberies on other lines considerable alarm prevails among business men.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Sept. 16.--A new and strange disease is affecting cattle in this part of Illionis. Milch cows suffer most. The disease is in the eyes, some cows being reported totally blind. It seems that the cattle running on the commons are most subject to attack. This report includes the range cattle in Jackson and Perry Counties, The eyes are said to assume a blue color. Some cows kept on pastures are affected.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 16.--The drought of over six weeks' duration in Alabama was broken today by copious rains all over the State. It is raining here to-night. The cotton not picked is nearly all open in the fields, and, where rains are heavy, much damage will be done.

The dead body of James Reilly, alias "Rickey" Reilly, was found early yesterday morning at the foot of East Seventieth-street. Money loaned on call in Wall-street yesterday at 4 per cent. At 5 per cent. it was plentiful. Leaders late in the afternoon gave up efforts to obtain 6 per cent. Cecilia McGovern attempted suicide yesterday at 54 Gregory-street, Jersey City, by taking a dose of paris green. She is 27 years old and was married a year ago in Ireland. She came to this country recently, and soon afterward her husband became insane and was placed in an asylum. This made her despondent. She repeated after taking the poison and asked a girl to summon a priest and a physician. The woman will probably die.

AUBURN, Sept. 21.--The twenty-second ballot in the Republican Senatorial Convention was taken this morning without a change of one vote, Cayuga casting 10 for Wheeler, Tompkins and Tioga 12 for Barager, and Seneca 5 for Sweet. TUCSON, Arizona, Sept. 22.--Citizens who have returned from San Pedro state that all the crops on the bottom lands between Mammoth and Benson have been entirely destroyed by the recent floods. DUBLIN, Sept. 22.--The weekly Nationalist papers throughout Ireland publish the usual reports of the proceedings of the various local branches of the League, despite the fact that under the terms of the new Crimes act the editors are liable to imprisonment for publishing the reports, which teem with violent denunciations of the Government.

HAMBURG, Sept. 23.--The Hamburger Nachrichten says that England has no need of making any concession to France on the Suez Canal question. Hyppolite Maffei, an old Frenchman, arrived here Wednesday night from San Francisco, with his friend Louis Baulle, intending to sail for France today. They went to a hotel in the lower part of the city and Thursday morning Maffel went out for a stroll through the city. Since then he has been unable to find his hotel, where he left a trunk, valise, and shotgun. He is now at the Hotel Martin, on University place.

Smallpox is spreading on Staten Island to an alarming extent. Three new cases have been reported in Stapleton within the past 48 hours, and one case was reported yesterday from Port Richmond. Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific tickets were offered for sale yesterday by the offices of all the trunk lines except the Pennsylvania, and the famous "ticket boycott" against the Rock Island may be considered practically ended. Legal advice by their own counsel is said to have figured largely in inducing the trunk lines to restore the Rock Island's tickets to sale.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 23.--The News has made a careful review of the corn crop of Indiana. Opinions have been secured from all the persons in a position to judge accurately. The yield in the State will be about 60 per cent. of an average, the opinions varying from 50 to 70 per cent. There is yet a large amoant of old corn in crib, which will have an important bearing upon prices this Fall.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 23.--The people of Nyack and vicinity paid their respects to Col. and Mrs. Fred D. Grant to-night in a verb pleasant and enthusiastic manner. A public reception was held in Voorhis Hall, beginning at 8 o'clock, and the hall was crowded to its utmost capacity.

TROY, Sept. 23.--The First Assembly District Republican Convention for Saratoga County, held at Ballston Spa to-day, nominated Harvey J. Donaldson for member of Assembly.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23.--There will be about 250 delegates to the coming General Assembly of the Knights of Labor at Minneapolis, representing about 600,000 members in good standing.

CORK, Sept. 23.--Mr. William O'Brien, who is charged by the Government with sedition, under the Coercion act, was taken to-day from the Cork Jail to Mitchellstown, where the alleged seditious language was used, to stand trial before the court there.

HAVANA, Sept. 23.--A severe shock of earthquake was felt in Santiago de Cuba to-day, the vibrations lasting half a minute. It was followed an hour later by two other shocks, but of less intensity. Two persons were injured and some houses were damaged. Shocks were also felt in Guantanamo and Manzanillo, and in Kingston, Jamaica.

The Central Labor Union of Brooklyn held a erotracted session yesterday, which continued far into the night. A strong effort was made to get the union to indorse the candidacy of John J. Clancy, the United Labor Party's nominee for Mayor of Brooklyn. The opposition was so determined, however, that Clancy's friends concluded not to press the matter, and so allowed it to be made the order of the day for 4 o'clock next Sunday.

The new Arion Club house at Lexingtonavenue and fifty-ninth-street was illuminated from basement to roof last evening, and from 8 to 9 0'clock a stream of ladies and gentlemen poured into the broad entrance.

No. 7 West 24th-st., in rear of hotel. The most select and elegantly appointed baths in the city. The plunge is filled continually with fresh water. The sulphur and medicated baths are in charge of William Welsh, an experienced manager having the indorsement of many of our leading physicians. Ladies' hours only from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M.

The schooner yacht Atalanta, owned by Mr. C.S. Maltby, arrived at City Island yesterday and went out of commission for the season. The Captain reports that Sept. 10. at Martha's Vineyard, Philip Alfhan, a Swedish sailor, 25 years old, fell from the masthead to the deck and broke his neck.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Sept. 25.--The mysterious disappearance of certain negroes and the subsequent finding of their bodies, under circumstances that indicate foul play, has been of late a subject of comment in this part of the South, but only lately has the key to the mystery been furnished.

READING, Penn., Sept. 25.--William Hartung, a well known citizen of Reading, fell into a kettle of catsup which was being boiled in the yard of his residence and died last night from his injuries. He served the Reading Railroad Company in various capacities for forty years.

BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., Sept. 25.--Frank W. Stowe, of New-York, General Agent of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, has been indicted by the Grand Jury of this county for soliciting insurance for the Guaranty Mutual Accident Association, an assessment company of New-York. This is the first prosecution for many years, but offenders are likely to be followed up hereafter.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25.--There were hundreds of visitors to-day to the old Tim Aldrich place, in Oxford, where the body of Lillie Hoyle was found last Tuesday afternoon. NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 25.--When President Timothy Dwight heard that Yale had won the boat race over Harvard at New-London last June he flung his hat in the air in giviag vent to his joy.

DOVER, N.H., Sept. 25.--P.A. Crosby, Treasurer of the Lasters' Protective Union Fair, a married man, has absconded with the fair receipts, amounting to $5,000, and is accompanied by Mrs. Emma Sawyer Lord. Crosby is 37 years old, and came to this city 18 months ago from Richmond, Me.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 25.--George Zeigler last evening stopped in a corner grocery, where Daniel Alexander agreed to pay for all the liquor Zeigler would drink. Zeigler drank 22 glasses of five-cent whisky, walked 200 yards home, sat down, and soon died.

Giuseppe Milando and Gentitio Antro were walking down Carroll-street, Brooklyn, last night, when they met Joseph Summerville, of 351 Atlantic-avenue. They took pains to revive an old quarrel with Summerville, during which Milando cut him on the head severely with a razor.

Mayor HEWITT had before him the other day the case of a man who, beguiled by a seductive advertisement, went to a mock auction and invested $1,100 in comparatively worthless furniture. The auction was held in what seemed to the casual wayfarer to be a private residence.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25.--Three actors stood in the lobby of the Continental Hotel cafe late this evening talking shop. They were good friends, and cracked jokes right and left. They were Wilton Lackaye, of the Allan Dare Company; James Mahoney, who was with Lotta last season, and Peter Church, an actor who lives in Washington.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--Great joy is manifested among the Bohemians of the city. Some time since a Bohemian paper of Cleveland, Ohio, the Dennice Novoveku, announced that Mrs. Cleveland had declined to accept the present which the Bohemian Turners were going to make her.
LONDON, Sept. 25.--The Cunard Line steamship Servia, Capt. McKay, sid. from Queenstown for New-York to-day.

THRASHED--HOW THE CLUBS STAND. The Brooklyns outbatted and outfielded their Baltimore opponents at Ridgewood yesterday, but failed to win. To hard luck only can their failure to beat the Orioles be attributed.

According to a French musical paper, a dumb automatic recorder of musical sounds has just been invented, and the "melograph," as the ingenious contrivance is to be called, can be affixed without trouble and at little cost to any piano.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 25.-The train of the New-York Veteran Firemen's Association, en route from Kansas City to St. Louis, collided with a freight train at Holden, slightly damaging the baggage car and causing a detention of two hours. The veterans arrive in this city at 1 o'clock this afternoon all well and uninjured.

A somewhat weatherbeaten lad, giving his name as Lloyd E. Quinn, of Troy, N.Y., and his age as 9 years, asked Policeman Mahoney yesterday at Broadway and Thirteenth-street to show him the way to the Grand Central Station. Mahoney took him to the police station instead, where he said his father was a carpenter of Troy.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 25.--The town of Ronceverte, in Greenbrier County, is greatly excited over the mysterious and cold-blooded assassination of a woman, occurring there, it is supposed, last night. The murdered woman was Mrs. Louise Eldridge, the wife of a restaurant keeper.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club will be sure to have a half dozen good races to-day, the character of the entries insuring that. The clever handicapping also promises very close contests in all six, and as there are fair fields there should be good betting.

MADRID, Sept. 26.--Riots have been caused on the island of Ponapi, one of the Caroline group, in consequence of the expulsion of the Protestant misssionary. One man has already been killed. Reinforcements have been sent from Manila to restore order.

The American sloop Volunteer and the Scotch cutter Thistle are all ready to begin the struggle for the America's Cup, and the Signal Service promises to give them a good easterly breeze to start with and more of it for the finish.

Mr. Bronson Howard's new play, "The Henrietta," is a very good one; it has an abundance of humor, there are many witty passages in the text, most of the characters are happily conceived and well drawn, and the action is quite brisk enough to keep the interest from flagging.
BOSTON, Sept. 26.--Judges Colt and Nelson, of the United States Circuit Court, to-day rendered a decision in the case of the United States against the American Bell Telephone Company and others.

The Grand Opera House was literally packed last night with an audience that yelled itself hoarse in the endeavor to manifest its approval of a performance of Messrs. Sims and Pettitt's melodrama "Harbor Lights."

Trouble is brewing at the Children's Home of the Church of the Messiah, 420 East Fifty-third-street. The Home was established by the ladies of the church for the care and shelter of the children of the poor, but is not strictly a charitable institution, as the parents are expected to contribute something, however small the amount, toward the maintenance of their offspring.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 26.--The first explosion of natural gas since its introduction into this city occurred this morning at 1,156 Seneca-street. The explosion set fire to the house, causing a loss of about $1,000. No one was injured, the family fortunately being absent at the time.

John S. Kennedy is determined to push the question of the legality of the Rev. E. Walpole Warren's "importation" to this country by Holy Trinity Episcopal Church. "I have given instructions to my lawyer," said he, ...

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26.--Opinions vary greatly among the politicians of the State as to the reason why Senator McPherson, in defining his attitude touching the Senatorial struggle, straddles a fence so that no man may know exactly what his position is.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26.--The annual festival of the Worcester County Musical Association, the thirteenth in its history, began today with three rehearsals.

The encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic now in progress at St. Louis will probably prove one of the most important in the history of the organization and will certainly be watched by the public with almost unprecedented interest.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 26.--At 8:30 o'clock last evening the west-bound St. Louis express on the Fitchburg Railroad, and which consisted of three sleeping coaches filled with passengers, sighted an obstruction on the track one mile west of North Pownal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--Paul Grotkan, the Milwaukee Anarchist, who is threatening to come to Chicago and deliver speeches, did not appear here to-day, and the police officers who have been detailed to pay their respects to him, as soon as he arrived, had nothing to do.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26.--Manager Harry Wright was all smiles as he watched his boys march on the field to play the Washingtons to-day. He was up in the Directors' box with Robert Downing, the actor, when the 2,500 people brought their hands together and clapped and shouted a welcome to the Phillies after their three weeks' absence.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 26.--In the District Court of the United States, sitting here today, Judge Jackson entered a decree which is of the utmost importance to investors in what are called "wild lands," within the boundaries of this State.

"North Carolinian," Wilmington, N.C.-- Magna Charta is correct. There is no authority for any such Latin word as carta.

BERLIN, Sept. 26.--The Tagcblatt asserts that the Czar has again proposed the selection of Prince Waldemar of Denmark as Prince of Bulgaria, and that if Prince Bismarck entertains the suggestion the Czar will visit Emperor William.

The Maurice Grau French Opera Company appeared at the Star Theatre last evening in Audran's opera, "Le Grand Mogol," which was originally made known in this country in English by Col. McCaull at the Bijou Opera House, where Lillian Russell, then appearing for the first time in operetta, and Selina Dolaro filled the chief roles.

The Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn held its first meeting since May last night in the Hamilton Building, on Court-street. Frederick R. Lee presided, and in a brief speech pointed out the necessity for hard work during the approaching campaign.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Sept. 26.--The American schooner Nettie B. Dobbin was to-day fined $50 for neglecting to enter at the Custom House until the third day after her arrival from Jonesport, Me.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 26.--The last society event of the season in Seabright was the afternoon tea given on Friday last by Mrs. Joseph T. Low, and it was an event long to be remembered by the fortunate participants.
A furor was created in the Street yesterday by the flourished announcement that finally Henry Hart was to give up the management of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company to Jay Gould.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26.--Cardinal Gibbons left this city at 11 o'clock to-day for his Western trip. He will go to St. Paul, Minn., where he will remain some time, and thence proceed to Portland, Oregon, where he will confer the pallium on Archbishop Gross, of that see. The conferring of the pallium is the chief reason for his visit West at this time.
Handsome Mr. Crowley and charming Kittie O'Brien, the two occupants of the lion house in Central Park, who command so much attention from visitors, will be married about the last of October.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 26.--The Hon. A. W. McLellan, Postmaster-General, has admitted bribery by agents in his election for the House of Commons, and his seat for Colchester is consequently rendered vacant. Charges of personal bribery against Mr. McLellan are yet to be heard.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 26.--John McManus, alias "the Kid," was released from jail about 10 o'clock this morning on the decision by Judge Beardsley that the service of the papers in the ten-thousand-dollar civil suit brought against him by Jeweler Fairchild was illegal.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 26.--The Etoile Belge says the Government will urge the passage of a bill making military service compulsory upon all citizens able to bear arms.
The New-Yorks batted the delivery of Madden with comparative case yesterday and won a game from the Bostons on the Polo Grounds.
LONDON, Sept. 26.--The steamship Robilant, (Ital.,) Capt. Feiugo, from New-York Sept. 10, for Genoa, passed Gibraltar yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 26.--O. Preston, of Hornellsville, the candidate of the Union Labor Party for Secretary of State, came here to-day and tendered to George D. Lennon, of New-York, Secretary of the Executive Committee, the withdrawal of his name in favor of John Swinton, whom the committee will soon place in nomination.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--The Presidential Reception Committee has matured its plans for the reception and entertainment of Mr. Cleveland, and they were to-day approved by the President himself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--The total amount of bonds purchased by the Treasury Department to-day under the circular of the 22d inst. was $1,253,250, of which $1,076,200 were 4 per cents. and $177,050 4 per cents.

SARATOGA, Sept. 26.--There was a conference in the Executive Mansion at Albany last night, which was attended by several Democrats who have more or less to do with the affairs of the party. D. William N. Loew, a lawyer having an office at 15 Centre-street, was held in $2,500 bail at Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of forgery. In May a quantity of furs belonging to Mrs. Clara Schulhof were burned.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26.--Miss Phoebe Couzins, daughter of the late United States Marshal J.E.D. Couzins, made application to President Cleveland to-day for the position of United States Marshal for the Eastern District of Missouri. Miss Couzins had had full charge of the office for the last year during her father's illness.

The success which attended the efforts made by the Republican clubs of Union County, N.J., in the contest for control of the Board of Freeholders last Spring, resulting in the overturning of the Democratic majority which for years had controlled that body, has led the party to make a bold effort to elect its candidates at the approaching election for county offices.
OTTAWA, Sept. 26.--The express train which left Ottawa this afternoon for Montreal on the Canada Atlantic Railroad was wrecked three miles below Eastman's Springs.
Daniel Lyons, the murderer of Joseph Quinn, was convicted of murder in the first degree yesterday. District Attorney Martine closed his argument against the prisoner at noon.
Complaints have been general of late regarding the slow progress of the repaving of Fifth-avenue, especially the section about Madison-s quare.

The mandamus proceeding to compel the Police Commissioners to appoint election inspectors for the party that Henry George represented last Fall came up in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, before Judge Barrett, because Judge Patterson was suddenly called to Philadelphia by the death of his uncle.

The management of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company is to change hands once more. After a brief season of authority Henry Hart has been forced to the conclusion that, even with a majority of the Board of Directors of his way of thinking, be cannot keep the stock from depreciating in value.

The offices of the New-York Central Road were nearly all left in charge of clerks yesterday afternoon in order that their chiefs might go down the Bay to meet Chauncey M. Depew, who was expected before evening on the Elbe.

HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Dr. McGlynn spoke here this evening in behalf of the Labor Party. It was expected that the Rev. Father Nilan, of Poughkeepsie, would be present and make a speech in open defiance of Archbishop Corrigan, but he did not come. It is said that McGlynn, George, and Nilan will speak in Rondout on Oct. 6.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26.--The Republican Congressional Convention for the Twenty fifth District to-day nominated the Hon. James J. Belden for Representative in Congress to succeed Frank Hiscock.

Babbitt from command of Fortress Monroe Arsenal and ordered to command the San Antonio Arsenal, Texas, relieving Major Isaac Arnold, who is ordered to command Fortress Monroe Arsenal.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Sept. 26.--The National Line steamer Egypt, Capt. Sumner, from Liverpool, Sept. 15 for New-York, has arrived here for repairs to her shaft. She has 900 passengers on board, and will resume her voyage on Wednesday.
