Yachting occupied Wall-street attention yesterday far more than did trading on the Stock Exchange. Business was dull enough before the bulletins began to come in that the Thistle and Volunteer had started, but thereafter it was almost wholly left alone.

The contest between the Thistle and Volunteer was the subject of much facetiousness among the comedians last night. At Dockstader's it was asked why the men on the Thistle did not bet on their own yacht.

There was a dearth of news in the Sharp case yesterday, Sharp's lawyers will probably have a consultation to-day, or, at the latest, to-morrow, when Mr. Cockran returns to the city. Nothing will be done until to-morrow, when the order vacating the stay of execution will be settled, and Sharp will not be taken to Sing Sing until Friday.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--In a letter from Wadelai, dated April 17, Emin Bey declares that he will not return with Stanley. He says: "I have passed 12 years here and have succeeded in reoccupying nearly every station in the country which Gen. Gordon intrusted to me.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27.--At 7:30 o'clock this morning, while the north-bound passenger train on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad was running on an embankment, two miles south of Jackson, at the rate of 40 miles an hour, the baggage car left the track.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--Copies of the postal Convention entered into between the United States and the Government of Jamaica, have to-day been mailed to all the Governments of South and Central America and the West Indies.

A raid was made early yesterday morning on rooms at 133 West Thirty-sixth-street, which the police suspected to be an opium Joint. The police captured four people--Claude Harley, the proprietor; Samuel Keller, George W. Blake, and Sadie Moore, a girl of 20. Keller and Blake said they were clerks, but all the names are believed to be false. In the rooms gambling and opium smoking implements were found and seized.

Yesterday was the first day of registration in Brooklyn, and 31,303 citizens took advantage of the fine weather to enroll their names. The day's work compares very favorably with the first day of 1885, when the last Mayoralty election occurred, and is a slight improvement over the same day last year.

The national prize shooting festival, under the auspices of the Harlem Independent Schuetzen Corps, Helvetia Rifle Club, Independent New-York Schuetzen, Morrisania Schuetzen Verein, and Zettler Rifle Club, open yesterday at Washington Park. Marksmen were present from all over the country.
LIMERICK, Sept. 27.--Military and police were present to-day at the eviction of Michael Lane and family from their holding on Col. Meadow's estate at Ardnacrusha.

Jacob Sharp's condition grew steadily worse all day yesterday and by nightfall it was so bad that Dr. Loomis entertained grave doubts that his patient would be able to stand a removal next Friday, or even later, for that matter. Although there is no immmediate danger, the impression prevails about the jail that Sharp will never leave his cell alive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--The President heard of the victory of the Volunteer over the Thistle at Oak View. He had heard a good deal of talk at the White House during the day about the race, and as everybody in Washington talked of it as the great interesting topic, he naturally shared in the common, interest in learning the result.

BOSTON, Sept. 27.--Citizen Francis A. Hobart, of Braintree, came to town to-day and registered at the Tremont House. When Citizen Hobart registers it is generally understood that the Republican State Convention has fairly began.

The Thistle lay quietly at her anchorage off Tompkinsville last night, and, vanquished though she was, looked beautiful in the moonlight. Every thing above decks was shipshape and tidy, and two of the Thistle's sailors walked the deck and talked about the great race.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 27.--To-day it was announced that the Dollar Savings Bank is to dispose of all the Government bonds in its possession, and the money realized to be distributed in this city.

PARIS, Sept. 27.--At the Cabinet council to-day the shooting affair on the German frontier being under consideration, M. Flourens, Foreign Minister, stated that Germany had declared that she could not too deeply regret the deplorable incident, and that she would make every reparation legally required if the facts stated by France were correct.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--The yacht race at New-York excited little interest in London, except in the city proper, where large crowds assembled early in the evening around the bulletin boards at the cable offices, dispersing, however, before the result was announced.

Coroner Eidwan held an inquest yesterday in the case of Thomas Grogan and Nelson Lampman, who perished in the fire at 10 and 11 South-street on Sept. 19. Foreman Frederick Goodersen, of Engine Company No. 10, said everybody could have been saved if there had been a fire escape.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 27.--D.W. Caldwell applied to court to-day for his discharge as Receiver of the Nickel Plate Road, in order that the property may be turned over to the new company on Oct. 1.
The yacht race did not monopolize the attention of all lovers of sport yesterday, for there were 5,000 or more people at the Brooklyn track to see a half dozen very good races won.

A fire which broke out in the five-story brick building at 438 Pearl-street at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon created much excitement. The building was used as a storage house and finishing department for furniture by Josiah Partridge, who occupied half of the second and all of the third, fourth, and fifth floors.

The unanimous and clamorous nomination of J.J. BELDEN for Congress in the Twenty-fifth District of this State is an incident in the current Republican politics of this State of more than usual significance.

The turning points in the lives of most men and women are slight, but they none the less decide their destiny. Secretary Chase, who shared the war burdens of the Nation, had been broken down by overwork and the cares of State, and his physicians shook their heads.

There is grief in the asylums of Anglomania. The wine of France hath lost its savor, and the Prince of Wales is sad. The roar of the British Lion hath grown dolefully unterrible, while the American Eagle flutters its wings and shrieks raucous and deflant.
Never before has the George C. Flint Company's store, at 104, 106, and 108 West Fourteenth-street, contained a larger or more complete assortment of artistic furniture than at present.

The Rev. Howard Crosby, the Rev. Cornelius Praetori, and others recently wrote to Mayor Hewitt complaining of the "white washing" of Capt. Alexander S. Williams at his recent trial, and asking him to "examine the testimony and act in such manner as the cause of pure government may require."
The misfortune of being unable to attend the yacht race yesterday in no wisedulled the interest of those New-Yonkers who were compelled to remain in the city.
The pavilion erected by Mrs. R.H.L. Townsend at Believe Hospital for the treatment of women suffering from ovarian tumors was yesterday formally presented to the city.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 27.--At the Union Veterans' Union National Encampment to-day the report of the Pension Committee, the Hon. Ivory Pike, of Illinois, Chairman, was unanimously adopted.

James McCreery Co., of Broadway and Eleventh-street, have spread their Fall novelties upon their counters, and the ladies are gathering them in with a celerity which is somewhat greater than is the wont even at this famous establishment.
LONDON, Sept. 27.--At the Newmarket races to-day the Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds was won by brother to Rosy Morn by threequarters of a length, Her Majesty second, and Scarlet Runner third.
LONDON, Sept. 28.--A Chinese transport has been wrecked on one of the Pescadores Islands. Three hundred soldiers and the Captain and crew, with the exception of one man were drowned.

In the minds of very many people the question of the relative merits of the Volunteer and Thistle, as individuals, and the centreboard sloop and the cutter, as types, was emphatically set at rest yesterday afternoon, when the Volunteer ...

Miss Mary Bennett, 20 years old, had a very narrow escape from death on Monday at the High-street crossing the New-York and Greenwood Lake Railroad at Orange, N.J. The young lady is a deaf-mute and a daughter of John Bennett, a well known preacher in the sign language.

It does not seem premature to announce that the America's Cup will await another British challenger at the opening of the season of 1888. It appears to be agreed that the Thistle was "outlucked" yesterday, and that the shifts of the light breeze that took place were for the most part in favor of the Volunteer.
BOSTON, Sept. 27.--Another chapter in the bitter contest between Mr. Patrick Maguire, editor of the Republic, and Postmaster Corse was added to-day.
SARATOGA, Sept. 27.--The pinched face of a gentleman seemingly suffering from gripes was the most conspicuous piece of ornamentation in the convention hall.

Mrs. Emma Skerrett, for 43 years a well known actress, died Monday night, at the Peabody House, Philadelphia. Mrs. Skerrett was English by birth, and was 61 years old. She came to this country in 1844 with her husband, George Skerrett, and first appeared at the old Park Theatre, New-York. She was, thereafter, soubrette at Burton's for a time.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27.--The first gun of the coming conflict in the Grand Army of the Republic was fired to-night in Central Turner Hall. Late to-day a call was sent around for a meeting of veteraus to consider the pension question, and to-night about 1,500 assembled in the Turner Hall. The meeting was secret, and only members of the order were present.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27.--Gov. Green to-day appointed Bayard Stockton, of Princeton, as Prosecitor of the pleas for this county, to fill the vaancy caused by the suicide of Mercer Beasley, Jr. Mr. Stockton is a son of the late Richard Stockton, who for many years was Treasurer of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company. He was appointed over the heads of a number of politicians who sought the office.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27.--Some highly interesting testimony was given to-day in the hearing on the charges of fraud preferred against Gen. Lester B. Faulker, the prominent Democratic politician, in connection with the failure of the First National Bank of Dansville, of which the General's brother, James Faulkner, was President.

William R. Hayden, James B. Dickson, and Nick Roberts, of the New-York Amusement Exchange, have agreed to dissolve partnership. Mr. Roberts will continue the business. Mr. Dickson goes into theatrical booking for himself, and Mr. Hayden will devote his time to certain amusement interests that he has en tour.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--A Board of Survey, to consist of Lieut Col. Amos Beckwith, Assistant Commissary-General of Subsistence; Capt. Allen Smith, Fourth Cavalry, and Capt. F.H. Hathaway, Assistant Quartermaster, has been ordered to assemble at St. Louis to examine certain damaged stores.

When the steamship Elbe dropped anchor off Quarantine, about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, the boat Castleton shoved her nose through the fog up to the ship's side, and a red-eyed company on board, forgetting the sleepless night just passed, began to cheer lustily.

ASHLAND, Penn., Sept. 27.--A representative of the St. Louis Club to-day signed Harry Lyons the third baseman of the Ashland Club. Lyons played with the Binghamton Club early in the season, and was afterward with the Philadelphias.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28--The propagation of fish in the lakes and rivers of the Dominion is one of the most important features of the work carried on by the Fisheries Department. During the past season upward of 90,000,000, fish of every variety taken from the various Government hatcheries have been given their liberty.

The Pacific Railroad investigators had a tame time of it yesterday, and those who were obliged to sit through its session agreed that 10 minutes of Huntington or Crocker had more entertainment in them than was provided by all the witnesses examined.
Levy Nichol, who has been employed as a bookkeeper by H.F. Taintor, a manufacturer of Paris green in Greenpoint, disappeared last Saturday with $750 belonging to his employer.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28.--The concerts of the second day of the Worcester music festival attracted immense audiences, that of the evening far exceeding the seating capacity of the great hall.
It was favorites' day at the Clifton track yesterday, the races being run with the following results:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 28.--B.C. Hart, manager of the Columbia Theatre here, booked both Harry Miner's "Golden Giant" and the Murray and Murphy company for next week, but summarily cancelled the "Golden Giant" engagement.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--The yachtsmen of the Clyde are astounded at the result of yesterday's contest between the Thistle and the Volunteer, and the majority are despondent respecting the result of the series of races.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--President Cleveland will be made the recipient of one communication on or before his arrival in Chicago that will, in the opinion of the professional labor agitators and idiots of the town, furnish him with food for study and reflection.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Mr. Edward A. Moseley, on his individual responsibility and not as the Secretary of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, has made an answer to some recent harsh criticisms of the Administration by Mr. Richard S. Spofford, of ...

MONTREAL, Sept. 28.--Trial by jury is in this province rapidly becoming a farce. A young French Canadian named Lesieur was charged in the Court of Queen's Bench with robbing the mails, and the evidence against him was as clear as could possibly be, the chief witness for the defense being committed by Judge Baby for perjury.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--A steady stream of people filed by an improvised box office at the Chicago Opera House yesterday from 9 o'clock in the morning until 5 in the afternoon.
The much-talked-of State Convention of the Progressive Labor Party began its session yesterday morning at Webster Hall, in East Eleventh-street.
HAVANA, Sept. 28.--A shock of earthquake was felt at Sagua to-day.

Secretary Fairchild had a long conference with leading New-York bankers yesterday afternoon. It was an informal meeting, and financiers were coming and going continually, generally climbing the long flight of steps to the Sub-Treasury's doors full of praise for the Administration policy in money matters and going away after they had told their beliefs to the Secretary.
BINGHAMTON, Sept. 28.--A magnificent race was rowed this afternoon on the Susquehanna River, at Owego, between Charles E. Courtney and George Bubear.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The forty-fourth annual fair of the Rockland County Agricultural and Horticultural Association opened at this place yesterday with flattering prospects, and will end on Friday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28.--The rain continued to drop down steadily to-day and with increased showers. Everything was drenched, and the ardor of citizen and soldier was damped.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--The appraisement of the property of Robert Hare Powel Co. and Robert Hare Powel's Sons Co. has been finished, and was filed in court to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 28.--The Northwestern Miller says: "As a result of the water being out of the west side canal a day and a half last week the flour output of the mills suffered quite a decline.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The fifth annual conference of friends of the Indians opened this morning. The members were welcomed by Mr. A.H. Smiley, of the Board of Indian Commissioners, who entertains them as his guests. Gen. Clinton B. Fisk was chosen President for the fifth consecutive year.
OTTAWA, Sept. 28.--A gentleman in Ottawa who recently forwarded some papers bearing on the fishery question to the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain has received an acknowledgment from him.

More than a million dollars' worth of goods belonging to Catlin Co. and H.B. Claflin Co. were in danger of destruction yesterday morning by a fire which broke out about 5:30 o'clock in the basement of 53 and 55 Thomas-street, a five-story structure which makes an L with 216 Church-street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--Considerable surprise was occasioned in Western railroad circles yesterday by the discovery that the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul had given 10 days' notice of an advance in grain rates from points west of the Mississippi River between La Crosse and St. Paul.

Adolph Delmez, who shot Matilda Klotz at 86 East Third-street, was held yesterday to await the result of the girl's injuries. Delmes visited the girl Tuesday night and fired the shot at her in the hall.

SARATOGA, Sept. 28.--After a two days convention the Democracy has delivered itself of a platform and selected a ticket for use this Fall. Two of the five nominees, Secretary of State Cook and Treasurer Fitzgerald, having served only a single term, were renominated in accordance with Democratic usages.

The Governors of the Stock Exchange yesterday voted to list the following securities: Two hundred and sixty thousand dollars additional 6 per cent. gold bonds of the Helena, Boulder Valley and Butte Railroad Company; $3,000,000 additional ...

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28.--A singular tragedy is reported this evening from Oklahoma, Indian Territory. Two white men, aged about 30 and 35 respectively, while engaged in herding cattle on Stillwater got into a dispute which ended in a duel. A number of shots were fired, each man being wounded in several places. Both were found stretched on the ground bleeding to death. They will not live.

A.F. Jammes's store, at 13 West Thirtiethstreet, was broken into on the night of Sept. 15 and robbed of 1,500 pairs of gloves, 75 pairs of silk stockings, and 4 carved amber lace fans, in all valued, at cost price, at $2,866. Gas was burning in the store over night, and, besides the police, Mr. Jammes had two special watchmen to guard his place.

The second of the contests for the America's Cup will take place to-day, and the most knowing yachtsmen believe that by to-night the prized trophy will be perfectly safe.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 28.--Several days ago two young ladies arrived here and registered at the Eutaw House under the names of Miss Ray and Miss Wilpertel.

About 500 elevators in the lower portion of the city came to a standstill with a gasp at 11:30 o'clock yesterday, and the elevator boys, in some cases, gasped too, for they were helplessly suspended in the air.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28.--A preliminary examination was held here to-day for applicants for the higher degrees to be conferred on nonresident graduates upon examination. As the final examination requires a very high standard of scholarship, many were not expected to apply, but an encouraging number of recent graduates of Princeton presented themselves, and a large number intimated their intention of appearing next year and employing the present year in preparation.

" T.F."--Neither. It is steel. Free evening class for instruction in shorthand at Cooper Union will begin on Oct. 3 at 8 P.M.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 28.--The train of three cars which is to carry the Presidential party on their trip to the South and West is being made up in this city at the Pullman shops. Over 50 skilled mechanics have been at work on the cars for the past 10 days, and they will be the handsomest and most complete in the world.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 28.--Gen. Ferdinand C. Latrobe was to-day unanimously nominated as Democratic candidate for Mayor. He has twice been elected to the same office.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 28.--Delegates were chosen this afternoon to the County Convention at the quietest Democratic primaries which have occurred since the war.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--East-bound shipments of flour, grain, and provisions from Chicago to seaboard points for the week's ending last Saturday were 26,602 tons, against 25,979 tons, an increase of 623 tons over the preceding week.

For the five State offices to be filled at the election on Nov. 8 four tickets have already been placed in the field, not counting the Union Labor Party and the Socialists, to whose pretensions no good citizen will pay any attention.

The Kings County Republican General Committee held a special meeting at Everett Hall, in Fulton-street, Brooklyn, last night, and completed the final arrangements for the preliminary work of the campaign.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--Capt. Black and Moses Solomon, the lawyers for the Anarchists, together with Mrs. Black, returned to-day from New-York, where they had been to secure the help of Gen. Roger A. Prior ...
MONTREAL, Sept. 28.--Charles Page, who raised checks on the Jacques Cartier Bank and Bank of Montreal to the amount of $35,000, has been sentenced to 14 years' imprisonment.
There will be an extra day's racing at the Brooklyn track to-morrow, the programme for which will be as follows:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 28.--The TurnerSawers feud in Bell County, Ky., has been renewed. At least, two more lines have been sacrificed. Trouble began afresh last Saturday night on Yellow Creek, 10 miles northeast of Pineville, the county seat of Bell County.

The Rev. G.T. Jackson, Pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church of Pine Brook, N. J., yesterday reported at Newark's Police Headquarters that while he and his family were at prayer meeting Tuesday night his residence adjoining the church was entered by thieves.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 28.--The marriage of Mr. John H. Buckley, of the well known firm of Buckley Son, rubber goods manufacturers, to Miss Libbie F. Selleck was solemnized this afternoon at the groom's residence on Belden-avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28.--A resident at Morris Cove, on the east shore of New-Haven Harbor, discovered the body of a man in the water this afternoon. When an examination was made of the remains a copy of a Brooklyn newspaper with "Gill B. Farnam, St. Mark's-place, Brooklyn, N.Y.," written ...

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 28.--A terrible fight between the hundred or more bricklayers and Italians employed on the new Main-street sewer occurred this afternoon. The contestants on both sides were severely punished, some of them being so badly cut with knives as to render their condition critical.
About 300 persons assembled in Historical Hall, in Clinton-street, Brooklyn, yesterday, at the conference of Prohibition and temperance workers. The Rev. George Hicks was elected Chairman.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28.--T.G. Shaughnessy, Assistant General Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway, says that only 40 miles of track on the Sault Ste. Marie short line remains to be laid. Forty-five miles are already constructed.

There was a strike at the Standard Theatre the other evening, which, fortunately for the management, was soon compromised. The four children which impersonate the owls in the Dismal Swamp scene complained to Stage Manager Gill that their salary was insufficient.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28.--Winston Paige, of Schenectady, came to Syracuse Tuesday and made application to Chief-Judge Ruger, of the Court of Appeals, for a stay in the case of Jacob Sharp. Judge Ruger to-night declined to say anything about the matter.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 28.--In a suit tried in the Rockland Circuit Court at New City on Monday, a verdict was rendered against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, as lessees of the West Shore Road, in a suit by W. Nash to recover $5,000 damages for the death of his wife, who was killed by a train on the West Shore Road near the Haverstraw Tunnel.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 28.--In the State Senate to-day President Davidson took the floor and in an eloquent speech introduced the following resolutions, which were unanimously adopted:

LYONS, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The annual market for peppermint oil in Wayne County, which is famous throughout the world as the greatest peppermint oil region, has opened lower than at any time in 30 years. The usual price for the commodity here is never less than $2 per pound, but this season only $1 80 is offered.

An exhibition will be given this afternoon at Fort Lafayette of Lieut. Zalinski's dynamite gun for the special benefit of an English commission, composed of Major Bainbridge, of the Ordnance Department, and Lieut. Williams, of the Queen's Navy.

The shooting festival at Washington Park closed yesterday with the most satisfactory results. The marksmanship was considerably above the average. The interest manifested in the festival was very great, and the receipts from the targets alone amounted to over $2,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 28.--Last Wednesday a neat, genteel-looking man, walked into the St. Charles Hotel, registered from Florida, and was assigned a room. He was an Englishman, and appeared to be a tourist. After remaining in the hotel for a few days he disappeared, leaving a bill of $18 unsettled.
The yacht race of to-day promises to be more interesting, if not closer, than the one of Tuesday. The first race was indeed very far from being a drifting match.

The steamship Alps, which arrived yesterday from Gonaives, reports that on Sept. 23, at 7 A.M., off the south coast of Cuba, in latitude 19 44', longitude 74 24', a shock of a marine earthquake was felt, lasting about 45 seconds.
After her race yesterday D.A. Honig bought the fast 2-year-old filly Omaha from Mr. R.W. Walden at private sale, though the filly was entered in a selling race.

The Health Commissioners made several important changes in the sanitary divisions yesterday. The position of Chief Inspector of Food and Chemical Analyses was abolished and Dr. Cyrus Edson, who held it, was made Chief Inspector of Contagious Diseases in place of Dr. J.B. Taylor, who resigned.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 28.--To-morrow will be the most memorable of all election days in Tennessee. The weather promises to be good, and a very large vote is looked for.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--Mr. Gladstone has a critique in the Nineteenth Century on Ingram's "History of the Irish Union." He says that the work is not a history at all; that it offers no inquiry into the graver charges against the authors of the union, and that it does not show even a rudimentary knowledge of the leading facts of Irish affairs.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 28.--The Union Veterans' Union, assembled in national encampment, to-day unanimously re-elected Gen. M.A. Dillon, of Washington, as Commander-in-Chief, and Gen. W.J. Clark, of Cleveland, as First Deputy Commander.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 28.--Cadet E.E. Lang, of the Third Class, has been dismissed from the Naval Academy for hazing Fourth Class man.
Assistant Constructor Hoover is to be detached from the Brooklyn Navy Yard and transferred to Philadelphia, where he will take charge of the construction of the new cruisers in Cramps' yard.

There have been times when both political parties in Massachusetts seemed to be disposed to take advanced ground and the claim of the old Commonwealth to lead in political progress was apparently vindicated.
The annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York opened at St. Augustine Chapel, East Houstonstreet, yesterday.

The New-York Driving Club will have a second Fall meeting on Oct. 5, 6, and 7 at Fleetwood. The notice is unfortunately short for this meeting, as entries close Saturday, Oct. 1 at 5 P.M., but it is believed that a full list of events will not be wanting on the closing day. The entrance fee will be the same as at the previous meeting, 5 per cent. of the purse.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Thirty recruits have been ordered to the Department of the Platte for assignment to the Seventh and Eighth Infantries. Upon the recommendation of a retiring board the leave of absence granted Capt. E.B. Rheem, Twenty-first Infantry, has been extended until further orders.

There was dullness on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but there was strength, too, and nearly every stock on the list scored an advance. The bulls, a long time discouraged, plucked up new faith and got almost to a hurrah point, becoming pretty thoroughly persuaded that finally "things had turned."

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 28.--The Republicans of the Eighteenth Senatorial District met in convention here today and nominated the Hon. Harlan P. Kline, of Amsterdam, for State Senator. Fulton and Hamilton Counties presented the name of Andrew J. Nellis, of Johnstown, and when the result of the formal ballot was announced they publicly declared that they would bolt Kline and support the Hon. Edward D. Cutler, who will probably be the Democratic nominee.
A circular has been sent to many English residents of this city and Brooklyn calling upon them to meet this evening at 77 Nassau-street to discuss a plan of organization for political purposes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 28.--Sergt. Ralph Teeple, Company K. Fifth United States Infantry, stationed at Fort Totten, Dakota, has been here some weeks drinking heavily. Early this morning he cut his throat with a razor, from the effect of which he died this afternoon. He was an unmarried man and took part in the recent shooting matches at Fort Snelling, securing second place on the list of Dakota marksmen.
BOSTON, Sept. 28.--The Republicans of Massachusetts have again pinned their faith to the King of Spades, or, in other words, to Oliver Ames, the shovelmaker of North Easton.

Alderman Ficke, who owns a saloon, is a believer in the true political meaning of the verb "to see" when used in connection with any official who can give anything. Recently he applied to the Excise Board for a license, but he only wanted a "non-spirituous license."

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--The Western Association of Professional Baseball Clubs was organized last night. Delegates representing eight Western cities met, elected officers, and signed an agreement forming the new organization.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28.--The Commander-inChief question has assumed a new phase with Grand Army men. An entirely new Richmond has appeared in the field, and, to put it mildly, he is "sweeping things."

LONDON, Sept. 28.--Braw Lass won the Great Eastern Railway Handicap over the Bretby Stakes course at the Newmarket meeting to-day from a field of 11. Isobar was second and Antonina third. Lisbon was the favorite, at 2 to 1 against him, and 6 to 1 was laid against the winner.
A misty, drizzling afternoon that finally wound up with a rainstorm, in which the last race was run, did not prevent some excellent racing at the Brooklyn track yesterday afternoon.

Jimmy McLaughlin added one to his list of winning mounts at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track yesterday afternoon. That was the only mount he had during the day. Garrison, on the contrary, had four mounts and failed to ride a winner, finishing second in one race and last in the other three.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30--It was arranged today that the ten-thonsand-dollar race between Jay-Eye-See and Patron, announced for to-morrow, but postponed on account of the weather and the damaged condition of the track, will take place at Washington Park on Oct. 15. It was also decided that preceding the main event of the day there will be a contest between Harry Wilkes and Belle Hamlin for a purse of $1,500.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 30.--The steamship Port Victor, Capt. Baird Wird, arrived here today 15 days out from Yokohama. She brought 26 cabin passengers and 15 Chinese, 1,250 tons of tea for New-York and eastern points and 350 tons for San Francisco; also 700 bales of silk and a large miscellaneous cargo.

READING, Penn., Sept. 30.--The dead body of Joshua, Fahl, of Auburn, a coal train conductor, was found a mile below this city this morning. His temple was stove in and his neck broken. It is believed he fell from an up coal train.

Strong, Brigadier-General of the State Militia and Secretary of the State Senate, who was recently convicted of the embezzlement of $5,000 ticket money in the court at Baton Rouge, was today sentenced to two years at hard labor in the State penitentiary and to pay a fine of $4,25l 85, and to pay a like sum to the State.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 30.--After a long vacation the Judges of the Court of Appeals met in the Capitol to-day for consultation. The court will reconvene on Monday, when the call of the old calendar will be resumed. The calendar for Monday will be Nos 440, 360, 442, 443, 444, 445, 447, and 448. Tuesdays, October 4 and 18, will be motion days.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 1.--Suits for damages aggregating more than $150,000 were filed in the Civil Court to-day against the Iron Mountain Railroad. Thirty-seven complaints were filed.

TOKIO, Sept. 2.--It is somewhat unfortunate that the Japanese in their wholesale adoption of Western civilization should have failed to discriminate between the good and evil features thereof. The nineteenth annual Fall games of the New-York Athletic Club were held yesterday afternoon at the club grounds in Mott Haven, and notwithstanding the gloomy outlook were very well attended. A heavy rain just before the sports began made the track somewhat heavy and the turf quite uncertain, but although only one new record was established the performances were on the whole very creditable.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 1.--There is in the St. Joseph's Infirmary one of the most remarkable cases of lockjaw that ever occurred. The physicians say that there is nothing like it on record in the medical books. Thomas Bolling is the subject.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The Grand Army Veterans of the late war in this county met in this city to-day in large numbers, and formed a County Veteran Association.

District Attorney Martine has appointed Jerome Brady to the office of Stenographer to the Grand Jury, in place of Henry W. Unger, who resigned to go into the practice of law. Mr. Brady has had long experience as a shorthand writer, having held other official positions, and is well known among journalists as a prominent member of the Press Club. The salary is $2,500.

The Ladies' Staten Island Club will hold an open tennis tournament at Livingston Oct. 5, 6, and 7. First and second prizes will be awarded on the ladies' singles, ladies' doubles and ladies' and gentlemen's doubles. Play will begin each afternoon at 1:30 o'clock. Entries close Oct. 4, and may be sent to Mrs. William Lentilhon, Secretary, NewBrighton, Staten Island. The entrance fee for doubles is $2, for singles $1.
MONTREAL, Oct. 1.--Samuel Johnson, Treasurer of the Hamilton Powder Company, defaulted a few days ago to the extent of $7,000, going to Ogdensburg, where he was arrested.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 1.--Great excitement exists at Bellevue on account of the failure of the Bellevue Bank at that place. The failure was caused by poor investments and bad management. Liabilities about $100,000. Depositors are made secure, and will lose nothing. The failure will result also in the suspension of the Bellevue Milling Company.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--Oarsman Albert Hamm is suffering from a broken arm, received while practicing on a tricycle for his approaching race with Wallace Ross. The match is indefinitely postponed, as it will be some time before Hamm will be able to resume practice.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The price of certain sizes of coal was again advanced to-day at Rondout by the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company. Grate coal is now sold for $4 a ton; egg, $4.50; previous price, $4; stove and chestnut, $4.75; previous price, $4.50. ALBURN, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The Democratic County Convention was called to meet in the Court House, this city, at noon to-day. At 12 minutes before 12 o'clock G.B. Wright, Secretary of the County Committee, called the convention to order and named Christopher Kane for temporary Chairman.

In the United States there are published 14,706 newspapers. About 106 of these have opinions of their own--the remaining 14,600 copy from the 106. Reducing this still further the 106 borrow their ideas from about a dozen. To be the editor of one of this dozen requires brains, not only of good quality, but considerable quantity.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 2.--Last night, as "Uncle Tom's Cabin" was being played at Harris's Theatre in Robinson's Opera House to a crowded house, a steam street roller in passing the theatre blew its whistle. Instantly a man in the balcony yelled "fire " and the audience sprang up and rushed for the doors. Three cool-headed policemen happened to be in the theatre, and through their efforts the panic was stopped. No one was hurt.

PAUL, Minn., Oct. 2.--It was reported here to-day that Edwin Booth and Lawrence Barrett have completed arrangements by which Mary Anderson will join their company at the end of the preseut season, and that they have leased for two years one of the leading theatres in New-York for the use of a company of which she will be a member.

Patrick Duone and Dennis Norton, two boys who were gathering berries in a piece of woods on the outskirts of Elizabeth, N.J., were shot yesterday by two hunters. Duone was shot through the lungs and will die, while Norton's injuries are serious. The two sportsmen fled, and the police have been unable to trace them. Norton says the shooting was deliberate. The boys reside at Elizabethport, where there is much excitement over the affair.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--John Sullivan, living on Henry-street, had a difficulty with his son and other boys this afternoon, in which he was severely beaten. He went into his house and emptied a doublebarreled shotgun into the crowd of children which had gathered around the boys, wounding about a dozen of them, but none severely. Sullivan was promptly arrested.

The rivet heaters employed by the Standard Oil Company at Constable Hook went on strike yesterday morning for increased pay. On Saturday they held a meeting and they worked an hour yesterday before making known their demands. They were receiving $1.25 per day and demand an increase of 25 cents, which was refused. Their action may possibly be followed by the boiler makers.

Mr. Mansfield appeared at the ChestnutStreet Opera House, Philadelphia, last night in "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde." The spacious and handsome theatre was crowded to overflowing, and the distinguished actor's efforts were cordially appreciated.

Francesco Sesario, another cholera patient from the steamer Alesia, died yesterday in the Quarantine Hospital. It is feared that more deaths will occur among the unfortunate passengers, but there seems to be no danger that the disease will gain a foothold on shore. The Alesia has been thoroughly cleaned and fumigated, and her three cabin passengers will probably be allowed to come up to the city soon.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3.--A reception was given to President Cleveland by the people of St. Louis to-day that can never be effaced from his memory. BALTIMORE, Oct. 3.--Forty shares of Baltimore and Ohio stock were sold to-day at 132 and 10 at 133. The demand for the stock is still active. The announcement that President Robert Garrett was on his way home created con siderable surprise here.

Business on the Stock Exchange seems to prove duller with each succeeding day. Only a few professional speculators are at work. The "public" continues lost, strayed, or stolen. Prices go up or go down with little regard to intrinsic values. Good news is potent no more as a bull argument. Bad news scares nobody any more. The "room trader" is monarch of all he surveys.

LYONS, Oct. 5.--Charles Vaughu, a web known farmer and horseman in the town of Williamson, in the northern part of Wayne County, was instantly killed last evening. He was riding on the back of a young horse, when the animal suddenly threw him head foremost to the ground. He fell on his head and shoulders, and his neck was broken. He breathed for a moment and then died.

MADISON, Ind., Oct. 7.--Gas was struck in Madison Well No. 1 last night at a depth of 300 feet. The flame shot up four feet, and has been burning ever since. Boring will proceed 300 feet deeper to Trenton rock, when a large flow is confidently expected.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 7.--Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde and Arthur O'Connor, the Irish members of Parliament, were given an enthusiastic reception in this city to-day and were greeted to-night by an immense audience at the Academy of Music. Over 2,000 persons were present. Mayor Cummings presided, and seated on the platform were a large number of prominent citizens and clergymen.

MIDDLETOWN, Oct. 7.--At Monticello yesterday the Republicans of Sullivan County renominated Martin A. Smith for the Assembly. The following county ticket was nominated: County Judge-- William L. Thornton; County Clerk--James F. Calbreath, Jr.; County Treasurer--Richard Gildersleeve; School Commissioner, Second District--Victor Champlin.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 7.--The schooner Peregrine White, while cruising off Cape Sable, found a large grayish mass floating on the water. It was taken to a chemist in this city and pronounced to be ambergris. The specimen weighs about 125 pounds. It is very valuable, the find being worth $30 an ounce, or $59,800.

TRAPPE, Penn., Oct. 7.--A great many Lutherans from all over this State and prominent divines in the Lutheran Church gathered at the old Trappe Church to-day to do honor to the memory of the patriot preacher of the Revolution, the Rev. Henry Melchor Muhlenberg. One hundred years ago the remains of the venerable patriarch were interred here.

SIMLA, Oct. 7.--Advices received here state that the force which captured the camp of the notorious Dacoit leader Bohshway and killed Bohshway was composed of mounted infantry under command of Major Harvey. Ten of the followers of Bohshway were also killed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--The offerings of bonds to the Government to-day amounted to $689,300 of which $540,200 were 4 per cents and $149,100 4 per cents. This makes the total to date $13,103,150 and leaves only $896,850 to be secured to-mor row to bring the amount up to $14,000,000 required for the sinking fund within the time fixed by the recent circular.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct.7.--Considerable of a sensation was created here to-night by the announcement that Frank Jackson, the well known stockman of the famous Maple Hill live stock farm, had made a hasty assignment and skipped out for Cananda or some unknown place. His liabilities are placed at $75,000. Jackson's father is the heaviest loser.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Oct. 7.--Typhoid fever has prevailed to an alarming extent at Central Bridge, Schoharie County, for several weeks. The family of Landlord Jacob C. Lettis, at that place, has been nearly exterminated. His wife and two sons have just died, and the third son, the only member of his family surviving, is hopelessly ill.

A lamp hanging over the fruit stand in front of French's Hotel on Park-row fell down shortly before 12 o'clock last night, and set fire to the matting and wood work of the stand. An alarm brought two engines, a hook and ladder truck, several hose carts, and a large crowd to the spot, but a hand extinguisher did all the fire fighting that proved neces sary.

NEWTON, N.J., Oct. 8.--James McPeek, a brakeman on the Sussex Railroad and a brother of Conductor Eli McPeek, was instantly killed this morning. He was climbing from the engine to a box car, when he slipped and fell under the engine.
